PETITION.TITLE: Medicare: Abortions
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled: The Humble Petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
* That every abortion kills an unborn human baby.
* That the right to life of all innocent human beings is the most fundamental of all human rights.
* That the first duty of the Parliament and of the Government is to protect this right to life.
* That in 1989/90 alone Medicare provided medical benefits for almost 70,000 abortions at a cost to taxpayers of $7.8 million.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Australian Parliament will protect the right to life of unborn Australian babies by ceasing to fund abortions through Medicare and by all other means at its disposal.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Baldwin (from 50 citizens), Mr Cobb (from 45 citizens), Mr Cowan (from 27 citizens), Mr Ferguson (from 89 citizens), Mr Free (from 316 citizens), Mr Hicks (from 54 citizens), Mr Howard (from 228 citizens), Mr Allan Morris (from 54 citizens), Mr Ruddock (from 195 citizens), Mr Sharp (from 3 citizens), Mr Simmons (from 48 citizens), Mr Tickner (from 76 citizens), Mr Webster (from 19 citizens), Mr West (from 25 citizens) and Dr Bob Woods (from 76 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Medicare: Abortions
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled:
The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
* That every human being, from the first instance of fertilization, is of unique and precious value, not only to him/herself, but also to his/her parents and to the community at large.
* That every abortion kills a human being before his/her birth.
* That the right to life of all human beings is the most fundamental of all human rights according to article 3 of the 1948 UN Universal Declaration of Human Rights.
* That the primary duty of the Parliament is to protect this inalienable right to life of all citizens, born and unborn.
* That in 1989/90 alone, medical benefits were paid for almost 70,000 abortions at a cost to Australian tax-payers of $7.8 million.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Australian Parliament will protect the right to life of all Australian citizens before birth by ceasing to fund abortions through Medicare and by other means at its disposal.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Australia-A Christian Commonwealth
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assemble:
The humble Petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That we, the undersigned, call for the full and total recognition by Federal Parliament and the High Court and all government agencies that Australia is a Christian Commonwealth according to law and its heritage traditions and customs.

That as Australia prepares for the Centenary of Federation on 1st January, 2001 AD, we celebrate our Centenary as a Christian Commonwealth as described by the Founders of Federation such as Sir John Downer, who said ``The Commonwealth will be from its first stage a Christian Commonwealth'' and as stated in our Federal Constitution-``humbly relying upon the Blessings of Almighty God . . . ''
That our Federal Parliament therefore implement the following policies before 1st January, 2001 AD.
1. The Adoption of a Christian National Anthem-``God Bless Australia'' to the tune of ``Waltzing Matilda''.
2. The Adoption of a Christian National Motto-``One Nation Under God'', for use on our coins, banknotes, etc.
3. The appointment of practising Christians as Vice Regal Representatives of our Christian Queen, Elizabeth II.
4. The retention of our Christian Prayers at the daily opening of Parliament in the standing respectful presence of all Members of Parliament.
5. The retention of ``God Save the Queen'' for Vice Regal Functions as our Royal Anthem and as our National Hymn for all other civic functions.
6. The retention of Christian Christmas Carols in our State Schools and other civic functions during the Christmas Season.
7. Officially inform the United Nations and all the other nations of the world that Australia is a Christian Commonwealth.
Your Petitioners therefore humbly pray that your Honourable House will reaffirm our Christian Heritage as a Christian Commonwealth.
And your Petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Anderson (from 3 citizens), Mr Tim Fischer (from 24 citizens), Mr Howard (from 18 citizens) and Mr Webster (from 6 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Rights of the Child
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled:
The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

1. that ratification of United Nations Conventions, such as the above, by the Federal Government, without Parliamentary debate or consultation with the people through a referendum, is a gross abuse of the Australian Constitution and is contrary to democratic principles;
2. that the Convention's philosophy of parent/child relationships is based on a false premise and embodies the totalitarian principles of State ownership of children;

3. that the Christian principle of parental authority is essential for the proper functioning of society, but phrases in the Convention implying parents' rights are virtually meaningless, with escape clauses permitting the widest of interpretation;
4. that Articles 12 to 16 giving children the right to seek, think, say and be whatever, where ever and with whom they wish violates the common sense of any normal parent;
5. that some Articles contradict other Articles and imprecise wording adds to the confusion by providing loopholes for the protection of paedophiles and certain types of child traffickers;

6. that some of the proposed rights are inappropriate for immature child minds and have no logical connection with the protection of children from abuse or deprivation, such protection being already provided by existing Australian laws.
Your petitioners therefore request the House to legislate or provide for:
(a) a twelve month Moratorium on the ratification of the Convention to enable the people of Australia to discuss and examine in detail the 54 Articles;
(b) a referendum to follow the Moratorium, seeking public approval before ratification of the Convention.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Beale (from 14 citizens) and Mr Webster (from 31 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Rights of the Child
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable, the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled:

This petition of certain citizens of Australia draws to the attention of the House the matter of United Nations Covenants and the way in which they may impact on our existing common law system, method of Government and independent judiciary. Your petitioners request the House to legislate or provide for:
1. A 12 month Moratorium on the ratification of the Convention on the Rights of the Child to enable the people of Australia to discuss and examine in detail the 54 Articles of the Convention.
2. A Referendum to follow the 12 month moratorium, seeking public approval before ratification of the Convention.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

2. They are aware that the Prime Minister and the Minister for Veterans' Affairs have guaranteed on a number of occasions:

(a) no Repatriation General Hospital will be transferred to a State until a satisfactory agreement has been reached on matters, such as priority of access and quality of health care for Veterans and War Widows, and unless the interests of hospital staff have been adequately safeguarded; and

Your petitioners therefore pray that your honourable House will propose and pass a motion that ``the existing Repatriation Hospital system be retained under the responsibility of the Commonwealth Government to ensure Repatriation General Hospitals remain centres of excellence for the health needs of the Community.''
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Rights of the Child
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled:
The petition of certain citizens of Australia draws to the attention of the House their deep concern that the United Nations Convention on the Rights of the Child:
1. (a) makes inadequate provision for a subjective judgement by parents as to what is in the best interests of their children
(b) makes inadequate provision for parents to use their discretionary powers to act on such judgements.
2. creates the potential for conflict between parent and child (rather than the atmosphere of happiness, love and understanding mentioned as valuable in the preamble.

DEBATE.TITLE: STANDING COMMITTEE ON EMPLOYMENT, EDUCATION AND TRAINING

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Report on Literacy Needs in the Workplace

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 14 March, on motion by Mr Price:
That the House take note of the report.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bradford Mr J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —The report of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training on literacy needs in the workplace was tabled in the Parliament on 14 March 1991. As I finished speaking I was in the process of castigating another member of the Committee, the honourable member for Moreton (Mr Gibson). I would like to pick up from that point by quoting him. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: In my opinion, the minority report represents a naive and superficial approach to the process of identifying and reacting to teaching methodology issues.

We who signed the dissenting report were accused by the honourable member for Moreton in his contribution of being driven by ideological dogma rather than by credible evidence. He suggested that the minority report should be ignored.

The truth is that, far from being ignored, the minority report that this Committee brought down has received wide recognition and, indeed, acclaim. In many ways, this was simply because it turned out to be the most important part of the report. It is the most important part of the report because it focuses on one of the most important issues. As it turns out, although the minority report deals with teaching standards in particular, it has in fact been acclaimed by many teachers. The report was featured prominently in my local paper and a number of teachers, including senior teachers, who contacted me actually agreed with it. The plain fact is that many experienced, longstanding teachers are very uneasy about the way numeracy and literacy are being taught in our school system.

The Committee was essentially charged under its terms of reference with considering literacy in the workplace. Our report concluded that more than one million adults are functionally illiterate in Australia at this time. Thirty-five per cent of that one million are actually native English speakers. This is clearly an indication that for many people, for one reason or another, there was an inadequacy in their initial school education.

There are many people-the honourable member for Moreton, as a former primary school teacher, is obviously among them-who would be satisfied to blame the students for that inadequacy. I believe, and those of us who signed the dissenting report believe, that there is adequate evidence to suggest that teachers may also be partly to blame.

I want to make it very clear that by this statement I am not engaging in teacher bashing in any way whatsoever. I believe that we need to give greater recognition to the importance, particularly, of primary school teaching. In many ways, the primary school teacher is the most important person in a young student's life after his or her parents.

Recent statements made by the honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard) which were reported in the press-that teacher salaries should be much higher-should be seen in the context of the recognition that we on this side of the House believe should be given to the teaching profession. Yet the Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Dawkins) stood up in this place yesterday and made light of the suggestion. He talked about the possibility of bigger classes and the additional costs that would be involved, but he failed to see the point that the honourable member for Bennelong was making. I suppose that only accentuates the failures that we see in other areas of his administration of his Department. The point is that we need better teachers, and we will only get better teachers when the value of the teaching profession is given the recognition it deserves. The statement by the honourable member for Bennelong needs to be seen only in that particular context.

There is no doubt that literacy and numeracy are actually moving targets. I was very pleased to receive from the Australian Council for Adult Literacy a paper entitled A National Adult Literacy Strategy. Very correctly, it makes these points:

For an advanced technological society such as Australia, the goal is an active literacy which allows people to use language to enhance their capacity to think, create and question, in order to participate effectively in society.
I underline a further point:
The literacy and numeracy needs of society are changing so rapidly that there must be ongoing opportunities for adults in the home, community, workplace, institution and classroom.

We cannot escape the fact, no matter how hard we might want to because it is embarrassing or difficult to come to grips with, that numeracy and literacy are the foundation upon which all further training and education are built. It is a fact that 70 per cent of those who will be in the work force in the year 2000 have already left school. This demands a response from both government and industry.

The costs of this illiteracy are in the billions and billions of dollars through reduced productivity in the workplace, but the benefits of addressing and redressing the problem are equally measurable in the billions of dollars. It will be a shared responsibility between the community, government and industry, and industry accepts that responsibility.

The fundamental issue that we cannot escape, and I refer here to the minority report, is to make sure that it is not still happening in schools. To the extent that people have left school now, and I underline the fact that 70 per cent of those who will be in the work force in the year 2000 have already left school, the problem will have to be fixed, but let us make sure that the problem is not being perpetuated in schools now. That is why, contrary to what the honourable member for Moreton said, the minority report was important, because it focused attention specifically on the issue of literacy and numeracy standards in schools today.

I was very pleased to read in News Weekly a couple of weeks ago an article by Mary Helen Woods. She made some very poignant statements about the report, and particularly addressed the issues raised in the minority report. I quote:
An essential first step would be to introduce nation-wide standardised testing of students with the co-operation of both parents and teachers.

That, in a sense, was the hub of the minority report-that we wanted to see that sort of approach to making sure the problem was not continuing. We also addressed in the minority report our concern about the standards of teaching, and the same author makes this comment:
Standards of primary school teaching will not improve until the teacher's colleges raise their entry qualifications.

We believe, and I just want to underline what we have said in recent days, that teachers' pay and conditions need to be improved, and their status in the community needs to be lifted to attract better applicants to the teaching profession.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sawford Mr R.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am very pleased to be associated with the tabling of the report on literacy needs in the workplace Words at Work by the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training. In doing so, I acknowledge the astute stewardship of the chairperson of the Committee, the honourable member for Chifley (Mr Price), and especially the leadership of the chairperson of the subcommittee, the honourable member for Cowan (Mrs Jakobsen), who is in the House this morning. I also acknowledge the members of the Committee and especially those on the subcommittee. The secretariat was ably led by John Cummins, as was the subcommittee by Bronwen Worthington.

SPEECH.PARA: Literacy is the ability to receive and transmit messages. It includes non-verbal communication and the ability to apply critical thinking. Receiving skills are reading and listening. Transmitting skills are writing and speaking. Numeracy, cultural knowledge and the ability to access information complement those transmitting and receiving skills.

I do not wish to underscore the importance of the report's recommendations nor its important acknowledgment and recognition of lifelong learning in a rapidly changing, information-based and technologically driven world. However, I do wish to emphasise particularly the intent of recommendation 17, which concerns early intervention, and the intent of recommendation 18 that all students leaving school should be literate. But before doing so, the following background information is, I believe, relevant.

In 1980 the Australian Council for Educational Research (ACER) conducted a literacy survey of 10-year-olds and 14-year-olds in Australian schools. The total test was mastered by 71 per cent of the 10-year-olds and 83 per cent of the 14-year-olds. ACER had conducted a similar national survey in 1975. There was no significant area in which student performance at either age level declined in those five years. However, the report pointed out:

While some will wish to emphasise the high proportions of students who could do most tasks, others will be most concerned about the educational and social consequences for the students who are unable to do some tasks.
Despite the emphasis placed on literacy by schools, the number of adults who have difficulty accomplishing everyday literacy tasks is unacceptably high.

The first national survey of adult literacy was conducted in 1989. Perhaps that shows some measure of the concern of this country about literacy. That report No Single Measure found that at least 10 per cent of the adult population-more than one million adults-are estimated to be functionally illiterate in English in terms of the demands of contemporary Australian society. About 700,000 of those people are, in fact, of English-speaking background and about 300,000 of non-English-speaking background. Some of the latter group may have been able to speak English with some fluency, but were unable to complete everyday reading and writing tasks in English accurately. The alarming cost to the nation of those functionally illiterate Australians has been estimated at $3.5 billion.
However, there is no doubt that the starting point to remedy literacy problems lies in our education system. The Committee report quoted the Harrison submission, which states:
An adult with literacy problems has first been a child with literacy problems.

Some members of the Committee have previously acknowledged that over 90 per cent of people in our prisons are illiterate and that the cost of people in prisons is $140,000 a year. Their lack of skills is directly related to poor literacy. The result is violence, drug reliance, crime and anti-social behaviour, et cetera, because they cannot resolve conflict, participate positively in our society or communicate effectively at the lowest or the most simple level.

There is no doubt in my mind that schooling between the ages of seven and 11 is the most powerful single determinant of future success in literacy or anything else for that matter. Yet, if we were to examine the resources that are available to state and private primary schools in this nation, we could not be anything but alarmed if we compared those resources with the resources given to secondary, technical and further education (TAFE) or higher education sectors.

I am not suggesting that the resources to secondary schools, TAFE and higher education are inappropriate. What I am very strongly suggesting-in fact, I want to scream about it to everyone in this nation-is that in primary schools we have got the fundamentals very wrong.

Take the following example of two schools-one primary and one secondary-with exactly the same enrolment of 430 students. I have always believed that in this country something magic happens at Christmas time. One year kids need one set of resources; six weeks later a new set of resources is needed.

TALK.START.PARA: —Marvellous, isn't it?

—It is absolutely marvellous. It explains a lot of things about how education is organised in this country. Take the year 1988, the State of South Australia and two schools-one primary and one secondary-with 430 students each. On a comparative basis, the secondary school has 170 per cent more basic staff-not counting the add-ons-a ratio of 34 : 20; 400 per cent more senior staff, 8 : 2; 225 per cent more ancillary staff; 500 per cent more base State government grant; and 244 per cent more per capita State government grant. Teachers in a secondary school have a minimum of 250 per cent more preparation time than teachers in a primary school. Unlike teachers in a secondary school, primary school teachers are responsible for all the curriculum.

SPEECH.PARA: What is the magic educational rationale for that huge differential in the allocation of those resources? There is not one. There has never been one. If there is one, it contains no substance at all. Those allocations reflect power-the power of higher education, TAFE and, to a lesser extent, the secondary education sector and the impotence and weakness of representation from the primary sector.

I assure the House that, if one continues those comparisons between the allocation of resources to primary schools, TAFE and higher education, the figures are even more dramatic. I have taught in all those levels and I know what it is like to teach in them. The demands put on a primary school teacher are greater than those on a secondary school teacher and certainly much greater than those on a TAFE or higher education lecturer.

Resources allocated to our nation's primary schools force the fundamental organisational practice of one teacher and a class of 30 kids for a year. That practice is seriously flawed, as anyone who has any knowledge of education knows. In 25 years in schools, I have never seen one primary teacher able to fulfil the expectations of a contemporary educational program. It is impossible. It is a rather stupid and silly expectation. That is not to have a crack at primary teachers who are, without doubt, amongst the best and most hardworking teachers in the country. It is merely stating what ought to be obvious and what apparently is not obvious. The expectations society puts on primary teachers are impossible to fulfil. The representation given them by bureaucrats, union leaders and governments alike is, to this stage, totally inadequate.

In recommendation 17 and indirectly in recommendation 18, the Committee has, quite rightly, made a strong case for early intervention. It is totally unacceptable that between one million and 1.8 million of a population of some 17 million Australians are functionally illiterate. In a nation that has as its greatest challenge the need to be internationally competitive, it is totally unacceptable that between $3.5 billion and possibly $6.5 billion is lost in productivity because of basic literacy problems. Not only do we need to catch up with the clever countries like Japan and Germany; we also need to create an edge to get in front. It is not good enough just to catch up.

The recommendations in the report suggest a wide course of actions, but the key to the successful implementation of those recommendations will be the urgent need to address the largely unmet needs of the foundation stone of our education system, the Australian primary school. Unless those needs are met, all attempts at redressing this nation's literacy problems will be wrongly focused and the results will be highly marginalised. I commend the report to the House.

TALK.START.PARA: —The debate is adjourned and the resumption of the debate will be made an order of the day for the next sitting Thursday.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Report on the Review of Student Financial Assistance

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 11 April, on motion by Mr Price:
That the House take note of the report.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jakobsen Mrs C.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is very pleasing to have the opportunity to continue my remarks on the report on the review of student financial assistance by the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training, which was tabled on 11 April 1991. On that occasion we did run out of time so I am pleased that the Selection Committee has allowed us a little extra time today.

SPEECH.PARA: As indicated in my brief contribution on that day, I believe that this report has thoroughly canvassed the issues surrounding student financial assistance and has made recommendations which are worthy of consideration and implementation by the Government. The submissions received covered a wide range of issues but only a few of those submissions were actually opposed to the concept of student financial assistance.

The main issues covered in the submission included the complexity of the program; eligibility criteria, particularly relating to independent status; income and assets testing; differences between Austudy and the Department of Social Security rates of payment; assistance for rural students; apparent payment of benefits to those who could well support the costs of their own education; payment to students with little interest in staying at school; delays in processing and answering inquiries; and the provision of incorrect information by Department of Employment, Education and Training staff. As you will gather from that list, some of the areas covered were not only very contentious but also very important in the context of the population's understanding of Austudy and the credibility of that payment in the community.

In its evidence to the Committee, the National Union of Students stated that one of the basic problems in any historical overview of the Commonwealth's financial support to students was that there has never really been a comprehensive statement by the Commonwealth as to what the policy intentions were for either the tertiary education assistance scheme-TEAS-or Austudy. It appears, however, that when the program was established, its intention was to meet basic living expenses. I point to paragraph 2.2 on page 11 of the report where it says:
The Minister when introducing the student assistance legislation in 1973 observed that student allowances ought to be sufficient to give students the leisure to think as they pursued their studies.

The union also observed that the scheme gradually changed from one of supplying full income support to one of income support which was to be supplemented by the parents and/or part time work. I am sure that the House will realise that, in that change, we have removed in some instances the capacity for students to have the leisure to think, which was one of the things the Minister wanted in the beginning, and we have given some advantage to people whose parents are in a position to assist them financially.

Nevertheless, the stated objective of the Austudy program is to overcome financial barriers to continuation of secondary and tertiary education by providing income support to financially disadvantaged students undertaking full time studies. Specific program goals are to increase overall retention rates in the post-compulsory secondary school years, participation rates in tertiary education, and higher education participation rates of the financially disadvantaged.

In its evidence to the Committee, however, the Department of Employment, Education and Training believed that the aim of improving access to education was almost certainly being met. Unfortunately, much of the data relating to the socioeconomic mix is now dated and it is difficult to ascertain whether this is in fact the case.

Participation rates in all education sectors are increasing and, in fact, accelerated following the introduction of Austudy in 1987, so it would appear that Austudy has assisted to some extent in keeping people at school and in education. All governments are currently working towards achieving a year 12 retention rate of 65 per cent by 1992. In recent years, Australia has experienced rapidly increasing year 12 retention and completion rates and increases in secondary and tertiary participation rates. This is no accident, of course. As the Minister for Land Transport (Mr Robert Brown), who is at the table, would be aware, the Government has had a very strong thrust in this area of keeping people in education and providing education opportunities when they required them.

Year 12 retention rates have increased from the pre-Austudy figure of 48.7 per cent in 1986 to 60.3 per cent in 1989. If this trend continues it is expected that the Government's goal of achieving a 65 per cent retention rate by 1992 will be met. Another indicator of the relative effectiveness of Austudy in achieving its objectives of improving educational outcomes is the estimated year 12 completion rate. The overall completion rate has increased substantially between 1984 and 1989, from 43 per cent to 58 per cent. These completion rates are clearly increasing for each socioeconomic status level.

It is estimated that in 1991 about 42 per cent of tertiary students and 36 per cent of secondary students will be assisted under Austudy. In 1990, 46.5 per cent of tertiary students and 40 per cent of secondary students were on the full allowance. The improvement in retention rates in high schools to year 12 is one example of the effective use of Austudy, but even that has been questioned to some degree because people do not always understand the environment in which student financial assistance operates. For instance, a study conducted by the Institute of Family Studies into youth incomes and living costs found that it was not clear whether Austudy acted as an incentive to young people to remain at school but thought that it certainly assisted low income families to maintain their children at school.

The Institute concluded that Austudy did not appear to be an incentive to young people to return to education, particularly those young people who perhaps need that opportunity most-those who had left school before the completion of secondary education. The Institute's view, while valid, overlooks the fact that Austudy for post-compulsory secondary students, those over the age of 16 in years 11 and 12, was not meant to be an incentive; rather, it was meant to remove the pre-existing financial disincentive presented by the existence of unemployment benefit for which many 16-year-olds from low income families would have been eligible.

The choice, therefore, was one between continuing on at school with no financial assistance and leaving school and receiving unemployment benefit. To its credit, the Government recognised this quandary and dealt with it by means of an age related payment which equated the level of unemployment benefit. In other words, it was a balancing act which the Government was endeavouring to perform.

It is imperative that eligibility for Austudy be simplified and that its relevance to the watershed decision of whether or not to continue with education be increased by making it more realistic as a mainstay of income support. I commend the report to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Miles Mr C.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —The previous speaker, the honourable member for Cowan (Mrs Jakobsen), said that the report on student financial assistance was worthy of consideration. I want to place a stronger emphasis on it; this report is very important in enabling the Parliament to look at the area of student financial assistance. I come to this debate not as a member of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training but as a person who is interested in education and has read the report.

SPEECH.PARA: I think that in this day and age, when the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) says that we need to become a clever country, this report has some very poignant points to make to whoever is administering education at the Federal level. When I read this report I found that there were some quite significant-in fact, very important-recommendations. They are to be found right at the beginning of the report. I want to preface my remarks by saying that the role of a Minister in this Parliament is to ensure that there is good management of the programs under his administration. The first recommendation of the report was:
The Government develop clear policy objectives for student financial assistance.

We have had student financial assistance since 1973 in this country and it appears to me on reading this report that still, 18 years later and at a cost of $1.1 billion a year, we do not have clear objectives for the expenditure of this money. I regard it as totally unacceptable that we are managing $1.1 billion of taxpayers' money without clear objectives. I say that particularly in the climate we are facing in this country at the moment. We are going through tough financial and economic conditions. I believe that money really has been squandered in this area because of a lack of clear objectives as to what we were trying to do-what the Government, and previous governments, were trying to do in this area.
It behoves all of us to take note of this report and ensure in the future that there are clear objectives, so that recommendation No. 2 of this policy can also be put in place. It says:
The Department of Employment, Education and Training develop performance indicators in line with the Government's policy objectives . . .

If there are no clear objectives there cannot be clear performance indicators, and if there are no clear performance indicators the third recommendation of determining the effectiveness of this program cannot be achieved. This is the crunch of this report. It is really saying that whoever is the Minister for education in this country really has to get a handle on this program and ensure that it is effective.

I turn to the Auditor-General's report which inquired into the effectiveness of Austudy. On reading that report I found that in a couple of areas it refers to the number of times that overpayments were made. Here is a scheme put in place to assist young people in their education, but we find that between 12 and 27 per cent of students receiving assistance under different schemes were overpaid in 1988. It is unacceptable that in up to 27 per cent of cases students were paid more than they were due. One might ask: how can that sort of thing happen? There will always be some mistakes in public administration, but not 27 per cent of the time.

I can say from personal experience with the number of young people-and parents, in particular-who have come to me in regard to Austudy and pointed out the mumbo jumbo that has come back from the Department that it is absolutely incredible. I would need two hours to go through two or three of those instances in this Parliament and show the House the reams of paper. It takes hours and hours to make sense of it. Yet here we have a very large program trying to assist our young people-as I said, over $1 billion is being spent in this program-but we do not know whether it is being effective.

I commend this Committee. I think it has done an excellent job. I commend the Committee because it has really hit at the heart of the recommendations which this Government and future governments need to look at in regard to student assistance. Certainly, in respect of many of our young people from the regional parts of Australia there is no equity with regard to getting into tertiary education. Compared with urban children, I think only about one-third get through to tertiary education, and that is a great tragedy in this country. There is a need for assistance, but our responsibility in this Parliament is to ensure that that amount of money which we allocate is effective in getting the maximum number of young people into education where they need assistance.

The previous speaker, the honourable member for La Trobe (Mr Charles), who took a great interest in this report, I understand, regards it as a damning indictment of the Minister. Having read through it and thought about it, it is, really. Whoever had been administering this-and it would not have mattered if it had been somebody on the coalition side-if this report came out, it would be a damning indictment of the person who had the responsibility in the Federal Parliament for $1.1 billion. Yet we still do not have clear objectives and we do not have performance indicators to tell whether this program is being effective. We cannot measure whether it is being effective.

Because we have lacked that clarity of thinking in this area, I believe there will now be young people in this country who have missed out and who will miss out on financial assistance for their education because the administration of this area has been slack. I think that is a great tragedy. We do need to improve our human resource base in this country so that we can be competitive in world markets and so that we can be a productive country. But the essence of being productive is to develop our young people.

In the previous debate here one of the honourable members from South Australia was saying that it is important that we ensure that people get a good education in primary schools. There is absolutely no doubt about that. It is a great tragedy that many people are functionally illiterate. It is partly-and largely-due to what happens in the first two or three years of education in this country of ours. In this area, unfortunately, there have not been those clear objectives, there have not been effective ways of testing whether the goals have been achieved and, as a consequence, there will be young people who should have had financial assistance in this country who have missed out.

Unless we take note of some of these reports which have these very serious recommendations to make to us, then I do not believe as a parliament we will effectively address some of these areas we are faced with. This is about education; it is about financial assistance. I ask the Government to look at this report very seriously and do something about it so that the money which is provided is targeted more effectively and so that the system is run more efficiently.

DEBATE.TITLE: STANDING COMMITTEE ON ENVIRONMENT, RECREATION AND THE ARTS

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 18 April, on motion by Ms McHugh:
That the House take note of the report.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Edwards Mr R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank you, Mr Deputy Speaker, for your cooperation in making it possible for me to speak this morning. I am pleased to stand and talk about the report The Injured Coastline, and I will be followed by my colleague the honourable member for Cook (Mr Dobie) who I know has similar interests in these matters. This is a very important report for Australia. It is to the credit of the Committee chairperson, the honourable member for Phillip (Ms McHugh) and her predecessor, the former honourable member for La Trobe (Mr Milton), who have had this as one of their priorities over the years. I would also commend colleagues on the Committee and the secretariat for the work they did. It is a very impressive piece of work, and it is not a subject that is easily encompassed in such a report.

SPEECH.PARA: Perhaps that is the way I shall lead into my remarks today. How do we understand the problem of coastal management in Australia? The best way to describe it is by saying that some 90 per cent of Australians use the coast each year. Many of us, of course, live quite close to the coast, as do I-some 800 metres from the Indian Ocean. The honourable member for Forrest (Mr Prosser) lives quite close to the coast as well.

I will just list some of the uses made of coastal areas: swimming, surfing, windsurfing, boating, fishing, transport, sadly, for dumping sewage in, stormwater, the development of marinas, canal developments, sand mining, hotel developments and, more recently of course, those pernicious things called jet skis. They are just some of the uses made of the coastal area.

It is little wonder that the pressure upon certain coastal regions is extreme. Many of those uses are conflicting uses. We do find from time to time, for example, there are conflicts between people who want to use an area for swimming or surfing and, as I commented, for jet skis. At times jet skis will come in quite dangerously and intrude into areas used for swimming and surfing.

My local shire, the City of Stirling, has a lot of problems in managing that, because it has no control. To its credit, it would really like to prohibit jet skis from the surf beaches, such as Trigg Point and Scarborough, but cannot do so. Because jet skis qualify as a boats, they are able to get into the ocean and it is very difficult to manage them; and now they are one of the real problems we are encountering on the coast.

An example of the problem of management of coastal regions can be provided by looking no further than Scarborough, the major surf beach in my area, where difficulties have arisen because a very high rise hotel has been created. I was not opposed to moderate development at Scarborough, but the creation of a very high rise hotel-and I said this before the matter was dealt with in terms of building-puts very large numbers of people into an area where there are already large population pressures. From a planning point of view, it is bad to engender such conflict of use for a major surfing beach, because it happens to be a major surfing beach, and so there is engendered conflict in use, which is a bad way to do planning.

There are many issues-and they are going to be addressed later, incidentally, in terms of the Western Australian Royal Commission into Commercial Activities of Government and Other Matters-but the fact is that the conflicts which have developed in Scarborough have developed because of piecemeal planning: there was no overall management. This is interesting because, generally speaking, the City of Stirling has been very good with its coastal management: it has had a coastal management plan and it has tried to work to it. Unfortunately, however, that Scarborough special beach development zone has tended to fall outside its coastal management pattern and, as a consequence, there is the absurdity-many people who come to Perth think it is absurd-of this very large hotel right on the beach front, when there could have been a moderately sized hotel which would have still met the purposes.

In talking about coastal management we also need to look at marina development, and I instance Hillarys Marina. It is interesting that in many respects it is now a white elephant. It is a white elephant financially, and many people have gone broke over the place, because in fact it was too large. What was needed was a series of boat ramps for people to get their boats into the water in the northern suburbs of Perth. There did not necessarily need to be a deep-keel area in which people could, so to speak, moor their boats. It was not necessary.

Something like 90 per cent of the boats that were owned in metropolitan Perth were owned in that area around Dalkeith, Swanbourne, Nedlands, Cottesloe, et cetera. Interestingly, if a marina had been required, it probably would have been better near the Cottesloe groyne. One can imagine the outcry there.

In many senses it was a fault of planning. One of the difficulties, as a consequence, is that we are getting this pattern in Western Australia of marina development proposals which cause enormous trouble. Where there is a high energy coastline, such as there is in metropolitan Perth, and sand is being moved up and down the coast, putting up marinas and groynes willy-nilly will cause all sorts of problems, including siltation. There is now a major siltation problem at Trigg Point, which used to be a very popular surfing spot. It is still very popular, but the surf is no longer very good because Trigg Point in fact is silted up; and it is very difficult to get a good clean wave over the reef any more because there is sand underneath it.

We have not had the full hydrological studies done, but I think that, if we were to look at studies before we made these moves, we would begin to wonder whether it was always wise to undertake these developments. As I pointed out, I think that one of the real difficulties is that, if developments go ahead willy-nilly, there are these sorts of side effects.

Another area that has to be addressed is the question of canal developments. They have become very popular in Australia. If we face rising sea levels-and many of these canal developments, of course, by definition, are only slightly above high water levels-there really is a difficulty in terms of future security if there is a rise in the sea level. There is no way in which enough barriers can be built to protect the canal development if there is in fact a rise in the ocean level.

I mentioned earlier that we need a management system to deal with jet skis in terms of modern beaches. I have found very few people who at some stage have not found them to be inconvenient. The surf clubs in my area complain of them; the fishing people complain of them; the surfers and windsurfers complain of them. They are really a high energy vehicle, being used often within close proximity of more passive activities that usually have no exhaust effects and no sound effects. Surfing and windsurfing are quiet activities. There is a problem that has to be addressed.

I am very impressed by the attempts of local groups, including beach inspectors, to ensure that we do not have conflicts between surfing, windsurfing and swimming. They are trying to get areas of beach allocated for those activities.

I turn to another matter, which occurs in the area of the honourable member for Forrest-the proposals for resort developments at both Dunsborough and Prevally Park. I hesitate to interfere in somebody else's electorate, but I am concerned by the obsession of developers who say that they must have immediate access to the coastline. We can have developments, but they do not have to have immediate access to the coastline; they do not have to have a private beach as such. This is the great fallacy we must challenge continually. People do not necessarily have to be opposed to development, but there does not have to be a private beach to go along with it; developers can come back from the coastline.

What we have to say to our developers is that we are not blind in opposition to development, but, if they say they want a private beach by locking off some coastline, the answer to that proposal from me is, `No, you do not'. The coastline should be a popular resource, a community resource. It is not something that can be privately acquired. I have mentioned previously the difficulty we have with private ownership of coastal areas such as surfing beaches. Three Bears, which is up from Yallingup, is privately owned. It is to the credit of the Department of Conservation and Land Management and the owner that we have not had difficulties with that being closed off, but we may have to have a protocol where these things are gazetted in future.

Another matter is the difficulty that arises in relation to ocean pollution. One of the big problems is the disposal of bait straps and plastic bait bags by people in the crayfishing industry, and there is massive ocean pollution. I call upon that industry to address its responsibilities in this area. I am sketching out a number of issues that I think highlight the importance of this report. It talks about national responsibilities, working with State and local governments to improve coastal management. I am sure that everyone in Australia shares the view that we need a proper approach to coastal management. We can overcome many of these things that I refer to here in a very sensible way.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dobie The Hon J.D.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have great pleasure in speaking to the report entitled The Injured Coastline. Being on the committee that produced the report, the Standing Committee on Environment, Recreation and the Arts, was one of the highlights for me in the 25 years since I was first elected to the Australian Parliament in 1966. When we talk of environment and actions that need to be taken to overcome the problems which now present themselves, we should never lose sight of the fact that many violations were committed unwittingly. Whether they were committed unwittingly or not, as members of this Parliament we should not shrink from the requirement to see that these problems are resolved. At the same time, we as environmentalists of fair and reasonable nature should see to it that those people and those far sighted corporations which have taken action are duly recognised as having done so. We must see that carping criticism plays no part in the environmental debate which will continue as long as humans occupy this planet Earth.

SPEECH.PARA: The report before the House is a particularly comprehensive, fascinating and informative document, as has been noted by other speakers in this debate. As my colleague the honourable member for Wide Bay (Mr Truss) remarked, it is also an eminently readable document. I recommend to anyone who has a little more than a passing interest in environment matters to get themselves a copy and browse through some of the major recommendations and some of the more anecdotal pieces. It certainly helps to put a national perspective on this issue. It is an approach which has been sorely needed for some time. Australia has, after all, one of the single largest coastlines of any nation-some 36,735 kilometres.

It is a coastline which faces major problems in terms of erosion, pollution, degradation and inadequate management. Coastal pollution is a problem which has yet to be meaningfully tackled at the national level. As the Chairman, the honourable member for Phillip (Ms McHugh), said in her speech, as long ago as 1970 the then Senate Select Committee on Water Pollution observed that the discharge of sewage and industrial wastes into the sea and coastal waterways was the major cause of water pollution in Australia. It was at this time that I spoke on the matter of coastal pollution for the first time in the Parliament. I can remember advising members of the House, of whom very few remain in the Parliament, that it was not aesthetically pleasing to share a wave with what was technically called solid waste. I am pleased to tell the House that this is no longer the case at the Cronulla beaches.

It is for this reason that, after a very long time of involvement in the problem of coastal pollution, I welcome the report now being discussed. It must be regarded as a first step not only for the present Commonwealth Government but for all other governments well into the future. The Parliament must recognise the important responsibility it has to the Australian community in playing a crucial and decisive role in the preservation, control, use and rehabilitation of this vitally important national resource.

Before I go any further I want to take time to congratulate the chairmanship of the Committee: Peter Milton, no longer in this place, on his having started the investigation; and the present Chairman, the honourable member for Phillip, on being the driving force in bringing this report to its successful conclusion. Like the Chairman, I have been on this inquiry since its inception. In congratulating the Chairman, I would also like to congratulate the staff not only on their unremitting efforts in preparing the report but also on their unrelenting labours to see that we had as many members of the Committee as possible present at all of the venues we went to around the whole nation and in every State.

The report has been almost two years in the making. It having been made over the life of two parliaments, one must pay tribute to Ian Dunsdon, and particularly to David Crawford. As the Chairman said, the excellent work of the whole secretariat is the reason we have such a good report.

It is also an apposite and timely document, as not only have we seen a burgeoning public interest in all matters environmental in recent times, but for those of us who have been concerned for conservation and protection all our lives it is equally significant that this burgeoning interest has brought with it a community concern for solutions to be found and effective action to be taken by all levels of government. For any person in public life to ignore the necessities and responsibilities attaching to this generation is a dereliction of duty in providing for the well-being of future generations.

At this stage I would like to praise the work that has not only been considered but also been achieved by the present Minister for the Environment in the Greiner Government, the Hon. Tim Moore. Only two weeks ago in my own electorate of Cook the Environment Minister dedicated a further 78 hectares of marshlands at Towra Point in Botany Bay south. Not only does this realise a long term ambition of mine, it also provides a rare photo opportunity for the Minister and me standing in, and almost under, the marshlands at low tide. We must then hope that the action taken by the Greiner Liberal Government will act as a forerunner to action which should be taken by all other Ministers in Australia having this responsibility. I include everyone in that position in this Parliament.

Having spoken about nearly being swamped by the marshlands in my own electorate, I would be quite wrong if I did not mention the incredible number and variety of sewage plants which we not only visited but entered as well. I have never served on a committee in this place over the last 25 years which examined the outflow of sewage systems more than we did. I am sure all members of the Committee who went on these visits will congratulate each other on this aspect of the investigation. I resisted the temptation on all occasions to drink the water that was offered as being pure at these places.

There are 19 conclusions and recommendations in this report. I do not intend in the short time available to each speaker to list these conclusions and recommendations, but I do say to colleagues in this Parliament that they would do well to read these recommendations. I mean all members of the Parliament in all parties.

It cannot be denied that we have allowed the honourable member for Phillip some tolerance and poetic licence in her description of Bondi. There is no question that Bondi is the best known Australian beach in the world. I know she will permit me the same poetic licence to say that the Cronulla beaches, which just happen to be in the electorate of Cook, are as naturally beautiful as any beach in an urban area anywhere on our planet.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tell us about Wanda.

—The honourable member interjects; I suggest he reads the report. I could go on, but time is running on and the Chairman's indulgence must be wearing thin about my talking of Cronulla all the time. However, I would like to stress to the House that it is the care and concern that the honourable member has for her beaches and the care and concern I have for my beaches have made us as one in raising the problem of beach pollution with some degree of success. That is not merely because these beaches affect places of beauty, but also because without the care that has been, and is being, given to them-such as that given by the Greiner Government in New South Wales-to make them healthy and safe for all, the vast number of Australians could not enjoy spending their leisure hours in these particular coastal waters.

SPEECH.PARA: The title of the report The Injured Coastline says it all. The Australian coastline has been injured most grievously by both nature and mankind. As this report concludes, and as I shall end my speech, considered, serious and fair dinkum action must now take place to overcome the injuries we know to exist. I also thank the Standing Committee of this House for having been aware of this need and for having been generous in allowing debate on this report to have such an extended time in this House.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The time allotted for this debate has expired. The debate is adjourned and the resumption of the debate will be made an order of the day for the next sitting Thursday.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ruddock Mr P.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this House:
(1) deplores the appalling abuse of the Kurds in Iraq by Saddam Hussein and his military;
(2) notes that the UN Security Council resolution on the ceasefire did not include provisions to protect minorities in Iraq;
(3) regrets that the Australian Government failed to lobby for the inclusion of such provisions; and
(4) urges the UN Security Council to take such action as is necessary to end this human tragedy.

We have all been shocked in recent weeks by the spectre of people in flight from an oppressive regime. They flee from a regime that has sought to subjugate them totally and brutally over the course of many years. Since 1975 four out of every five Kurdish villages in Iraq have been levelled, forcing some 300,000 Kurds into the southern deserts of Iraq. Over 4,000 traditional Kurdish settlements, many with mosques and churches of historical significance, have been destroyed.
In its 1988 report Amnesty International said that the killing of the Kurds in the immediate aftermath of the Iran-Iraq war was:

. . . a systematic and deliberate policy on the part of the Iraqi Government to eliminate large numbers of Kurdish civilians, both as a punishment for their imputed political sympathies and in retaliation for the activities of Kurdish opposition forces.

The report states that late in 1987, 6,000 Kurds, mostly civilians, and whole families, were deliberately killed by government forces. Other information was received about the deliberate killing of hundreds of others. Over 400 Kurdish civ- ilians, among them women and children, were reported to have been executed on 2 April 1987 at the Tanjaro military gar- rison. In August 1987 hundreds of unarmed Kurdish civilians were deliberately killed and thousands wounded when Iraqi government forces attacked Kurdish villages in the north.

Thousands of Iraqi troops were reported to have launched attacks using tanks, helicopter gunships, artillery and chemical weapons on hundreds of villages in the provinces of Duhok, Mosul and Arbil. In August, Iraqi Government forces arrested 1,000 people wounded from chemical weapon attacks and summarily executed them and buried them in mass graves nearby.

On 16 and 17 April 1988, 5,000 Kurds were deliberately killed and thousands wounded as a result of chemical weapon attacks by Iraqi forces on the town of Halabja. Many of us saw those vivid and most oppressive scenes on our television screens. Most of the victims were civilians-many of them women and children. Thousands of political prisoners continued to be detained without trial or charge. Children of political opponents were also arbitrarily arrested and detained as hostages. Mirza and Mardan Rasho, two brothers aged six and 13 respectively, were arrested in July 1985 and their fate is unknown. The fate of some 8,000 Kurds, among them 315 children, known to have disappeared following their arrest in August 1983 is still unknown.

Some 1,900 Kurds returned to their homes in Iraq from refuge in Turkey after the Iraqi Government announced an amnesty for Kurds in September 1987, and it is unknown what has happened to them. It is this brutality that we have seen in the past which the Iraqi Kurds have experienced and from which they have fled. Now we have a situation where, in the aftermath of the Iraq or desert war, involving Australia amongst other countries, more than two million Kurds have fled their country to the northern border areas of Turkey and Iraq. In order to understand the magnitude of that, there are nine million Kurds in Turkey, 12 per cent of Turkey's population; five million in Iran, 3 per cent of Iran's population; and there were four million in Iraq, 20 per cent of Iraq's population. There are 800,000 in Syria and smaller communities in the Soviet Union and Lebanon. So, two million people have fled the country out of a total of four million people.

Treacherous terrain has hampered relief efforts and last week it was estimated that, on the Iranian border alone, some 2,000 people, mostly babies and children, were dying each night. The United Nations (UN) High Commissioner for Refugees (UNHCR) estimated that there would be approximately 30,000 refugees as a result of the Gulf war and prepared for such a contingency. However, the swiftness and vastness of the refugee problem caught them unprepared. Of an estimated $1.2 billion which they believe they will need just to keep these people alive over a period of three months, approximately $96m has been pledged.

The international community must bear some of the responsibility for this tragedy. At the end of the war, the allies, and Australia among them, encouraged the Kurds in the north and the Shi'ites in the south to rebel against Hussein's regime. The brutal crushing of the twin uprising has caused the massive flood of refugees which we now see. We must not shirk our responsibilities. Some laudable initiatives have been activated. British Prime Minister John Major's plan to establish a UN safe haven for the Kurdish refugees hopefully will lessen the scale of the tragedy. But, as both the British Ambassador to the UN and the United States have pointed out, safe havens are not long term solutions: they are a purely humanitarian concept, not a juridical or political concept.

The UN has no mandate to create an independent nation of Kurds and nor should it be given one. Article 6 of the UN's covenant deals with that. The only long term viable solution for the Kurds is to make it safe for them to go home. The United Nations Security Council resolution 687 on the formal cease-fire, adopted by the Council vote of 12 to 1 on 3 April 1991, contained no protection for Iraq's minority, although we note that the Iraqi legislature voted to accept the conditions of the resolution on 6 April. At the beginning of the war, the Opposition continually stated that the international community should turn its attention, along with Australia, to the postwar situation and the possible impact of the war on groups such as the Kurds.

From the time President Bush called a unilateral cease-fire on the night of 27 February, Australia could have, and should have, lobbied for the inclusion in the Security Council resolution of the protection of minorities as a condition of peace. We failed to do this. Senator Evans's response as to why this was not done was as follows:

We made the judgment that, particularly given our status as not being a current member of the Security Council, there was little we could add to a very lively debate on these issues that was already proceeding. That is the view that we continue to hold.

Australia, however, on its past record, has lobbied for many variations to Security Council resolutions. A resolution condemning Iraqi action against its citizens was finally adopted by the United Nations Security Council on 6 April, but only after the enormity of the plight of the Kurdish refugees became apparent. In view of the time, I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard the terms of the UN Security Council resolution.
Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
The UN Security Council passed resolution 688 on April 6 1991.
* The resolution reads after the preamble,
``The Security Council . . .

``(1) Condemns the repression of the Iraqi civilian population in many parts of Iraq, including most recently in Kurdish populated areas, the consequences of which threaten international peace and security in the region.

(2) Demands that Iraq, as a contribution to remove the threat to international peace and security in the region, immediately end this repression and express the hope in the same context that an open dialogue will take place to ensure that the human and political rights of all Iraqi citizens are respected:

(3) Insists that Iraq allow immediate access by international humanitarian organisations to all those in need of assistance in all parts of Iraq and to make available all necessary facilities for their operations;

(4) Requests the Secretary-General to pursue his humanitarian efforts in Iraq and to report forthwith, if appropriate on the basis of a further mission to the region, on the plight of the Iraqi civilian population, and in particular the Kurdish population, suffering from the repression in all its forms inflicted by the Iraqi authorities.

(5) Requests further the Secretary-General to use all the resources at his disposal, including those of the relevant United Nations agencies, to address urgently the critical needs of the refugees and displaced Iraqi population;
(6) Appeals to all Member States and to all humanitarian organisations to contribute to these humanitarian relief efforts;
(7) Demands that Iraq co-operate with the Secretary-General to these ends;
(8) Decides to remain seized of the matter.

TALK.START.PARA: —The resolution strongly suggests that Iraq must solve the Kurdish exodus and stop repression of that minority before it is granted a formal peace. This resolution did not have the full support of the Security Council members, since it was considered by some that it would set a dangerous precedent if the UN were to interfere with domestic issues. The United Nations can involve itself in a member state's affairs only if it raises issues that transcend its immediate borders. Several members of the 15-member Council considered that the Kurdish resolution took the international nature of the exodus too far. So there were these difficulties.

SPEECH.PARA: Clearly, in passing this resolution, the United Nations has indicated that there are sufficient international ramifications for the tragedy of the Kurds to allow it to act. Having failed to protect the Kurds, Australia should now act itself to ensure that the Kurds are not further displaced. The Opposition has argued strongly in those terms; particularly the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson). The Australian Government has responded-and I acknowledge this-by providing aid, and a number of initiatives have been taken. Government members will no doubt elaborate in relation to that.

I mention one final matter: the situation that we have heard about in the latest reports is that Kurdish leaders have made an agreement to establish an autonomous region in Kurdistan. That is a welcome development. The determination of refugee status if Australia is to accept people for resettlement is a matter which I do support, but I want to make the case strongly that there needs to be consistency in applying long-standing rules that do apply in this instance and ought to apply on the same basis as they do in other circumstances.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired. I would mention to the honourable member for Dundas that, although the terms of the motion do not strictly comply with the guidelines issued by Mr Speaker, because of the importance of this matter and also the importance of private members' business, I will take this up with Mr Speaker and leave it to his discretion. Is the motion seconded?
—I second the motion, Mr Deputy Speaker, and reserve my right to speak.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Theophanous Dr A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —We on this side of the House share some of the concerns expressed in the motion moved by the honourable member for Dundas (Mr Ruddock). Obviously we share the concerns about the fate and situation of the Kurdish people. I am not sure, however, about the way in which the motion is phrased, especially paragraph (3), for example, which uses the words `regrets that the Australian Government failed to lobby for the inclusion of such provision' in terms of the United Nations Security Council resolution concerning the protection of minorities. I am not sure, first of all, how accurate that is, given that the Australian Government is not on the Security Council and has had only a secondary role in relation to the determination of the contents of the agreement and the resolution on the cease- fire.

SPEECH.PARA: Having said that, there is also the question of whether the cease-fire agreement could have been unanimously accepted if there had been an attempt to include those provisions. As the honourable member for Dundas has pointed out, Australia has supported a further resolution at the United Nations; and that was supported by most, though not all, members of the Security Council. So it is not as if the United Nations has failed to act on this matter.

The honourable member for Dundas has failed to give a analysis about what has actually happened in this matter. There are the deplorable actions of Saddam Hussein in the way he has treated the Kurdish people not merely following but also prior to the war. It is probably one of the most disgraceful condemnations of most nations of the world that they failed to condemn the regime of Saddam Hussein at the time he was actually using chemical weapons against the Kurdish people-people who are part of Iraq. Many nations-and we are guilty as well-failed to condemn him and his government at that particular time.

In this context it is important to note that we should be forthcoming in our condemnation when international events of this kind occur. It is very interesting in this context because there have been more recent events. Saddam Hussein is to be condemned for his actions and what he has done to the Kurdish people in this round following the war. But not only Saddam Hussein is to be condemned. It is interesting to note what happened to those people when they were forced out. Many of them went into Iran.

Notwithstanding its previous reputation, Iran opened its borders and took all the Kurdish people. Interestingly, in light of the fact that we have the President of Turkey, Mr Ozal, here, what happened on the Turkish border? On the one hand, of those people pushed out by Saddam Hussein, some were able to get into Turkey, but at a given moment, in the middle of that crisis, when most people were up in the mountains, the Turkish Government ordered the border to be closed. On the other hand, those people were being pushed into the mountains by the forces of Saddam Hussein. There were freezing temperatures and they had hardly any possessions or clothes. They wanted to go into Turkey but the Turkish Government closed the border. Many of those people died in those mountains-tens of thousands according to the United Nations and Amnesty International.

I am surprised that the honourable member for Dundas has not mentioned that situation. If we are concerned about the Kurdish people-and we all are-we should be talking about not merely Iraq's but also Iran's and Turkey's treatment of them. The fact is that the Turkish border was closed at a time when they needed that humanitarian assistance and thousands and thousands of those people died. That act is to be condemned. The Turkish Government has a lot to answer for because of its recent action, never mind the previous treatment of the Kurdish people.

As the honourable member for Dundas said, it is not up to the United Nations to determine an independent Kurdistan. However, when there is a people such as the Kurds, spread around that whole region-Iran, Iraq, part of the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics and Turkey-and, as a people they are continuously denied recognition and autonomy by most of those governments, we in the international community ought to be concerned. It is one thing to say they should have an independent state. The fact that they do not have an independent state is a controversial issue. But certainly not to be ignored is whether they should have autonomy and whether there should be recognition of their cultural rights, their rights as a minority and their right to practise their language. They have been denied these rights in those three countries.

Iran recently has decided to relent and give some recognition to the Kurds. However, the record of all three of those countries in relation to the Kurdish people has been appalling. It is no wonder, therefore, that the Kurdish people in Australia are pretty upset about the visit and, especially, about the awarding of the Order of Australia to the President of Turkey.

The rights of the Kurdish people need to be protected by the international community. I would have liked this motion to have gone beyond merely mentioning the recent actions of the United Nations Security Council and, instead, to have recommended what should be done to ensure the future autonomy of the Kurdish people and the genuine recognition of their human rights. I think the proposal to establish a safe haven for the Kurds is a great initiative. However, the safe haven was proposed because the Kurdish people were dying in the mountains. They had to come down from the mountains because they could not get into Turkey. Once they came down from the mountains they were faced with the prospect of being butchered by the forces of Saddam Hussein. That is why the international community had to move. I must congratulate those who initiated the idea of a safe haven.

The Australian Government has supported the proposal for a safe haven. Not only did we support the concept of a safe haven but also we are now sending personnel over there. We have sent Army personnel to help protect the Kurdish people, to help set up camps and to do a number of other things. I congratulate the Government for doing that. The implication in the motion of the honourable member for Dundas that the Government has not done enough is incorrect. Of course, we have done enough.

TALK.START.PARA: —You're joking!
—We have done enough compared with--
—Compared with what?
—Compared with the rest of the international community. In fact, Australia, per capita, has done a great deal in terms of supporting the Kurdish people in this recent crisis.
—Not enough.

—It is always possible to say that it is not enough. However, in terms of our resources and the cost of the operations, we are doing a great deal. The Government ought to be given credit for what it has done. I am saying that the plight of the Kurdish people is of an international order. Everyone can do more. Certainly, however, the Government has been doing a great deal. I think it ought to be congratulated not only for its assistance to international agencies but also for supporting a safe haven for the Kurds. I hope that the Government will support some kind of political solution so that the Kurdish people will at least find their rights protected in Iraq, Iran and Turkey in the future.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Aldred Mr K.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —In seconding the motion now before the House I want, at the outset, to point out that the Kurds are the self-styled descendants of the ancient Medes-with a very noble history reaching far back to the dawn of civilisation. However, in modern times, and particularly since the peace settlement following World War I, their existence has been marked by division, subjugation, neglect and, more recently, in the case of the Iraqi Kurds under Saddam Hussein, cruelty in the extreme.

SPEECH.PARA: The tales of pillage, rape and slaughter perpetrated on the Iraqi Kurds by the forces of Saddam Hussein are now a matter of grim record. They present a shameful account of attempted genocide, never to be erased from the pages of world history. With the final defeat of Saddam by the United Nations forces, principally those of the United States, one would have supposed the agony of the Kurds to have ended. However, this was not so. The Americans withdrew, unexpectedly, and, tragically for the Kurds, left a portion of the Iraqi fighting force, including its Republican Guard, sufficiently intact to redouble its own brand of punishment on those rebel Kurdish guerillas who had risen in response to Saddam's weakened position.

Whether the United States withdrawal simply did not take the plight of the Kurds into account, or whether, as was suggested in the Melbourne Age editorial of 4 April, President Bush `understood that the legitimacy of any new regime in Baghdad would be undermined if it were seen as Washington's puppet', we will never know. We do know that the Kurds, who represent 20 per cent of Iraq's population, were once more open to Saddam's cruelty and are now open to his revenge. A transcript of the United States World Report of 15 April stated:
As flag-waving Americans welcomed home their heroes, Saddam Hussein's humiliated army finally found something to cheer about too . . .
I am certain this black humour is not lost on honourable members. The butchery had recommenced.

Mr Deputy Speaker, I feel strongly, and I am sure many of my colleagues would agree, that the United Nations Security Council resolution should have included provisions to protect all minority groups living in Iraq, including the Kurds. Further, it is a matter of great regret to me and, I am sure, to other Opposition members, and possibly some Government members as well, that the Australian Government failed to lobby for the inclusion of such provisions. I would point out, in response to comments from the honourable member opposite, that in fact non-members of the Security Council can, and do, lobby. However, since the making of the resolution the course of events appears to have improved prospects for the Kurds.

Despite the appalling conditions being suffered by the Kurdish people as they move from their squalid camps and make their way home, there is now a light on the horizon. According to the Australian of 6 May, correspondents in Tehran and northern Iraq reported that Kurdish officials and the Iraqi Government were holding talks in Baghdad on the possibility of an autonomous homeland in northern Iraq-the Kurdish free zone, as it is called. Meanwhile, countries of the world are pledging help to the Kurds. In fact, in this context I commend the Australian Government for the aid it has pledged recently in the form of a medical and sanitation team to be sent to northern Iraq for Operation Habitat.
Finally, it is to be hoped that the Government of this country will heed the words of Mr Chanin Baker, spokesman for the Australian Kurdish community, who stated recently:
There should be an international guarantee to ensure that the Kurdish people will not be subjected to genocide again.
