Australia should play its part to ensure that such a guarantee is effected.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Catley Dr R.

TALK.START.PARA: —If this motion had been debated at the time the honourable member for Dundas (Mr Ruddock) gave notice of it, I might have found myself pretty well in agreement with what he had to say. Unfortunately, I think the motion was formulated about three weeks ago and events have overtaken it. I would, of course, at that time have deplored the appalling abuse of the Kurds in Iraq by Saddam Hussein's regime. I would have noted that the United Nations Security Council did not seem to pay sufficient attention to oppressed minorities within Iraq. I would have said that I felt that the Australian Government might have been urging on its American allies a bit more action with respect to the protection of the Kurdish minority. I would have been in great sympathy with the honourable member's suggestion that we urge the United Nations Security Council to do more for the Kurds.

SPEECH.PARA: However, over the three weeks since the formulation of that motion, things have proceeded apace. Action has been taken along the lines that the honourable member quite rightly felt should have been taken three weeks ago. Indeed, at that time, in a speech to this House, I criticised American foreign policy for its inactivity towards the Kurdish minority.

Since the motion was formulated, the Kurdish situation has improved somewhat. However, that situation does revolve around what the international community is prepared to do for the Kurds. The Kurds, by most tests, are a nation, but they face the misfortune of being spread across five major countries-Turkey, Iran, Iraq, Syria and the Soviet Union. Trying to create a nation state for the Kurds at this stage would involve taking on five principal states of the United Nations and asking them to have their territory carved up by international action-a wholly unreasonable demand on them.

The most that can be expected for the Kurdish people, as their leadership has been admitting this week during the negotiations with the Iraqi Government, is an autonomous area for the Kurds in Iraq, and this is the objective that I believe we should aim at. Their present situation is caused principally by the repressive nature of the Iraqi regime, but also partly by the American postwar diplomacy in the sphere of Iraq. Having been enormously successful with force of arms against the Iraqi military regime over its occupation of Kuwait, the American Government then ill-advisedly, in my view, encouraged the Kurds and the population of southern Iraq to engage in an insurrection against the Iraqi regime. This insurrection proved unsuccessful.

The consequences in southern Iraq were not quite as dire as they were in the north, because American forces were in a situation to protect the failed insurrectionaries. In the north they were left to their own devices and the Iraqi regime seized on the first opportunity it had had for some time for the successful force of arms and wreaked its revenge on the Kurdish rebels.

The Americans then changed their diplomatic posture-to their credit they changed it-and they have now intervened in order to create a situation in which the Kurds can negotiate an autonomous area for themselves to which their 1 1/2 million to two million refugees living in destitution, unloved by the Turkish border guards, can return and live a life in reasonable peace with the Iraqi Government. The Kurds' leadership recognises that it cannot create an independent Kurdistan and that the best it can do is, with American and other Western support, get a better deal from the Iraqi Government. I support that position.

I must say that the Australian Government has acted in support of that position. Between August and now it has provided $6m for emergency assistance for the Middle East, some of it going to the Kurds; it has the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs (Mr Hand) at present in the Middle East looking at what can be done in terms of providing a safe haven for some of them in Australia; and it has announced this week the dispatch of 70 Australian military personnel with a view to assisting particularly the British in their protection of the Kurds in the negotiations with the Iraqi Government, so that they can have a safe haven to which to return.

In general, however, I would commend the honourable member for Dundas (Mr Ruddock) for moving his motion, although I fear that events have overtaken it, but to the good fortune of the Kurds. I do not have any principled disagreement with what he says other than to say that things have improved, and I commend the Australian Government for assisting in that improvement during that three-week interval.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The time allotted for the debate has expired. The debate is adjourned and the resumption of the debate will be made an order of the day for the next sitting Thursday.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Nehl Mr G.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this House recognises the need for a special national priority in funding for the Pacific Highway.

I move this motion with the weight of a great deal of knowledge of the need for that special priority. When I first started my campaign to get a new Pacific Highway in 1984, I was virtually a voice in the wilderness. It delights me to say that my continued efforts since then have produced a major turnaround in this nation in regard to attitudes to the Pacific Highway. When I started off, people said I was fairly crazy to want a four-lane, dual carriageway, divided highway from Hexham to the Queensland border, but that is not the case now. I now have the support of every political party in Australia; the total support of the New South Wales Government; and also the support of the present Government in Canberra.

I had hoped that I would be able to introduce this motion on 21 December because that was the day before the first anniversary of the Clybucca bus smash, the worst road accident in Australia's history. On that first anniversary, the Kempsey Lions clubs opened a marvellous memorial garden at Clybucca in memory of the people who lost their lives. I have sympathy still for the families of those people and also of those who lost their lives in the Cowper bus smash in the Clarence Valley.

The emergency services-all of them right round Australia, not just those in the MacLeay Valley and the Clarence Valley that were involved with those two bus smashes-deserve a special tribute. Those of us who are fortunate enough not to be involved in assisting dead and dying and badly injured people do not know what those emergency service people go through.

I would also like to comment on the growth of the driver reviver program on the highways. I think this is incredibly valuable because we must cut down the number of deaths. The Pacific Highway has something like 8,000 vehicle movements per day, of which 13 per cent are heavy vehicles. We can expect the traffic to grow by 4 per cent per annum every year to the year 2000. I venture to suggest that the national priority for the Pacific Highway is recognised right throughout Australia. Everywhere I travel and speak about it, I get total support from everybody with whom I come into contact. I have had the opportunity of presenting nearly 50,000 signatures on petitions to this Parliament, to this House, seeking special priority in funding for the highway. It is an Australia-wide recognition that extra funding is needed.

In the time available, I cannot detail the enormous benefits that come from good roads-benefits in terms of reduced pain and suffering and certainly also enormous financial benefits. I am very pleased that I will be supported by the honourable member for Bradfield (Mr Connolly) and that the two Government speakers are the honourable member for Richmond (Mr Newell) and the honourable member for Page (Mr Harry Woods). I know that they support what I say on this. We need a bipartisan attitude to get both sides of the Parliament working together with the State Government to provide more funding.

The high cost of bad roads is incredible-increased travel time for domestic or commercial purposes; frightful vehicle costs; fuel costs which go up by 15 per cent when driving onto a rough road surface from a smooth one; extra fuel consumption when driving on a bad surface, which has a cost nearly three times the cost of regular road maintenance; and the wearing out of tyres two to three times faster on a poor surface. While the details of the benefits from road construction are fully documented in my 1986 publication The Pacific Highway Towards 2001, I should just quote:
. . . the Bureau of Transport Economics . . . found that there was an approximate cost-benefit ratio for the economy of 1 to 3.16.
So that for every $1m spent on road upgrading and reconstruction, the economy benefits by $3.16m.

The savings that pass through to the community from better roads and road construction are, to name just a few: lower vehicle wear and tear costs; lower fuel costs; less occupant travel time; lower freight costs; less road maintenance; lower accident costs; less government expenditure on hospitals, health and emergency services; lower insurance costs; and lower third party and property legal costs.

In 1990 fatal accidents in New South Wales totalled 17 on freeways with 17 deaths and on State highways 191 accidents with 224 deaths. That is appalling indeed. I have a particular interest in the Pacific Highway, and on it in that year there were 49 fatal accidents with 60 people killed, compared with 31 fatal accidents and 34 deaths on the Hume Highway, 27 fatal accidents and 25 deaths on the Great Western Highway, and 17 fatal accidents and 23 deaths on the New England Highway.

It is important though that we do not get carried away by the accident statistics. They are valuable, they are essential; but we need to take the positive view that work is going on. In fact, in 1990 those 60 deaths on the Pacific Highway represented a figure that was down by 55 per cent on the figure for the previous year. Of course, the previous year with 133 deaths included those two horrendous bus smashes at Cowper and Clybucca.

But to put these figures in perspective, the total of 60 deaths last year is lower than the 10-year average for the Pacific Highway in the 1980s, which was 71. Things are improving; there is no doubt about that at all. I pay tribute to the New South Wales Deputy Premier and Minister for Roads, Mr Wal Murray, and the Federal Minister for Land Transport (Mr Robert Brown), because things are improving. In the current three-year period, the State and the Federal Governments will be spending $300m. That is nearly three times the figure in the previous three years.

I know, and other members of this chamber who drive on the Pacific Highway know, that work is going on. I want to take the very positive view that it is happening, but that it needs to happen faster. I know the Minister, were he here, would probably interject-as he has in the past-that on the one hand I want more money but on the other hand I want fewer taxes. That is true, but it is a question of the allocation. With the fuel levy and the amount of money that is being collected from fuel, surely another one or two cents a litre could go back onto the roads. That is what we need.

It should be pointed out that the $300m State and Federal initiative will increase the number of overtaking lanes between Hexham and Tweed Heads to 130. The total length of dual carriageway will be 38 kilometres. No way is that enough. Sharp bends will be eliminated at 50 locations. All known black spots on the highway will be eradicated. One hundred and thirty-five kilometres of poor road surface will be repaired. Four narrow bridges will be replaced. We will have overtaking lanes every 10 kilometres between Coffs Harbour and Tweed Heads and every five kilometres between Raymond Terrace and Coffs Harbour. A great deal of work is going on and will continue to go on.

I want to make one point about the Minister. I notice that on 7 May he put out a press release announcing 50 overtaking lanes with $36.4m new work. I think the Minister is just a little naughty, shall we say, in re-announcing work that has already been announced. This is part of the work announced by the Minister and Mr Murray last October.

In conclusion, I never want to see another Cowper accident and I never want to see another Clybucca bus smash again. I want to see roads so good that there are no serious accidents. I want to see our roads so safe that our hospital casualty wards are only needed for heart attacks and strokes and for kids falling out of trees and breaking their arms. I want a four-lane dual carriageway divided highway between Hexham and the Queensland border. I want a new Pacific Highway.

TALK.START.PARA: —I second the motion and reserve my right to speak.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Woods Mr H.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I can certainly fully understand the concerns of the honourable member for Cowper (Mr Nehl) about the Pacific Highway. Anyone who lives on the north coast of New South Wales, and has done so for a few years, cannot help but be concerned for the safety of those who travel on that road. We have seen two terrible bus crashes on that road in the past few years. It has made north coast people particularly sensitive to the issue of the improvements to the Pacific Highway. The Minister for Land Transport (Mr Robert Brown) recently drove himself over that route, and I know that he and the Federal Government share in that concern.

SPEECH.PARA: The Pacific Highway is a major arterial road which serves industry, tourism and various communities along the New South Wales north coast. It carries an average of 8,000 vehicles a day, of which about 13 per cent are heavy vehicles. Traffic is expected to continue to grow at a rate of about 4 per cent until the year 2000. Various studies have acknowledged that the road is not providing an adequate level of service for its users. It has a poor accident record which is significantly higher than the State average.

As I said before, the Federal Government is very much aware of the community's concern at the condition of the road and its poor crash record. It also recognises that the road is a key rural and tourist link which is essential for the continued economic development of the north coast of New South Wales. For those reasons, the Federal Government has already made a strong commitment to give the road a higher national priority and to work, together with New South Wales, towards that. I believe that the honourable member for Cowper recognises that. That commitment is to improve the worst sections of the road as quickly as possible, to upgrade it to a four-lane divided standard over time as this becomes economically warranted and to enhance the safety of that road.

Following the horrific bus crashes which occurred near Kempsey in Cowper, and in my electorate which cost a total of 55 lives late in 1989, there were many calls for the Pacific Highway to be declared a national highway. Really, the status of the road is not the important issue. What is going to change the safety of the road is the funding, and that is the best indicator of the commitment of the Government.

The Federal Government's joint funding effort with New South Wales has meant that more funds are available to upgrade the road faster than if it were a national highway. A total of $300m is to be spent on the highway and that almost trebles the funding effort on the road over the previous three years. By any measure, this level of funding is a significant commitment by both the Federal and New South Wales governments, and it will provide a sound basis for achieving a very much improved and safer road for tourism and other uses.

This $300m program is expected to deliver a number of major improvements. It will result in a large increase in overtaking opportunities by the construction of an additional 50 overtaking lanes and 28 kilometres of dual carriageways; a 33 per cent reduction in the existing narrow stretches of the highway by widening 96 kilometres of road pavement and shoulders; a 24 per cent reduction in the number of existing sharp curves at 50 different locations; and a 25 per cent reduction in the number of existing narrow bridges. One in particular that I am pleased about is Mororo Bridge just north of Maclean which I nominated a few years ago as a particularly dangerous spot. That is to be duplicated so that it will provide for the four-lane divided highway in the future. It is one particular spot where trucks coming towards it radio ahead on their citizen band radios to check if anything is coming the other way because they cannot both fit on the bridge at the same time.

Another major improvement will be the elimination of all the currently listed accident black spots. These improvements should result in a reduction of 20 per cent in road casualties and should bring them down to under 1,200 in 1994. Both the New South Wales and Federal governments recognise that the highway cannot be upgraded to an optimum standard in only three years and, therefore, a strategy for the longer term upgrading of the highway has to be developed.

That strategy will include undertaking a total transport study in the corridor to identify the traffic task to be performed by road and rail. That is sensible. We have the parallel systems running together and it is sensible to identify the tasks that each should be performing. There will be an economic evaluation of the benefits and costs of upgrading the total route to four-lane divided standard. It is recognised that that is what we are aiming for, but it needs to be evaluated and examined as to the benefits and costs and as to when that should happen.

There will be a study of the extent to which an upgraded summerland way from Grafton to Brisbane could provide an alternative route for heavy traffic currently using the Pacific Highway. That is an item in which I am particularly interested. I believe it could give definite benefits to towns like Grafton, Casino, Kyogle and that whole northern area. It also includes an assessment of how to maximise private sector involvement, perhaps through tollways, to accelerate the upgrading of the Pacific Highway.

When this strategy is completed in about the middle of this year, governments will then be in a better position to consider the upgrading of the highway beyond the current three-year program. But until the results of this strategy study are available, it would be premature for governments to give a commitment of funding beyond 1992-93.

The honourable member for Cowper mentioned fuel tax, and tax generally, and that more of that tax should go back into roads. That really does not have much to do with putting a higher priority on the Pacific Highway. It does indicate his feelings, but he really does not go far enough because if he is to enter into that argument, the honourable member for Cowper should say where that tax has to come from.

TALK.START.PARA: —Out of the fuel levy.

—Yes, out of the fuel levy, but the honourable member for Cowper forgets that that money is already spent and, if it is spent, is he to take it out of the welfare budget, the education budget or the health budget? It has to come from somewhere. From the point of view of the colleagues of the honourable member for Cowper that might be extremely hard to do. After all, the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson) has announced that he favours a $3 billion cut in the Budget to start with. On the other hand, maybe he has some ideas of gaining additional money from the consumption tax favoured by that side of the House.

SPEECH.PARA: If that is so, it is really an admission that that tax will not be revenue neutral, that it will raise additional money, and it is a tax that will hit the poorer hardest-the lower income sections of the community. It is not to be revenue neutral, and it has been designed to tax the people of Australia more. If the Opposition is going to say it wants more tax on the roads, it has got to say where it is coming from, but it is not going to say anything. After all, that was raised.

As part of our commitment, the Pacific Highway continues to have one of the highest priorities in developing Australia's national network of roads. That priority is evidenced by the fact that the Federal Government has spent more money constructing projects on the Pacific Highway in the past seven years than it has on the New England Highway.

The task of upgrading the Pacific Highway is ongoing, it is a cooperative partnership between New South Wales and the Federal Government to fund a $300m joint upgrading program over the next three years. After all, the people know where that additional money that is being spent comes from. They are quite aware that it is not going to be taxed from any other source, and those items need to be made perfectly clear when we call for additional money for roads or for any other purpose. The Hawke Government's strong commitment to the current $300m program and to the development of a longer term strategy for the upgrading of the road shows that it places a high priority on making the Pacific Highway a safer and a better road.

One comment made by the honourable member for Cowper was that he would like to see the road so good that there would be no accidents on it. Whilst I agree with his feelings, I do not believe it is possible. I think that people's attitudes, drivers' attitudes, must play a part. Education for drivers, on drugs and all those types of things, need to play a part; not only the improvement of the roads.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Connolly Mr D.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to support my colleague the honourable member for Cowper (Mr Nehl) in recognising the need for a special national priority in funding for the Pacific Highway. In doing so, I just want to draw the attention of the honourable member for Page (Mr Harry Woods), who just spoke, to some of the sad realities of this situation. He referred to the fuel levy. He said that the levy was totally committed. That may well be so, but let it not be forgotten that the fuel levy for many years has cheated the road users of Australia, as it was a levy introduced many years ago to effectively provide adequate funding for road development.

SPEECH.PARA: The truth of the matter is that a minority of the levy goes towards road development and most of it goes to Consolidated Revenue. It is surely the Government's responsibility to face up to that fact and make the necessary changes in the interests of the Australian people. The people are prepared to fund roads.

The evidence in New South Wales is clear: the Greiner Government in recent years has introduced an additional fuel levy which the people have been prepared to pay. What the people simply say is, `We want to see results for our money and, regrettably, on the Pacific Highway of New South Wales in particular the problem is critical'.

While the Government is going to do something over the next three years-and we are delighted to hear that-the truth is we have been waiting for most of the last eight years for something to be done, and hundreds of people have died in the meantime. How many more have to die before we see a serious improvement in the road situation? I would suggest that the National Roads and Motorists Association should consider issuing a certificate at either end of the infamous Pacific Highway. That certificate, for example, could say, `Congratulations, you have done it and you are still alive'.

People who have taken that road, especially in wet weather or at night time, know that they have taken their lives and those of their children into their own hands for that most dangerous few hours. When day breaks and the rain stops, drivers might have a strong black cup of roadside coffee, sigh with relief and say that they will never, never drive on that appalling road again, if they can possibly avoid doing so.

We all keep wondering when that wretched stretch of road will be divided into four lanes with a decent surface and people's lives will stop being put at risk. No-one would argue that taxes from the back of Bourke should not go to fund a road that is allegedly not seen as being in the national interest, although I am delighted to hear from the honourable member for Page that the Government is now giving, at a somewhat late stage, a high priority to its development.

The fact of the matter is, as I have said, many Australian families have at some stage used the Pacific Highway. It is therefore a national artery of significant importance, and the statistics show that more traffic uses that highway than the so-called national highway-the New England Highway-which is to the west. Imagine what the international tourists must think on that road? They have decided to travel from Brisbane to Sydney, through one of the highest population densities in Australia. They know it contains many popular tourist spots, with magnificent beaches and so forth. They have decided to go along the coast, to take a swim at world class beaches and to have a holiday. What they find on that part of the coast is a two-laned, potholed bitumen track. This is supposed to be a civilised country with high standards of living, which we know are now falling, and a decent road system.

Some facts about the Pacific Highway: overtaking is effectively restricted for nearly half its length; 77 per cent of the road is of only two lanes, with overtaking lanes on only 13 per cent of the highway; nearly a third of its length has shoulders less than a metre in width and 64 per cent of shoulders are in either fair or poor condition; there is a total of 92 curves along its length of 965 kilometres, and the speed one can travel is 35 kilometres below the speed limit; and there are a total of 79 no-overtaking zones longer than 1.5 kilometres.

The position is critical and, clearly, the Government must further upgrade that road-the sooner it does so the better-otherwise how many more Australians are going to die before this disgrace of a highway is significantly improved?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Newell Mr N.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for Cowper (Mr Nehl) for putting this motion before the House today, and I thank him because it allows us to put on record, from the Government and the Opposition sides, our attitudes and our feelings about this particular piece of highway, which is a problem in the sense of the density of traffic that now travels on that particular highway is not commensurate with the facility that is actually provided. I will admit that. The Minister for Land Transport (Mr Robert Brown) will also admit that.

SPEECH.PARA: The commitments that the Minister for Land Transport has made on behalf of the Government are in recognition of that, and the honourable member for Page (Mr Harry Woods) has announced those particular commitments. I would like to mention some of them again. The Government did make the commitment to improve the worst sections of that particular highway, and we are obligated to put on record our preparedness to upgrade the highway to a four-lane highway, as economies allow, and also to upgrade the safety of sections of the highway through things like the `black spots' program.

There is no doubt that as money becomes available and the commitments are met, as the highway does improve, all those things the honourable member for Cowper adverted to with regard to casualty rates and hospitalisation of people and those unfortunate things, which we tend not to give a great deal of thought to but which are associated with the transport of people by car, will be reduced.

The commitment announced by the Minister in February 1990 actually culminated in an announcement of a bipartisan approach with the New South Wales Minister for Transport, Mr Baird, last May, about the joint funding package to accelerate the upgrading program. It was a joint effort and it was certainly welcomed by both the people of New South Wales and at a Federal level by my colleague, the honourable member for Page and me. The agreed program was launched by the Minister and actually the New South Wales Deputy Premier, who was part of that opening. He is a member for the National Party, as the honourable member for Cowper will know.

The honourable member for Page also mentioned that $300m will be spent on the highway over the next three years. The Federal Government contribution of $130m was to provide $16m from the Australian land transport development program, some $16m from the new provincial cities and rural highways program, and $10m from the new accident black spots program. As part of the Federal Minister's commitment to that, he spent four days travelling that highway and looking at the particular black spots, the nasty little bits of the highway; and we have certainly had action. I know that in my electorate, and the honourable member for Page agreed, we have had a good response from the Federal Government to eliminate black spot accident areas.

Mention has been made by honourable members in this debate of the need for further funding and the lack of spending in the past on the highway. The past is the past, and we will not forget it, but let us not be ungrateful about the extra money that has gone into this particular highway. It is not a federally funded highway as such, but the Government has taken on the responsibility to spend money there because the need has been shown. The fuel levy has been given to State and local governments in untied grants. It is not as though it goes into Consolidated Revenue and disappears; it has been given back.

The 3 x 3 levy from the New South Wales Government is also going a long way to improving the highways. I do not begrudge that, but what the honourable member for Cowper and the honourable member for Bradfield (Mr Connolly) seem to have forgotten is that the Opposition has also called for cuts of $3 billion from government spending. How will they ask their side to finance further improvements in the highway when they are faced with that sort of call from the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson) and no doubt from other members of the Opposition?

TALK.START.PARA: —It was supported by Tim Fischer.

—It was also supported by the Leader of the National Party (Mr Tim Fischer), as I have been reminded. The other point I would like to make is with regard to the education of drivers. One honourable member mentioned that and I really feel--
—Order! The honourable member's time has expired. The debate is adjourned. The resumption will be an order of the day for the next day of sitting.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Scholes The Hon G.G.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That:

(1) the disposal of glass products and non-biodegradable containers in national parks and other areas protected by Commonwealth law should be a specific offence if the materials are not placed in areas designated for their disposal;

(2) persons convicted of committing such an offence should be liable to a penalty not less than 8 hours supervised rubbish clearing in public areas or national parks which would not include time travelling to the designated area;
(3) where the offence includes the deliberate breakage of glass products, the sentence should be a minimum of 24 hours actual time;
(4) recurring offences after the initial conviction should attract a doubling of the penalty on each occasion; and

(5) the House requests the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories to take this matter up with State and Territory Ministers for the Environment in order that uniform legislation, particularly covering National Parks and wilderness areas, can be enacted.

This is not the first time that I have raised this matter. It is one that I have considerable feeling about. I believe too few Australians care about the areas which are preserved for their enjoyment and for future generations, in that too many treat those areas with a contempt which deserves to be noted and treated in specific ways. The motion calls for those people found guilty of disposing of glass and other non-biodegradable products in national parks and other areas under the control of the Commonwealth, in places other than those which are set aside specifically for the disposal of those products, to be dealt with in a specific way upon conviction. That means that, rather than a fine, which for many of those involved is meaningless, or a day or two in prison, which can lead to notoriety in some peer groups, they be required to attend at a place to be nominated and, on the first occasion, to spend eight hours cleaning up the areas that they have abused and used as their private rubbish dumps. On subsequent offences, that penalty should be doubled.

For persons who break glass products in particular, that penalty would be trebled. There is a good reason for that: the dangers to others caused by the irresponsible actions of a few who-usually after a few drinks or in order to show their virility or that they are smarter than the rest of us-smash bottles and other things against rocks, in parks, on paths and on beaches. Those actions place children, in particular, in danger. Those wilful actions cause a potential danger to all other persons.

Glass products do not fade away; they do not rot. They remain and accumulate for years. Those who are so contemptuous, so irresponsible and so unconcerned about other members of the community should have it drawn to their attention in the strongest possible way that their actions are unacceptable and are not going to be passed off by a stern warning from some person in a court or paid for by a fine which may or may not be a serious impediment to the person concerned. It will be drawn to their attention that our society expects them to go out, in their own time and at their own expense, to repair the damage they have done.

The adoption of this type of formula will deal with what I consider to be a very serious problem. Most honourable members are aware of cases of children standing on a broken bottle, usually at a beach or somewhere else where they are entitled to feel safe. We are all aware of the very substantial efforts that have been made in recent times by Australians to clean up the mess made by other Australians on their beaches-the days of work and the tonnes and tonnes of rubbish that have been removed from our parks, recreation areas, beaches and riverfronts. But there are still those in our community who see littering, the throwing away of products which do not rot and do not disappear and the risk they impose on others by disposing of glass and the breaking of glass products in areas frequented not only by adults but by children, in which areas they are entitled to be, as something that other people should worry about or something that they should have no concern about whatsoever. They treat us and the country that we want to protect with utter contempt.

If someone turned up and broke the windows in their house they would be racing off to the police and insurance companies and wherever else, asking that the persons concerned be punished. But they are prepared to do this damage elsewhere and to do it without any concerns at all.

The motion also asks that the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories (Mrs Kelly) raise this type of approach for uniform adoption by Territory and State governments. This would apply these rules to our beaches, rivers, parks, recreation areas and public areas in general. It would mean that a uniform penalty would exist. I believe the fact that people would have to actually go out to clean up the mess they make would encourage them in future to pick it up and to take it with them when they leave.

It is quite appalling that, when one walks along the Barwon River in my area, where councils have made very strong efforts to provide attractive areas for people who walk, jog and want to picnic along the river and have attempted-I use the word advisedly-to increase the number of trees for beautification of the area, one finds that their attempts have failed because someone has thought it smart to consistently break off or pull out the trees that have been planted.

One council, the City of Newtown, has since 1988 planted 3,000 trees in an area of about 25 hectares. If there are 50 trees still left there, I would be surprised. If 50 trees had died by natural causes, I would also be surprised. The other 2,900 have been destroyed by wanton vandals in our society.

In the same areas where this takes place one can walk along on a Sunday morning and find the paths littered with broken bottles, Coke cans and beer cans. These are paths where kids ride their bicycles and where people jog and walk. They are accidents waiting to happen, and the accidents happen too often.

I am proposing that we adopt a system of penalties which befit the crime. If one wants to be what once was called a litterbug, but what I would now call a vandal, then so be it. These are people with no concern whatsoever for their fellow human beings and no concern at all for the areas which are being preserved more and more and which are becoming more and more important to Australians. They are the people who want to throw away their glass products, their biodegradables and the things that will not rot. They are the people who want to throw away the things that someone else has to get paid to remove-and that is another factor; councils are unnecessarily being forced to pay very substantial sums of money to pick up what people could carry away in a few moments.

Cans and bottles are dumped where cars have been parked 10 yards away from a rubbish bin. Some people are too damned lazy to get out of their cars, walk over to the rubbish bin and put their rubbish in. The penalties imposed would have those people who do the damage clean up the damage.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the motion seconded?
—I second the motion and reserve my right to speak.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Halverson Mr R.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I congratulate you, Mr Deputy Speaker, on the very fine job that you are doing. I intend to take a slightly different tack this morning from that of the honourable member for Corio (Mr Scholes). Few, if any, of us would argue against any practical or worthwhile initiative aimed at further reducing the litter problem. Unfortunately, the motion put forward by the honourable member for Corio hardly comes within that category. Whilst the underlying concept may be sound, the suggested method of implementation is totally impractical, if not impossible.

SPEECH.PARA: This proposal is so significantly and obviously deficient in so many respects that it is difficult to take any of it seriously. It may be well-intentioned but it is certainly ill-conceived. Firstly, for some reason best known to the mover, the motion is confined to glass products and non-biodegradable containers. I have attempted to grasp the rationale behind this decision but, try as I may, I cannot understand why someone who thoughtlessly and carelessly discards an empty plastic bottle is any more of a villain than someone who thoughtlessly and carelessly discards an old car tyre or who discards soiled, so-called disposable nappies which are, for obvious reasons-including their popularity and the difficulties associated with their proper disposal-widely regarded as being one of the worst and most offensive types of litter.

According to the terms of this motion, one may roll up with one's newspapers, food scraps or perhaps a trailer or two of garden refuse and deliberately dump the lot, secure in the knowledge that their very biodegradability will save one from the compulsory supervised litter pick-up duty which is specially and specifically reserved for one's non-biodegradable littering counterpart. Even non-biodegradable items are okay as long as they do not come within the category of containers.

Furthermore, it is not clear from the wording of the motion whether the proposed penalties are in addition to or instead of the existing penalty of $500 for the illegal disposal of rubbish or litter in a national park or reserve. Apparently the mover of this motion is unaware of the recent trend away from supplying rubbish bins or designated litter disposal areas in national parks and other relatively remote or isolated recreational or wilderness areas. Increasingly, visitors to such places are being encouraged to take their rubbish away with them and to deposit it at centralised and easily accessible litter disposal points often located along highways or major roads.

This `take it away with you' system occurs, for example, in the World Heritage listed Cradle Mountain Lake St Clair National Park in Tasmania. It has also been widely adopted by councils in the remote north-west areas of Western Australia from Carnarvon to Wyndham-where `Don't Litter: Penalty $ . . . ' signs at popular tourist designations, parks and remote beauty spots are being replaced with notices exhorting visitors to `Show your Aussie pride; take your litter for a ride'. These notices include details of the nearest travel litter disposal points.

Not only does this system have a positive, rather than punitive, approach, but also it saves significant amounts of time and money. Previously, numbers of rubbish bins were scattered throughout these areas, hopefully, but not necessarily, at places where people may stop for meals or to camp or pursue other activities which may result in the generation of litter. All these bins had to be regularly checked and serviced, whether or not they had been used. Sometimes council employees and park rangers would drive long distances, often along unmade bush tracks, only to find the bin empty. In other instances, bins could be serviced on a daily basis but still be full to overflowing. With the introduction of the special travel litter disposal points, public rubbish disposal facilities can be readily located, identified and accessed by the public and regularly and easily serviced and maintained by the authorities.

Because of the demonstrable success of these `carry out whatever you carry in' programs, it is likely that in future tour buses entering Uluru National Park will be encouraged to voluntarily take their rubbish with them, or will be required to do so as a condition of their commercial permits for operating in the park. In Kakadu, where a commercial garbage contract is let at a yearly cost of about $80,000 to clear the rubbish bins provided at the major visitation areas and campsites, signs have now been erected to encourage visitors to take their rubbish with them as they leave. This is increasingly being recognised as the best solution to the problem of littering in public places. It works, and the costs involved are minimal, but, most importantly, it is based on encouraging people to recognise that the environment is their environment and that they have a responsibility, and indeed an obligation, to look after it. Surely this is a better way to go than trying to impose silly penalties on offenders who have little, if any, chance of being caught.

A famous cook, Mrs Glasse, whose book The Art of Cookery was published in 1747, is attributed with prefacing her recipe for hare soup with the instruction `First catch your hare'. In regard to the motion currently before the House, one could paraphrase this instruction to read `First catch your litterer'. Though not a betting man, I am prepared to back the possibility of snaring the hare, rather than snaring the litterer, any day. At least with the hares, if one is so inclined, one can use a gun, a net or a dog. Not so with litterers. In regard to the motion currently before the House, we should look at the vastness of the areas concerned and the very small number of staff available to police them.

Undoubtedly, the greatest deterrent to any offender is the fear of detection. Bearing this in mind, I would be obliged if the honourable member for Corio could explain to me how, in relation to this motion, he proposes to trace the owners of glass products and non-biodegradable containers not placed in the areas designated for their disposal. Does he really believe that deliberate litterers wait until they are being observed by some representative of officialdom before dropping their unwanted rubbish? Does he seriously think that these people will seek out one staff member of the, on average, 43.84 staff who service the almost two million hectares of Kakadu, or one of the 19 staff responsible for the 132,538 hectares of Uluru, and brazenly deposit their little piles of litter at their feet? Perhaps he envisages a special patrol of non-biodegradable container dropper spotters, continually on the prowl, or a team of fingerprint experts ready to dust off each offending glass product and match the prints against the National Crime Authority or Interpol fingerprint registers.

There is no way known that the existing park staff, whose meagre numbers include maintenance, scientific, management and administration personnel, park rangers, guides and the people who care for the native flora and fauna, could ever hope to adequately police the vast areas under their control. It would be a Herculean, if not impossible, task.

The alternative would be to appoint additional staff whose singular responsibility would be litter control. Certainly the numbers required would be considerable and may help to make a dent in the spiralling unemployment figures; but who is going to pay for these detection teams? Who is going to supervise the persons, if any, convicted of incorrect disposal offences? It reminds me of the old song, `Who takes care of the caretaker's daughter while the caretaker's busy taking care?'. Under the terms of the motion we are debating this morning, persons convicted of littering in national parks would be liable to not less than eight hours supervised rubbish clearing. In some instances-for example, the deliberate breakage of glass products-the suggested sentence is 24 hours actual time. Item 4 provides for a doubling of the penalty for recurring offences. Is it possible that a recidivist deliberate glass-breaker could be looking at weeks-even months-of supervised rubbish clearing?

The motion does not specify who would be responsible for the supervision. Certainly it could not be the existing park staff, who would have to be diverted from other more important tasks. In any event, with the current fiscal restraints on park management, not enough staff would be available for this sort of supervisory activity. Therefore, in addition to the detection teams, we are looking at employing squads of supervisors who will spend unproductive hours watching other people pick up rubbish. That will mean more wasted time, effort and money.

This proposal is-and I make no apology for the pun-littered with deficiencies and impracticalities. For example, what if the offender is incapacitated or disabled in some way and cannot physically spend X number of hours picking up rubbish? What if he or she does not have the financial resources to revisit the area? In the case of the deliberate glass-product breaker, is the 24-hour minimum sentence to be carried out over a single unbroken period, over several days or over a week? In fact this very idea may encourage an increase in littering-a `Why not drop it unnoticed, because someone else may be caught and will need something to pick up' mentality.

My colleague the honourable member for Braddon (Mr Miles) will examine in greater detail some of the many other unworkable and unclear provisions contained within this motion, and the costs and difficulties associated with attempting to police it. However, in the 15 minutes allowed we are hardly able to do the job justice. Unfortunately, the whole thing is rubbish. Perhaps the best outcome would be to gently and carefully biodegrade it or recycle it into something more practical.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Elliott Mr R.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to support the motion put forward by the honourable member for Corio (Mr Scholes). I think the honourable member for Casey (Mr Halverson) has gone off on something of a tangent on this issue and has not done justice at all to the motion moved by my colleague, or to the seriousness with which the issue is taken by people in this chamber, in the gallery and in the wider community. It is a matter of great interest to all of us who have care and concern for national parks and try at all times to make appropriate provisions to ensure that people obey and comply with the basic rules relating to pollution-free nature that we seek in national parks.

SPEECH.PARA: The honourable member for Casey suggested basically a hands-off approach-`Let us have an education campaign; hopefully that will do the job and we will not have to worry too much about the polluters, because they will take care of things themselves'. In New South Wales there are examples of polluters being left to run their own race. For example, in respect of the disposal of chemicals and the pollution of areas such as the Hawkesbury-which the member for Lindsay (Mr Free), who is in the chamber, could talk about-the State Government has said, `Let's leave it to these people to self-regulate and self-control pollution'. As result we have the worst possible conditions prevailing.

In areas such as the Parramatta River, which rightly should be seen as an area of great national significance, polluters have been allowed to engage in any sort of activity, and when the matter is raised with the New South Wales Pollution Control Commission, it says, `Well, we do not have the resources to regulate it; self-regulation will be the way'. That is what the honourable member for Casey was talking about today when he referred to people disposing of glass products and other sorts of things. Rather than come into the chamber and say, `Well, we will talk about developing recycling strategies and so forth for products', he said, `No, we will not talk about that. We will let people do basically what they like'. I agree; it is healthy to have education campaigns, anyway. But that is not an end in itself.

The honourable member for Corio, in putting forward this motion, sought to come to grips with the problem. He did not speak negatively about the need to have recycling, and he has drawn the logical distinction between non-biodegradable products and biodegradable products, for obvious reasons. It is clear in respect of the long term implications-the damage and destruction that will be caused to national park and wilderness areas-that glass items and so forth will continue to be a litter, pollution and environmental problem for a long time to come. I think it is right that we demand that the whole community treat this issue as one very much in the public consciousness, which is what this motion seeks to ensure.

Under existing arrangements with the penalty provisions that have applied, little positive action has been taken to ensure any enforcement. The inconsistencies between the State and Federal requirements in this field are part of the problem that occurs when one tries to ensure that there is a real, constructive and concerted campaign against polluters. It is not fair enough to say, as the honourable member for Casey said, `Well, let us opt out of this area; let us say that it is not our problem. Educate the people; they will do the right thing and that will be the end of the problem'. We have to take a genuine and committed interest in our national parks and wilderness areas. It is only by having firm and constructive processes in place that we can ensure that happens.

As I said, the fundamental experience based on this self-regulation model outlined by the honourable member for Casey has been tried and is an absolute failure under the Greiner Government in New South Wales in that area. Environmental protection in that State has become a joke. For example, no environmental protection against chemical pollution of the atmosphere is carried out west of Parramatta in the Sydney metropolitan area. That is an absolute scandal. Now we are getting reports about the tremendous problem with smog which occurs in Sydney. I know as a representative of one of the electorates in western Sydney how great that problem is, and yet we still have members of the Opposition saying, `Let us not bother about any form of regulation, prevention and proper enforcement provisions in regard to polluters and their activities in national parks; we can just accept that occurs automatically'.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Miles Mr C.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —Putting all of Sydney's air pollution into biodegradable containers would be a great task. I am not sure whether that meant the previous speaker, the honourable member for Parramatta (Mr Elliott), was unable to sustain a debate of five minutes on this motion. I support the speech of the honourable member for Casey (Mr Halverson) because of the impracticalities of the motion. It is not that the Opposition thinks the motion does not have merit, but, like all pieces of legislation, proposals and motions which come before this chamber, it has to be practical. It is obvious that the proposal brought to the House today has some serious gaps.

SPEECH.PARA: I know the honourable member for Casey is concerned about ensuring that in his area there is no littering of rubbish and so forth occurring in areas such as the Healesville Sanctuary, which is well known to many Australians as a beautiful spot to visit. He is concerned, as are other members of the Opposition, about national parks and reserve areas to ensure that people do not litter them. I do not think anybody in Australia would not be concerned about that. However, as legislators, when we look at proposals like this we have to ensure that they are practical and that there is no duplication and inconsistency with other legislation in place. As the Federal Parliament, we have particular roles to play in the federal system of government in Australia, yet we are talking about our responsibility for rubbish bins around the country. That is largely the responsibility of other people and other levels of government.

Let us look at a couple of the impracticalities of this motion. One relates to Commonwealth areas, which are covered by Commonwealth law. Are we also going to ensure that all the post office areas and all the defence areas are going to be maintained in the same way? The motion now before the House is very loosely worded. The Opposition does not object to its sentiments; the Opposition is opposed to littering and wants to make sure that offenders are dealt with. However, the practicalities in the wording of this motion mean that it is questionable whether it should be debated. Why limit it to containers? The honourable member for Casey pointed out that many other things, such as old tyres and nappies, are left around in these areas. Why do we not cover those things? They are just as bad as litter as the items that are mentioned.

There are literally thousands of sites covered by Commonwealth law in Australia, including post offices, defence areas and Commonwealth buildings throughout the length and breadth of this country. It will take a massive number of people to police these areas and sites, and it is just not possible to do so. With the release of the unemployment figures today, maybe this is what is really intended by this motion. Maybe a few tens of thousands of people will be soaked up to do the policing.

Another area indicates that the person who has offended will be supervised while collecting the rubbish in, say, a national park or reserve area. On the one hand, we will have a person who has offended, probably by breaking one bottle, having to spend eight hours in a national park collecting rubbish and being supervised by another person. Really, it defies logic when we think about the cost involved, particularly at this time when we understand the severe pressure on the Federal Government's Budget. Through this motion we are suggesting that there are ample funds to police all these things.

In summary, we agree with the sentiments of the motion. We would like to see all our reserves and national parks kept neat and tidy and offenders dealt with. In reality, this motion is impractical, it has inconsistencies and it duplicates some of the measures already in place.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired. The time allotted for the debate has expired. The debate is adjourned and the resumption of the debate will be made an order of the day for the next sitting Thursday.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 6 December 1990.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Webster Mr A.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

I rise to speak in one of those rare parliamentary debates which brings before us, as law-makers, the question of first principles. I rise to speak on and in support of the Abortion Funding Abolition Bill 1990.

In making my comments today, I am conscious that the debate concerning abortion is very complex. It has medical, legal, theological, ethical, social and personal aspects. It is a highly emotional subject and involves acutely painful dilemmas. I have presented this Bill, however, and have sought to have it debated because for too long the Parliament has avoided the issue of abortion, precisely because of that complexity. In that regard, I thank the Selection Committee of the House, under the Deputy Speaker, the honourable member for Stirling (Mr Ronald Edwards), for its decision to allocate time for this debate, however brief it might be.

In presenting this Bill in this place on 6 December last year, I outlined both the reasons for and the objectives of the Bill. It is appropriate now to summarise both briefly. The Commonwealth's main involvement with abortion is through Medicare subsidisation of abortion procedures, almost without exception. Therefore, the Bill addresses the Medicare subsidisation of abortion and seeks to allow Medicare funding only for abortions performed to avert the death of the mother, and in cases where the procedure is for a different purpose and where the doctor was unaware that an abortion would occur. The Bill also requires doctors to certify that the reason for any abortion was to avert the mother's death or that it occurred indirectly, and there is absolutely no incursion into the privacy between the doctor and the patient, as many would seem to imply.

I will now refer to some economic trends which add to the pressures to use abortion as a means of birth control. In individual situations, very often it revolves around a conflict between the continuation of the pregnancy and the effect that this will have on the mother's or father's individual or collective financial situation, their future plans and their current lifestyle, or whether a boy is wanted and an ultrasound test shows that a girl has been conceived.

In these conflicts the unborn baby has no choice and too often loses out, essentially because it is small, unknown, defenceless and voiceless. Those responsible know that the community will turn a blind eye to the killing of its youngest members. Recently a circular was put out by the New South Wales-based women's abortion action campaign in opposition to the proposed Abortion Funding Abolition Bill. In this circular the group, which is said to have close ties with particular abortion centres in Sydney, admits quite openly that the main reasons for abortion are social and economic factors and not life-threatening medical conditions.

We can address this problem by legislative, legal and other means, including advertising the availability of the support services for pregnant women through public education campaigns, and articulating the arguments in defence of human life. We must make every effort to reduce the economic pressures which weigh on the mind of the mother so heavily that often the baby becomes expendable. There is no doubt that deliberate abortion has become entrenched in the Australian community as a form of birth control. There are no nationally collated statistics for abortion in Australia, but some guide as to numbers can be obtained from the statistics for Medicare claims made under the abortion items 6469, 274 and 275 of the Medical Benefits Schedule.

Since abortion item 6469 became part of the Medical Benefits Schedule on 1 April 1975-without the vote of Parliament-it is estimated conservatively that successive governments have subsidised over 750,000 deliberate abortions at a cumulative cost for this item alone of $80m. The inescapable conclusion is that the Commonwealth Government is underwriting the Australian abortion industry and is lining the pockets of a relatively small number of abortionists at taxpayers' expense.

An alarming fact is that the number of abortions is increasing each year. The latest abortion statistics show that during 1989-90 abortionists were directly subsidised by the taxpayer for almost 70,000 abortions at a cost of $7.8m. There were other associated payments which netted the abortionists several million dollars more. The latest figures, which were released to a Senate Estimates committee in September 1990, represent an increase of 4,800 over the previous year and an increase of 7,600 in the past two years. Any increase in the number of births has been almost offset by an increase in subsidised abortions. Abortions are increasing at a proportionately higher rate than births, which is a most disturbing development.

I have put the following question to honourable members before: is the embryo-foetus a human person some of the time or any of the time before it is born? If only some of the time, what is the suggested non-arbitrary marker point? Why is it right for the community to involve itself in the affairs of a seven-months-pregnant woman but not a two-months-pregnant woman? If the foetus is worthless and a woman's property, what would be wrong with women falling pregnant with the intention of having an abortion for the purpose of selling foetal tissue to transplant or research clinics?

Those outside the House who have followed the debate on this Bill will know that its opponents wish to focus not on the primary question of rights recognition for the unborn, but on the question of whether the Bill will have a greater impact on low income women than on high income women. I acknowledge that there are many compassionate men and women in this place whose concern for the poor, and poor women in particular, and whose anger at the capacity of the rich to buy their way around their moral and legal obligations blind them to the question of first principles. In failing to focus on the primary question, however, their response to this Bill is misdirected.

I say to those who see their opposition to this Bill as an act of solidarity with the poor that the problem facing a pregnant poor woman or a dependant woman is not the pregnancy but the poverty and the dependency. It is the poverty that is unwanted, not the child. As I can understand but never institutionalise desperate acts of infanticide by poor women, I understand but cannot institutionalise abortion by poor women.

I do not deny that a society marked by inequality will place unbearable burdens on many women facing parenthood, but I say to honourable members: let us not take the easy and cheap path of paying Medicare money to suppress the problem on an abortion clinic table. Let us develop family policies that sustain a woman in pregnancy and parenthood. There are those who speak mindlessly of unwanted pregnancies leading to abused and neglected children. To those people I say: look at the staggering growth of abuse and neglect and at homeless youth in a society with free and legal abortion. Is it not possible that the subversion of respect for life by the abortion industry and abortion philosophies is responsible for the increasing violence against children? Is it not likely that there is some deeper spiritual problem in our society at the root of violence against both the unborn and children?

In Australia laws on abortion are often attacked on the ground that parliaments have no business imposing their moral views on citizens. The problem with that argument is that virtually all laws are based on morality, or at least on someone's view of it. In considering the Bill, we, individually and as a Parliament, have before us only two choices: we can choose life or we can choose death. There are no in between arguments or debate. We cannot be pro-choice; we are either pro-life or pro-death. I urge honourable members to think very hard about all the issues involved and to choose life. I urge honourable members to support this Bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Is the motion seconded?
—I second the motion and reserve my right to speak later in the debate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Neil Mr L.R.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support the Abortion Funding Abolition Bill. Each day society is outraged when it hears of the rapes, murders and other violent crimes committed to our fellow men or women, yet most sit mute when, at whim, a young innocent unborn life is terminated in the time it would take to snap one's fingers. Yet the termination of young unborn babies in this country is not only tolerated but also legal-what a tragic indictment on our society.

SPEECH.PARA: The honourable member for Macquarie (Mr Webster) has eloquently articulated his private member's Bill. No-one can doubt his obvious sincerity in introducing it. To my mind this Bill deserves much more consideration than the limited time available for debate here today.

I have had the unfortunate experience of listening to a number of women confess to serious emotional disorders because of aborting a child years earlier. An address by John O. Anderson in 1989 on post-abortion grief in part highlighted some of this grief. I quote from part of his paper:
It had been about a year since she had had her abortion. At the time she had felt relief; and no apparent problems since.

But now she was walking alone down a shopping mall. Coming toward her was a young husband and wife, happily pushing a stroller with a baby. As she eyed the infant, she mentally calculated, `If the baby I was carrying had been born, it would be about the age of this one.' And then it happened: she was suddenly gripped with anguish; she wanted to cry; struggling with her emotions, she hurried out of the mall.

What happened to this young woman? Did she suffer from post-abortion grief, the syndrome that just in the past few years has been given a psychological designation? Most likely she did, and her story could be repeated thousands of times.

Only recently have we come to grips with the reality that abortion has emotional after-effects. However, society has not understood or perhaps even wanted to admit that this problems exists. It seems that no matter which side of the abortion question we are on, we should honestly face this issue. Let us be clear that post-abortion grief for many women is not a myth, but a reality. We are finding that hundreds of thousands of women who have aborted their children exhibit a deeply disturbing trend of psychological distress and physical harm. Through a growing number of studies and from the testimonies of the women themselves, evidence is piling up to show that abortion is adversely affecting society. Much of the evidence has been collected only recently.
One woman wrote:

Little did I know at 19 years of age that my abortion was the beginning of years of pain, heartache and guilt, such trauma that led me to drinking and drug abuse to numb the pain, that I couldn't change what I did.
Another woman wrote:

Post-abortive stress, it is real. Like a person who goes to war and comes home only to have people tell him, `Oh that is behind you'. A woman who undergoes an abortion can no more follow that kind of shallow advice than a veteran suffering from post-war stress. You don't just `put' the taking of a human life from inside your womb `behind you'. It never leaves your memory.
Post-abortion syndrome, which may well afflict millions of women, is still surrounded by a conspiracy of silence in the largely pro-abortion media and medical organisations.

In our society it is easy to become isolated. Many women are alone without family or friendly support systems and their pain can go unrecognised. Couple this with poverty, low self-esteem, feelings of uselessness and purposelessness, confusion about relationships and their own identity and on top of this an unplanned or unwanted pregnancy, and where do women turn? Sure, pregnancy support centres do meet some needs. Initially, most centres provide assistance for those women who are distressed about an unplanned pregnancy, but as time has progressed these support centres are providing caring, supportive counselling services to all pregnant women in need. Apart from this one-to-one work, there are often opportunities to do other types of preventative work, for example, sex education in schools and natural family planning. But more needs to be done to help these areas of support.

We, as legislators, have a responsibility to accept that challenge. The private member's Bill introduced by the honourable member for Macquarie is the catalyst for that challenge. I urge the House to support his Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Filing Mr P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support the honourable member for Macquarie (Mr Webster) in speaking to his private member's Bill, the Abortion Funding Abolition Bill 1990, which is also sponsored by the Parliamentary Pro-Life Group, of which I am proud to be a member. I do so in the knowledge that the issue of Medicare funding for abortion is a subject which arouses great emotion within the Australian community. I do so in the sure knowledge that many in the community support abortions on demand, but that should never be a final determinant of the position of a member of parliament on any issue.

SPEECH.PARA: To influence me in making my decision as to whether or not to support the Bill, the pro-abortionists have pushed the argument that in recent years pro-life legislators have suffered electorally as a result of their beliefs. I do not believe that is in fact the case, but even if it were, that also should not be a final determinant of a member's position.

I acknowledge the fact that I am a male discussing an issue that physically affects the lives of women and I am aware that many women in the community believe the matter to be a matter of decision making only for women. I reject the latter proposition.

Our responsibility in debating this Bill is to choose whether or not we believe that taxpayers' funds should be used to pay for abortions where there is no risk to the life of the mother. The Bill raises fundamental questions as to the concept of the beginning of life and where our responsibility for the preservation of life begins.

On a previous occasion the honourable member for Perth (Dr Charlesworth) commented that there is no clear agreement on when human life begins; that, taken to its logical conclusion, the objection to interfering with the chance of a human life eventuating would preclude contraception or family planning. He concluded:
The best way to reduce the number of abortions is to have better sex education, better and more family planning and indeed more support for those who find themselves in those circumstances.

I agree with the honourable member's latter statement. However, in the context of this Bill, it is not the central issue. The debate on this Bill turns on whether or not a community should pay for the termination of the life of an unborn individual whose fate is determined by circumstances other than the risk to the life of the mother.

If we accept the use of taxes to fund abortions on demand, we are in essence concluding that there is a period of embryonic development where there are no inherent rights attributable to the unborn individual which are equal or superior to those of the rest of the community. In other words, we are making a judgment as to when the rights of an unborn individual begin. In supporting abortion on demand we are saying that those rights begin at a stage after the stage of embryonic development that physically permits a termination of the pregnancy.

This debate is not one about freedom of choice. An individual's right to life is not a matter of choice. If it were, we would be making a determination about the relative value of a particular life that is not ours to make. In the end there is no greater responsibility for a society than to ensure that it survives. Those of us entrusted with making decisions on behalf of our greater community, the Australian nation, have a basic duty to provide for measures that are consistent with that responsibility.

We are tolerating a situation where taxpayer funded abortions are increasing at a rate greater than the increase in the number of births. As a society, we have a significant number of adult members who are precluded from adopting Australian-born children because of the decline in our birth rate. As a consequence, they are often faced with the prospect of going overseas to seek potential adoptees. The decline in our birth rate is ageing our society and forcing us to rely on immigration for replacement members, rather than on native births.

What are the measures that we, as legislators, have taken in this situation? What is the conclusion that can be drawn from our financial support for the voluntary termination of the lives of unborn individuals? In an article in the Melbourne Sunday Age on 10 March this year, Jo Wainer, a leading pro-abortionist, stated that the recession was forcing more and more women to seek abortions. A senior counsellor at the Fertility Control Clinic, Mrs June Dryburgh, contended that economy was always a factor for women considering an abortion.

The greatest argument used in opposing the abolition of Medicare funding for abortion on demand is that only the wealthy will be able to afford proper medical supervision, while the poor will be forced to resort to backyard or unsafe procedures. That is at the heart of the argument of those who claim that abortion on demand is a matter of freedom of choice. In the end, the nub of their argument for abortion on demand is one of economy. Human life itself becomes subservient to financial considerations.

The preservation of life is fundamental to our society. One cannot equivocate when considering that principle. The use of taxpayers' money to fund the termination of the lives of unborn individuals is wrong and should be discontinued. This Bill sets out to right that wrong. I commend the Bill to the House and congratulate its mover, the honourable member for Macquarie, on taking this historic step towards restoring a basic human right-the right to life.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Charlesworth Dr R.I.

TALK.START.PARA: —As I have mentioned before in this place, I respect the views and opinions of the honourable member for Macquarie (Mr Webster). I believe he is very genuine and sincere; I just disagree with him.

SPEECH.PARA: The argument that is used is very subtle in a number of ways. One of the ways in which it is subtle is that we do not refer to doctors; we refer to abortionists, as though the people who carry out these procedures are not medical practitioners with the highest ethical standards that we would expect. We also use an argument which equates termination with murder. If that is the case, and if that is in fact the argument that we want to use in this circumstance, then what we should be doing here is providing that all of those medical practitioners who engage in this activity should be charged with murder. Indeed, that is a logical consequence of what the honourable member is suggesting although, of course, he never goes that far because he understands, as I do, that when it comes to moral questions it is a case of what it is better than or worse than; it is a case of making fine judgments.

The honourable member suggested that this is a very complex issue. None of us would suggest that there is not a difference between the man who steals to feed his starving children and the man who steals because he wants a new swimming pool in the backyard. We would make a moral judgment as to stealing in those circumstances and it is necessary in each circumstance to make those sorts of judgments when we talk about moral issues.

Indeed, when does an acorn becomes an oak tree? Where do you draw the line? This is one of the great problems in this debate, and I accept that. It has been mentioned by the honourable member for Moore (Mr Filing), and it is the case, that if one is going to draw the line at contraception, and say that contraception is okay but anything that happens after that is different, then why should one not draw the line at birth? Indeed, there is no-one who can come up with a convincing argument one way or the other.

If we look for scientific evidence, as has been suggested, the scientific community cannot arrive at a consensus as to where life begins. There is a great deal of conflict in that regard. In my last speech in the House on this matter I mentioned that evidence and, indeed, a large body of very eminent scientists came to the conclusion that they cannot make a judgment on where life begins.

If one goes to the Catholic Church, which of course is one of the strongest bodies that opposes abortion, one finds that there is no consensus amongst its members, either. The way in which they treat a miscarried foetus and a newborn child that has died is different. If the Catholic Church makes that distinction, then who are we to question its position?

I oppose the Abortion Funding Abolition Bill for two reasons. First, I do not think that it will achieve its very laudable aim of reducing the number of abortions, an aim that I would support. Second, I believe that a significant issue in this respect is freedom of conscience and the freedom of people to make those decisions for themselves in our society. I would argue that the rights of the mother and the rights of the child change during the period following conception until birth. Indeed, perhaps there is a time when we have to say, `Okay, the rights of the child, when this foetus is viable, become stronger'. But that is a difficult question. Nobody has satisfied me with respect to an answer to it. Those who want it in black and white are fooling themselves; they are looking for a simple solution which does not exist.

The honourable member for Moore mentioned the issue of taxpayers' funds being used for things that people should disagree with. This is a facile argument and one which should be destroyed because, consistent with that same argument, those taxpayers who do not have children at school should object to school funding.

Removing Medicare funding for abortion will not change what is available. Abortions are not underpinned by Medicare funding; they are underpinned by the fact that there are unwanted pregnancies. Unwanted pregnancies are a result of ignorance, poor education, rape in some circumstances, failed contraception or just a mistake.
