Those unwanted pregnancies will remain and the choice will remain for women. It needs to be understood that there are ways of combating this: better sex education, as has been mentioned; family planning; better support from us; more tolerance and compassion; support from family members; and support from other members of the community. Those things are important and necessary if we wish to decrease the number of abortions. If this legislation is passed, it will change the available treatment. That would be a mistake; it would be undesirable. That is why I oppose this legislation.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bradford Mr J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I, too, support the private member's Bill of the honourable member for the Macquarie (Mr Webster), the Abortion Funding Abolition Bill 1990. There is no doubt that this would be one of the most emotional issues to come before this Parliament and it is an issue that concerns all members of the community and all members of Parliament. It is not an issue of Christian versus non-Christian or Catholic versus non-Catholic or Labor versus Liberal; it is matter of fundamental concern to everybody. I hope that this Parliament will ultimately vote in support of this historic Bill.

SPEECH.PARA: In answer to some of the questions that the honourable member for Perth (Dr Charlesworth) raises-and I note that he would like to see a reduction in the number of abortions and I consider that a very positive contribution-I do not question the ethics of those medical practitioners who are involved in carrying out abortions, but I do question their morality. I do question their theology and their motivation. The real question here is: why should Australians in the broad sense fund abortion on demand? I guess the fundamental issue that is raised in this Bill is the question of why abortions should be provided at the cost of the taxpayers. Of course, in a broader context it raises the whole issue of abortion. Therefore it is a very important Bill that deserves to be discussed to the full extent.

In the end, it boils down to a question of economics. The question then becomes one of why human life itself should become subservient to financial considerations. I pose the question: how many of those who espouse human rights would suggest that those rights should be circumscribed by financial considerations? For that matter, in taking the line of those who contend that the availability of abortion provides freedom of choice, is a person who chooses to terminate a human life because of financial pressures making a valid choice or is the so-called choice, that of abortion, actually made for her? Are we, if we allow for the continuation of funding for abortions, in effect making that choice for people?

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The time allotted for this debate has expired. The debate is adjourned and the resumption of the debate will be made an order of the day for the next sitting Thursday.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Question proposed:
That grievances be noted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Prosser Mr G.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I cannot recall the number of people who have contacted me after applying for public housing and being told that nothing is available. Indeed, many have been informed that their names would go onto the waiting list and that suitable accommodation may not be available for up to three years.

SPEECH.PARA: Inevitably, these people are on low incomes. Often the main breadwinner has lost his or her job and can no longer afford to pay private rental accommodation or, in an increasing number of cases, families have lost their homes because they have been unable to meet their mortgage repayments. Previous record high interest rates and now rapidly escalating unemployment have meant that a growing number of Australian families are unable to stay in their own homes.

Whatever the circumstances, the only option for these families is public housing. Consequently they are devastated by the news that there is no accommodation available and that they face a wait, in some cases, of up to three years. They come to me desperately searching for alternatives. Many are looking for a way in which their applications can be speeded up and the names brought to the top of the list. Unfortunately, in most cases, this is just not possible.

This is the human side of a serious problem stemming from our State and Federal public housing policies. The deficiency of these policies has been highlighted by the impact of the current economic recession. Housing, particularly public housing, is a national problem which will not be resolved until the Commonwealth, in conjunction with the States, adopts a new and innovative approach.

In Western Australia, especially in my own electorate of Forrest, the shortage of public housing is well documented. Each of the main centres in Forrest has experienced a significant increase in the demand for public housing in recent years. As a consequence of this, the waiting period for housing has also increased considerably. In Albany, the southernmost tip of my electorate, a single person could currently have to wait for over four years for public accommodation; a pensioner, 3 1/2 years; and a family, just over 2 1/2 years. In Denmark, a family may wait for up to three years before being placed on the public housing list. In Busselton, the average waiting period for a family is 2 1/2 years, while in Bunbury, a family can wait three years depending on the size of the house and the location required.

The experience of my electorate reflects the national situation. The number of individuals and families waiting for public housing around the country currently stands at nearly 200,000, an increase of some 40 per cent in just five years. For all of these families the difficulty lies in trying to meet the cost of rental accommodation in the private market while waiting for a house to become available. A recent national study indicated a significant number of low income families not in public housing spend more than 40 per cent of their income on rent. As the Government's recession-induced policies continue to bite, unemployment becomes more widespread and real wages continue to fall, the demand for, and strain on, public housing will continue to worsen.

In Western Australia this is happening at a time when the State Government can least afford it. The State's notorious big leather satchel, its Consolidated Revenue Fund, has suffered under the combined effects of the national economic downturn and the State Government's many misguided and highly dubious business dealings.

This year in Western Australia the State Housing Commission has budgeted to spend $65.5m on the construction of public housing. This is a massive 47 per cent reduction in real terms in the amount spent in the last financial year-that being $110.1m. Land acquisition and development spending has also been savagely cut from $78m in 1989-90 to $52.5m in 1990-91. While the State was able to prop up its spending in the last financial year by calling into account some $101m in internal funds, this source has now been exhausted and the result has been savage cutbacks in government services, including public housing.

It is imperative now more than ever that the Government get best value for every dollar spent on public housing. This must extend not only to the construction of public houses, but to their management, administration and maintenance. Similarly, checks on tenants of public housing must be frequently undertaken to ensure their circumstances have not changed and that the system has not been abused.

I previously suggested that the Commonwealth encourage or even provide incentives for the States to make better use of their housing grants. It is time for the States to become more innovative and forward thinking in the area of public housing. For example, the States should look seriously at an accelerated plan to sell off public housing to long term tenants. In doing this, they would be giving a large number of Australian families the opportunity of realising the great Australian dream of owning their own home.

Most Australian State governments offer limited home purchase finance schemes, but these rely essentially on government capital as the source of funds. Consequently, the schemes do little or nothing to free up resources which can then be redirected to increase the stocks of public houses. Instead, by offering public houses for sale on favourable terms and finance on a commercial basis, there is scope for governments to raise additional revenue. However, a fundamental feature of any such proposal would be to have that revenue raised and channelled into increasing the supply of public housing.

A second benefit accruing to government would be a reduction in maintenance costs. Collectively, the States currently spend just over $240m per annum on maintenance. If public houses were sold off, particularly the older houses, State governments could realise significant savings, which again would be directed to increasing the overall stock of housing. The Commonwealth could also encourage the States to utilise private sector resources to complement the existing government services. For example, some public housing authorities already contract out maintenance duties to the private sector.

There are other innovative measures which can be actively pursued by the States-measures which involve greater cooperation with, and participation by, the private sector. One such measure has been developed recently and implemented by the New South Wales Government. I take this opportunity to congratulate my colleagues in that State on their innovative approach to the issue of public housing.

The New South Wales Government, concerned about the growing public housing waiting list and yet mindful of the State's limited financial position, looked to the private sector for assistance in increasing the stock of public housing. It recently entered into a partnership with the AMP Society, the aim of which is to provide 1,000 new homes for rental for those on the public housing waiting list. While the 1,000 new homes will be constructed or acquired as part of the New South Wales Department of Housing capital works program, the finance, totalling some $145m, will be provided solely by AMP. Thus the housing stock available for public tenants has been substantially increased without the associated government expenditure.

The properties will be managed and maintained by the New South Wales Department of Housing in the same manner as all other government housing. Returns to the investor are a consumer price index floor on capital gain and a real rental return. If State governments are to have any hope of catering for the growing demand for public housing they must become more progressive and forward thinking. They need to cooperate more with the private sector to maximise the funds they have available. Equally, there is a role for the Commonwealth. The Commonwealth must encourage the development and the use of these schemes, whether it is through the Commonwealth-State Housing Agreement or the Premiers Conference.

More importantly, the Commonwealth must create the right economic environment so that the public housing system will not be overburdened. A healthy economy and full employment will offer the greatest assistance to the States in ensuring that only those in genuine need move into the public housing system.

Although they are agrarian hillbillies, those in the Queensland National Party showed how one puts one's head in a trough and how one rorts a system-whether it is by drought rorts, graft or corruption, it really does not matter. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ronaldson Mr M.J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I could talk about a wide variety of matters today, but the Australian Labor Party mateship never ceases to amaze me. I would have thought the honourable member for Hinkler (Mr Courtice) was too far away from Perth to get tied up in this, but he has been caught up in the scam as well. Perhaps he should read the Brian Burke election manual which is written on both sides of a paper bag; but that is another story.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to grieve on a large number of matters today. The first one, and I think probably the most important, is the diabolical position that the people of Bangladesh find themselves in at the moment. I was horrified to read this morning that the government owned paper is now talking in terms of half a million people. I think that is quite horrific. I know the Government has increased the amount of aid that it is sending and I urge it please to increase that.

The second matter I wish to grieve on today is the meat industry inquiry. Honourable members will know that the likes of Wally Curran and his cohorts in Victoria have totally destroyed the industry in that State. We have seen job losses in the thousands. We have seen export earnings reduced in the millions.

I think everyone was of the view that the meat industry inquiry was probably going to be a means to an end. That has not happened because the union, after 14 months and with three sitting days to go, has pulled out. This has cost a lot of money. It has been a bipartisan approach to the problems in the meat industry. Yet, with three sitting days to go, the Australasian Meat Industry Employees Union (AMIEU) has pulled out. The reason is that it is not happy with the Australian Industrial Relations Commission. It is not happy with the wage decision of a month ago.

It is intriguing, as reported by Shane Green in the Australian this morning, that the very man who was heading this meat industry inquiry, Mr Harrison, was formerly an assistant national secretary of the Amalgamated Metal Workers Union. He has told the meat workers union to get back into that inquiry because he knows that the work practices that have riddled and wrecked that industry for year after year need to be solved.

What has the union done? It has pulled the plug on the inquiry with three sittings days to go. I believe it is a despicable performance and I hope that Senator Cook wins in his battle with the union to get it back there. It is a further indication that the leaders of the union movement in this country are totally out of step with what the grassroots trade unionists want. They want jobs.

That brings me to another point-the 9.9 per cent unemployment rate that was announced this morning. I will be pleased to see the would-be Prime Minister come in here and tell the Australian people that it is a good figure and it is on track. It is off track. His leadership ambition is off track. Mr Deputy Speaker, you know and everyone in this House knows of the toing and froing over the last few months. Those in the New South Wales Right have been trying to get their boy up; it has been going on. Mr Deputy Speaker, you and I know that positions would be offered to various people if the coup comes off.

I challenge the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) to come in here today and to tell the Australian people whether he is healthy or otherwise. If he comes back in here in two months time and says that he is unhealthy and has to give it away, we will know and the Australian people will know that it was a con job and that a deal was done with the Treasurer (Mr Keating) to get him out. Let us hear what the Prime Minister has to say.

Let us hear what the Treasurer has to say on this 9.9 per cent figure. I have been here for 13 months and every single day during Question Time we hear about `Howard in 1983'. If we combine the unemployment rate and the underemployment rate, guess who has got the worst figures? It is the Treasurer-not the honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard), but the Treasurer. That does not take into account the April underemployment rate. We are as close to 10 per cent as possible.

Mr Deputy Speaker, we have not even had a drought yet, and you know full well that that drought was a major component of the recession that we went through in 1982-83. Every person in this House had better keep his or her fingers crossed that the winter drought that we are potentially facing at the moment does not come off. Honourable members from Queensland, New South Wales and Victoria know very well that we are in an extremely dry period at the moment and heaven help us if we do not get a lot of rain shortly.

The Australian Bureau of Agricultural and Resource Economics was reported yesterday as saying that wheat planting will be potentially down by 25 per cent and the farmers' groups are saying that it could be down by 50 per cent. That will potentially spell further disaster for a rural sector that is already in depression and not recession.

If my colleagues from both sides of the House took the time to go out to rural electorates, they would know very well the depth of that depression. They know very well the depressed state of mind of country people. In regard to my home town of Ballarat, I have not seen the relative unemployment figures today, but I can tell the House that the youth unemployment rate two months ago was approaching 29 per cent. Twenty-nine per cent of our young people are unemployed. That is frightening, in my view. They will not be given the opportunity to get that work experience and the potential is there for them to get on the social security wagon-the birth-to-death syndrome. Quite frankly, we owe our young people considerably more than that.

Just getting back to the AMIEU, I challenge it to get back before Mr Harrison today, and I challenge it to take very seriously the threat of the National Farmers Federation that if it does not do so, it should be deregistered. If Senator Cook is really serious about this problem he will support those moves and he will have that union deregistered.

Victoria, as a result of the Cain-Kirner Government over the last eight or nine years, quite frankly, is an economic mess. It is a total mess. The honourable member for Higgins (Mr Costello) knows what it is like. He knows what the state of mind of the Melbourne people is. I can tell him that it is three times as bad in the country and at the moment they are holding no hope for their future. The sooner that Government goes, the better, and the sooner this Government goes, the better. I tell honourable members on the other side to spend a bit of time here during lunch to pick themselves a seat with a view because they are going to be on this side for a long time and the better the seat, the better the view.

TALK.START.PARA: —Do you think they would have a better chance with Keating?

—The realities are that we on this side of the House would like to see the Treasurer as Prime Minister, because honourable members on the other side could pick their seats wherever they like, and I suspect probably even on the front bench, because there will be total decimation. The Australian people do not trust the Treasurer. If the Labor Party wants to put him in, then we would fully support that.

SPEECH.PARA: Tim Colebatch, in the Age this morning, referred to the Government's construction forecasting committee which yesterday forecast new pictures of deep gloom for the nation's building investment prospects. We get the Treasurer coming in here day after day telling us that investment is taking place and that investment is on track. Mr Colebatch writes:

The experts predict that not only will the building slump be worse than previously thought but there will be no real recovery for years. Total building activity in three years' time will be even lower than it is now.
Mr Colebatch writes that the Committee forecasts that-and I quote:

The economy will remain `subdued' before slowly recovering to a growth rate of about 2.5 per cent by 1993-94. That is barely one-third the growth rate experienced in the 1984 recovery, implying that the country faces the worst run of years since the Great Depression.
This is pretty strong stuff. This is coming from the Government's own committee. Mr Colebatch writes that the Committee forecasts that-and I quote:

The annual value of non-residential building activity will slump by $2.4 billion this financial year and keep falling for three more years. By the time it touches bottom in 1993-94, it will be adding $5 billion, or one-third, less to the economy than it did four years earlier. Investment in factories and other business premises will decline by about 30 per cent over four years, while hotel and office construction will decline by 40 per cent. Education and health buildings will be the only areas showing any growth.

Investment in housing-seen by the Treasurer, Mr Keating, as the first step in recovery-is set to fall still further. Far from recovering, it is forecast to slump another $700 million or 3.8 per cent over 1991-92, having already fallen $2.9 billion or 14 per cent this financial year.

The realities are that this Government has made an unmitigated mess of this economy. It is about time that it either took some very hard decisions or took its decisions back to the Australian people. I challenge it to do one or the other. It should either do that or go back to the people.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gibson Mr G.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was honoured recently when I was asked to be the speaker at a function to launch the establishment of a new group in Queensland called Medical Aid for El Salvador and, subsequently, to become the patron of that organisation. The invitation provided me with an opportunity to learn more about the continuing tragedy in El Salvador and to realise that we still have an enormously long way to go to achieve the basic principles of social justice, peace and freedom for many peoples throughout the world. It also makes one pause and reflect on the fact that, although we may be going through some tough economic times in Australia at the moment, we are still very fortunate indeed to live in this country.

SPEECH.PARA: The war in El Salvador has been brutal and has taken a major toll of the country and its people. El Salvador's conflict has claimed some 75,000 lives, more than 40,000 of them civilians, leaving an ever widening circle of shattered families, orphaned children and homeless people. Such problems are exacerbated by the continued abuse of human rights, harassment and torture inflicted on civilians considered to be troublemakers or assisting the forces opposed to the Government.

Medical Aid for El Salvador was established in 1982 by a group of United States citizens who were brought together by a common concern for the citizens of El Salvador who had found themselves in the middle of an American-sponsored war. The founders were opposed to the United States Government's policy of providing tens of millions of dollars of military aid to El Salvador. Over the past decade the US has given more than $1 billion in military aid. The US involvement in this conflict props up a repressive, unjust and undemocratic regime and exacerbates the suffering and pain of the people of El Salvador.

El Salvador has had a long and violent history in which the populace have long opposed the repressive measures of the Government. Its history is characterised by savage repression against any challenge to the economic interests of the powerful. It is the level of social injustice which keeps the war going.

There is an immense disparity in the distribution of wealth which maintains the large-scale social injustice for the people. The history of El Salvador, and it still remains the same today, tells us that a very small percentage of the population, namely 20 powerful families, owns the vast majority of the country's economic resources. The citizens of El Salvador cannot express their dissatisfaction with the Government by any means except through social unrest.

With the high level of violence there are, of course, major health problems. The destruction of infrastructure and the pressure on hospital places leave the overall health standard in a poor state. Extra pressure is put on the few health places through the large number of internally displaced people. As a result of the war some 600,000 people are displaced, with 70 per cent of these being women and children. The military coup of 1979 heightened the violence and repression of the workers. Since that time, military and paramilitary death squad violence has occurred. The continual repression of the people by the military has caused a massive allocation of resources to the military and away from basic health and other community services.

In the mid-1980s more than 40 per cent of the budget was allocated to military expenditure. As well, the continued civil unrest has caused a considerable reduction in health facilities for the local people. Those who oppose the Government are also afraid to go to the state-run hospitals to seek treatment.

In 1981, for a country of more than four million people, there were 46 state controlled hospitals with a total capacity of only 7,375 beds and 1,793 physicians. The war has seen this number tragically reduced. In 1987, the El Salvadorian Government allocated the equivalent of $A32m towards health or approximately $7.50 per person per annum. The Australian Government allocates more than $750 per person per annum to health care.

Budgetary pressures, made worse by an annual population growth rate of 3 per cent, have seen the standards of health care, housing and general welfare fall substantially. Only 37 per cent of Salvadorians have access to even minimal health care and, according to the Salvadorian Ministry of Health, 75 per cent of children suffer from malnutrition.

The flight of professionals, combined with the lack of transportation and other problems, now means that the country has one of the worst health care ratios in the central American region. In 1989, for every 10,000 Salvadorians there were only 3.2 doctors, 2.1 nurses and only 12 hospital beds. Extreme poverty brings major health problems in terms of providing basic dietary requirements, sanitation and drinkable water.

The economic situation in El Salvador has continued to decline with a fall in prices for agricultural exports and accelerating inflation. Twenty per cent of the population earns 80 per cent of the income, creating a mass of urban and rural poor. There are more than three million Salvadorians-some 60 per cent of the population-who, according to official statistics, live in extreme poverty and do not earn enough to cover what is termed as `the basic shopping basket'.

The task of caring for those in need and the integration back into society of those displaced has not been assisted by the government authorities and the security forces. The military has often undertaken indiscriminate bombardment of rural areas and has prevented church and volunteer agencies from entering such areas for many days afterwards. These attacks have left many people with poor access to even basic health services.

According to the United Nations Children's Fund, only 40 per cent of rural Salvadorians now have access to safe water and basic health services. The level of violence in the country has caused a constant flow of peasants to the shanty towns which surround the cities. In and around San Salvador alone are more than 300 shanty towns which have been erected by hundreds of thousands of people fleeing the conflict. These towns are crisscrossed by gullies, along which streams carry the sewage and waste of the city. According to the Government, there is an estimated housing shortfall of nearly half a million homes.

Demands on humanitarian organisations are extensive and outstripping all capacity to provide for those in dire need. Many volunteer aid agencies-and most noticeably the Catholic Church-are attempting to supply basic drinking water, improve the streets, build housing and set up clinics in many of the shanty towns. These efforts are not always welcomed by the El Salvadorian Government. There is ongoing persecution and selective violence applied to community organisations that are working for the welfare of the poor.

As with some other countries, those who work to redress the injustices suffered by the poorest and most needy in the community arouse the suspicion of the authorities. There are many brutal accounts of selective terror against those working for social justice: the murder of four church women from the United States; the assassination of the Roman Catholic Archbishop of San Salvador, Oscar Romero; the slaying of two United States union representatives; and, most notably, in November 1989 the massacre by the military of six Jesuit priests. As recently as three months ago, there was a massacre in the countryside of 15 Salvadorian church workers by the Government's First Brigade-an incident which has gone largely unreported by the Australian media.

It is this level of persecution of aid workers which has led to the call by the Australian Council for Overseas Aid for the Federal Government to seek diplomatic help to protect aid workers. Of the more than 100 international aid workers who were in El Salvador before the fighting intensified in late 1989, only 20 now remain. Many have been detained, run out of the country, or have left after receiving death threats. It is only with the support of the international aid agencies and workers, such as Medical Aid for El Salvador, that Salvadorians can survive.

The United States Government continues to sponsor and support a regime that operates a system of fear, terror and repression and which is based on injustice. We have the situation where the self-appointed world policeman can continually oppose injustice in one part of the world, namely the Middle East, yet can sponsor repressive regimes in central America.

The health problems will not be solved until there is an end to the war. The war will not end until there is an end to the injustice in El Salvador. There must be action to end the levels of poverty and the continual repression. Only when the war ends-and hopefully this will be soon-will organisations, such as Medical Aid for El Salvador, be able to properly address the health needs of the people who have been so tragically neglected. I commend the organisation to all honourable members and urge their full support.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Taylor Mr W.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the short time available to me today in this grievance debate, I would like to speak on two aspects of public policy, perhaps at opposite ends of the perception spectrum. One is a very real and ongoing problem directly affecting people now, as well as being a vital element of our national economy; and the other is a less visible-but nonetheless increasingly important-aspect of our national will.

SPEECH.PARA: I speak, firstly, of the paralysis of the rural recession and, secondly, of the impending ministerial announcements-which are reportedly to be made early next month-into major government initiated changes in the direction of our national defence effort. Both are driven by a common theme-money.

On the first point, I speak with some first-hand electorate experience as a representative of one of the most productive rural regional centres in our nation. On the second point, I speak as someone not only with three decades of defence service behind him-until three years ago-but also as a private citizen and parliamentary representative who has an increasing unease that we are being led up the proverbial garden path by two defence Ministers who, no matter how hard they try, continue to be dominated by the Russell Hill legacies of the previous Minister for Defence, the honourable member for Swan (Mr Beazley).

On the first point, the rural crisis is arguably a crisis of the greatest proportion in 50 years, wherein the range of international commodity downturn is perhaps unparalleled. The honourable member for Higgins (Mr Costello) said of it in this place earlier in the week, and I think very appropriately:
This feeds into country service centres where people who service rural producers are no longer able to make good incomes. We are seeing a basic wind-down in rural infrastructure.
The mood out there in the bush is one of desperation. Regrettably, as the people turn to this Parliament in general, and this leaderless Government in particular, they find few, if any, solutions.

My colleague the honourable member for Riverina-Darling (Mr Hicks) spoke in this place in the last sitting week of the spiralling and unsustainable on-farm costs. Today, I would like to reiterate what I said in that same debate about the impact of the recession on provincial centres, relating that to my home town of Toowoomba on the Darling Downs in Queensland.

Toowoomba is the second largest inland city in this country and with 90,000 residents it is now a microcosm of everything that happens in our day-to-day economic life. Regrettably, it is a city which is in danger of degenerating into a city without a soul. Why do I say that? I give this House but a few examples.

Firstly, we find that the central business district has about 80 empty commercial spaces. This, of course, is indicative of the general economic downturn. Next, we look at the Southern Cross Corporation Ltd-a company with a high national and international reputation in the production and supply of irrigation equipment and accessories for the motor vehicle industry. Ten years ago, that company had over 2,000 employees; today, it is down to a little over 400 with 50 employees having been retrenched in the last few months.

Next, we turn to what was one of the largest department stores which had serviced Toowoomba and the Darling Downs region as a family company since early this century, until it was taken over by the McDonnell and East Retail Pty Ltd chain several years ago. On Christmas Eve, with two hours notice, the store was closed and 130 employees were added to the unemployment queue.

Next, we look at Palila Clothing Co. Pty Ltd-a factory which was established 40 years ago and which local Chris Carter ran as a very reliable subcontractor in the textiles, clothing and footwear industry. Only a month ago, that company went to the wall, throwing nearly 150 people onto the unemployment queues. There are other examples within the city which time today does not allow me to explore, other than to say that while the on-farm situation continues to be critical, the flow-on effect has a traumatic effect on such enterprises as seed merchants, farm machinery producers, general retailers and, very importantly, the boarding education sector.

I finish my brief comments on the rural crisis by saying that whilst some farmers out there may have extended themselves financially, very few are seeking simply a government handout to redress their situation. What they are looking for from the Government, with the support of this Opposition, is a reversal of a situation which has in large part been generated by a government that increasingly does not want to know, despite what the rural task force chairman, the honourable member for Hinkler (Mr Courtice) has to say.

The 700,000 small businesses across our country are feeling the pinch and an important subset of that small business sector is rural enterprise, which produces about 40 per cent of our national export income. It is, therefore, incumbent on all of us at the political level to do whatever we can to correct their increasingly desperate financial situation. While they remain in trouble, so does our nation.

I turn now to the mooted Defence Force changes on which we have seen a wide range of media reports in recent weeks. In the Bulletin on 7 May, journalist David Barnett wrote an article titled `Wanted: someone to defend the defenders'. I consider the article to be both accurate and timely. Implicit in that article and consistent with a line that I would take is that Defence Minister, Robert Ray, and his junior Minister, the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel, the honourable member for Kingston (Mr Bilney), will both be tested as they come to grips with the contents of the major Defence statement to Parliament early next month. Both know that the large shadow of the previous Defence Minister still prevails on Russell Hill, and that one of his legacies is a proliferation of politicians-regrettably, both in and out of uniform-in those departmental corridors.

The former Minister for Defence may have achieved for the Defence Force in terms of capital re-equipment programs and strategic thinking, but at what expense to our Defence Force? One has only to look at the statistics of his time in office to see both the unparalleled manpower experience losses and persistent question marks about the apolitical nature of certain aspects of the Defence hierarchy under his portfolio management. I do not intend to elaborate on the latter today, other than to say that those civilian officials and senior uniformed officers in the Department know to what and to whom I refer. The former Minister for Defence's party political management of some elements of the Department of Defence was never a feature of previous coalition governments and I know that it will not be a feature of a Hewson government in 1993. Perhaps those to whom I refer might get out of the kitchen before it gets too hot.

Recently the Executive Director of the Australian Defence Association, Michael O'Connor, criticised both the Defence Department and its departmental consultant, Alan Wrigley, for their proposals for the expanded role of the Reserve element of the Australian Defence Force. In my view Michael O'Connor is correct when he says that the Wrigley militia concept is both unrealistic and unattainable given the present Defence budget. The Defence Department's recently leaked proposals on a ready reserve, if correct, may perpetuate a new version of the 1960s emergency reserve, which, I can say from personal experience, was a resounding failure.

The basic problems are that both Defence Ministers still see the 1987 Defence White Paper has a non-negotiable tablet of stone. Both skirt around the real issues of the need for defence strategic review, which the Opposition has in train, together with the importance of the need for the widest public debate on such issues as force structure, civilianisation and Australian industry involvement in the defence infrastructure, of which we have read so much in recent weeks.

Ministerial briefings by the Ministers of selected journalists in advance of the parliamentary statement next month are nothing more than a self-indulgent softening up of the public. Both Ministers suffer from a lack of in-depth understanding of either what a national strategy or its resultant defence strategy is all about. Selective media briefings are no substitute for parliamentary and public debates. I therefore say to Senator Ray, in particular, that he needs to reassess his opposition to a Defence Green Paper which would allow the fullest debate rather than an inadequate parliamentary statement of the sort that I suspect we are about to face.

The Minister for Defence Science and Personnel, for example, clearly is unable to sustain the specific thrust of the Defence Force logistic review announced last year. The Minister knows, Defence Department officials know and I know that the review is not substantiated by any definitive cost-benefit analysis. I am not surprised, therefore, that we see such articles as I saw in yesterday's Australian Financial Review, which talked of the depressed property market threatening to delay such logistic reforms.

Increasingly, government decisions on Russell Hill are being made in a policy vacuum of financial desperation. On this side of the House we have put defence back on the political agenda and we look forward to next month's statement.

I might finish by referring to what the honourable member for Hinkler said in this House a little while ago about ex Lord Mayor Sallyanne Atkinson. All I would say to the honourable member is that people in glass houses should not throw stones. What about the new Lord Mayor, Jim Soorley, and his gambling debts? Will the Australian Labor Party reveal the extent of those debts and the extent to which it has paid them off? Nobody minds a gambler, but everybody minds a welcher.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Newell Mr N.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —In this House in December I drew the attention of members to some of the grave problems being encountered by the frail aged and those with disabilities within the electorate of Richmond. At that time I told the House that the home and community care program, which is jointly funded by the Federal Government and the New South Wales Government, had been the subject of much media discussion and comment within the electorate.

SPEECH.PARA: The program was initiated by the Hawke Government when it came to power to provide all frail older Australians with the opportunity to live independently in their own homes for as long as possible or, more importantly, for as long as they choose to. This Government's aim was to vastly expand the range, quality and spread of services available to people and to ensure that those in need of the services would have access to them. To this end the Government invested large amounts of growth money into the program. Since 1985 the program has experienced funding growth of some 140 per cent in real terms. The number of actual funded services has increased by 104 per cent and covers all regions of Australia.

Until 1988, when the Greiner Government took power in New South Wales, New South Wales benefited from the national expansion of the home and community care program that was taking place. However, since 1988 the New South Wales Government has shown its willingness to cut services to people and to stifle the expansion of desperately needed home and community care services. The Greiner Government is thwarting the aims of the Federal Government to have services delivered to people in need in New South Wales. The Greiner Government prefers to direct the funds made available by the Federal Government into anything but services for people. There is no clearer example than that which has occurred in the electorate of Richmond.

The projects funded under the home and community care program allow many people who might otherwise have had to move into residential care to remain in their own homes. At the time that I spoke to the House in December I had met with home and community care organisations to discuss the whole question of the delivery of services because of the many representations which had been made to me. The major problem for home and community care workers and their clients at that time appeared to stem from policy decisions of the Home Care service of New South Wales program which operates under the home and community care umbrella in New South Wales, but is controlled by a statutory body under the broad control of the New South Wales Department of Family and Community Services.

Public concern at that time related to the effects of Home Care's policy decisions which had led to 131 people in the city of Lismore being axed from the program and 163 people having their hours reduced. The anecdotal evidence of the distress the cuts imposed on the frail aged in Lismore by suddenly being removed from help which was vital for their day-to-day life was, to put it mildly, horrifying.

It was, to say the least, very difficult to explain to people that the Family and Community Services Department was overseeing the reduction of service delivery when at the same time the Federal Government was making available a significant amount of growth money to expand the home and community care program.

I was not surprised to learn recently that the New South Wales Government is trying to direct money out of the home and community care program to pay for an inefficient health system by claiming that hospitals that prepare about 53 per cent of the delivered meals in New South Wales should be immediately paid double the amount that they are currently receiving at an approximate cost to the taxpayer of over $3m. This cost would result from a simple doubling of the home and community care program meal subsidy in New South Wales which is paid to all delivered meal providers. The New South Wales Government wants hundreds of thousands of dollars to be paid into its health system this year out of the program. That is money that is wasted, money that could go to provide people with services. Try explaining this to the people who need community care and support!

That program of removing people from the support program is continuing, despite the adverse publicity, the insoluble problems and the heartache and tears which those cuts are causing. Lismore people are still being axed from the service despite previous savage cuts. Those who use Home Care services in Lismore thought that the axe-wielding had finished, but it has begun again. Those cuts which were initiated by the New South Wales Government were made by Home Care in the name of regional equity. That means that the service is taken away from one person and given to another in another area so that Home Care can achieve some sort of balance.

We were told last year that Home Care was simply readjusting the formula to make it more equitable for the people of Ballina and Byron Bay. Some of my New South Wales colleagues have told me that the same kind of pattern of cutting and reallocating of services is occurring in other parts of New South Wales. But-and I emphasise this-it is not occurring in other States.

Those people cut from the service should not be dumped in this way. They have already been classified as `at risk' and may be forced into premature institutionalisation. The irony of it is that some of the people now receiving Home Care in other parts of the electorate, while needy, are as desperate as some of those struck from the service in the name of regional equity. This has been confirmed by Home Care workers. I am not suggesting that those people who were given help by Home Care following the readjustment are not in need, but I fail to understand how the State Minister responsible can sleep at night while presiding over a service which has compelled its workers to create so much havoc in the lives of people by removing necessary services from them. When I last addressed the House on this question, I said:

. . . anything the Minister . . . can do to persuade his colleague . . . in New South Wales to prevail upon home care to review the north coast situation would be gratefully welcomed by many people who are now worried about their future when just a few dollars or a few more hours would make all the difference and at the same time save the taxpayers of this nation much more in the short term as well.

For older persons or persons with acute disabilities, the lack of assistance with housekeeping services can often be the deciding factor in their ability to live in their own homes. In this case the calls for reason and compassion by the Federal Minister for Community Services and Health (Mr Howe) are falling on the callous, deaf ears of the New South Wales Government.

Without doing a disservice to the vast number of Home Care workers who give much more than they are paid for under the Home Care and home and community care banners, I have to raise the question of the competence of the administration of the New South Wales State Minister responsible for Home Care, Mr Webster. Doubts have been expressed to me about the competence of his administration of this service. Those doubts, which are really accusations, are made by people who know the administration and Webster's maladministration.

It is true that Home Care, indeed many of the home and community care programs, has many problems to face. No planning method has yet been devised which can accurately predict what the need for such services will be in our ageing population. Nevertheless, in my electorate, people have been deliberately removed from a support service when they had been assessed by competent people as needing care and support. The administration of Home Care seems to be obsessed with State-wide standardisation of its provisions when the effort should be towards meeting different needs.

I have some concerns too about the use of private consultants in this process and the value of their work. Dr Brian Pezzutti MLC, a local Liberal apologist, recently came to the defence of Mr Webster in the columns of the Northern Star, a regional daily. Dr Pezzutti in part said:

Fluctuations in the number of consumers occur normally as needs change. The Homecare service . . . regularly reassesses its consumers to determine the relative need for service that each consumer has. This can result in service changes to individual consumers.
Dr Pezzutti proceeded then to pour cold water on the media comment about the cuts in an attempt to dampen down the vehemence of local criticism.

I do not deny the problems which the Home Care administration might have. I know that it has a massive turnover of staff, but frankly the clinical analysis which Dr Pezzutti advances and which seems to be endorsed by the State Minister lacks the warmth and compassion which we learned to expect from the administration of Wran and Unsworth. It is too cold. It is just not good enough. I again ask the Minister to use his best offices to prevail upon the State Minister, Mr Webster, to review what is happening on the north coast and indeed in all New South Wales. People in need and assessed to be so by competent people should not be taken off support services merely for the purported sake of regional equity.

Other home and community care services and voluntary groups who are having to deal with the results of those cuts report tragic cases to deal with. In one case a woman who was ill on a Thursday had a doctor visit but, because she was not mobile, sat with no medicine and no help over the weekend until the following Tuesday. Like many people who have come to the north coast she had no local family and no neighbourhood support.

There are other questions about the delivery of services which I want to address at another time. However, I wanted to highlight before this House the dreadful plight people are in as a result of Home Care New South Wales axing very needy and many now desperate people from its programs. We should all question the claims coming from the New South Wales Government that regional equity is the reason for visiting such hardship upon frail older people and younger people with disabilities. Talk of regions may be important in the long term but the hard-hearted, well-paid bureaucrats and politicians in New South Wales must immediately start to recognise that the focus of the delivery of home and community care must be the individual who relies on the service to live. Abandoning frail older people in the short term because of the statistics runs counter to any talk of equity.

I have asked the Minister to take this matter up again with his State colleagues to see whether he might be moved to exhibit some of the compassion which was a hallmark of previous State Labor Governments in New South Wales. I emphasise again that the cost-cutting and the shifting of costs that is occurring in home and community care is not occurring in other States of Australia. It is simply occurring in New South Wales and I ask the Minister to address those facts.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cowan Mr D.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —During the grievance debate I wish to speak principally on the primary industries in Australia and the way that the economic situation is affecting them. Of course, 60 per cent of New South Wales is now affected by drought.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to speak particularly about the Government's cattle transaction levy. I think that honourable members generally will be aware of the fact that some months ago we passed legislation that places a levy on practically all the cattle that are sent to meatworks, which go through the saleyards or change hands by way of private deals.

I am grossly concerned about the cattle transaction levy because, due to the drought, in recent weeks and particularly in recent days a number of auctioneers-and certainly a lot of stock owners-within my electorate and elsewhere have been in touch with me because they are most concerned about it. As an illustration, the north coast area-from Newcastle to the Queensland border-is a breeding area for young stock. We breed the cattle there and much of it is purchased by people from the western parts of the State, Victoria and Queensland.

It has been particularly brought to my notice by M. Webb Bros Pty Ltd, the auctioneers of Gloucester, that at its sale the other day it sold young calves, which we term bobby calves, for only $8 a head. This is a scandalous price to give a farmer for stock. But there is a transaction levy on that particular beast. I have the dockets here. Whilst that is the price, the levy is $1.09 per calf. To that must be added the cost of freight, yard dues and, of course, the debt that is owed to the auctioneer by the owner of the stock concerned. This situation is occurring not only in the Gloucester area, but also at Taree, other yards throughout the State and, I assume, throughout Australia.

Whilst it was a levy that was actually sought-and there may be some exceptions so far as dairy stock is concerned-the actual principle of the levy and the change were sought by the Cattle Council of Australia. I am not blaming the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Kerin) for this; I am saying that the Government virtually responded to the request of the Cattle Council of Australia. I have advised the constituents who have actually spoken to me that they should contact the organisation and seek from the Government some change to the levy.

Stock in the yards at the moment is selling at about half or one-third of the price it was six months ago. The farm is, therefore, receiving a very small return and, of course, the auctioneers concerned have the responsibility of actually collecting the dues.

This particularly applies so far as the coastal area in New South Wales is concerned. This area at the present time is severely affected by drought. I speak of the graziers that are running the stock and also the dairy farmers concerned. I appeal on their behalf to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy to review the levy. It has been suggested to me by Mr Denver Webb of M. Webb Bros of Gloucester that the transaction levies should be abandoned in the drought affected areas of the State. I know that that is going a long way, but it is a sensible suggestion when one appreciates the disadvantages to the owners of the stock concerned. Mr Webb says that, alternatively, no transaction levy should be charged on an animal that realises less than $10 a head. He goes on to make some other very sound suggestions about this levy.

I want to bring to the notice of honourable members the concern of those breeders involved, and the auctioneers who give an excellent service to the stock owners, so that they know that that problem is there and to ask them to request the Government, particularly the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, to look seriously at the problem as it affects those breeders.

There is no need for me to emphasise the very great problems that are facing those engaged in primary industry today because it is done daily here in this House by members from both sides. This comes, of course, at a time when our economy is down, when costs generally are rising and when, unfortunately, our farmers are looking at declining markets throughout the world for wool, wheat, dairy products, sugar and beef. These are the major industries that bring income into Australia.

Let me emphasise here that the farming community of this country has received very little government support from either the Commonwealth Government or the State governments concerned. In other words, our farmers are dealing on a free market throughout the world against competitors who are dumping their products, who are being subsidised by their governments. I particularly refer to the European Community countries and the United States of America.

Here we have a group of people who are stabilising and supporting Australia's economy and have done for decades. These people are not asking for a lot of support but, when the time arrives, they expect a government, either Commonwealth or State, to support them for the purpose of saving the national herd, for the purpose of keeping the quality of our soil and for the purpose of enabling them and their families to stay on the land.

Sixty per cent of New South Wales is in drought at the present time. We are approaching the winter months and throughout the entire State the nights are cold now. The ground is no longer warm. So, even if we get the rains now, it will not save the situation so far as our pastures and our crops are concerned. Let me say that our farmers meet all of the export inspection charges for meat. This is something that has been brought about by this Government.

Our superphosphate bounties have completely gone. There is no support today for superphosphate. I think that the diesel fuel rebate is the only support that a farmer receives. If we examine the taxation legislation we will find that a lot of the concessions that were available yesterday have been taken away today. There has been a reduction in wool promotion.

We can go further and look at the issue of roads that I raise constantly here in this chamber. More money should be going to our smaller gravel country roads that cart the produce of the farms to market.

TALK.START.PARA: —You have done a good job with that.

—I do my best with this, in the same way as my friend the honourable member for Franklin does for Tasmania. He is a little battler for Tasmania; I am a little battler for the people that I represent up in the Lyne electorate-particularly the farmers at the moment and those who are needing help.

SPEECH.PARA: If we look at Austudy, the assets test, and the charges and impositions on business today-the farmers are businessmen, but I am referring to the smaller businessmen around our town-we will see that they are enormous. We have even placed impositions on local government for people who want to build a home or rezone a bit of land, for example. These are all problems today. The poor pensioner folk who have worked the farm for a lifetime and want to retire in town cannot do so. The honourable member for Richmond (Mr Newell) would know this. He would know dozens of people in that position, as would the honourable member for Eden-Monaro (Mr Snow). If they were genuine, they would support me when I say that these people are being penalised. I want to put in a word for the farmers and the people that I represent.
This nation will not bounce back and its economy will not be restored until such time as people recognise that, if the primary industries are down, they must receive support from government.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Snow Mr J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —This morning the Australian Capital Territory Minister for Health criticised Medicare. I want to point out that the main health problems in the ACT and the region around it relate to the ACT Government's administration of health care, not to Medicare. Some weeks ago, a financier told a parliamentary committee that Australia ought to offer to run health insurance in other countries. That is how good Medicare is. The ACT Minister, Mr Humphries, claimed that too many people who could afford to take out private health insurance are not doing so. Firstly, it is clear from a recent survey that only a small proportion of such people are not taking out private insurance. Further, such people are required to be covered by Medicare now, charged on the basis of income. Before Medicare, many people, rich and poor, were paying no health insurance at all. Now, at least those who are well off are paying.

SPEECH.PARA: It has been brought to my attention by the Royal Canberra Hospital Committee that the ACT Government is replacing public hospital services with private services. The ACT Government is closing public hospital beds, thus forcing people to pay for private hospital care. The public hospital service in the ACT has deteriorated. The waiting time for elective surgery is 12 months and the list had risen to 1,558 by December 1990. In 1962 there were 650 beds for a population of 60,000 people. In April 1991 there were 820 public beds for a population of 288,000. That does not include the people in surrounding areas who use those hospitals.

It is difficult to see how the people of the surrounding regions will be able to continue to use ACT hospital beds in the way that they have been because of the shortage of public hospital beds in the ACT. The Committee convenor, Regina Slattinger, tells me that people are actually dying from the lack of public hospital beds. How many more will die if the closure of Royal Canberra Hospital North goes ahead? All human beings are entitled to health care when they are sick, regardless of whether or not they pay for it.

People are more important than buildings. Doctors, nurses and other health providers who dared to come out into the open about this to voice their concerns on the fast-tracking of the redevelopment of the Woden Valley Hospital and the closure of the Royal Canberra Hospital were labelled troublemakers and were black-listed. The fast-tracking is purely for political reasons. The ACT Government wants to remove the public hospital and health service from the public agenda before the next election. It will not succeed.

In fact, 48,000 citizens of the ACT and the surrounding areas have signed a petition to stop the closure of Royal Canberra Hospital on Acton Peninsula. They were refused a hearing in the ACT Legislative Assembly. The petition was presented by Rosemary Follett, the Australian Labor Party Leader of the Opposition, on three separate occasions and the ACT Government ignored the wishes of the people by disallowing any discussion. The people are demanding their democratic right to be heard.

I plan to speak on this also in the adjournment debate as I know that this debate will end shortly. But I want to say now that the Minister for Community Services and Health (Mr Howe) recommended in December 1990 that there should be more cooperation between the three tiers of government. This is imperative if we are to receive social justice for all people-not only in Canberra, but also in the region.
