SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fitzgibbon Mr E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Ivor Peebles was Shire President of Merriwa Council until his death some two years ago. He made a magnificent contribution to local government and served on many State committees and local government authorities. He served a term as President of Shortland County Council, which spreads throughout the Hunter Valley and beyond. The Peebles family, as a result of the efforts of Ivor and his wife, Deirdre, became one of the best-known families in New South Wales. The family epitomised all that was good about a family. The couple had fine children-boys and girls.

SPEECH.PARA: One of the finest of the children was Angus Peebles. He was a broadcaster with radio station 2NM in the Hunter Valley. I am not quite certain of the exact age of Angus at his death, but I believe that he was about 28. A couple of days ago, Angus, without any prior warning of ill-health, dropped dead. His loss will be felt throughout the Hunter Valley. I extend to the Peebles family, particularly to Mrs Deirdre Peebles, my deepest sympathy. I know that many people who serve in local government in New South Wales would want to be associated with the condolences that I extend to the Peebles family.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Broadbent Mr R.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —All honourable members in this House know that there was a merger between the Commonwealth Bank and the State Bank of Victoria. We also know that the Premier of Victoria, Joan Kirner, said that there would be no involuntary redundancies. We also know, as a point of fact, that this nation's Treasurer (Mr Keating) said that he would keep a close watch on the efficiencies of the Commonwealth Bank by appointing a secretary to a department to its board.

SPEECH.PARA: Yesterday, officers of the Commonwealth Bank walked into the State Bank of Victoria Services in Clayton, Victoria, and told the plumbers, carpenters, painters, electricians and other allied trades that their time had come and that they were to be offered redundancies. The Bank officers said, `We would like to offer you redundancies. We would like to contract out our work'.

The Liberal Party of Australia, of course, is supportive of contract labour. But these people were promised that their jobs would not be put in jeopardy. The people of the State Bank of Victoria Services were promised by the Premier of Victoria and the Treasurer of this nation that there would be no involuntary redundancies; their jobs were promised to them. To a man-or woman-they want to keep their jobs. Is this the first part of the program for the disembowelling of the State Bank of Victoria? These people, Mr Speaker, were your voters until a short time ago.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Snow Mr J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —On Tuesday, 7 May a man sustained a gunshot wound in an accident in Braidwood. He was taken to Royal Canberra (North) hospital where he was stabilised. But because a specialist did not want to treat him there, he was sent to Royal Canberra (South) hospital, at Woden. Not so long ago, he would have been kept in Royal Canberra (North) hospital and operated on there. This is the sort of thing that is happening with the downgrading of Royal Canberra (North) hospital and the shunting of people from one area to another.

SPEECH.PARA: A large number of people are suffering in Canberra and the region because of the failure of both the New South Wales and the Australian Capital Territory governments to come to a firm agreement about the treatment of regional people while the Australian Capital Territory Government is unjustifiably downgrading the hospital services in the ACT.

The community has been told that there is no money to keep Royal Canberra (North) hospital open. But last year millions of dollars were spent on the fast-tracking redevelopment of the Royal Canberra (South) hospital. In addition to that, a $7m to $10m car park is, I believe, proposed for Royal Canberra (South). That money could well have been spent on a cardiothoracic unit which has been long overdue in the public sector.

We are told that more beds cannot be opened at Royal Canberra (North) because of the shortage of nurses; yet nurses who finished their training last year at the University of Canberra and applied for work were rejected.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Scott Mr B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise today to highlight the difference between the policy of the Opposition and that of the Government in the wool tax debate. I will point out how the different percentages of tax will affect woolgrowers in the coming 12 months.

SPEECH.PARA: The impact on families and woolgrowers of the Government's proposed tax of 15 per cent will be quite significant, in spite of the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Kerin) telling us that it will be insignificant. If we look at tax on $4.50 a kilogram clean, the average price for the next 12 months, we will see that a 15 per cent tax would be $2.02 per sheep and that a 12 per cent tax would be $1.62 per sheep; the difference is 40c. For the average woolgrower running 5,000 sheep, that 40c would equate to $2,000; if he were running 10,000 sheep, that 40c would equate to $4,000.

If we look at the Opposition's policy, we will see that with a tax rate as low as 8 per cent, the saving could well be $4,700 for 5,000 sheep and $9,400 for 10,000 sheep. That money is significant in the very hard times that woolgrowers will be confronted with in the next 12 to 18 months. That money could very well put food on the table; it would certainly keep a child at school. I urge the Minister to look at the 15 per cent tax and not be so adamant that it is the percentage that will be applied.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Newell Mr N.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 28 April I had the pleasure of attending a function in an area of New South Wales, in the electorate of Page, called New Italy. New Italy derives its name from the fact that a group of Italians settled there 110 years ago. For the 110th anniversary of those people arriving in Australia, the people of New Italy had a reunion, a get-together.

SPEECH.PARA: I will tell the House a little about New Italy. It is built on the site of the first settlement in an area just south of Woodburn, on the Pacific Highway. In New Italy, the Italian community-many of whom live in my electorate of Richmond, around the Lismore area-have established a number of things which I think the whole Italian community, indeed, the whole of Australia, should be proud.

The people of New Italy have established a restaurant; they have established two fine buildings to house exhibits. In one building they have exhibits of their pioneering implements and the materials that they worked with. In the other building, which they have just established, they house exhibits which they obtained from the Australian and Italian governments. A lot of the exhibits were exhibited at Expo in Brisbane in 1988.
I thank the Minister for the Arts, Tourism and Territories (Mr Simmons) for providing a grant of $10,000 towards that national museum. The grant was very graciously accepted by the Italian community.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Nugent Mr P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I draw the attention of the House to the plight of my constituents in Aston, which is a Melbourne outer-eastern suburb. It consists predominantly of young people, lots of families and lots of small business. I learned this morning from the Department of Social Security statistical centre in Melbourne that in the Boronia area of my electorate there are now 2,493 people unemployed compared with 647 a year ago, a rise of 285 per cent. In the Knox area there are 3,174 unemployed compared with the figure a year ago of 882, a rise of 260 per cent. In the Nunawading area there are 3,687 unemployed compared with 1,369 a year ago, a rise of 170 per cent. In my electorate, that means that in 12 months there has been an average increase in unemployment of 257 per cent. This is totally outrageous.

SPEECH.PARA: I have met many of these people, unlike the Treasurer (Mr Keating). We have, of course, an abnormally high proportion of young people and there is great distress to families who have to support mortgages, children and all the rest of it. It is the result of the deliberately induced recession from the Treasurer. I call upon him and Brian Burke's mate, the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), to resign and to acknowledge their responsibility for this disgraceful situation in which my constituents find themselves, as does the rest of Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fitzgibbon Mr E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Sunday is Mother's Day and although Mother's Day has become a bit too commercialised, I am sure, nevertheless, that all honourable members here would like to join me in wishing all the mums throughout the length and breadth of Australia a very happy day on Sunday. If children come home from school one day and tell their mothers that they have the opportunity to go on an excursion to Parliament House, I urge mothers to get right behind their children because it is such a pleasure for the members of this House to welcome schools which visit Canberra and, in particular, visit Parliament House. We enjoy playing host to them. I had 47 children from Maitland Grossman High School here yesterday. They were a marvellous bunch of youngsters.

SPEECH.PARA: While I am on my feet, I pay tribute to the staff who operate the educational unit within Parliament House. Any children who visit that centre have the time of their lives. It is one of the best things that any Australian Parliament has ever provided for the people of Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ronaldson Mr M.J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —On Tuesday I received a letter from the City of Ballarat. It reads:

SPEECH.PARA: Dear Mr Ronaldson

The Municipal Association of Victoria have advised the Council of the City of Ballarat that the Treasurer and the Australian Taxation Office are considering the imposition of PAYE tax instalments on allowances paid to Councillors, and to imposing Fringe Benefits Tax upon alleged benefits (such as meals provided at Council meetings,) and the attendance of Councillors at Civic functions. Council has directed that I write to you to convey their extreme concern and utmost disappointment that such a proposal should even be in the consideration stage.

Council hopes that both the Treasurer and the Australian Taxation Office will see that there is no merit whatever in imposing PAYE tax on Councillors or Fringe Benefits Tax on Civic functions, and reject the idea totally.

The realities are, Mr Speaker, as you well know, that a lot of underpaid councillors are required to attend a lot of council meetings and civic functions. I think the City of Ballarat has a very strong case in relation to that. I do not believe there should be open-ended non-pay-as-you-earn allowances, but I think an upper limit should be set, up to which PAYE deductions should not be made.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Courtice Mr B.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —Recently the honourable member for Maranoa (Mr Bruce Scott) spoke about the concern of his rural constituents. That is about the only thing he was consistent in. Three years ago when his area and my area suffered from severe drought, we saw $30m ripped off the system under the former National Party State Government. That $30m would have gone a long way to alleviate the problems that the woolgrowers and wheatgrowers in Queensland now have.

SPEECH.PARA: I find it rather ironic that the honourable member for Maranoa would now bother to pretend to show some concern about his constituents when he defended, along with all his mates in this House, the rorting of national disaster relief arrangements and the drought slush fund that went into the pockets of a handful of greedy graziers at the expense of the battling farmers throughout Queensland.

In the downturn that we now have, that $30m would have gone a long way to helping their income and providing some substantial support which they badly need. I think it is grossly hypocritical of a National Party member to stand up and pretend that he or the National Party has any concern for the farmers, particularly given that the National Party wants to bring in a goods and services tax-a 15 per cent tax across the board-on the income of farmers and the very products that they sell.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to make an apology for what I said in my previous speech. That is not the Bob Brown from Tasmania; that is the Bob Brown from the Federal Parliament. I apologise for it.

—I think that is one of the few times we have had an apology from the honourable member for Franklin. Order! It being 2 p.m., in accordance with sessional order 106a, the time for members' statements has concluded.
—My question is addressed to the arriving Prime Minister. Now that Brian Burke has resigned--
—I am sorry, Mr Speaker, I would not want to mislead the House-departing Prime Minister.
—Order! The Leader of the Opposition will get to his question.

—Now that Brian Burke has resigned and solved one of the Prime Minister's problems, and in view of today's unemployment figures, will he sack his disloyal deputy, the Treasurer, for his gross economic incompetence?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Point one: my Treasurer and Deputy Prime Minister is not disloyal.

ANSWER.PARA: Opposition members interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! There is far too much noise. Members of the Opposition!

—As I have said before to this House, I enjoy the full support and cooperation of the Treasurer and Deputy Prime Minister. As to sacking him, let me say, as I have said before in this place, that perhaps there would have been more basis for some such question if, over the years of his stewardship of this country's economic management, those opposite had been prepared to acknowledge what many people, not only in this country but around the world, have acknowledged-the quality that he brings to the job of Treasurer. He has had the responsibility for overseeing the most dramatic transformation of the economic structures and form of regulations of this country to make it a more competitive economy than ever before in the history of this country. The Leader of the Opposition talks about employment. The fact is that at this point, with the increase in unemployment referred to today, which has entirely arisen, I might say, because of the increase in the participation rate--

ANSWER.PARA: Opposition members-Ha, ha!

TALK.START.PARA: —They can laugh, but the facts are simple: there has been an increase in employment of the order of 10,000; the increase in unemployment arises from the increase in the participation rate. We still have at this point an increase in employment in this Government's period in office of 1,430,000-odd. What those opposite do not like-and why do they not give the Treasurer the credit he deserves for this?-is the fact that that rate of employment increase of 1.4 million represents a rate of employment growth something like four times faster than in their period in office. Those are the facts. They had seven years in office. They can be judged in this question of employment and unemployment on that performance. We have been in government for eight years and have achieved a rate of employment growth some four times faster than theirs. The fact is, as both the Treasurer and I have said, that unfortunately, given the fact that--

ANSWER.PARA: Opposition members interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Members of the Opposition will cease interjecting.

—The fact is, as the Treasurer and I have said, that unfortunately, given the fact that some two years ago we were faced with a rate of expenditure growth twice as fast as the rate of production, we had to slow down the level of activity in this country.

ANSWER.PARA: Both the Treasurer and I, and the Government as a whole, deeply regret the fact that, in the process of slowing down this level of activity, there are many people in this country who are suffering.

TALK.START.PARA: —You did it deliberately.
—I am told by someone opposite that we did it deliberately. Why does the honourable member opposite not remember, when he says we did it deliberately--

ANSWER.PARA: Opposition members interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Members of the Opposition will cease interjecting.
—You are walking away from Paul again.
—Order! The member for Mayo will cease interjecting.

—I am more than happy to answer the serious question that has been asked of me, but I suggest that, if honourable members opposite regard the question seriously, they at least do me the courtesy of listening to the answer. Someone from the Opposition interjects and says we did it deliberately. Why does the Opposition not recall the following facts? It criticised us because it said that we did not have interest rates high enough and, when we started to take them off, it criticised us for the timing of our taking them off. According to the Opposition, we should have left interest rates in this country higher for a longer period than we have done. If we had followed the Opposition's advice in those circumstances, the level of unemployment in this country would be higher than it is now.

ANSWER.PARA: The answer to the Opposition's question is: no, I will not be taking any move against my Treasurer, because, firstly, he is not disloyal and, secondly, when the record books of this country are written, I would suggest that his standing as a Treasurer will be above any that the tory parties have been able to produce in all the years they have been in office.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Treasurer and Deputy Prime Minister.
—Has Laurie Brereton been around to see you yet?
—Order! The member for Gippsland will cease interjecting. The member for Bennelong will cease interjecting.
—Can the Treasurer advise the House of the implications of the labour force figures released today?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Prime Minister has already taken up in substance some of the material facts of today's release of labour force figures. They reveal that the unemployment rate has risen from 9.2 per cent to 9.9 per cent, which is, of course, much too high and is a rate which is unacceptable to the Government and is a cause of great concern to the Government. I said in my speech to the Economic Planning Advisory Council last month:

ANSWER.PARA: . . . increased unemployment is a great cost to the economy and an ordeal for the families of those who lose their jobs.
However, there is an encouraging sign in today's figures.
Opposition members-Where?

TALK.START.PARA: —Where? The answer is that employment rose by 10,000, whereas in March employment fell by 80,000. If the 10,000 rise in employment is indicative, it means that it is possible that the bottom of the fall in employment could have been reached. That is coupled with the very amazing fact that in a recession we have actually got the participation rate rising, which must be a phenomenon unique to this month and to this series in Australia. I cannot think of any other country in the world where the participation rate has risen during a recession. The participation rate did not just rise; it rose by 0.5 per cent, which by any measure is phenomenal in one month, and particularly in a recession.

ANSWER.PARA: As the Prime Minister indicated, it means that the rise in the unemployment rate has come from the rise in the participation rate or, to put it another way, if we had the same participation rate today as we had a month ago, unemployment would be the same. I know that a few of the Opposition's slower characters would be flat out spelling `participation', let alone knowing what it is.

TALK.START.PARA: —So they're great numbers, are they, Paul?
—No, they are not.
—Why don't you have the decency to admit it?
—The Deputy Leader of the Opposition will cease interjecting.

—Why does the honourable member opposite not have the decency to admit that a 10,000 growth in jobs is important, instead of being a miserable, snide tearer-down of the Australian economy, as he persists in being every month-a thoughtless destroyer of everything that is decent about the place.

ANSWER.PARA: The Prime Minister is quite correct in saying that the Opposition has cavilled at every reduction in interest rates that the Government has introduced from January 1990. Again I refer to the statements of the Leader of the Opposition that we were pushing the pace of interest rate reductions, that it was political.

TALK.START.PARA: —It was the Treasurer who was political.
—Did the honourable member think he had been misrepresented? He thought he was misrepresented, did he?
—Order! The Leader of the Opposition will cease interjecting across the table.
—He thought he was not being political in saying in January 1990 that a reduction in interest rates was pushing the pace? That was not political?

ANSWER.PARA: Dr Hewson interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The Leader of the Opposition!
—That was absolutely shamefaced, unashamed politics, and the truth is--

ANSWER.PARA: Opposition members interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government reduced interest rates first 16 months ago. The fact is we have seen the economy go into a deeper recession, and it has had these employment effects. I can only say that, whilst this point about the participation rate is true, it still provides little comfort because what really matters is the number of people actually seeking jobs who have not yet found one, whether they are registered as unemployed or not. The fact is these are disappointing figures, but if the 10,000 employment growth is indicative, we may have seen the bottom of the troughing out of the loss of employment.

—My question is again addressed to the Prime Minister. Did the Government bring any pressure to bear on Mr Burke to secure his immediate resignation? Did the Government receive any new advice from the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade regarding the appropriateness of Mr Burke's continuing as ambassador? Does the Government have fresh evidence amounting to proof of impropriety against Mr Burke? Will the Government reconsider the $28,000 termination payout to Mr Burke?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer is no. No pressure was brought to bear upon Mr Burke.

ANSWER.PARA: Opposition members interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member for Gippsland will cease interjecting.

—I repeat: no pressure was brought to bear upon Mr Burke. Canvassing the possibility of his resignation came, as I understand it, from Mr Burke. The second part of the question was: was there any new advice from the Department? Not that I understand. As to the question of new proof about any other actions, again the answer is no. On the final point about the payment, what the Leader of the Opposition seems not to understand is that the case is that if the Government had done what the Opposition had pressed us to do from the beginning-starting when there was mere innuendo, allegations-and then--

ANSWER.PARA: Opposition members interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Honourable members opposite wanted his dismissal at the very beginning when there was innuendo, allegations, and they have kept at it. All I am saying is that, if the Government had dismissed Mr Burke, he would still have had to receive, under the terms of his contract, a termination payment. He is not getting something as a result of his resignation that he would not have got if he had been dismissed.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Higher Education and Employment Services. Is the Minister aware of claims that the Government's labour market programs for the unemployed are of little value in an economic downturn? Could the Minister inform the House of the actual situation?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baldwin The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —There has been a range of concerns raised from a variety of quarters about the usefulness or applicability of labour market programs in the sort of labour market circumstances that we now have. In particular, some spokespersons for the Opposition, including the honourable member for Bennelong, have questioned the value of such programs. I am referring to a recent radio interview that the honourable member for Bennelong gave in the course of which he said, among other things:

ANSWER.PARA: . . . once you get into the more esoteric job subsidy programmes and Jobstart is a good example, they are of highly questionable value, and that's not just a partisan political view which was the result of a study done by a couple of senior academics at the ANU at the end of last year.

In fact, that study was done by Chapman and Stretton at the Australian National University, and it said very different things from what is implied by the statement by the honourable member for Bennelong.

It did not question the value of labour market programs in a recession; what it did say was that there needed to be a reorientation and a refocusing of those labour market programs. In point of fact, it is ironical that the very program that the honourable member for Bennelong referred to, that is, Jobstart, which is a wage subsidy program--

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise a point of order. The Social Security (Job Search and Newstart) Amendment Bill is currently being debated before the House, and the Minister is canvassing issues that are being covered by that debate.
—There is no point of order.
—As I was saying, the very programs which the Opposition spokesperson was so critical of are the very ones--

—I raise a further point of order. Under standing order 144 questions cannot refer to debates in the current session, or proceedings in committee not reported to the House. Today's blue sheet has this very matter on it. I draw to your attention the reason this is in our Standing Orders. There is the opportunity for the Minister to raise all these matters in the debate before the House. He should not be wasting Question Time doing it now and, therefore, he should be ruled out of order.

—The honourable member for O'Connor will resume his seat. The Minister is not canvassing the legislation before the House. The Minister is answering the question that he was asked by the honourable member.

—I might say that these programs-and we are in a position to make judgments based on the post-program monitoring activities carried out by the Department of Employment Education and Training-even in a recession are highly effective. The Jobstart program in particular has continued to have a high rate of success, with some 60 per cent of participants, three months after having completed the program, being either in employment or further education and training. So it is an utterly spurious claim.

ANSWER.PARA: I might also say that there have been an awful lot of distortions in the media recently about the Government's approach to this broad problem of how we help the long term unemployed under current labour market circumstances. There has been reference in a number of media articles to the Government's active employment strategy (AES). There have been a host of distortions about that-and I am not going to address the terms of the legislation, but I am going to talk in general terms about the Government's approach.

The fact is that we have heard suggestions that the Government is about to do something from 1 July with the introduction of the AES, and is about to implement a terribly draconian program in which all the long term unemployed are going to be cut off and junior officers of the Commonwealth Employment Service (CES) are going to be involved in making decisions to terminate benefits. There has been a series of articles in recent times-most prominently in the Melbourne Age, I might say-in which it has been suggested that junior officers of the Commonwealth Employment Service are going to be peremptorily cutting people off the dole, there will be no appeal rights and that will be final.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have a point of order. Mr Speaker, I take the same point of order as the honourable member for O'Connor. The Minister is now canvassing matters that are before the House and I ask that the question be ruled out of order.

—The Minister was asked a question about a Government program. The Minister is in charge of that program. The Minister advised the House that he was not going to canvass the matters that are in the legislation before the House, which is an amendment Bill to the Social Security Act. The Minister cannot canvass that matter, but he can answer a question in relation to a matter which he is currently administering as part of his portfolio.

—Questions have been raised about the adequacy of the number of labour market program places. I point out to the House that, as a result of Government decisions in the 12 March statement and elsewhere, the total number of labour market program places is due to increase from 206,000 in the current financial year to 245,000 in the following financial year with, in fact, an additional 15,000 on top of that if Aboriginal places are included. It is a very substantial increase which, on current projections, should exceed the rate of growth of the long term unemployed. As at March 1990 there were 180,000 long term unemployed, and we are planning to implement 245,000 labour market places in 1991-92, so it is a very substantial response to that problem. As I argued, the programs are demonstrably effective.

ANSWER.PARA: I come back to the question of appeal rights-and here I am not referring to the legislation, I am referring to CES procedures. The fact is that the negotiations concerning these so-called activity agreements, which the Government is seeking to implement, will not be finalised by junior CES officers. They will be arrived at, in the first instance, by people at a level of ASO4, and the actual approval and negotiation of activity agreements will be at the ASO5 level.
If there is cause for appeal, that will be carried out at the ASO6 level, which is a reasonably middle to high level--
Opposition members interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not talking about legislation. I am not addressing the terms of the legislation--

ANSWER.PARA: Mr Broadbent interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member for Corinella.

—Mr Speaker, I rise on a point of order. Point after point that the Minister has made is to the exact detail of the legislation. I do not know whether you have been following the debate or had a chance to scan the legislation. But this is related to the legislation before the House.
—I have told the Minister earlier that he cannot canvass the matters that are related to--

—Order! The Minister should not canvass the matters that are related to the legislation that is to come before the House this afternoon. If the Minister has nothing else to add but that, he should cease his answer. If the Minister is answering other parts of the question, he may continue.

—Just to wind up, I was not canvassing the legislation. We are implementing a range of demonstrably effective programs which will continue to assist the unemployed even in circumstances of a recession. The claim that we are implementing a draconian, punitive system from 1 July is false. There has been a host of media reports which totally distort the situation. I wanted to put that on the record.

—My question is directed to the Prime Minister. Can the Prime Minister explain why ex-Ambassador Brian Burke could recognise that he had to resign now but the Prime Minister could not? Indeed, why is it that, even in his moment of disgrace, Brian Burke displayed a greater sense of what is right than the Prime Minister has?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the question is quite obvious. I had an obligation and directly the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade had an obligation and responsibility to discharge our duties in terms of both the advice given to us and our judgment in respect of that advice. That is what we have done. Mr Burke does not have the obligations of a Prime Minister and the Minister to take advice from a department as to whether a certain course of action is required or not--
—Who is running it? Are the bureaucrats running it?
—Order! The honourable member for Kooyong.

—Mr Burke, in his consideration of the circumstances that have developed as a result of the issues surrounding him, has come to a conclusion that the best thing for him to do is to resign. I am not, and no-one on this side of the House is, going to question his motives or what led him to that position. It is perfectly clear that in this matter the obligations and the responsibility of the Minister for Foreign Affairs and myself as Prime Minister are in a category of our own. We have to do our duty. We did it and made the best judgment--
—You did not do anything.
—Order! The honourable member for Gippsland.
—We made the best judgment in terms of discharging the obligations upon us. That did not mean that Mr Burke may not come to some other conclusion. He has.

ANSWER.PARA: Mr Tuckey interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member for O'Connor.
—Speaking on behalf of the Government, I respect the decision he has made.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Finance. Can he advise the House why the Government has now withdrawn the Moomba-Sydney pipeline from its program of asset sales? What are the budgetary implications of this withdrawal? What prospects are there that the pipeline could be sold in the future?

—Mr Speaker, I rise on a point of order. Standing order 146 says that a question fully answered cannot be renewed. The Minister bored the House to death on this issue on a previous occasion. We have heard it all; it is not necessary to repeat it.
—Order! The honourable member for O'Connor will resume his seat. If the honourable member for O'Connor continues to use points of order to make attacks on members, I will deal with him.

—I rise on a further point of order, Mr Speaker. I ask you: is it improper for a member to get up and quote a section of the Standing Orders-standing order 146-which says that a question fully answered cannot be renewed? Should he then be threatened for trying to get a bit of work done in this place?
—Order! The honourable member for O'Connor will resume his seat.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Willis The Hon R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I can understand the Opposition's sensitivity on this issue.
—We are not sensitive.
—I warn the honourable member for O'Connor.

—It is the case that the Government has withdrawn the pipeline from its assets sale program. That is the consequence of the refusal of the Opposition and the Australian Democrats to allow the passage of legislation which was designed to put the pipeline's current non-commercial haulage arrangements onto a reasonable commercial basis. Without that change, the pipeline is a totally unattractive investment.

ANSWER.PARA: It is the fact that the current contract specifies that up to the year 2006 it shall operate on a cost recovery basis only for about 95 per cent of its business. In other words, there will be no profit and no return on investment up to the year 2006. From the year 2006 to the year 2016, the contract allows only a very limited profit. For the next quarter of a century the gas haulage rates are on a totally uncommercial basis.

The Government's view was that, if the pipeline was to be sold, it should be sold for something like its real value. That involves putting its operations on a reasonably commercial basis. From the time we came to office we attempted to negotiate with the Australian Gas Light Co. (AGL), the other party to the contract, to put the pipeline on a commercial basis and to change the haulage arrangements, to make them more satisfactory. That proved to be impossible, so we resorted to the legislation, which has now been rejected by the Opposition. To proceed with the sale would be to sell it for a fraction of its real worth-that is, to dispose of an asset and deprive the nation of hundreds of millions of dollars in the process.

As has been mentioned before in the House, it is the case that the implications for the Budget are very substantial, and they bear repetition. The actions of the Opposition effectively sabotaged the Budget for about three-quarters of a billion dollars-no minor act of sabotage, I might say. We had a figure of about $700m written into the Budget, but we expected that we would have got more than that. The action taken after the Budget, up to the time of the Opposition's act of sabotage, certainly gave us reason to believe we would have got more than $700m.

As regards the prospects of future sales, so far as the Government is concerned there are no such prospects, unless the current uncommercial haulage arrangements can be changed. As for the Opposition, it seems to have recently reaffirmed, through the shadow Minister for privatisation, that it is still its intention to privatise it, despite the action it has taken to stop it being put on a commercial basis. Apparently, what the Opposition really means is that it would virtually give it away. On the basis on which it currently exists, who would pay any substantial amount of money for it? Something with a replacement value of over $1 billion but operating on a totally uncommercial basis would not attract much of a price. Effectively, the Opposition would give away a major asset of the people for a very small amount of money.

The Opposition has said in the past that it would attempt to negotiate with AGL to get a revision of the contract. We have been doing that for the last seven years. That proved to be totally unrewarding. It would be no more likely than us to succeed for the same reason that we did not succeed through negotiations-that is, AGL, the other party to the contract, has absolutely every commercial reason to reject any change in the contract. There is no way in which it is going to act for the Opposition in the way that it refused to act for us, because it is totally against its commercial interests.

The Opposition is really saying that, by rejecting this proposal to put it on a commercial basis through legislation and then keep it in its privatisation lists, it is quite happy to pursue a course of privatisation for privatisation's sake. It is pursuing a political agenda, rather than an economic one. To give him some credit, the shadow Minister for privatisation said that. On the ABC a couple of months ago, 25 February, he was asked:
Would you say that assets can only be sold when the market is buoyant or that they should be sold to suit a political rather than economic agenda?
His answer, in part-I will not read it all-was:
I really think that we should be selling to suit a political agenda.
Later he elaborated on that and said:
. . . I'm saying that we're in politics and we have political objectives so we would be selling these primarily, not entirely, but primarily to suit the political objectives, yes.

Now we know where the Opposition stands. Quite clearly the Opposition stands in the position where it would privatise for privatisation's sake, in pursuit of which it would be quite prepared to hand over the assets of the people to its business mates for a fraction of their real value.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Prime Minister, who said that unemployment would never reach 10 per cent under his Government. Does the Prime Minister still stand by that assertion?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Obviously there is a possibility that the unemployment rate will reach 10 per cent.
—No child will live in poverty!
—The member for Gippsland!

—If one looks at the participation rate, one finds that it has now risen to 63.7 per cent. The Opposition when it was in government had an unemployment rate of well over 10 per cent, with the participation rate down at a level of just over 60 per cent. The Opposition did not have the participation rates which have developed under this Government, because people have seen the opportunity of getting into work as we have had an expanding economy, which has grown at a rate roughly twice that of the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development average, and at a significantly higher rate than the Opposition was able to achieve when it was in government. People have made themselves available to enter the work force.

ANSWER.PARA: With that increase in the participation rate, it has been that much more difficult and there has been that much more demand for jobs. Had the Opposition in its time in government had the participation rate this Government now has, its unemployment rate of 10.4 per cent would have been significantly higher. It is the responsibility of government, when it is confronted with circumstances which require a tough decision, to take that tough decision; that is what this Government did. I repeat what I said in answer to my previous question, Mr Hawke-Mr Speaker.
An Opposition member-Oh! You silly old bugger!

TALK.START.PARA: —Order!
—Mr Speaker, I heard something from across the way, which misled me.

ANSWER.PARA: Opposition members interjecting-
An Opposition member-You are a clone of a once great Prime Minister.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Members on my left will cease interjecting. The Deputy Leader of the Opposition asked the question; he should listen to the answer.

—The Government was confronted with the situation that under the expansionist policies it had pursued, which provided more than 1 1/2 million new jobs, it had reached a position where Australia's expenditure was growing at double the rate of its production. In those circumstances, with an existing tough, tight fiscal policy and a tight wages policy, the only thing available to the Government to bring that back into equilibrium was to tighten monetary policy. It gave the Government no pleasure to do that, but it had to do it. As I said in answer to a previous question, as the Government did that it was criticised for not going higher and, as it took the rates off, it was criticised for taking off rates too soon. The fact is that this Government had the courage to take the decision which was necessary. If that has produced these results, as both the Treasurer and I have said, we deeply regret the suffering that that is causing for some people in the Australian community.
—You did it. This is your policy.
—Order! The Deputy Leader of the Opposition!

—Had the Government not done this, the Australian people as a whole would have been the victims over a much longer period because the world would have imposed a solution upon this country which would have been much more draconian.
—No-one believes that.
—Order! I warn the Deputy Leader of the Opposition.

—We will come out of this recession in quite a different way from the recession which the Opposition inflicted upon the Australian community. As I said yesterday, because the Opposition's Treasurer had no control over wages, the Opposition had an 18 per cent blow-out in wages and a double digit inflation figure. In this situation the Government is providing for Australia a lowering profile of inflation and a situation where the Australian inflation rate will be comparable with that of our major trading partners. That is the major distinction between what is happening at this period and what the Opposition engineered.

ANSWER.PARA: The Opposition when in government not only engineered double digit unemployment but also simultaneously engineered double digit inflation. Against that, because of the Government's wages policy-where the Opposition had none-Australia will come out of this with a permanently lower rate of inflation. As the Treasurer and I have said, Australia will also be able to make a significant impact upon its current account deficit problem, where it now has a 24 per cent better situation in the first nine months of this year as compared with the previous year.

So I repeat: I, the Treasurer and the whole of the Government regret that this has been a necessary outcome of our having to slow down the level of activity in this country. At the same time, we are producing a restructured economy with lower inflation, which will mean that as we start to come out of this recession, as we will in the second half of this calendar year, we will emerge from it with a much stronger, more efficient and more competitive economy with a significantly lower rate of inflation.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct a question to the Prime Minister. Can he inform the House what recent action the Government has taken to assist the city of Newcastle in recovering from its earthquake of 1989?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for Newcastle for his question. He is certainly entitled to ask it because, with his brother, if I might say so, he has been a constant advocate to me and the rest of the Government to ensure that the Government does everything it possibly can to assist the people of Newcastle in the aftermath of that tragic event. If I can slip parliamentary propriety for a moment, both the Morrises deserve congratulations and the great appreciation of the citizenry of that area.

ANSWER.PARA: Having given those well earned congratulations, may I say that following the earthquake in December 1989 I met with Premier Greiner and we agreed to special relief measures under the natural disaster arrangements which would involve New South Wales and the Commonwealth sharing equally the task of rebuilding Newcastle. The special arrangement meant that the Commonwealth Government would pay half the costs of the New South Wales Government, and we would also pay all the costs of repairing our own buildings. Of every dollar that New South Wales spends on Newcastle, 50 per cent comes from the Commonwealth.

One major Commonwealth building requiring repair after the earthquake was the Customs House, a major heritage asset of the city of Newcastle. Following the detailed preliminary work by the Hunter Federal Task Force under the chairmanship of the honourable member for Shortland and with the support of the honourable member for Newcastle, an attractive proposal has been put forward which would see this building transformed to be part of a strategy to revive the east end of Newcastle, and that is a proposal involving the expenditure of over $3m.

On the broader question of earthquake relief, to date the Commonwealth has provided $250,000 to the Lord Mayor's fund; additional funds in the form of tax deductibility; assistance through the use of defence personnel; financial assistance in other areas outside the natural disaster relief arrangements; $10.8m in 1989-90, and it will provide an estimated $29m in 1990-91 and $13.5m in 1991-92. It is probable that expenditure will continue beyond 1991-92. Finally, we intend to carefully monitor the situation to ensure that Newcastle continues its recovery from this disaster, and I will be receiving further advice from the Hunter Federal Task Force on this matter. Again I thank the honourable member for his question and congratulate him and his brother on their continuing commitment to their constituencies.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Prime Minister. Given that unemployment has exceeded 10 per cent in all States except New South Wales, why will he not sack the Treasurer, the architect of this appalling economic mismanagement?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thought I answered this question first up today, Mr Speaker, but I will give it to them again. Not only will the Government not be sacking the Treasurer, but we will be continuing to work with him to ensure the continuing restructuring of this economy. I repeat that we are confident that in the second half of the calendar year 1991-this year-we will see the beginnings of economic recovery. The signs are mixed at the moment but, as you know, Mr Speaker, the employment figures are traditionally the last indicator to respond to recovery.

ANSWER.PARA: We believe that that recovery will continue strongly into 1992 and, importantly, that the Australian economy will be in very much better shape than it has ever been before. That will be because, in addition to having the appropriate macro- economic management to produce recovery, we will continue assiduously with our program of micro-economic reform to fill in the neglect which we inherited from previous conservative administrations. We will have had massive changes on the waterfront, in our maritime industry, in our telecommunication industry and in our road transport system, as well as the continuing reform of the tax system for which the Treasurer has been particularly responsible. I repeat that when the history books are written, this Treasurer will stand head and shoulders above any conservative treasurer that the Opposition has ever produced.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy. Can the Minister explain to the House the basis for contributions made to the rural sector by the Government?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kerin The Hon J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —As we all know, the primary industries have problems, particularly with wool and wheat, and the Government's response has been measured, consistent and principled. I say measured, because we required an analysis which would demonstrate the most efficient and effective means to provide support; consistent, because we have applied the same criteria to all industries; and principled because, for the first time in the history of this country, the Government applied the most rigorous principles of equity when we framed our responses. The response from the Commonwealth has been to contribute directly to the wool industry, to the wheat industry and to farmers generally through the rural adjustment scheme and through this very testing economic time.

ANSWER.PARA: Recovery is not aided, however, by comments recently made by the Federal Leader of the National Party, for example. The National Party is in a complete mess on this issue of wool. In a media release he described the 15 per cent wool tax as `pure thuggery' and the `death knell' of the industry. He tried to clarify his comments on the day. When he was asked on radio what he meant, he said:

I'm not reaching a view point that there is another agenda operating out of Canberra out of the bureaucracies of Canberra, indeed perhaps even Minister Kerin to somehow bring about a greed of agony and adjustment in the bush at far too faster rate and this wool plan yesterday is an example of that.

So we understand the thinking of the Leader of the National Party. If we interpret the gibberish after deciphering the agonising syntax, the Leader of the National Party is either suggesting that I am deliberately conspiring to bring about the ruin of the wool industry or that impartial, dedicated and competent professional public servants are conspiring to the same end. This is a popular slur in the best or worst National Party tradition.
Members of this House will recall that the Opposition announced its `wool plan' on 18 April and that at that time the shadow Minister for primary industries and energy said:

The Coalition's plan for the wool industry, if implemented by the Government, will ensure its long-term viability, allow a grower levy substantially below 12 per cent which covers all stockpile and debt costs as well as promotion and research and development, and will not need Government advances.
However the Coalition believes the Government should provide assistance only as a last resort and every effort must be made by the industry to ensure that there is no deficit.
That is a reasonably responsible position from the Opposition when it is so confused.

In a bizarre way, the crux of this issue is not really the crude popularism of the Leader of the National Party, nor is it the arithmetic optimism of the shadow spokesman; rather, it is the indifference or incompetence of the Leader of the Opposition. On 30 April, in his contribution to this debate-12 days after the announcement of the Opposition's wool plan; this is an interesting quote-he said, in answer to a question on radio:

Clearly the judgement has to be made about the levy of a fair sharing of burden, if you like, between the industry and the rest of Australia and you want to make sure that the industry accepts the problem that it has substantially created and puts in place policies to deal with it . . . Now, I don't know, standing here, whether it is 12 or 15 or where it is and we need to look at it. As far as the detail goes, we have got to wait to see the Government's legislation to see precisely what they have in mind.
Generous a critic as I am, I think we have to admit that the Leader of the National Party--

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, I rise on a point of order. The question asked the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy to detail the Government's contribution to agriculture. He spent no time on that. Presumably, the Government has made no contribution to agriculture. He should get back to the question.
—Order! It is in order for the Minister to contrast the Government's actions with another point of view. The Minister may answer the question. The Minister is in order.

—I have previously complimented and welcomed the constructive support of the Opposition on a range of issues-sugar, wheat and wool-when it has been constructive. But really, the National Party is in a real mess. The Leader of the National Party in the Senate, Senator Boswell, is pretty good. He has come up with a scheme. He says that the difference between 12 per cent and 15 per cent tax is $3,000, whereas Senator David Brownhill says that it is $502. We have carefully gone through all this. I think that Senator Boswell must be into big sheep. The only way I can arrive at his figure is if each sheep shears 15 kilograms.
—Order! The Minister might answer the question, which asked what the Government had done rather than what--
—This is a very serious question.
—Mr Speaker, I rise on a point of order. The terminology of the Minister was deliberate. It was offensive to one of my colleagues in the Senate and the Minister should be asked to withdraw it.
—Order! The Minister will continue to answer the question.

—The only way one can get a difference between 12 per cent and 15 per cent of the order that Senator Boswell poses in a press release-I presume he is being serious-is if the sheep shear about 15 kilograms of wool. That is about three times what the average sheep shears in Queensland. I do not know whether Senator Boswell has been experimenting with genetic engineering on the grazing lands of the northern State, I do not know whether there is a New Zealand connection and I do not know whether his shearers are more efficient. This is a serious issue. As I said, the Government's response has been measured, consistent and principled. What we see from the Leader of the National Party in response to our policies are these mad accusations of thuggery; we see some responsibility from the Deputy Leader of the National Party; we see absolute confusion and no policy position from the Leader of the Opposition; and we see absolutely total confusion on the part of the National Party in the Senate on serious issues.

—My question is addressed to the Prime Minister. I refer him to today's announcement that unemployment amongst adult males has topped 10 per cent-the highest level on record. Is the Prime Minister proud of this achievement? Does the Prime Minister believe that his capacity to manage the economy is superior to that of the current Treasurer? Will the economic management be his selling point when shoring up his numbers in the Treasurer's coming leadership challenge?

—Mr Speaker, I rise on a point of order. Earlier today a point of order was taken about matters listed for debate in this chamber being the subject of a question. This matter is listed for debate in this chamber today under the name of the Leader of the Opposition.
—Order! There is no point of order.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not know how many times those opposite need to be told. The Treasurer and I, and the rest of the Government responsible for the formulation and implementation of Government policy, take no pleasure at all from the fact that in the community there are many people suffering from unemployment. As distinct from members of the Opposition who seem to continually make glee the worse the news becomes, as they see it, we have a sincere regret. We take no joy from these figures at all. I have said that if we had not acted in the way in which we have done the world would have imposed upon Australia a significantly more draconian resolution of the situation with which we were confronted.

ANSWER.PARA: We are proud of the fact that, confronted with the realities we were, we had the determination to take those decisions which have avoided inflicting on this country what would have been a very much greater disaster. It is the case that if we had not acted in the way we did, we would have had many more people unemployed now. The world would have marked us down. The rest of the world is not doing that. They are recognising, in a variety of ways, the appropriateness of the action that had to be taken and the determination with which the Government is doing it under the economic leadership of the Treasurer.

I have been asked whether I regard my economic leadership as superior to the Treasurer's. The fact is that the Treasurer and I have said from day one of this Government that we act in concert. I have been proud to be shoulder to shoulder with him when our employment figures have been rising; when our unemployment figures have been coming down. I have been proud to stand beside him and to take the credit with him, when we should get that credit. I am equally prepared, and always will be, to stand next to him, shoulder to shoulder with him, when the figures are going the other way. That is the way it has been for eight years, and that is the way it will be for many, many more years yet.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question to the Minister for Science and Technology concerns the future of Australia's aerospace industry. I ask: can the Minister advise the House of the significance for the Australian aerospace industry of the recent agreement between the Boeing company and the Australian aerospace companies Hawker de Havilland and Aerospace Technologies of Australia?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Crean The Hon S.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for his question. I know that this is a significant development not just for the country but also, specifically, for his electorate because of its employment implications. The recent agreement is a very significant advance for the aerospace industry in this country. It is, in fact, a significant vote of confidence by the largest aircraft manufacturer in the world in relation to its next generation of aircraft.

ANSWER.PARA: The aerospace industry in this country has carved out a significant niche for itself in international markets. It is a supplier to all of the prime aircraft manufacturers-there are not many of those. That is what makes the arrangements easier. It is world competitive; it is innovative; it has a skilled work force. The restructuring that the Government insisted upon in relation to Aerospace Technologies of Australia (ASTA) has seen it move from the military aircraft industry into the domestic aviation industry.

This industry now has export growth to the value of $150m in elaborately transformed manufactures, and $340m in total exports. This represents a growth in exports in the last 12 months of 20 per cent. This growth has been brought about for a number of reasons but, significant to this, has been the Government's offsets strategy whereby it required the suppliers of aircraft to undertake certain agreements in this country to manufacture.

In the 12 March statement what this Government did was to indicate a preparedness to waive those offset requirements if, in fact, the manufacturers were prepared to commit themselves to long term contracts. Boeing is the first such company to enter into an agreement. That involves an arrangement involving $455m worth of exports in relation to this country providing significant contribution to its new 777 aircraft for tail structure surfaces. ASTA and Hawker de Havilland are both involved in that exercise. Boeing is the first. An agreement with Airbus is imminent. In relation to the other aircraft manufacturers, the arrangements are well advanced.

The new strategy that has been developed by this Government sees a combination of trade liberalisation, to the extent to which we are prepared to waive the offset requirements, in return for a commitment to long term contracts with significant export potential based on our international competitive strengths.

As a result, the aerospace industry has been strongly positioned for participation in global markets. But it is not content to rest there, because we cannot just rest on our laurels. The other significant addition to this industry that the Government has fostered has been the recent granting of the Cooperative Research Centre to the aerospace structures consortium, which will involve itself in the development of advanced fibre reinforced composite constructions, which have the potential to develop smart structures for the aerospace industry. It is the commercialisation, again involving Aerospace Technologies of Australia and Hawker de Havilland, and the linkages with those companies that is a key component for ensuring that we will not lose the competitive edge. So I am very optimistic about the future for this industry. Boeing is the first of but many success stories that will come from it, and it has happened only because this Government is prepared to take a strategic approach to the aerospace industry and back it.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, have you seen remarks by the Clerk of the Senate that actions of members of parliament in their party rooms may be a contempt of Parliament or are a contempt of Parliament and may be in breach of the Crimes Act? As this is a statement made by a senior officer of the Parliament and reported in the press, will you, Mr Speaker, examine the implications of this and, if necessary, ask the Privileges Committee to report to the Parliament on this matter?
—I have not seen those remarks. The honourable member for Corio might bring them to my attention after Question Time.

—Mr Speaker, I wish to ask you a question. You may have noticed that there has been a growing practice in this House, particularly since this Parliament has been in existence, of individual members hissing when they disagree with actions or statements being made by members of the Opposition. I ask you, Mr Speaker: have you heard this mode of conduct?
—You are one of them.
—Order! The member for Mayo!
—If so, would you rule against it?

—It is often very difficult to hear many things with the interjections that constantly come from the honourable member for Mayo, who was even interrupting the honourable member for Warringah just then. I would think that honourable members, if they wish to show disapproval, might do so in the normal way in which it has been done by the House in the past. Honourable members interjecting or clearing their throats in an excessive manner and other honourable members, such as members on my left in the rear corner, making other strange noises, I think are also things that people should take account of. So I would expect that all honourable members on both sides of the House, if they were wanting to show disapproval, or approval, of what members on either side were saying, might do so in the more traditional manner.
—I understand that the Deputy Leader of the National Party of Australia wishes to make a personal explanation. The honourable member may proceed.

—Mr Speaker, earlier this week in Senate Estimates Committee D, in relation to a reply from the Parliamentary Ministerial Services Branch on overtime payments for staff of members of parliament, against my name for the year 1 July 1989 to 30 June 1990 the figure for overtime was listed of $84,795.64. Mr Speaker, this was wrong, according to my records, and I asked that this matter be checked. Mr Paul O'Neil, the responsible officer, has advised me that it is wrong and that the correct figure is $38,424.46-a dramatic reduction on that original figure and very much in line with what is the norm for my type of office in this place.

—I have a question for you, Mr Speaker. You may or may not be aware of the current propaganda being run in the parliamentary dining rooms where we are being encouraged to have healthy food. As this is having an appalling effect on the quality of the food, will you take certain steps to ensure that this practice is discontinued?

—While some honourable members might think that the last thing the honourable member for Kalgoorlie should have is healthy food, I do not think that either the President or I intend to take any action on what he raises.

DEBATE.TITLE: ROYAL COMMISSION INTO ABORIGINAL DEATHS IN CUSTODY

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tickner The Hon R.E.

TALKER.NAME: Mr TICKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Aboriginal Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Aboriginal Reconciliation)

TALK.START.PARA: —I present certain reports of the Royal Commission into Aboriginal Deaths in Custody, and seek leave to move a motion for the publication of the reports.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this House, in accordance with the provisions of the Parliamentary Papers Act 1908, authorises the publication of the following reports of the Royal Commission into Aboriginal Deaths in Custody:

National Report Volumes 1 to 5; Regional Report of Inquiry in New South Wales, Victoria and Tasmania; Regional Report of Inquiry in Queensland; Regional Report of Inquiry into Individual Deaths in Custody in Western Australia Volumes 1 and 2 and Regional Report of Inquiry into Underlying Issues in Western Australia Volumes 1 and 2.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-The reports I have just tabled are historic documents. They must command the attention not only of the governments and the parliaments of Australia but of the nation itself. The Royal Commission into Aboriginal Deaths in Custody evolved into an unprecedented national inquiry into the conditions of Australia's indigenous people operating under letters patent issued by the Governor-General, Governors in all States, and the Administrator of the Northern Territory.

SPEECH.PARA: The 11 volumes of the reports, ranging over 5,000 pages and containing 339 recommendations, provide an agenda for the nation over the coming decade. As honourable members are aware, one of my priority objectives as Minister for Aboriginal Affairs has been to build a movement of cross-party and community support for initiatives in Aboriginal affairs. This objective will take on greater significance as governments across Australia respond to the Royal Commission reports.

The Royal Commission was established on 16 October 1987 and inquired into the deaths of 99 Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people in the custody of police, in prison or in youth detention institutions. It also investigated action taken by authorities subsequent to these deaths. The inquiry was established with the support of the Federal Opposition and as the direct result of the perception of both Aboriginal and non-Aboriginal people that Aboriginal deaths in custody were both far too common and the public explanations too sketchy to discount the possibility of foul play.

Commissioner James Muirhead, QC was requested to report by 31 December 1988. The huge scale of this task became evident only too soon. Commonwealth and State letters patent were subsequently amended to increase the number of commissioners to five, to extend reporting deadlines and to extend the Royal Commission's jurisdiction to the important social, cultural and legal factors contributing to the deaths. Mr Elliott Johnston, QC became National Commissioner in April 1989.

At the outset, I would like to place on record the Government's appreciation of the work of commissioners Johnston, Muirhead, Wyvill, O'Dea, Dodson, Wootten and their staff. The Royal Commission has examined in close detail both the lives and the deaths of the individuals concerned, and the huge range of historical and social factors operating to produce the situations these people faced. Public hearings were held, families were represented by legal counsel, relevant people were interviewed wherever poss- ible, and all aspects of custodial care and legal processes were examined. The views of Aboriginal people were sought, particularly through the work of the Aboriginal Issues Units. Reports on the circumstances of individual deaths have been presented in the relevant jurisdictions and tabled as they became available. I know I can speak for the Parliament in expressing on this occasion the deepest sympathy to the relatives of the deceased.

Although some individual reports recommend consideration of further action against individuals, the Royal Commission's final report does not accord with initial expectations of foul play. The commissioners have not found that any deaths were the result of deliberate unlawful violence or brutality by police or prison officers. To that extent, families and friends in their continuing grief and anger have found the findings of individual reports difficult to accept. But they cannot, I think, doubt the sincerity, dedication and compassion with which the commissioners have carried out their task.

Nevertheless, the report stands as an indictment of the operation of the legal and corrective services system in respect of the most disadvantaged group in Australian society, and of our society itself, in allowing that situation to develop and persist. The Royal Commission finds that there has been a failure to live up to the standard of care owed to those in custody; it has found many system defects and many individual failures to exercise proper care and basic human compassion.

Particularly prior to the establishment of the Royal Commission, in very few cases were initial investigations into deaths other than perfunctory and limited in focus, leading invariably to deteriorating relationships between Aboriginal people and the broader community; leading to increased anguish and cynicism on the part of the families and friends; and to neglect of opportunities to avoid future deaths.

The report contains an extensive charter of law reform related to the criminal justice system, police and prison authorities, which falls primarily within the responsibility of State and Territory Governments. The recommendations range through the full extent of the criminal justice system to include: diversion from police custody; imprisonment as a last resort; reform of police and prison practices; and reform of custodial health and safety practices, including a formal recognition of the States' duty of care to those held in custody. The report also makes wide-ranging recommendations about future post-death investigations and the independent monitoring of deaths in custody.

In all these circumstances and on these issues, I must stress that this Royal Commission report must not be seen as some prison officer bashing or police bashing exercise. It is not. The report puts forward constructive and practical proposals for law reform. Significantly, it acknowledges that improvements have already been made in Aboriginal-police relations and puts forward proposals to further advance this process. It is vital that Aboriginal communities and Aboriginal organisations, such as Aboriginal legal services, play a key role in developing these reforms.

I turn now to Commissioner Johnston's consideration of the issues underlying Aboriginal deaths in custody. In response to this aspect of its work, the Royal Commission has proposed a transformation of relations between Aboriginal and non-Aboriginal people in this country. Put simply, too many Aboriginal people are in custody too often. They are over-represented in custody at a rate-calculated nationally-29 times that of the general community. In some cases that rate is considerably higher.

As a result, Aboriginal people die in custody at rates that have been the subject of international attention. The circumstances of these deaths are set out in chapter 3 of volume 1 of the report. Thirty of the 99 deaths resulted from hanging. In those 30 cases, the following objects were among those used for suspension: strips of sheeting, strips of blanket, football socks, a length of electric flex, a belt, the sleeve of a jacket, a shirt, a mattress cover, a shoelace, the sleeve of a cardigan, a bandage and a pair of jeans. Other deaths occurred as the result of shocking self-mutilation such as a razor to the throat, and the driving of a paint brush into an eye.

I give these examples not to sensationalise or shock but to bring to this House a sense of the human tragedy which underlies a death in custody. The finding that foul play on the part of authorities was not a factor in the deaths in no way diminishes the standing of the Royal Commission or undermines the reason for its establishment. History will record that the Royal Commission has played a vital role in laying open before us the harshness and oppression experienced by so many contemporary Aboriginal Australians.

I ask the House to consider the damning picture of the lives and deaths of these 99 predominantly young Aboriginal Australians who died in custody. The average age at death was 32 years. Of the 99 Aboriginal people who died, 43 had experienced childhood separation from their natural families through intervention by State authorities, missions or other institutions; 83 of the 99 were unemployed at the date of their last detention; 43 of the 99 had been charged with an offence at or before the age of 15-just kids; only two of the 99 had completed secondary schooling; 43 of the 99 were taken into custody in the period immediately before their deaths on matters directly related to the over-use of alcohol and, in the remaining cases, the Royal Commission concluded that alcohol was a contributing factor in their being taken into custody for the last time.

The Royal Commission concluded that the standard of health of the 99-whose average age, I remind the House, was 32-varied from poor to very bad. The average age of those dying from natural causes was a little over 30 years.

There are many reasons why I am proud to be an Australian but these statistics can be no source of pride for any of us in this House or in any elected sphere of government in Australia, or any non-Aboriginal Australian. Fundamentally, the disproportionate number of Aboriginal people in custody stems from the underlying factors which bring Aboriginal people into contact with the law in the first place.

The report finds that the single most significant contributing factor to incarceration is the disadvantaged and unequal position of Aboriginal people in Australian society in every way, whether socially, economically or culturally. Much of the national report and the associated regional reports is devoted to demonstrating the existence of that inequality and disadvantage. The report documents, in a way never before achieved, the impact of European settlement upon Australia's indigenous peoples, their dispossession and subordination within a dominant and often hostile society frequently motivated by self-interest, the development of racist attitudes both overt and hidden and the way in which these attitudes became institutionalised in the very practices of legal, educational, welfare and Aboriginal assistance authorities.

That these attitudes were themselves the product of a particular time or society and often well intentioned, does not excuse our society from attempting the task of reconciliation and redressing disadvantage. The report documents the impact of these things upon the lives of individual people and the way that that impact continues to be felt and demonstrated today, especially where Aboriginal people have lost their way and where despair and hopelessness have been bred of the destruction of Aboriginal culture and the stifling of independence and initiative. The report demonstrates the close link between this continuing inequality and disadvantage and the refuge sought in alcohol over-use and high custody rates for Aboriginal people.

The report refutes at every level the myth sometimes put forward that the special assistance available for Aboriginal people has put them in a position above that enjoyed by other Australians. It is evident that there are no quick and easy answers to these continuing problems.

There is, however, one principle which looms large as central to change for Aboriginal people. The Royal Commission describes as fundamental the issues of empowerment and self-determination. As a senior and experienced lawyer with considerable knowledge of Aboriginal issues, Commissioner Johnston acknowledges that he had no real idea of the degree of `pin pricking domination, abuse of personal power, utter paternalism, open contempt and total indifference' which confronted Aboriginal people in their everyday lives, with no personal control over one's own children, one's employment, personal savings and decisions as to whether to buy a car or other personal belongings. He points out that communities today are still faced with a multiplicity of grants which effectively mean that agendas are being set elsewhere, that assumptions as to what is best for Aboriginal people are made elsewhere.

Commissioner Johnston highlights what he describes as the first prerequisite of the empowerment of Aboriginal society-the will for renewal and for self-determination. He also stresses the important role played by Aboriginal community based organisations. The role of these organisations is continually emphasised in the recommendations of the report. At every level control of lives and communities must be in Aboriginal hands, in the same way that non-Aboriginal Australians expect to control their lives and communities.

For this to happen, the report makes clear, Aboriginal Australians must themselves have the will and capacity to put an end to their disadvantaged situation, and to take charge of their lives. Commissioner Johnston quotes impressive evidence of the efforts being made all over Australia by Aboriginal organisations and communities, at the local and wider levels, to demonstrate that this can be done, indeed is already being done. Aboriginal people do have the determination and capacity to succeed.

A prerequisite for Aboriginal self-determination is the creation of conditions which will eliminate the systematic and entrenched disadvantage which permeates every aspect of Aboriginal life. The Royal Commission's report contains detailed and comprehensive recommendations to address that disadvantage which are directed to governments at all levels.
