Within the time available to me it is obviously not possible to refer to the hundreds of recommendations to government directed towards overcoming the continuing and critical disadvantage suffered by Aboriginal Australians. However, to convey some understanding of the breadth of those recommendations I note that they include, in no order of priority:
- a national survey of Aboriginal population and infrastructure;
- Commonwealth, State and Territory governments to develop a system of single block grant funding for Aboriginal communities with a model accounting system;
- triennial funding of Aboriginal communities;
- the Commonwealth to negotiate with the States and Territories to achieve the equitable distribution of local government funds to Aboriginal residents, as a condition of funding;
- the development of codes of practice by the media industry and media unions;
- a progress report on the Australian Law Reform Commission's customary law report;
- the urgent provision of funds to enable implementation of the national Aboriginal health strategy-I note that the Commonwealth has already made a significant additional allocation for this purpose;
- review of liquor licensing legislation, notably in the Northern Territory, with a view to reducing the availability of alcohol and meeting the needs of Aboriginal communities;

- support for the Aboriginal employment development policy, including specific inter-government agreements on objectives and outcomes, and the establishment of a peak industry body and local industry, community and local government groups to promote employment equity in the private sector;
- a review and extension of the community development employment program, including to rural towns with large Aboriginal populations; and
- the Commonwealth to act to provide a right of individual appeal on human rights violations to international committees.
- funding to be provided to organisations such as Link-Up for the purpose of allowing Aboriginal people to re-establish links with families separated by past government policies;
- the establishment of a national task force on alcohol abuse;

- an urgent requirement for governments and Aboriginal organisations to negotiate to devise strategies for Aboriginal youth to reduce the rate at which Aboriginal juveniles are involved in the welfare and criminal justice systems;
- Aboriginal communities to be given equitable access to ongoing expenditure by the Commonwealth, State, Territory and local authorities on roads;

- the Department of Employment, Education and Training to be responsible for the development of a comprehensive national strategy designed to improve opportunities for the education and training of those in custody;
- high priority to be accorded to the development of social, economic and cultural development plans by Aboriginal communities on a local and a regional basis;
- recognition that the success of the National Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Education policy will depend on the success of pre-schooling initiatives;
- the establishment of a small unit of Aboriginal people from northern Australia to study the means of achieving greater self-sufficiency in remote northern communities;
- the implementation of a strategy for the training of Aboriginal people to build and maintain essential community infrastructure; and
- all jurisdictions are urged, where this has not already occurred, to provide a comprehensive means of addressing the land needs of Aboriginal people.

I turn now to the critical issue of the process to be adopted by governments in responding to the Royal Commission report. Australia has a commendable international human rights record and acknowledges that human rights issues are of international concern.

I acknowledged at the United Nations Working Group on Indigenous Populations in Geneva last August that the Government is aware that the Working Group, Amnesty International and other international non-government organisations will be monitoring the implementation of the Royal Commission's recommendations. In a very real sense the world is watching.

However, our motivation in ensuring a coordinated and comprehensive national response to the Royal Commission's report will not be, and should not be, international scrutiny. It is the historic and comprehensive nature of the Royal Commission report itself, and our commitment as Australians to a fair go for all, which should drive us to ensure such a response. As a nation we must not squander the opportunity presented by the Royal Commissioner's report to act on an agenda of reform in Aboriginal affairs for the coming decade.

Prior to receiving the Royal Commission's report I had already indicated my predisposition to support an open and publicly accountable process to monitor the response of all governments to the report. I was, therefore, gratified that the first recommendation of the report proposes a public and comprehensive reporting process by the Commonwealth, States and Territories in consultation with the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission. Commissioner Johnston also stresses the need for extensive consultation with and involvement of Aboriginal people in the implementation of the Royal Commission's recommendations.

It is a matter of the utmost importance for me to emphasise that the Royal Commission report does not impact solely on the Aboriginal Affairs portfolio at any level of government. The recommendations are addressed to the whole range of government departments at Commonwealth, State and Territory levels. It will be necessary, therefore, for there to be a response from the whole of government in each Commonwealth, State and Territory jurisdiction.

I report to the House that the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) has asked me to assume responsibility for coordinating the Commonwealth Government response across all portfolios, supported by the Aboriginal Reconciliation Unit within the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet. This report of the Royal Commission into Aboriginal Deaths in Custody demands careful consideration by all governments. Its recommendations have implications for a range of government activities, from Australia's international obligations down to the everyday contacts of individual police, prison, hospital or welfare officers with Aboriginal people, and for every Australian.

I do not pretend that all the changes proposed can happen quickly, even though a number of recommendations may be capable of fairly rapid implementation. The recommendations reflect the linkages between many areas of policy affecting Aboriginal people, and point to the need for coordinated action between and within governments.

The Government has already set in train a process for consideration of the report which acknowledges the status of that report as a joint Commonwealth-State investigation, and the overlapping nature of responsibilities in many areas. The Prime Minister has written to Premiers and Chief Ministers in every State and Territory seeking their cooperation in a joint strategy of response.

I look forward to meeting with Ministers from those portfolios most immediately concerned in the near future to discuss the implications of the report and to agree on a timetable for implementation. The need for empowerment is at the heart of many of the recommendations, and governments will need to allow adequate time for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people themselves to consider the report and formulate a response.

I turn now to what is the final and perhaps the most important recommendation of the report of the Royal Commission into Aboriginal Deaths in Custody. I appeal to all honourable members of this House and to the wider community to give this section of the report deep consideration. As honourable members would be aware, last December I issued a discussion paper as the basis of future legislation to enable our nation to embark on a process of reconciliation between Aboriginal and non-Aboriginal Australians.

As I said earlier, it has been a fundamental objective of my time as Minister for Aboriginal Affairs to create a climate of cross-party cooperation in and community support for significant progress in Aboriginal affairs. I was, for this reason, delighted by the final recommendation of the Royal Commission report, which states:

. . . that all political leaders and parties recognise that reconciliation between the Aboriginal and non-Aboriginal communities in Australia must be achieved if community division, discord and injustice to Aboriginal people are to be avoided. To this end the Commission recommends that political leaders use their best endeavours to ensure bi-partisan public support for the process of reconciliation and that the urgency and necessity of the process be acknowledged.

In discussing the framework of the report and the other recommendations in the report, the Royal Commission describes the reconciliation process as `the fundamental backdrop to reform and change'. The Royal Commission further states that reconciliation of the Aboriginal and non-Aboriginal communities must be an essential commitment of all sides if change is to be genuine and long term.

As the Royal Commission observes, the process of reconciliation proposed by the Government will have as a principal focus the need to educate non-Aboriginal Australians about the cultures of Australia's indigenous peoples and the treatment of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people by European settlers and their descendants. This sad history-which includes the dispossession and dispersal of Aboriginal people, confinement in reserves, removal of children from their families and the destruction of much Aboriginal culture-needs to be recognised as a primary cause of the current disadvantaged position of Australia's indigenous peoples. All Australians need to understand this country's past and the place of Aboriginal people in it. We must come to terms honestly with our own history as a nation, with the intention not of creating guilt, but of building compassion and empathy for Aboriginal people and their disadvantaged position in society, as well as appreciation of Aboriginal cultures and achievements, and the unique position of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people as the indigenous peoples of this continent.

The Royal Commission recognises, as I do, four key issues essential to the process of reconciliation: first, the taking of concrete measures to tackle disadvantage and establish self-determination as being essential building blocks to that process of reconciliation; secondly, the reconciliation must have cross-party support and support from Aboriginal people; thirdly, the focus should concentrate on the process of reconciliation and not on a document or instrument which might be one of the outcomes; and finally, the process should not be impeded by either Aboriginal or non-Aboriginal people setting preconditions in advance.

The report suggests that if we are to remove the cause of distrust and enmity between Aboriginal and non-Aboriginal people and build good community relations, we must not only eliminate existing disadvantage but also recognise Aboriginal rights, cultures and traditions. This process of reconciliation must carry with it the complete rejection of the concepts of superiority and inferiority which have informed Australian society over the past 200 years.

Importantly, the Royal Commission's report emphasises the extent of past cross-party cooperation in Aboriginal affairs. The report traces the history of Aboriginal affairs policy and recognises that the first step in the reconciliation process-and the one which achieved the clearest endorsement from the Australian people-was the 1967 referendum. These are the words of Commissioner Johnston:

Since 1967 there has been an evolution of thought on the part of non-Aboriginal Australians which has been reflected in the actions of successive Commonwealth Governments irrespective of party composition.

In the final chapter of the report, the Royal Commission chronicles in some detail the changes that have occurred. The Royal Commission also recognises the widespread community support which, at the time of writing, had already been forthcoming for the process of reconciliation. I can report to the House that the ground swell of support for the reconciliation process has continued with endorsement coming from a wide range of Aboriginal organisations and individuals as well as from diverse sections of the non-Aboriginal community.

I have a responsibility on the occasion of the tabling of this report to invite the Opposition to join with the rest of the Australian Parliament to give unanimous backing to the proposal for the process of reconciliation endorsed by the Royal Commission. I embrace wholeheartedly the concluding aspiration of the Royal Commission, which reads:

In the end, perhaps together, Aboriginal and non-Aboriginal, the situation can be reached where this ancient, subtly creative Aboriginal culture exists in friendship alongside the non-Aboriginal culture. Such an achievement would be a matter of pride not only for all Australians but for all humankind.

If Australia, as a nation, had been able to achieve this recognition and reconciliation before this date, these tragic deaths may have been avoided. We might have been able to spare families the suffering they have experienced. It is not too late, however, for other deaths to be prevented. The Royal Commissioners have given us their insights, their advice and a clear direction for change. The families of those who have died, and indeed all Australians, have a right to expect that governments at all levels and of all political persuasions will act together to make sure that that change takes place. I commend the report to the House and I present the following paper:
Report of the Royal Commission into Aboriginal Deaths in Custody-Ministerial Statement, 9 May 1991.
Motion (by Mr Duffy) agreed to:
That the House take note of the paper.
Motion (by Mr Duffy)-by leave-agreed to:
That so much of Standing and Sessional Orders be suspended as would prevent the honourable member for Chisholm speaking for a period not exceeding 33 minutes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Wooldridge Dr M.R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the past the Opposition has been critical of the Royal Commission into Aboriginal Deaths in Custody. Today I intend to put that behind us and address the report and the very important issues raised in it. This is a report of some 5,000 pages and 339 recommendations. In spite of the fact that I speed read, I have been able to have only a very cursory glance at it today. So what I say is very much first impressions and very much personal feelings that one experiences when one tries to address an issue such as this.

SPEECH.PARA: On looking at Commissioner Johnston's work I was overwhelmed not only at the size, scope and complexity of the report but also at the issues raised in it. When the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson) asked me to take on the job as shadow Minister for Aboriginal affairs I had a telephone call from my friend and colleague the honourable member for Pearce (Mr Chaney). He said to me, `You're very lucky. This job will change you. No-one does this job and remains the same'. I did not know what he meant, but after having had the job for 12 months I do know. It is not possible to spend the whole of one's time travelling around the country talking to Aboriginal people-looking at their hopes and aspirations and the problems they face-without having a different attitude to the problem.

As I read Commissioner Johnston's report I very much felt emotions of joy, frustration and anger. They are also the feelings one gets in doing a job such as this: one feels joy at some of the successes happening around the place; one feels frustration at the scope of the challenge and at the pace in which opinion moves in Aboriginal society; and one feels anger when one sees Aboriginal people being manipulated by outsiders for other agendas, and one feels this far too often.

The Royal Commission has found that the conclusions in this report-in its own words-`will not accord with the expectations of those who anticipated that findings of foul play would be inevitable and frequent'. That is not the conclusion the commissioners reached. The conclusion they reached was that Aboriginal people die in custody at a rate exactly equal to that of non-Aboriginal people. A very large number of Aboriginal deaths in custody are purely a function of the imprisonment rate. Then they go on to discuss in length why Aboriginal people are so often in prison.

If I had one area of disappointment with the report it was that while it identified poverty as a major factor in the Aboriginal condition it did not look at poverty in itself in relation to the imprisonment rate. My experience as a doctor is certainly that if one were to compare a group of non-Aboriginal people in similar poverty one would find a much higher imprisonment rate than the normal population. In spite of that, Aboriginality is obviously an important factor in the imprisonment rate.

It also looked at the inequality and disadvantage that Aboriginal people face. From time to time when I am in rural and remote Australia I really have pangs of conscience. Many of the problems Aboriginal people face are also faced by all people in rural and remote Australia. This came home to me very much the other day in Cunnamulla when I was travelling with the honourable member for Maranoa (Mr Bruce Scott). I was talking to a local, who said to me, `I have lived here 37 years and in that time only two people from this high school have ever gone on to tertiary education'. I do not mean to belittle the problems of Aboriginal people in any way, but I cannot help remembering that many of their problems are faced by many other people.

There are a few recommendations that I would particularly like to take up because they touched a chord with me. Some weeks ago, the shadow Minister for health, the honourable member for Lowe (Dr Bob Woods), and I, both registered doctors, actually went to Hermannsburg in the Northern Territory for a week and practised as doctors in an Aboriginal health service. We treated kids with diarrhoea, some of whom had to be evacuated because they were in a life threatening situation. We saw people under 40 years of age with advanced aggressive diabetes, who would be lucky to live for a matter of months. We saw health data going back to 1945 which showed very clearly that people in Hermannsburg are dying younger now than they did in 1970 or in 1945.
One of the things mentioned in the report relates to health data. Recommendation 246 states:

That the State, Territory and Commonwealth governments act to put an end to this situation where insufficient accurate and comprehensive information on inputs to and activities of Aboriginal health programs is available. Such information is needed if Aboriginal organizations, governments and the community are to be in a position to understand and monitor what is taking place in this area . . .

When I first became shadow Minister for Aboriginal affairs I asked for what health data was available over time to try to get a sense of what was happening and whether what we were doing in Aboriginal Affairs was having a positive or negative effect, or no effect at all on the health of Aboriginal people. I found that the only available information came from the Pitjantjatjara lands and from the Aboriginal Congress in Alice Springs where a 1981 and a 1986 health survey had been done. That was the only place in the country where I could get any reasonable serial health data on Aboriginal people.

What that survey found was that, for all our effort, the health of Aboriginal people had not changed one jot in five years. The people at the Congress were actually rather embarrassed and defensive about it. That did not concern me at all. In fact, I was absolutely thrilled that at least somewhere in Australia they had the data to allow them to be honest enough with themselves to say, `Is what we are doing having any effect or should we perhaps look to modify it because we are not having the changes that we effected?'.

It makes it impossible to have an honest debate with oneself, within one's Party and within the broader Australian community, unless we actually know where we start from, where we are trying to get to and how we are going to know if what we are doing is having an effect. Quite frankly, activity does not equate with outcomes. They do not have to be our outcomes. They have to be outcomes that are negotiated in consultation with Aboriginal people and they have to be outcomes that they have a stake in.
The report also talks about the evaluation process, in relation particularly to Aboriginal health services. Chapter 31.3.56 states:
It is clearly beyond the scope of the Royal Commission to seek to evaluate the strengths and weaknesses of the approximately 70 AHSs in operation in Australia. Indeed, no agency has done so.
So after 19 years of operation of independent Aboriginal health services, no-one has ever sought to look at their efficiency and operation.

This is not to criticise the health services themselves, but, really, the situation is crazy. Aboriginal people should not tolerate a situation in which they are getting a service which is not good value for money. If nothing else, I hope that this report will seek to provide some impetus to the really urgent need to look at performance indicators through all areas so that Aboriginal people themselves know they are getting good value for the money that is being spent.
The report talks about health workers and the Northern Territory's experiences in this regard. Recommendation 262 states:

That the States recognise the contributions of Aboriginal Health Workers and, in doing so, review the Northern Territory's experience of the establishment of appropriate career structures and the registration of them.

The experience of the shadow Minister for health and I when we were working at Hermannsburg was that the Aboriginal health worker system is one of the most exciting and innovative in the country. It really can provide a lead to the rest of Australia. It highlights one of the problems that remote Australia faces; not just Aboriginal communities, but anyone living in remote Australia. I refer to the problem of providing medical or para- amedical services. People in these places never see a doctor. By and large, the health facilities are run by nurses.

One of the fallouts of this report was Sister Sophie Heathcoate in Wilcannia who was criticised in an earlier report, struck off the nursing register and, only in recent weeks, has had that overturned by a court in New South Wales. Unfortunately, the board that looked at her and the royal commissioner who criticised her, missed the point. In doing so they sent ripples throughout remote nursing areas in Australia. Remote nurses are being asked to provide services for which they are not trained. They are providing services for which they do not get adequate backup or adequate assistance. I hope that in looking at the whole area of Aboriginal health and remote Australia health services we can realise that there are people who are doing quite extraordinary work and need far more backup than they are getting at the moment.

The report raises a number of other issues which I will only just touch on. It talks about vouchers. I raise this matter for a reason that will become obvious. In volume 5 of the report, under Northern Territory issues, two recommendations have been made. It is recommended that there be an amendment to the Social Security Act to prevent cheques from being mailed and cashed to alcohol outlets and, secondly, that schemes such as the Tangentyere food coupons scheme, which allows people to bank with the Tangentyere branch bank and withdraw savings only as food coupons, be supported and extended.

Some months ago the Chief Minister of the Northern Territory wrote to the Minister for Social Security (Senator Richardson) and suggested that possible schemes involving food coupons should be looked at. I have a copy of the Minister's reply. It states:

You should already be aware that I have no intention of supporting the Northern Territory Government's failure to act in this area by introducing racial discrimination into the social security system.

I mention this not to score points off Senator Richardson but to highlight the point that Aboriginal affairs is an area that has entrenched political views and entrenched political antagonisms. There may be an element of truth in arguments on both sides of politics. There is also a very great element of mistrust. The mistrust is not just on one side of politics. However, with letters such as the above, the mistrust is on both sides of politics.
That leads me to reconciliation. Reconciliation is mentioned at length in the report and the Minister mentioned it. In the overview, Commissioner Johnston talks about reconciliation and says:

The process of reconciliation demands a very strong commitment to the elimination of that Aboriginal social, economic and cultural disadvantage which is the basic reason for the disproportionate number of Aboriginal men and women in custody--

The discussion paper that has been released by the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Tickner) is necessarily vague. That makes it very difficult to give a firm reply at this stage before we have seen the legislation. However, I say to the Minister now: if he wants to take up Commissioner Johnston's recommendation on page 25 of his overview and have a process of reconciliation that focuses on the social, economic and cultural disadvantage of Aboriginal people, there is a good chance that he will get support from right round the country. There is a good chance that we can take a small step in trying to remove that mistrust that exists on both sides of politics.

Yes, we have accepted for a long time that reconciliation is important, but reconciliation is difficult because it means a lot of things to a lot of people. However, if we want to look at the economic, social and cultural disadvantage of Aboriginal people and the ways of removing them, I think we have somewhere where we can go together.

This report comes 24 years after the 1967 referendum, mentioned by the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs. That is a generation of people. It shows how Australian people have really let down Aboriginal people in that generation. The Minister commented that the report stands as an indictment of the operation of the legal and corrective services system in respect of the most disadvantaged group in Australian society. I would go further: I would say all areas of government have failed, and are failing, Aboriginal people. Where the successes have occurred-as noted in this report, and in my strong experience of travelling around the country-they have occurred in spite of government, not because of government. They have occurred because Aboriginal people have been prepared to take their problems into their own hands and do something about solving them.

So, in as much as this report focuses on how people can help themselves, how they can obtain economic independence, how we can have practical services on the ground and practical solutions to complex problems, then there is somewhere where we can get cross-party support in the Parliament for the recommendations in this report. The loss of a loved one is a catastrophic event, and this report is the culmination of the loss of 99 people. That may be little consolation for the families of those who are involved, but the report does give us the opportunity to move forward. I would hope that sometime down the road those who have been touched by this might feel that something good has come out of it. Certainly we in the Opposition will do our very best to see that that happens.

TALK.START.PARA: —The debate is adjourned and the resumption of the debate will be made an order of the day for the next sitting.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker has received a letter from the Leader of the Opposition proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the House for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The failure of the Prime Minister to show leadership by taking urgent measures to correct the economic mistakes of his Treasurer which have seriously weakened the economy of Australia, as evidenced by today's report of a substantial rise in unemployment.
I call upon those honourable members who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of members required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hewson Dr J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am proposing today what I believe to be a very important matter of public importance (MPI). But yet again, the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) does not grace this Parliament and offer a response. I think it is the ninth matter of public importance that I have taken since I became Leader of the Opposition, and again I say that the Prime Minister has not got the decency to front this Parliament. Indeed, the only way we can get the Prime Minister to come into this Parliament and debate the economy or debate his leadership is to censure him. When we do that of course, the Leader of the House (Mr Beazley) runs around all over the place and all over the gallery saying that we are abusing the privilege of censure. The Prime Minister's failure to take matters of public importance does not really trouble me, but it is a sign of the disrespect with which he holds this Parliament and his unwillingness to be held accountable for his policies and his policy failures.

SPEECH.PARA: This matter of public importance is about integrity, competence and leadership in government. The MPI in particular is about the Prime Minister's lack of integrity, his pronounced incompetence and his decided lack of leadership. His Government has been guilty of many things, many catastrophic blunders in fact. It has engineered a recession we never needed to have, and the magnitude of that has been evidenced by today's unemployment data. It has presided over the worst fall in living standards in living memory; it has presided over an explosion of our international debt that prejudices the future of many Australians that are yet unborn; and it has failed to deliver on so many promises, but particularly promises relating to substantial reform. These have not just been honest mistakes by this Government. They have been a demonstration, really, of this Government's fundamental incompetence, and they have also been a demonstration of the corrupt frame of mind within which it operates. It has been a government which has put its survival first and the interests of Australians last. It is a Prime Minister who puts mateship ahead of integrity and ahead of leadership. He looks after his mates, but he forgets about the rest of us.

The Prime Minister is a failed leader of a failed government. He is showing an appalling lack of integrity, an appalling lack of confidence and an appalling incapacity for leadership in what are the most difficult circumstances we have seen in this country in 60 years. Indeed, ever since the last election, he and his Government have staggered from one crisis to the next. They are out of ideas, they are out of touch and they are out of time. This Government has-I think this is a point worth noting-betrayed the people whom it is supposed to represent. Just 45 years ago, Ben Chifley said that the Labor Party was:
. . . a movement bringing something better to the people; better standards of living, greater happiness to the mass of the people. We have-
said Chifley-
a great objective-the light on the hill-which we aim to reach by working for the betterment of mankind not only here but anywhere we may give a helping hand.

This Government, the Hawke Government, has put that light on the hill out for some 350,000 people, the people who have become unemployed in the course of the last 18 months in the recession the Treasurer (Mr Keating) says we had to have, but everyone in Australia knows we never needed to have.

Last month, for example, the Prime Minister boasted that the foundation of the Australian Labor Party (ALP) was `advancing the interests of the ordinary men and women of Australia'. Let us look at today's unemployment data and see how he has advanced the interests of the ordinary working men and women of Australia: the unemployment rate in April was 9.9 per cent on a seasonally adjusted basis. It is the highest since October 1983. But youth unemployment most disturbingly has already reached 27 per cent and is well on the way to confirming the worst fears of most people, namely, that it is headed for 30 per cent, which will be an unequalled historical record. Most importantly, perhaps, the adult male unemployment rate hit 10.3 per cent today, which is the highest on record and, as I said before, 350,000 people have been thrown on the unemployment scrap heap since October of 1989. This month, the month of April, has seen an increase in unemployment of 66,900 people, which is the largest since that survey of unemployment begun.

Interestingly, and I think most pointedly, when we look around each of the States we see that it is the Labor States where unemployment has rocketed away. In Victoria, it is 10.5 per cent; in Queensland, it is 10.7 per cent; in South Australia, it is 10.3 per cent; in Western Australia, it is 11.1 per cent; and in Tasmania, it is 10.8 per cent. Only in one State, a Liberal managed State where the Greiner Government is about to be re-elected because of its good economic management, the unemployment rate has risen to 8.6 per cent. Perhaps the most sobering thing about the unemployment data is to look beyond that published data to some other data that the Government no longer publishes but which was recently obtained as a result of a freedom of information request.

Commonwealth Employment Service (CES) data shows that there are already now in excess of one million Australians looking for work. With the current survey if a person works more than one hour he or she is dropped out of the unemployment data. But let us take the number of 15 hours and add those who have worked less than 15 hours in a week to the official data that was released today; we find that there are 1.6 million people looking for work or an unemployment rate of 19.3 per cent.

This Government has gone out of its way to fudge the unemployment data over a very long period of time. It has pushed people off into other benefits. It has stopped releasing key pieces of unemployment data, like that CES data, which hide the full extent of our unemployment situation which is clearly approaching now the order of magnitude of the Great Depression of the early 1930s. As I say, this Government has betrayed the people that it is supposed to represent. Those people want to know, all Australians want to know-in terms of the Prime Minister's statement of looking after the best interests of the ordinary working men and women in Australia-how it is that we have an unemployment rate approaching 19 per cent; or how is it that the 350,000 people, who have been thrown onto the unemployment scrap heap just since October 1989, have had their best interests served by this Government?

In recent weeks, I have walked around a lot of factory floors in Australia and gone down a lot of mines and spoken to a lot of people-car factories like Ford and Nissan, mines all over Western Australia and Queensland; I have spoken to workers at the Shepparton SPC Cannery and talked to people about how this Government has betrayed their best interests. All those people make one particular point. They do not want any more special deals to help Labor's rich mates. They want a realistic plan to make this country prosperous again. They know that all that Labor offers is simply more deals with union bosses; more soft options with weak management; more sleazy, grubby deals to save a few votes here and a few votes there in a desperate effort to secure re-election.

Under Labor there have been eight years of grubby deals, of putting its political survival ahead of the best interests of the people of Australia. The people of Australia do not mind tough action and tough medicine. They just want to be given a chance to compete on equal terms. They just want to be able to put things right at their workplace and have the opportunity to negotiate the terms and conditions of their employment with their employers. They are tired of union blackmail, they are tired of union influence and they are tired of a government that is dominated by union control.

There is only one party in Australia which is a party of privilege and that is the Australian Labor Party. The parties of the workers now in Australia are the Liberal and National parties. I make this point to Leader of the House, who is sitting at the table and scoffing: how many honourable members opposite thought they would be defending people such as Laurie Connell and Alan Bond as members of the ALP? Australians deserve a fair deal and we should challenge the Prime Minister to give them that fair deal.

There are a number of questions I would like to put to the Prime Minister on behalf of the people of Australia. Why does the Prime Minister not give the Australian people a fair deal by stopping all the special deals that he has done with his mates? Why does he not tell the Australian people, for example, the truth about the recession that he engineered before the last election or that he allowed his Treasurer to engineer before the last election? Why does he not tell the Australian people the truth about why we have such a shoddy transport system or why we have such a hopeless waterfront or why the waterfront is a national disgrace in this country? Why do we have such awful railways, such excessive taxation and such inefficient labour markets? Why does he not tell them the truth about that? It is because of his special deals with his special mates in the trade union movement. People are beginning to understand the cost of that.

Similarly, I ask the Prime Minister why he does not tell the people the truth about why we have such archaic rules in particular industries, such as the airlines and the media. The people of Australia are starting to understand it is because of the special deals that he has done with his special mates in big business. So why does he not just tell the people of Australia the truth about his Government?

It is supposed to be a labour government; it is supposed to be a government by, of and for the workers of this country. Instead it has turned out to be a government by, of and for the Prime Minister's rich mates. It is no wonder there is so much talk about a leadership challenge on the other side of the House these days. Probably nobody has done greater harm to the real cause of the working people of Australia than our Prime Minister. Our Prime Minister is in fact our national problem.

We all know, of course, the magnitude of the reform agenda that should be embraced if we are to put our house in order. There are no easy solutions, no quick fixes and no miracles. We have to have decided, hard-headed, clear-cut leadership, and it will need to be sustained over a period of time. We need to lower interest rates and we need thereby to produce a more competitive exchange rate. We need to do that by doing a lot of other things, in particular moving to enterprise bargaining at the workplace level so that the workers that I described before can control their own destiny and can get a fair return for effort and initiative and by lifting their game.

We need to reduce the role and influence of government in our society to the extent to which people cannot so easily put their hands out for support rather than putting their hands up to help themselves. We need to lower tax as a consequence of that so as to restore incentive. We need to fix up those transport and other infrastructure industries. We are not just fixing them up for the sake of reform: we want to deliver lower transport charges; we want to deliver lower waterfront charges; we want to deliver lower telephone charges; we want to deliver lower air fares, because they are the benefits that the people of Australia are looking for as a result of a genuine reform process. But they are the benefits that the people have been denied by a government which is incapable of truth, honesty, integrity and leadership. We need to boost national savings, not erode them and make fun of them as the Treasurer has done in recent days. We need to boost our productivity, we need to boost our exports; we need to do a host of other things, including improving the quality of our education and our health schemes.

The Prime Minister knows all that. Indeed, in his most cynical moods, he embraces the rhetoric-he picks up the words, he uses the phrases-while he knowingly continues to inflict pain and hardship on the average Australian. Today's unemployment numbers are a very clear-cut example. They are the bottom line, in effect, of miserable economic management on the part of the Prime Minister. There is a lack of concern, a lack of compassion, a lack of understanding. He is simply looking after his own political survival, as I have said, at the expense of average Australians.

I would put it to honourable members opposite that, in terms of the words of Ben Chifley, it is time to rekindle the light on the hill; it is time to dump the Prime Minister; it is time to dump the Prime Minister's rich mates. Is the best Labor leader really a cigar-puffing mate of millionaires or is a better Labor leader a clock-collecting, Mercedes-driving yuppie who tends to forget where he lives on occasions? I appeal to honourable members opposite: do something for the unemployed in this country-make the Prime Minister and the Treasurer join their ranks now.
Opposition members-Hear, hear!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beazley The Hon K.C.

TALKER.NAME: Mr BEAZLEY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Transport and Communications (4.06 p.m.)

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, this is the man who would be a statesman; this is the man who manages to make--

SPEECH.PARA: Opposition members interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I ask the Leader of the House to resume his seat until members of the Opposition conform with the rules.

—Mr Speaker, on a point of order: I think the House would be more interested in what the Minister intends to say if he could, at the outset, indicate whether the Prime Minister will be taking part in this debate.
—There is no point of order.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beazley The Hon K.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) is meeting with the National Catholic Education Commission at this moment and, subsequent to that, he will be meeting with the employers of waterfront labour. The Prime Minister will be doing what he has been doing for the last eight years, and that is governing this nation, just as the Opposition will be doing what it has been doing for the last eight years-marching into this place with a series of meaningless slogans.

SPEECH.PARA: I ask honourable members to look at all the internal contradictions in the speech by the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson). There were tears for the unemployed. We wish they were genuine. But at the same time he says that the Government should stand back, that the Government should not be involved in handouts, that the Government should cut $3 billion off the welfare system-not $3 billion off the welfare system when there are people back at work but $3 billion at any particular point of time.

This is the man who said he does not defend the top end of town. Yet the one policy on which we have absolute clarity from the Liberal Party of Australia is this: there will be a 15 per cent consumption tax on the food of the ordinary people of this country, on the clothing of the ordinary people of this country, on the necessities of life of the ordinary people of this country and on the telephone bills of the ordinary people of this country. Far from going down, they will go up by 15 per cent. On every single item that is essential to the livelihood of people of this country he will impose a 15 per cent tax. Who will benefit? The beneficiaries will be the people from whom the capital gains tax is removed. And who are the beneficiaries from whom the capital gains tax is removed? The top end of town. So those millionaires that he so laughingly referred to during his speech, many of whom have gone broke but still have residual properties, will be the massive beneficiaries of the changes in capital gains tax that the Opposition wants to bring about.

Let me say this: when the next election comes around there will be no recession; when the next election comes around it will have bottomed out. What the Opposition will be doing to the people of this country is marching into them and saying, `Right, well, the recession is over, you are all back to work, or most of you are back to work. What we have is a really great idea for you. Because you might be used to a bit of suffering, we will make it permanent; we will whack that 15 per cent on your necessities of life. But, you lucky people, you will know as you do that that the Laurie Connells, the Alan Bonds, the businessmen who are a darned sight more respectable than either of them down the line, but are of course part of the top end of town, will have their tax removed'.

That is a disgraceful position for any political party to come in and argue, at the same time coming out with a string of mealy-mouthed slogans, as has the Leader of the Opposition. I have listened to the Leader of the Opposition many times in this place. It is my melancholy duty as Leader of the House to do so. Every time I have heard him speak he has had a string of platitudes. Sometimes the platitudes have force, if the circumstances permit, if the circumstances outside give them force; sometimes they do not. But they are always platitudes; there is no argument. We got those platitudes again here today from the Leader of the Opposition. He had his statistics to cite; let me now cite some.

In the current recession, total employment has fallen by 2.5 per cent. In the 1982-83 recession, total employment fell by 3.3 per cent. The 1982-83 recession wiped out 40.1 per cent of the total employment growth the Fraser Government achieved between November 1975 and the start of that recession. There was a 40 per cent reduction under the advice given by the current Leader of the Opposition as a political adviser to the Treasurer of the day, the honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard), who has just entered this House-both of whom would wish to return to the job.

The employment fall since last year's July peak has wiped out only 12 per cent of the total employment growth achieved by the Hawke Government between its election in 1983 and last July. Under Fraser, the labour force participation rate fell from 62.7 per cent in November 1975 to 60.4 per cent in March 1983. The highest it ever reached, in the so-called resources boom on which those opposite hung so much and on which 18 per cent wage rises occurred as they let wage rises rip uncontrolled, was 61.5 per cent. Under this Government the labour force participation rate has shot up from 60.3 per cent in April 1983 to a peak of 64.2 per cent in July 1990. It is now 63.7 per cent.

The only way Fraser, Howard and Hewson stopped unemployment rates in the teens was by running the economy in such a way that tens of thousands of people became discouraged from looking for work and disappeared out of the figures into hidden unemployment. That is when there was hidden unemployment, not now.

What hypocrisy there is from those opposite. When the Liberal Party was running with those unemployment figures of over 10 per cent, it was running at an inflation rate of 11 per cent. The inflation rate at this stage of the game is around 5 per cent, and going down. When the Liberal Party was in government, the rate was 11 per cent and going up. The Liberal Party laid waste to this country's manufacturing industry, which has since been in a process of recovery.
Mr Reith interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —We get smart alec comments from the toppletoy opposite-the fellow who falls over and bounces up again, the fellow who cannot get a decent press conference going because, fundamentally, everybody accepts that he is an economic illiterate. The honourable member for Flinders is the man who would be Treasurer if the Liberal Party were to come into office.

SPEECH.PARA: Those opposite come into this place baying that they will introduce reforms into the economy. Who deregulated the exchange rate? Who deregulated the banking system? Who allowed the currency to fall to a level that at least allowed people and industry in this country a fighting chance? Who has removed the tariffs? Who has introduced that program of phasing tariffs out? All Liberal Party members can say is, `Gee, that is pretty good; we will do it faster'. They say, `We do not have to worry you out there in industry'. They will laugh at industry on this one. They say, `We do not have to worry those out there in industry, because we will achieve reform on the waterfront'. `Oh, yes', they say.

How do they intend to achieve reform on the waterfront? `Well', they say, `we will introduce a law which says that if you are a member of a trade union it is on a voluntary basis'. They say that will cure the waterfront. Will the Liberal Party actually involve itself on behalf of the shippers or anyone else in the negotiating process? Oh, no. Those in the Liberal Party say it is a matter for the employees and employers to work out after they have introduced their proposals and after they have introduced legislation which takes away the right to lifetime employment on the waterfront-the sort of legislation that they normally put in place to ensure that the ordinary people in Australia benefit. They say that when they have done that we will find ourselves in a situation where the waterfront actually cures itself. If it does not, they say they have a great fall back position: put the troops onto the waterfront; put the soldiers onto the waterfront. They say that, in order to benefit the ordinary people of Australia, they are going to put the soldiers in whenever they have a disagreement with those on the waterfront.

The Liberal Party does not know how to operate industrial relations systems. The honourable member for Bennelong had plenty of good words of praise for Ben Chifley. I am one of the few people in the House who has had experience of the utilisation of the armed forces in industrial disputes. It does not happen off the top of one's head, because the armed forces do not want to be in it. They particularly do not want to be in it when they are doing somebody else's job. They will tolerate being in it when they are in a situation where they are doing their own job in the ordinary way.

In the circumstances in which they found themselves in the pilots dispute, that is exactly what they did. However, it was the Transport Workers Union of Australia which handled the baggage, it was the clerks and others who handled the tickets, and it was the TWU and the other transport unions which were running cargo to and from the airports. That was fine, because there was agreement. If one does not get that agreement, what will happen on the waterfront, of course, will be that every product that comes off it will be black-listed. I have not yet seen anywhere in the Opposition's expenditure plans a proposal to expand the armed forces to something like 500,000 to take care of such a situation.

Let me say something else about the soldiers. The honourable member for Hindmarsh (Mr John Scott), who is in the chamber, is a soldier. He is one of the group of soldiers who actually do the work on the waterfront. If people go through our ranks, they will find that it will not be the officers in the defence forces, but the ordinary soldiers, sailors and airmen, who will be the people required to do that work. It will be the brothers and sisters, fathers, uncles and cousins of the people on the waterfront and elsewhere in the transportation system.

One cannot walk into either a store or a base for a major transport company and not find a substantial proportion of the work force who are members of the armed forces. Honourable members opposite would not know that, but let me tell them that they could not do it. If they think for one minute that the soldiers are going to tolerate the way in which those in the Liberal Party, in their careless, ignorant manner, would choose to exploit them in that fashion as far as the waterfront is concerned, then they have another thing coming.

Let me tell those opposite something else about what they will confront when we go to the polls two years from now. They will not be confronting a recession. They will be arguing about their wages policies; they will be arguing about their decisions to introduce a 15 per cent consumption tax on the ordinary Australian's necessities of life; and they will also be arguing about $3 billion of welfare cuts.

Despite the Liberal Party's opposition, in the last eight years we have cleaned up the welfare act of the Commonwealth. Over the coalition's collective political dead body, we have introduced more effective means testing and assets testing arrangements. Members of the Opposition have been shrieking away at us at election after election. They have had no theory about how they can decently conduct welfare policy in this country, and they still do not have one, because they have not specified where cuts are coming from. They cannot get the required levels of cuts unless they start dealing with the unemployed, for whom they weep tears here, the pensioners of this country or, probably, both. A third area, of course, concerns those who are in receipt of family assistance.

What depths of hypocrisy those opposite have managed to get themselves into. They are riding reasonably high at the moment. In a recession, what bunch of political mugs do not if they are in opposition? Who does not ride high in opposition in the middle of a recession? Those opposite are riding high at the moment, but they carry the baggage of years of defence of privilege, which they cannot get out of their policies.

TALK.START.PARA: —We haven't got a lame duck leader.

—The Opposition has not got a leader at all; it has a political adviser. Because of the general incompetence of the Liberal Party in producing real flesh and blood politicians, the Opposition has instead a cardboard cutout for a leader. He comes in here like a tailor's dummy and repeats time after time the same slogans but no argument. There is one other thing that will confront the Opposition at the next election--

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Broadbent interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —I warn the honourable member for Corinella.
—The Opposition has been getting it. The entirety of the reform program will be implemented by then--

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Ronaldson interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member for Ballarat!
—The reforms as far as telecommunications are concerned; the reforms on the waterfront; the reforms in the rail system--
—Where are they?

—They are all coming through. I know the Opposition has this theory that one waves a magic wand and they occur, but they are all coming through and they will be in place by the next election. There will be no basis for the Opposition to stand on in its micro-economic reform program except to add in its own time new dimensions of mindlessness to the way it intends to argue. The Opposition is a party without experience, and it is losing what little it has very rapidly. It is a party without principles. It is a party without policies, except policies which are dangerous to the livelihood of ordinary Australians. This has moved from the depths of hypocrisy that is in the hearts of Opposition members, and the public need take no notice of that-as they will not two years from now.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reith Mr P.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I want to know where the Treasurer (Mr Keating) is. Why is the Treasurer not down here to talk about and to defend his policies in respect of unemployment? Why is the Treasurer skulking in his office on the day that we get the worst set of unemployment figures for nearly a decade? When is the Treasurer going to have the guts to come into the Parliament to defend the failures of his policies? When is he going to have the decency to admit the failure of his economic policies? How much longer is this Parliament going to have to put up with the rubbish that we get from this Treasurer and this Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) on the so-called recovery coming through? How long is it going to take for it to dawn on this Treasurer that his policies have been an absolute disaster for this country? How thick can the Treasurer be? He is yet to equate the fact that he is the first Treasurer, the first Deputy Prime Minister, to have full time security outside his own home to the disastrous economic policies which he has imposed on this country.

SPEECH.PARA: These figures are a disaster-9.9 per cent and rising, and a clear breach in the making of yet another promise from the Prime Minister and others that unemployment would not go beyond 10 per cent. What an indictment on Labor, not just federally but at the State level as well. If we take out New South Wales we see that all the Labor States are now at 10 per cent or more. The excuses we have had from the Prime Minister and the Treasurer today simply will not wash. There is no excuse for the fact that we now have 844,000 people unemployed, and many of them unable to look to their families. It is no good talking about the participation rate; that is a sick joke. What is motivating the participation rate figures is that this lot, the Government, has forced the mums of Australia out to work just to make ends meet. That is the only excuse the Government could offer during Question Time.

The Government promised increased living standards. What do we get? Lower living standards. The Treasurer promised a golden age for this country. We now enter one of the darkest periods of Australia's economy since the 1930s. What a sick joke it was when someone declared the Treasurer to be the world's greatest Treasurer. What effrontery it was from the Prime Minister today when he said that we had one of the world's best Treasurers. He repeated it. It is just incredible at a time when unemployment has reached massive heights.

The Government has got a few things right. The Treasurer had John Stone cheering him on the economy for the first few months that he was in; but basically the Treasurer is a phoney, a miserable creature who has wreaked havoc on literally thousands of Australians. Now we get the ultimate arrogance; this bloke desperately wants to be Prime Minister. I have got news for this Treasurer. He has long been a bridesmaid and he will long remain the bridesmaid of Australian politics.

I was not surprised when I saw the figure of 9.9 per cent. This is what the Government planned. This is the unemployment we `had to have'. For the Treasurer, this is a beautiful set of numbers. The Government literally deliberately set out on a clear policy for the Australian economy of bash, burn and bury. It has stopped this economy in its tracks, and we get virtually no regrets whatsoever but a repetition of the fact that it has been an intentional policy all along. What do we also get from the Treasurer? He said, `The good news is it is going to be a good recovery'. The Government's line is that there are structural improvements. I say to the Treasurer that he ought to come into this Parliament and say to the young people of Australia what the structural benefit for them is-the figure is 27 per cent and rising-to have a time on unemployment benefit. He says that it is a good recession. What good will it do for young people? It is character building, I suppose. For eight years we have had disastrous economic management. When we ask for an explanation the Government gives us the great response, `It was worse under you lot'.

Last November, the Treasurer said-this was a classic line-`Don't you ever compare me with John Howard'. Never will we compare him with John Howard. When we look at the average unemployment under the Fraser Administration, we see that for the whole time of the Fraser years, it was 5.8 per cent. What is it today, and what has been the average unemployment under Labor? It is 7.7 per cent and rising. So if the Government wants to make comparisons with the Fraser years, let us have those comparisons because there is no comparison. The figure is rising. Not only that, things literally are getting worse.

The Treasurer was at Port Pirie the other day and he said that the recovery was coming through now. That is not true. I do not call the Treasurer a liar. There is only one reason why: because it is not parliamentary. But everybody knows that this recovery is not there for many Australians--

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I rise on a point of order. There is obviously a clear inference in that remark that the Treasurer is not being called a liar simply because of the fact that it would be unparliamentary. It should be withdrawn.
—I understood the Deputy Leader to be saying that he did not refer to the Treasurer in those terms.
—Today's figures do not support the Treasurer's claims of recovery, either-9.9 per cent unemployment heading towards 10 per cent or more. That is 844,000--
—Tell us the alternative.

—The honourable member ought to listen to some of this so that he has some response to his constituency. For males it is the highest unemployment rate ever recorded since the Depression. Government members should take that figure back to their electorates. This month it is the biggest jump ever. The recovery argument relies on four points. One is that things are better on the balance of payments. I would just say that any idiot could bring on a reduction in imports by bringing on a recession; that is it. The Government says that stock building is going to help. People will not be building up stocks if there is no demand for the things they sell.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government says that housing is going to lead the recovery. Government members should read the Age today, because it contains a report of the Government's own forecasters, the Australian Council of Trade Unions leading bureaucrats, looking at what is happening in construction, both residential and non-residential, and engineering. It is a stunning figure that they forecast-and remember the Treasurer said that this is going to `lead the recovery'. The Government's own forecasters said yesterday that the total of that building activity in three years time is going to be less than what it is today. The Treasurer is relying on that for a recovery. That is just an illusion and shows that the Government is fiddling with figures. And I will tell the Government what-they will come back to haunt it.

The last point of the Government is that inflation is coming down. Of course it is. There is a recession. In the whole boom and bust cycle of the Australian economy, if there is a bust, there will get a cutback in inflation. It happened in 1982-83. Following that, we had a fall-back in inflation. For the Government to crow about the inflation record as a result of the recession is obviously nonsense.

We need to have an appreciation in this Parliament that, beyond the recession, this economy has some basic structural problems. It is those problems, which the Leader of the Opposition referred to, and the solutions to the problems that ought to be driving people's focus when we get a figure like 9.9 per cent unemployment. In a sense we ought to say, `Here's a figure. It's not good. There are a lot of people unemployed. Let's now take that constituency and get it behind the changes that we've got to make to our economy'. There is yet much to be done. Next week we will celebrate the fifth anniversary of the announcement of the coming of the banana republic. How appropriate it is that that should be preceded by today's unemployment figures.

I conclude by referring to this simple graph. At the end of this term Labor will have been in office for 13 of the last 20 years. It has basically been running this country-at Federal and State levels-for the last 20 years. This is a misery index, showing interest rates, unemployment and whatever. It shows the record of the last 20 years. The index went up after Whitlam-misery rose; Fraser held the line and started to get it down, and ever since we have seen a worsening situation for the average Australian family. It is time for change. It is time for the Government to go.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kerr Mr D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Some little while ago we received advice from many quarters about interest rates. Just after the last Federal election this Government received constant criticism from the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson) about its decision to reduce interest rates. We were told then that we were bringing down interest rates precipitately-that the time was not yet economically responsibly correct to bring down rates. Yet today we see the very people who were counselling high interest rates to us, and the retention of those rates at levels that we said needed to be reduced, turn around and say that we kept them too high too long and put forward the most populist and short-sighted responses to what everybody would say is a situation of extreme difficulty for those who actually face the tragedy of unemployment.

SPEECH.PARA: It is not at all an effective response from those on the opposite side to simply dig out rhetorical flourishes to criticise government. This Government has made hard decisions, and is continuing to do so. In the middle of what must be one of Australia's most difficult circumstances, where its export industries are having to face lower prices internationally in a whole range of commodities, this Government made courageous decisions on the question of tariffs. This Government has continued to confront issues, time after time, the hard way-the only way-that is, to confront them where they actually exist and to deal with the real forces that any government in office must come to terms with.

It is too easy, as has been the case in the debate today, for the Opposition simply to say that things are crook in Tallarook. Time after time we have had the moan of the Hanrahans-the Opposition really does have that flavour. `We'll all be rooned', is the consistent theme that is echoing from the Opposition. It comes time and time again without ceasing.

When the Opposition is actually asked to put its finger on any positive outcomes that it would urge on government we get evasions, we get generalities and we get the kind of emptiness that really degrades the whole process of this Parliament. For example, there is the commitment of the Opposition to massive decreases in public expenditure to the tune of $3,000m. Where is that going to come from? Which unfortunates are going to be hurt? Does the Opposition endorse the New Zealand experience where, after pledging commitments to pensions-pledging that pensions would not be cut-the incoming conservative New Zealand Government has slashed pensions by about 20 per cent in real terms? What about its pledge about unemployment beneficiaries at the last election-that after 12 months no unemployment benefit would be extended? What are people to do? Starve?

How can this patronising attitude today where concern is expressed about the plight of the unemployed be equated with a policy that would condemn the unemployed to the scrap heap? Basically, the Opposition is trying to sell itself to both sides of the street. It is trying to say, `We are a warm-hearted, compassionate party', but its policies would strip away the guts of the Australian social welfare system. They would strip away the protections that the Australian people have built up over generations so that they can expect a decent pension. If they do fall into trouble they can at least rely on a safety net of unemployment benefits and support.

What about the courage of the leadership? There has been instance after instance where the Leader of the Opposition has not had the support of his own party. On the subject of asset testing family allowance proposals so that scarce government resources could go to the most needy, he was rolled in his own party room. Even on a minor matter such as charges for the Australian War Memorial he was rolled in his party room.

On the Burke matter-an issue that I will be debating later today-the Leader of the Opposition has found it conveniently simple to attack his opponents on the basis of standards that he says ought to apply, that is, that when people's character and judgment are impugned before a commission of inquiry they ought stand aside, but there is a conspicuous failure to apply those same tests to those on his own side, in particular, in the case of the Tasmanian Premier, Robin Gray.

The bottom line, in a sense, is demonstration after demonstration not of leadership but of a very galling capacity to speak softly about issues and say to all, `Yes, certainly, we sympathise with you, we offer you a better future, we are concerned about the decline of living standards', yet endorse policies that are designed to reduce real living standards. All this discussion about concern for living standards is really simple hypocrisy. The basic criticism that has been made by the Opposition of the wages policy of this Government is that it has held up real wages at a time when, in its view, in significant areas of industry real wages should be coming down. So we get this double standard-trying to walk both sides of the street.

I suppose most galling to me, in terms of seeking to get some comprehension of what ought to be a response to very difficult circumstances, is the failure to recognise that we need to look constructively at measures that are appropriate, not on a rhetorical basis, but on a substantive basis. There are real changes in the labour force that have occurred over the last decade. The fact that the participation rate has stood up so strongly over the last 12 months really attests to the fact that for the first time in Australia's history women are an integral part of the work force. It is not a case any more that women are an optional extra. In previous times in Australia's history, if there were hard economic circumstances the participation rate collapsed. That meant that women withdrew their efforts to seek work. This has not occurred and will no longer occur and we have to deal with new and changed circumstances.

That presents great challenges for Government because not only must it seek to provide employment for school leavers entering the work force but also to incorporate new entrants from female members of the community who in the past did not see it as part of their vision of themselves to be in the work force. Women now see themselves as having a right and an entitlement, even at times of economic downturn, to participate in the work force. That is something we have to take into account. That is not to say that I do not believe the Government ought to be looking at other measures-there are many-but to condemn this Government for lack of courage and vigour in pursuing a bold policy at a time of hardship is frankly the stuff that deserves contempt.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is beyond contempt.

—It certainly is beyond contempt. I would mention a couple of measures dear to my heart in terms of issues to which I hope the Government will give some consideration. I think it is the case that we need to find some mechanisms to make sure that in addition to the industry measures announced by the Government, we find new initiatives to bring investment into venture capital and commercialisation of research and development for Australia's domestic industry infrastructure. On a number of occasions I have proposed initiatives for the superannuation industry and more recently to investigate tax exempt special savings accounts as a market-driven alternative. That would use the model of the British scheme, modified so that it would actually adopt and influence our industry program and use it in a constructive way.
—Order! The honourable member's time has expired. The time allotted for debate has expired.

DEBATE.TITLE: CONSTRUCTION OF AUSTRALIAN EMBASSY COMPLEX, JAKARTA, INDONESIA

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hollis Mr C.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works, I present the fourth report of the Committee for 1991 relating to the construction of the Australian Embassy Complex, Jakarta, Indonesia.

SPEECH.PARA: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I thank the House. The report I have just tabled deals with the construction of a new chancery and associated recreational facilities in Jakarta. The Committee has concluded that there is a need to provide a purpose-built complex for the Australian Embassy in Jakarta to enable the mission to fulfil its representative functions. The new complex is also needed to provide cultural activity, space and staff amenities.

SPEECH.PARA: The proposed complex will be built on a recently acquired site in the Jakarta central business district. When referred to the Committee the limit-of-cost estimate for the work was $11.6m at December 1990 prices. However, as a result of the unexpected need to provide for on-site power generation, the estimated cost at the time of the public hearing in January 1991 had increased to $12.4m. However while it appears that on-site power generation will not now be required, the Overseas Property Group wishes to retain the additional cost in the estimate until this is confirmed. The Committee also recommended that a further cost of $800,000 be allowed for expansion purposes.

In recommending that the work proceed, the Committee recognised Aus- tralia's need to develop a positive and constructive relationship with Indonesia. Although the relationship between Australia and Indonesia has not been easy for either country in recent years, there is interest and willingness on both sides to improve those relations. The Committee believes it is important that, as the relationship continues to grow in substance and depth, the Embassy remains capable of effectively monitoring and coordinating the full range of interactions.

The Australian Embassy is currently located in two physically separate buildings in the central commercial district of Jakarta, which is now dominated by large multistorey buildings. The chancery premises-one owned by the Australian Government and the other leased-are separated by a very busy, 10-lane major thoroughfare. The owned accommodation, which is a five-storey building opened in 1967, is located on a narrow site which is congested by open air car parking, maintenance workshops, store and plant rooms and recreational facilities. This building has been progressively supplemented by leased space in nearby premises as the Embassy's functions and staff numbers have expanded over the past few years.

As well as detracting from the Embassy's efficiency and cost-effectiveness, through the separation of functions and staff, the present office accommodation is inadequate to satisfy existing needs, provides substandard office accommodation and is adversely affecting the ability of the mission to realise its goals and objectives. Therefore the proposal is based on the need to house all Embassy staff in one building in an acceptable standard of office accommodation, to favourably reflect Australia's image in Indonesia and to meet the Australian Government's obligation as an employer to accommodate properly its employees.

One matter of concern to the Committee was the proposed size of the complex. As a result of the importance of Australia's relationship with Indonesia, it is inevitable that staff numbers will expand, thus requiring disruptive works to provide additional space. This was reinforced by the views of the Ambassador and Embassy staff in Jakarta. Therefore, the Committee has recommended that the project be expanded during the initial construction phase to include the shell of an additional floor and space for lateral expansion at a further cost of $800,000.

The Committee concluded that the site chosen for the new Australian Embassy complex in Jakarta is in a suitable location for its representative and administrative functions. It has also requested that it be provided with a copy of the energy audit of the complex, which is to be undertaken following its completion.

Concerns were raised by the Ambassador and staff in Jakarta over the architectural merit of the proposed project. The mission did not believe the design of the complex adequately reflected the importance of Australia's relationship with Indonesia. While not wishing to enter into a debate on the architectural merits of this project, the Committee believes the design rationale for Australian embassies should be reassessed. In particular, the Overseas Property Group should determine what the designs are meant to achieve-for example, a sense of Australian identity, a prestige image or merely a functional solution to suit a particular design requirement.

Due to the restrictions in the Public Works Committee Act 1969 on meetings of the Public Works Committee outside Australia and its external Territories, the Committee was unable to inspect the proposed site or the existing Embassy complex in Jakarta. This is completely contrary to the normal practice of the Committee, which has always regarded site inspections as an integral and extremely important part of its work and consideration of a project.

This matter has been raised before and the time will come given some of the complexities of the projects about to be referred to the Committee-that the Committee will decide that without a site inspection it is impossible to discharge adequately the mandate given to it by Parliament. The Committee is aware that there are costs involved, but given the nature and the costs of some of these projects, it would sometimes be cheaper for the Committee or a sectional committee to conduct an on-site inspection than the present unsatisfactory arrangements, which often require local embassy staff and design and construction personnel to travel to Canberra to appear at our public hearings.

In the case of the current Embassy project, due to the absence of a site inspection, the Committee was hampered in its consideration of the project, particularly in relation to the issue of size. The Committee believes that section 12(1) of the Public Works Committee Act 1969 should be amended to allow it to meet outside Australia and its external Territories. The Committee has approached the Minister for Administrative Services-without much success, I might say on this matter. I commend the report to the House.

DEBATE.TITLE: PETROLEUM RESOURCE RENT LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1991

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Keating, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.
