TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

Mr Deputy Speaker, this Bill will give legislative effect to the package of measures associated with the petroleum resource rent tax (RRT) announced by the Government in the 1990-91 Budget. The Bill will extend, from 1 July 1990, the resource rent tax to Bass Strait, replacing the complex and arbitrary excise and royalty regime. The measure will not only permit the generation of a fair return to the community from the production of hydrocarbons, but will do so in a manner which encourages the producers to efficiently drain the Bass Strait province in a manner which has greater regard to the producers' capacity to pay.

The Bill also introduces a generous concession to exploration activities, permitting the deduction of exploration expenditure incurred from 1 July 1990 in respect of all offshore operations subject to the RRT, against RRT liability on a wider basis than at present. Exploration expenditure incurred by a person will now be deductible for the purposes of the resource rent tax against the RRT liability of any of the projects held by that person, rather than only those projects undertaken in the relevant permit area as at present. This is a significant reform.

The package of measures will provide a more certain and efficient basis for the taxation of petroleum production and encourage exploration activity in offshore Australia, our most prospective area. The resource rent tax is based on achieved profits rather than production levels and is, therefore, sensitive to changes in prices and costs. This responsiveness will remove the pressure for continual changes to the taxation regime in the Bass Strait as production declines or market conditions vary.

The extension of the resource rent tax to Bass Strait will, as I indicated earlier, promote the optimal recovery of Bass Strait petroleum reserves. New fields will become viable and recovery from existing fields will be enhanced. This is expected to lead to the recovery of a further 200-300 million barrels of oil from Bass Strait and, over the longer term, it can be expected that gas production will also be enhanced.

The introduction of wider deductibility for exploration expenditure will improve the efficiency of the resource rent tax and stimulate the exploration effort in offshore Australia. Previously, deductibility was limited to individual permit areas. The new arrangements make the after tax cost of exploration within RRT paying permits the same as the cost outside those permits. The current disincentive to explore in frontier areas will, therefore, be removed, an important change for the discovery of new hydrocarbon accumulation.

In recognition of the significant benefits to industry of wider deductibility of exploration expenditure, the existing carry forward arrangements for undeducted expenditures under the RRT will be modified. The new arrangement will reflect the relative likelihood of recovering exploration and development expenditures, in contrast to the existing composite carry forward rate. The carry forward rate for general expenditures incurred from 1 July 1990 will be reduced from the long term bond rate plus 15 percentage points to the long term bond rate plus five percentage points. Undeducted exploration expenditure will continue to be eligible for compounding at the long term bond rate plus 15 percentage points.

Mr Deputy Speaker, at this point I announce a minor change in the treatment of resource rent tax payments under the income tax law. Under the existing provisions, RRT is deductible for income tax purposes only after the final assessment has been made-typically in the income tax year following that in which the instalments are made. The Government has decided that instalments of RRT should be deductible for income tax purposes in the income tax year in which they are paid.

This change, which will apply to payments of instalments made on or after 1 July 1991, is consistent with the general principle that an income tax deduction should arise when a payment is made. Legislation giving effect to this change is expected to be introduced into the Parliament as soon as possible.

Mr Deputy Speaker, the Government has been aware of concerns that the transition from excise and royalty in Bass Strait to the more efficient resource rent tax could cause changes to Victorian gas prices, with possibly disruptive consequences for industry and domestic consumers. The Government has, therefore, decided to provide the Victorian Government with a special grant of $30m for each of the first two years of application of resource rent tax, to minimise any transitional pressures on gas prices.

This payment is in addition to the commitment made in last year's Budget to ensure that Victoria will receive revenues in 1990-91 and 1991-92 equivalent to the royalty revenue it would have received under the excise/royalty regime. In this way, Victoria will not be exposed to any significant short term adjustment pressures as a result of the extension of the resource rent tax to Bass Strait. At the same time, the Victorian economy, and Australia generally, will benefit from the long term improvements in efficiency and additional investment and production that resource rent tax will generate in Bass Strait. I now turn to outline some specific features of the amendments.
Bass Strait

Resource rent tax will apply to petroleum recovered from 1 July 1990 in the area of the Bass Strait permit known as VIC/P1. For the purposes of the tax all production licences related to the Bass Strait permit will be treated as one project and all expenditures incurred before 1 July 1990 will be taken to have been deducted. Although the resource rent tax is the effective secondary tax regime applying to Bass Strait from 1 July 1990, producers have continued to be liable for excise and royalty. The amount of excise and royalty paid by the producers up to 30 June 1991 will be used as a credit against their final resource rent tax assessment for the 1990-91 year. Any excess payments will be refunded to the producers.
Wider Deductibility

Where a person has excess deductible exploration expenditure from one project that is incurred on or after 1 July 1990, that excess will be transferable to other projects held by that person that otherwise have a tax liability. For company groups expenditure will be transferable on a groupwide basis. To prevent potentially significant revenue losses under wider deductibility, compounding of undeducted expenditure at the long term bond rate plus 15 percentage points will be limited to expenditure incurred within five years before the year in which the production licence was granted in relation to the project against which the expenditure is being deducted. Exploration expenditure incurred more than five years before the relevant year will be eligible for compounding at the GDP deflator. This is consistent with the existing project basis carry forward arrangements which limit compounding of the long term bond rate plus 15 percentage points to expenditure incurred within five years before a project's production licence came into force.

The transfer provisions for wider deductibility of exploration expenditure will contain certain anti-avoidance measures. These will require a person to have an interest in both the project in which the expenditure was incurred and the project to which the expenditure is being transferred at the time the expenditure was incurred, at the time of transfer and any intervening period. This will prevent a person from, say, acquiring a project with an income stream only to absorb undeducted exploration expenditure. In all circumstances transfer must be made to the project with the most recent production licence and the oldest eligible expenditures must be taken up first.

To minimise the risk that project specific expenditure for unsuccessful or marginal projects would not be deducted, the amendments will provide for an order of deductions that will ensure project specific expenditures are written off first. The order of deductions for RRT liable projects will be non-transferable project expenditure, including general expenditure and pre-l July 1990 exploration expenditure, project specific exploration expenditure, closing down expenditure and other project transferable exploration expenditure. These important changes to the resource rent tax have an estimated cost to revenue of $305m in 1990-91 and $450m in 1991-92.

A revenue positive outcome is expected in 1992-93 and in subsequent years. These changes come at a substantial cost to fiscal policy in the first two years of the operation of the new measures. The Government believes that this is a price worth paying for the greater efficiency and certainty which these taxation arrangements provide. It is important, therefore, that the elements of the resource rent taxation regime be held constant in future years when the new RRT arrangement starts to recoup revenues for the nation.

Put more bluntly, the producers will have secured a windfall benefit in these early years of the new arrangement and will not be entitled to a change of arrangements when the RRT starts to bite in subsequent years. I present the explanatory memorandum which contains a more detailed explanation of the provisions of the Bill.
I commend the Bill to the House and, in so doing, thank my colleague the Minister for Resources (Mr Griffiths) for his important involvement in the negotiation of these new arrangements.
Debate (on motion by Mr Reith) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Beddall, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beddall The Hon D.P.

TALKER.NAME: Mr BEDDALL
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Small Business and Customs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
The Customs Amendment Bill proposes to amend the Customs Act 1901 to:
(i) implement certain reforms to the current anti-dumping subsidisation regime which were announced by the Government in the 12 March industry statement, and
(ii) effect technical drafting changes to the internal body search provisions of the Act to clarify the nature and function of judges' orders made under those provisions.
The proposed amendments to Part XVB of the Act, relating to the anti-dumping and subsidisation provisions, focus on three aspects of Australia's anti-dumping and countervailing system:

* clause 7 of the Bill proposes the inclusion of several new subsections modelled on the relevant sections of the United States Tariff Act of 1930, to expand the definition of an Australian industry, and thus effectively allow material injury suffered by vertically integrated agricultural industries as a result of the dumping or subsidisation of processed agricultural products to be taken into consideration when determining the material injury caused by the dumping of such processed products;

* clause 8 of the Bill proposes to simplify the determination of provisional dumping measures by providing for the calculation of a full dumping margin at the preliminary finding stage of a dumping or subsidisation inquiry; and

* clause 9 of the Bill proposes a modification to the provision in the Act relating to the three-year sunset period for dumping measures, to ensure that any such measures which may be in place for a particular product apply for three years, unless earlier revoked.

In making these changes, the Australian Government retains its commitment to promoting a fair and orderly international trading system under the auspices of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade (GATT). The Government will, as appropriate, review and if necessary amend Australia's legislative provisions and actions taken under the Act in the light of future developments in the international economic and trading arena, particularly in regard to our continuing obligations under the GATT and the GATT anti-dumping code.

The principal objective of the anti-dumping amendments in this Bill is to provide that, where agricultural producers who are vertically integrated with the processors to whom they sell their products suffer material injury as a result of dumping or subsidisation of processed products, the agricultural producers will be included as part of the relevant Australian industry and thus will be taken into consideration in cases involving those imported processed products.

The new provision in clause 7 of the Bill will apply to those involved in the production of crops, including viticulture, horticulture and apiculture, as well as the rearing of livestock, and the conduct of forestry and fishing operations. These changes recognise the vulnerability of vertically integrated agricultural producers, who are generally price takers in their markets, with the prices they receive dependent on the prices their buyers are able to command for their processed products. Agricultural producers can, therefore, be materially injured as a result of the impact of dumping or subsidisation on the processors to whom they sell their produce.

The new provision in relation to the definition of `industry' has been modelled on existing United States legislation which serves a similar purpose. It includes strict tests of vertical integration. For a primary producer to be considered part of a processed agricultural product industry, the raw agricultural goods of the primary producer must be devoted substantially or completely to the processed agricultural goods and the processed goods must be derived substantially or completely from the raw agricultural goods.

In addition, vertical integration is subject to an economic test requiring either a close relationship between the movement in the prices of the raw agricultural goods and the processed goods, or that the raw agricultural goods constitute a significant proportion of the production cost of the processed agricultural goods.

The second objective of the anti-dumping amendments in this Bill relates to the three-year sunset provision on anti-dumping and countervailing measures. This was introduced into the Australian system in 1988 as a safeguard against the use of anti-dumping and countervailing measures as a means of long term industry protection. The Government continues to regard the sunset provision in section 269tm of the Act as a valuable aspect of the system.

At present, however, new anti-dumping or countervailing measures imposed while a measure is in place against the same product from a different source may only be applied for as long as the existing measure on that product remains in place. The implications of this are that, where companies engaged in injurious dumping into Australia seek to avoid duties by relocating their operations, any new dumping measures imposed on the relocated source will terminate at the same time as the original measure-no matter how short a time the new measure has been in place. Given the time, effort and cost involved in pursuing action against dumping, the shortened life of such anti-dumping measures is a disincentive for Australian industry to seek action where companies dumping products move their source to avoid the penalties for dumping. Clause 9 of the Bill will therefore ensure that, except in the case of a successful request for revocation, all anti-dumping and countervailing measures will be applied for the full three years.

Finally, with regard to the anti-dumping amendments in this Bill, clause 8 effectively provides that the Australian Customs Service will no longer calculate `non-injurious' free on board values for the purpose of setting provisional dumping measures. While that calculation, which attempts to set the price at which a product could be exported to Australia without causing injury to the Australian industry, will continue to be used at the final finding stage for the setting of dumping or countervailing duties, the elimination of it and use instead of the full margin of dumping or subsidisation at the preliminary finding stage will simplify the investigation process and will assist with the reduction in the time taken to process anti-dumping and countervailing cases.

The other amendments proposed by this Bill effect technical drafting changes to the new internal body search provisions of part XII of the Act, and relate in particular to the conferral of power on judges to make the detention and internal search orders which were part of the Customs (Detention and Search) Act 1990 which was assented to in October last year and commenced operation on 24 April this year. These amendments, contained in clauses 3, 4, 5, and 6 of the Bill, are explained in detail in the explanatory memorandum to the Bill.
The proposed amendments in this Bill have no direct financial implications. I commend the Bill to the House and present the accompanying explanatory memorandum.
Debate (on motion by Dr Kemp) adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: SOCIAL SECURITY (JOB SEARCH AND NEWSTART) AMENDMENT BILL 1991[COGNATE BILLS:SOCIAL SECURITY LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1991SOCIAL SECURITY (REWRITE) TRANSITION BILL 1991]

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 8 May, on motion by Mr Howe:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before the debate on this Bill is resumed, I remind the House that it has been agreed that a general debate be allowed covering the Social Security (Job Search and Newstart) Amendment Bill, the Social Security Legislation Amendment Bill and the Social Security (Rewrite) Transition Bill.

DEBATE.TITLE: SOCIAL SECURITY (JOB SEARCH AND NEWSTART) AMENDMENT BILL 1991

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Connolly Mr D.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The national unemployment rate continues to climb. The official rate is 9.9 per cent. Everyone in this House knows that when the shibboleths of the Government are stripped away the reality is that there are in excess of one million Australians who are seeking full time work. It is indeed a catastrophe for those people and for their families.

SPEECH.PARA: While we hear Ministers in the Government doing their best to defend an intolerable and impossible situation, the sorry facts are that today we are facing a recession which, in the words of the Treasurer (Mr Keating), we had to have. It is therefore very timely that we should be debating in this House, both yesterday and today, the Social Security (Job Search and Newstart) Amendment Bill 1991 together with cognate Bills dealing with the Job Search and Newstart arrangements. This package of arrangements was determined by the Government in its February 1990 economic statement. It was in response to-and I emphasise this fact-the view of the Opposition throughout the last Parliament that the Australian people expected nothing less than a far more active approach to the handling of the unemployment problem. I hasten to add this fact: after the last major recession facing the Australian people in the early 1980s, it took over six years to see the end of that large proportion of the population who lost their jobs. They found great difficulty in getting back to the work force over subsequent years. Nevertheless, the package before us today has the support of the Opposition in general terms. It is at least a step forward in the right direction, although one could question, in detailed terms, whether it goes far enough.

Leading economic forecaster, Phil Ruthven, has predicted that Australia's unemployment rate will reach 14 per cent to 15 per cent by 1993, if not before. If one looks at the 1982-83 recession one sees that it took at least six years for the unemployment rate to recover to pre-recessionary levels. We ask the Treasurer and the Government: how long will it take this time? As of February there were 28 unemployed people for every job vacancy. This was caused by a Treasurer and by a government which, as I said, gave us a recession which we had to have. According to the latest seasonally adjusted figures, there are almost 845,000 people unemployed in Australia. Of those, nearly 600,000 are receiving unemployment benefits, a 55 per cent increase on the annual average of the previous financial year.

The Government has failed to address adequately the fundamental changes occurring in the workplace internationally. In the last few years we have witnessed dynamic economic and political change across the world. As the ground has shifted between east and west, and new alliances and trading blocks have emerged, world markets have become increasingly unsettled and increasingly more competitive. The future for Australian industry is, at best, uncertain. The rules have changed. As we still try to comprehend the impact of the information and technological revolution, the future becomes much harder to predict. But as the world moves closer together, there is a general consensus that industries have to become leaner and more competitive. To cope with the technological and information revolution occurring across the world, Australia needs a flexible workplace. While there has been a recognition of the need to become internationally competitive, the Government's failure has been that it has not adequately addressed the challenges of the future over the last eight years.

With the Government's reliance on accord mark 6, despite the recommendations of the Industrial Relations Commission, and the strict regulatory approach to employment, Australia will continue to adjust poorly to the rapid changes in the international economy. There is no alternative except to take the approach of the Opposition parties. We must move much more rapidly towards a freer market situation where employees and employers can negotiate their own terms and conditions of employment. Unless that is done, unemployment will continue to grow. A small domestic economy such as Australia will never be able to afford to retrain everyone who loses a job. As I have said twice now, I wonder how many years we will have to wait before the unemployed of this current recession will once again find their way into the labour market and how many will never find their way into that market.

Increased international competitiveness means only one thing for this country-a huge overhaul. Top heavy with self-perpetuating bureaucracies, intransigent unions in the sectors that matter the most, and a gutless guiding hand of the present Government which is trying to keep its mates and selective interest groups happy at any cost is not preparing Australians for the necessary changes for a better future. If this Government wants to keep long term unemployment levels down, it must act as a facilitator for industry to move in the appropriate directions. It must encourage industry in developing regional economic links, not just ad hoc grants that do not even cover the cost of one regional meeting. We must be tangibly encouraging trade and professional organisations to establish networks throughout the Asia-Pacific region.

Services form the largest sector of the Australian economy and now account for about three-quarters of gross domestic product and employment. However, at present there is not even an adequate statistical base on the export of services from which to develop and plan appropriate policies and strategies and it is the largest and fastest growing sector of the Australian economy. The Government also needs to gain a greater understanding of the rapid changes in technology, telecommunications and the economic nature of information and develop appropriate planning and policy responses. We failed to capitalise on the computer age. At this rate, we will also fail to capitalise on the information age. By failing to capitalise on the international growth areas, our long term unemployment queues will only lengthen.

Furthermore, the obstacles for development of our industries that have a natural or developed international comparative advantage must be removed. When we have to import coloured wool to knit a jumper, something is terribly wrong with the industrial base of this country. We must ensure that there are no impediments to the development of industries where value is added to our abundant natural resources through the development of higher stage processing.

The Business Council of Australia said that in developing successful clusters of internationally competitive industries we must tackle transport, construction and energy costs, and infrastructure provision. The coalition alone is seriously tackling these reform issues. We can no longer afford the cost of this Government's failure. If the Government continues to move at its present snail-like pace, we will be left behind in the competitiveness race and hundreds of thousands of hard working Australians will find themselves in a lengthening dole queue with no future prospects of employment.

The first critical problem areas to surface are the unemployment rates for young people and people aged over 45. The proposed changes to unemployment policy which have been put forward in this legislation are done so in the context of substantial and rising rates of unemployment. The legislation has elements to protect the hardest hit age groups but, in many respects, the changes merely formalise existing practices. It is yet another bandaid approach by the Hawke Government. This is the so-called active employment strategy. As I said, it was the Opposition parties that previously urged the Government to go from a reactionary policy of income support to a pro-active policy of income support and job development.

Yet even today not enough training places are available. In many other countries training and education facilities are used virtually 365 days a year-morning, noon and night. By contrast, many of our facilities lie dormant for a large part of the year. The United States of America, for the last 30 years at least, has had a semester system ensuring some prospect of effective utilisation of resources for the four quarters of the year. Not only are more training and educational opportunities created but we give a future to our academic community, so many of whom today are leaving this country because they simply see no opportunities.
The issue of expanding training and education opportunities must be tackled far more seriously by this Government and impediments removed.

Unless limitations are removed a further consequence is that there will be no opportunity for the private sector also to get into the fundamental role of better training for employees to ensure that they have the qualifications and the experience necessary for Australian industrial development. As the Government will never realistically be able to adequately train or retrain, at its cost, all the jobless resulting from the expected economic changes of the future, surely we need to consider selective work for the dole programs. Considering the horrendous levels of youth unemployment, more flexible training programs need to be assessed.

It has been my experience that youth work programs can be successful if they are established in areas with high unemployment, a supportive community, a strong local government structure and where suitable work is available. All options need to be considered when we are facing a continuing increase in the number of long term unemployed, especially unemployed youth. It is interesting to note that long term unemployment was defined as six weeks in 1974, whereas in 1987 the mean duration of unemployment was 64 weeks and the median duration was 31 weeks. I wonder what the figure is today. I think the evidence is clear: it is well in excess of even the median duration of 31 weeks or the 64 weeks mean duration that I cited.

With regard to the Opposition's policy of providing benefits for the long term unemployed, we have proposed that a special benefit be made available to eligible people after nine months. I have heard on many occasions Ministers and members of the Government making fun of this policy and claiming that all we are proposing to do is to extend the period of unemployment benefits for an indefinite period while calling it by another name. This is not our intention.

As I said initially, the whole objective of our policy is to have a pro-active policy, not a reactive one. While the changes the Government is making are an improvement, its policy is still basically a reactive policy. Our view is that if people know that they are on unemployment benefits initially for a maximum period of nine months, the onus will be on them to do whatever is conceivably possible to ensure that they are available for work, if work is available, and that they utilise their opportunities to seek that employment.

The evidence which came forward a number of years ago in the Cass inquiry into unemployment benefits emphasises a need for this type of policy approach. It is quite clear that when people lose their jobs, their initial reaction after the shock of that failure is to say, `I will go and get another job'. They work extremely hard for six weeks to three months to achieve that objective. However, at the end of nine months, morale is beginning to fail-if there is a continuous stream of failed efforts in their attempts to find adequate employment. That is the time at which we should be helping those people-at nine months; not at 12 months as is proposed in the legislation. Frankly, by 12 months, so many people have thrown in the towel; it has been too difficult. They have made a few efforts, but they have failed.

To simply say, as this legislation does, that those people will be required to present themselves every fortnight at the Commonwealth Employment Service (CES) office to fill in a form to show that they have applied to at least two companies during that period, frankly, is rubbish. There is no adequate system in place by which the information on those forms can be tested. Nor is there any prospect, with over one million people now going through the process, that CES will have adequate resources to make that policy effective.

The Government's doctoring of unemployment figures for the under-twenties has been exposed by unpublished official regional labour force statistics of the Australian Bureau of Statistics (ABS). These show that, over the last year, 110,700 full time teenage jobs have been lost in Australia, but total teenage unemployment has gone up by only 41,000. That means that almost 70,000 young people have disappeared from the statistics. The real unemployment rate among under-twenties looking for full time work in Australia is 36 per cent-the worst ever recorded-rather than the 25 per cent official figure cited by the Government.

The worst capital city figures for youth unemployment occur in Melbourne. Melbourne's horrific youth unemployment rate of 27.1 per cent has been massively understated and really stands at around 45 per cent. More than 33,000 young Melburnians are still looking for either full time or part time work. More than half of the 96,400 young people still with jobs have only been able to get part time work. The pressure on their families is massive. Is it any wonder that so many are now living on the streets?

The second worst capital city for youth unemployment in Australia is Hobart. The official youth unemployment rate of 31 per cent massively understates the real level of youth unemployment, which is about 42 per cent. According to these unpublished regional ABS labour force statistics, we can also adjust Adelaide's 26.2 per cent full time youth unemployment rate to around 35 per cent; Perth's 26.6 per cent, to 40 per cent; Brisbane's 24.6 per cent, to 33 per cent; and Sydney's 18.1 per cent, to 29 per cent. In all of these cases, with the exception of New South Wales, Labor governments are in power. The statistics sadly illustrate the failure of their administrations.

For the older unemployed, Department of Social Security (DSS) data shows that, while a smaller proportion of people become unemployed, those who do tend to stay on benefits far longer. The DSS statistics show that older people find it very difficult to re-enter the work force. We will be amending the proposal to relax reporting requirements for older unemployed workers, as the provisions proposed by the Government are discriminatory. It is not acceptable to imply that people over 55 years of age do not have to attempt to seek work and to remove their requirement to put in a form every two weeks, as does everybody else. It is precisely because of such attitudes that some employers fail to accept that people should be given work on the basis of ability, not on the basis of their age.

The ANZ Bank figures for April indicate that the number of job vacancies have dropped by 46 per cent since the same time last year and by 68 per cent since April 1989. The Skilled Vacancy Survey (SVS) released by the Department of Employment, Education and Training has revealed that for the three months to April 1991 the SVS index dropped by 58 per cent from the figure for the three months to April 1990. It also showed that the largest decreases in the index occurred in woodworking trades, 56 per cent; construction trades, 41 per cent; food and services trades, 34 per cent; and health occupations, 29 per cent. The total number of advertised vacancies in trade occupations for the three months to April 1991 dropped by a massive 68 per cent from the figure for the three month period to April 1990. I referred earlier to the Newstart activity agreement. We do not regard the Government's proposals in this area as adequate. We believe that no distinction should be made between beneficiaries purely on the basis of age.

In conclusion, I would like to draw attention to the mythical growth in employment bandied about by the drowning rats in the present Government. For some time, the Treasurer and the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) have gloated about how their economic policies have resulted in the creation of 1.4 million new jobs since 1983. This figure is a fraud, and a complete distortion of reality. What the Government has neglected to add is that it has not allowed for the normal increases due to population growth, which have been calculated in an analysis of the ABS labour force survey.

The distortion is enormous. Nearly all of the 1.4 million figure was as a result of population growth, not economic policies. Certainly, it was not as a result of the policies of this Labor Government. The most alarming finding of this analysis was that the increase in the number of people in full time employment from March 1983 to March 1991 actually was less than the increase we should have seen through population growth alone. In fact, factors other than population-factors such as the economic policies of the Prime Minister and the Treasurer-have caused the expected increase in the number of people employed through population growth alone to drop by 45,300. You cannot get more rubbery than that. It is a sign of a government on its last legs that doctors such serious statistical evidence of the state of the economy.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McHugh Ms J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I, too, will address the Social Security (Job Search and Newstart) Amendment Bill. It is not really very easy to be putting forward such tough legislation in such tough times. Today's unemployment figures are, of course, unacceptably high to all of us. No-one, least of all those who are unemployed, can deny that the Government's top priority must be to get people back to work, and everyone is agreed on that.

SPEECH.PARA: The big difference between us in government and the coalition forces in government is that if unemployment is high-which has now occurred under both governments, and it is shameful-the coalition has little concern for the victims of unemployment. It has no programs. Indeed, the usual tactic of the Opposition when it is in government as a coalition is simply to transfer blame to the unemployed themselves, and then to dump them. We do not. We recognise our responsibility and, I repeat, the first responsibility is to get people into jobs and for those who are unemployed to have some decent programs.

This legislation is certainly tough, as I have said. Indeed, it is fair to say that it would be easier to introduce it in less tough times, as when it was first proposed. Nevertheless, it is part of a concerned and careful approach by government to the problem of how best to assist those who are out of a job.

For a start, we will not make the mistakes that were made in relation to those who became unemployed as a result of the previous recession in 1982. We must avoid the problems that were caused then. Those problems included the erosion of skills and the resultant increasing difficulties in finding suitable jobs. The expanding labour market from 1984 to 1990 which we created-the 1.6 million new jobs-nevertheless left the unskilled or deskilled workers behind, and they became the long term unemployed.

Commonwealth Employment Service (CES) figures show that the percentage of people unemployed for over 12 months has fallen now from 31.2 per cent of unemployed people in July 1988 to 23 per cent in July 1990. That is since our labour market programs, like Newstart and Skillshare, got under way-the programs that the honourable member for Bradfield (Mr Connolly) was just imagining he had proposed but that we actually put into place.

At the same time, other figures show that the average duration of unemployment in 1984-that is, after the 1982 recession-was 47.8 weeks. It went up to well over 12 months but by 1990-that is, after our labour market programs were in place-the average had fallen again to 46.7 weeks. Government policy with respect to reducing long term unemployment has had a positive effect, and the positive measures of assistance to long term unemployed people do work. This philosophy is continued with this Bill. Job Search will remove the risk of long term unemployment by giving newly unemployed people special Job Search assistance within the first three months of unemployment where it is most needed. Newstart will provide specialised and intensive assistance for those people who become unemployed for 12 months or longer, with a view to retraining those people, and income support will continue while this is occurring.

As the Minister for Community Services and Health (Mr Howe) said in his second reading speech, Newstart aims to integrate income support measures with labour market assistance training programs to assist the long term unemployed-that is, those unemployed for more than 12 months. Job Search, on the other hand, will help prevent long term unemployment wherever possible-in the words of the Minister, deal with problems before they become entrenched. With Job Search, the early intervention of the CES must help. Beneficiaries will be required to participate in labour market programs and/or vocational training programs with the aim of improving skills.

It is only in the last 10 years that long term unemployment has become a serious problem. The 1982-83 recession, we now know, created a large pool of long term unemployed who, if they are to re-enter the labour market, require retraining assistance. Newstart hopes to give such assistance by integrating income support measures with retraining assistance. Under the procedures outlined in this Bill, the CES will have a far greater role in assisting the long term unemployed than is the case now. Therefore, it is absolutely essential that the Government ensure that the CES has sufficient people to take on the extra load; if it does not, the active employment strategy will be ineffective. I repeat, it is absolutely essential that the CES has sufficient and well trained staff. I understand that the Minister is fully aware of the need to ensure that the CES is given sufficient resources to make the active employment strategy work. I urge him to continue to monitor this level of resources once the strategy is up and running.

Some Opposition members have spoken about bureaucratic nightmares and other alleged problems that the active employment strategy would cause. It has been asserted that Newstart will not work because of the workload on CES staff. The Opposition's answer is simply to reduce the length of time available to a person on Job Search allowance from the 12 months proposed in this Bill to nine months-and after nine months, what then? There is no plan to help. There is no program. The real distinction that we are making is not on age, it is on experience; it is on the amount of time a person has had to spend out of the work force; it recognises what happens to people when they have been out of the work force for a long time.

The Opposition is full of concern for the unemployed whilst the Opposition is in opposition. In government, it quickly shifts the blame for unemployment back on to the individuals and makes them fend for themselves. Also, the Opposition's programs have been extremely sloppy when in government. For instance, it talks about being pro-active and about having labour market programs which, of course, we introduced. When in government it talked about dole bludgers and yet there was no work test to get the unemployment benefit; there was no requirement to register with the CES to get the unemployment benefit; there was no requirement for the individual to front up to the social security office-people could send their aunt, uncle or cousin. It was sloppy.

I think the Opposition did not have the mentality to care for people who were the victims of unemployment. This Government recognises that in the overwhelming majority of cases the individual loses his or her job through no fault of his or her own-through the fault, probably, of a recession as now and as in 1982-1983 and, therefore, the Government has a responsibility to help those people find work.

It is very interesting to hear the Opposition quote the Cass report. It was under this Government that the Minister, then Minister for Social Security, set up the first review of the social security system for 40 years under Professor Cass. It was Professor Cass who found that what people most want to do is get back into work; and it was Professor Cass who forced this Government to look at the specific needs of specific groups in the population and the different needs of different unemployed.

The CES does help people find work, but this Bill will build on that philosophy and give unemployed people intensive assistance to help them find a job. Retraining forms a major part of the strategy and, particularly with the recession we are now in, it becomes essential that the Government allocate additional resources to training programs. In fact, that is what has happened. The Minister outlined in his second reading speech that an additional $227m is to be provided for labour market programs until the end of 1993-94, giving over 50,000 additional program places each year. Also, an additional $105m for training was announced in the recent industry statement.

The Bill should ensure that when the jobs are available again-and, I repeat, getting people back to work and building on the 1.6 million jobs created since 1983 must be the top priority-unemployed people will not be left behind as they were before. They will be able to have access to skills training programs which will assist them to re-enter the work force, not leave them to languish without help as the Opposition would have them do and as the Opposition always does.

A crucial part of this is the Newstart activity agreement proposal. Concerns have been expressed about these activity agreements by, amongst others, the Australian Council of Social Service (ACOSS) and the Welfare Rights Centre.

I will mention some of these concerns because they are very important. First, there are too few training places. I have already mentioned the large boost in places, but the Government must continue to monitor these and, if necessary, provide more. The active employment strategy demands that sufficient places be provided so as to ensure that when employment does pick up, when jobs are available again, everyone benefits and that the long term unemployed are not left behind.

ACOSS has also mentioned the problem of CES staffing, and it is spot-on. I repeat-and I will say it as often as I can-that we must ensure that the CES has staff to carry out this program as it wants to carry it out. The determination, the will and the understanding is there in the CES staff on whom we rely and on whom we have relied in the past.

A third concern that has been mentioned is the nature of the agreements themselves. These will be negotiated on an individual basis with each client receiving a separate agreement tailored to specific needs. ACOSS has expressed concern about the compulsory nature of these agreements and about the fact that the client is in a disadvantaged position; that is, it is feared that some clients may be told, `Sign this agreement or you will get no income support'.

It is also true, as ACOSS points out, that about 25 per cent of the long term unemployed who get to 12 months unemployment will probably have some sort of learning difficulty, so extra care is needed with these people. ACOSS also mentions the notification period, the need for a cooling off period and that there is a need to ensure that the agreement negotiation process is genuine and not harsh. I said before, it is tough legislation. We must ensure that in its implementation it is totally fair. Of course, compulsion already existed in the old unemployment benefits system with the work test. As I said, we introduced the work test. The Opposition did not care at all.

In this regard the guidelines being drawn up to guide CES officers in such negotiations are crucial. I urge the Minister to ensure that groups such as ACOSS are fully consulted and involved in this process. I urge, too, that CES officers are consulted and are part of getting this process together as a fair process. One of the major concerns of ACOSS was the lack of appeal rights. I am very glad that the lack of appeal rights in the original Bill has been overcome and that the Government amendments have resolved that.

In conclusion, the philosophy of the active employment strategy should be supported, but the concerns expressed by groups like ACOSS should and must be addressed if the strategy is to work. This program confronts attitudes on all sides. It confronts the long held attitudes of the employers and of some of the unemployed. Those attitudes will change. It may well be 18 months before any really good results come from this new strategy. Some people are simply not work ready after long periods of unemployment. Unfortunately, employers have shown that they are wary of the long term unemployed; they are far more likely to put them on last. That is their attitude. They will have to change that attitude. They will have to understand that the long term unemployed are being made work ready by these programs.

It is important that employers-and all of us-understand the new strategy. This is the biggest change to deliver help to the unemployed since the 1940s. Every one of us has to understand the impact of these changes. It has been suggested to me perhaps there should be active employment strategy briefings for all backbenchers in their electorates. Certainly the public must be made more aware of the changes than they are now so that unemployed people fronting up to a CES office will understand exactly what responsibilities they have and what responsibilities the CES has to them. So I hope there will be a lot of publicity for this program.

I conclude as I began. It is a terrible thing for a government to have to confront the fact that unemployment figures are so high. There is no more important priority for us than to get the unemployed back to work. I repeat that the big difference between us and the coalition is that in Government we still care about those who are unemployed. This Bill brings in measures to assist them better than they have been assisted in the past.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tuckey Mr C.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —The very last words of the honourable member for Phillip (Ms McHugh) were of interest to me. The honourable member said, `We still care'. Honourable members opposite should care-they put the unemployed there; no-one else. They have created the disaster which has been brought to our attention today by the Australian Bureau of Statistics in its labour force figures for April 1991 when it tells us that unemployment has now almost reached 10 per cent-this double digit figure that the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) was so scurrilous about when he reported those circumstances that occurred as a result of the national drought in 1982-83. This Government has no excuse such as a drought, although that might be impending. If it is, one might wonder what figures we will be debating in this place in another few months.

SPEECH.PARA: We do know that the price drought is upon the rural industries. I do not believe the effects of that price drought have yet totally affected the metropolitan areas which are the principal beneficiaries of the money that is earned and produced in country electorates such as my own.

We are debating the Social Security (Job Search and Newstart) Amendment Bill relating to changes in the unemployment arrangements. Of course, they carry some good names-Job Search and Newstart-but basically they are still unemployment benefits proposals. I am reminded of one of the Government's other efforts in this area. I wonder how many people remember Priority One, the disaster which nevertheless allowed the Government to spend taxpayers' money on advertisements such as the one I am holding? This evening government members will bring to this place the Political Broadcasts and Political Disclosures Bill. That is part of their $250m to $260m program of spending the taxpayers' money to advertise dud programs.

One might wonder what they have already prepared of this nature which they will bring in to tell people what a wonderful thing they are doing for the unemployed with these new things which will waste more of the taxpayers' money. No, they do not want anybody to be able to advertise on television-they want to know where every penny comes from. I believe they are correct in that. But I wonder what will be in their new disclosures legislation about this sort of caper?

Priority One had a full two page, $30,000 advertisement advertising something but not saying one word about it-not one word. There were pictures of kids and pictures of the Prime Minister, but not one piece of information as to how the program might work. One might wonder whether this will happen with the next lot.

One might wonder how truthful and decent this Government is when it sets about addressing party funding, which is what we will be talking about when we talk of disclosures and putting limits on this Government and governments of the future as to how they use or abuse taxpayers' funds in announcing their projects. We will see how dinkum the Government is in these matters.

The simple fact is that this legislation was announced by the Government during the election campaign at a time of substantially more economic buoyancy. It was announced as a reaction to the proposals announced in the Opposition's Economic Action Plan. Members of the Government panicked. The community at that stage-in a time, as I said, of somewhat better economic circumstances-had had enough of seeing people advertising thousands of jobs and nobody applying for them, yet there was a very substantial hard core of unemployed.

It is interesting how the honourable member for Kalgoorlie (Mr Campbell) finds himself so frequently in conflict with his own party these days. He is a great electoral strategist. He has a wonderful Labor electorate-lots of hardworking miners, lots of hardworking pastoral workers and, even a substantial degree, I would imagine, of public servants-all in remote areas. They are people who call a spade a spade.

The honourable member for Kalgoorlie over time has woken up to some of their attitudes to the unemployed. These are hardworking, good Labor voters, and they were fed up, just as they were fed up with most of the other things that the honourable member for Kalgoorlie seems to be putting on the agenda all the time.

I make this point because the facts were that the Government made these decisions because it discovered huge support for what the Opposition was talking about at that time, and that was to discontinue unemployment benefit-dole payments, as we have known them to date-after nine months and require people to demonstrate that they genuinely needed assistance if they were to continue receiving government assistance: to make it harder, to make sure that people had genuinely tried.

That is basically what these two proposals are about. The first stage has been extended to 12 months and the second, of course, to as long as is necessary, but with conditions; and the conditions relate primarily to a person seeking training and making some genuine effort to become useable in the work force.

Of course, day after day in this place the Leader of the House (Mr Beazley), the Prime Minister and the Treasurer (Mr Keating) get up and say, `Your policy'-which they have copied and which we are dealing with today-`cuts off the dole at nine months and leaves people on the scrap heap'. What an outrageous statement! It is part of the good old Australian Labor Party's Goebbels technique-tell an untruth often enough and people will begin to believe it. It was never our policy. It was quite clear and, as I recollect, the annual allowance for the special benefits we proposed was of the order of $800m a year-quite a significant sum. Yet they stand up here, as they have in the last week or 10 days, trying to create a myth that in fact unemployed people were going to completely lose support under our proposals. It is not true; it never was true. It is clear to be seen in black and white. It is supported by the Government's copy cat action here today. Those opposite believed they had to do it.

There is another difference: the Opposition chose to do it for proper reasons; the Government chose to do it because its pollsters told it that it had better get on the band wagon. This is the Government of pollsters; this is not the Government of well programmed decisions.

I think it is worth while to look at the massive unemployment situation that is confronting Australia today. There have been generally very buoyant world economic conditions throughout the life of the Hawke Labor Government. This Government has not had the recessions of international standing that occurred during the Fraser Government. It has not had the oil shock, with its massive effects on international inflation. And for all the words that we get around here about inflation under the Fraser Government, nobody ever again wants to make that international comparison which showed Australia's inflation rate in quite a good light; we just get these broad statements.

The other day the Prime Minister was going crook because, he said, someone had selectively quoted from a document. Let us get down to selective quoting. The Treasurer, in eight years, has mentioned the 1982-83 drought once, and that was when he pointed out that Gittins had used that year as a tax base-and, of course, it was very low because farmers had no income. We are just finding out again the economic effects of farmers having no income. That is coming on the tail of what the Government did to the employed people of Australia through its economic policies.

It is not just the economic policy of high interest rates that did it. In fact, that was just another reactionary move of this Government. The real reason that we have the circumstances we have today is that the Treasurer misread the economy in his first Budget, when he came in, as some might remember, with his inherited deficits theory. That is the same argument as someone going along to his bank and saying, `I have gone bankrupt over that business I bought two years ago, but it is all the fault of the previous owner'. Once one is given control of the shop, it is one's job to get the figures right. As we know today, of that $8 billion of Budget deficit, $7.6 billion was new spending initiatives, and they were there deliberately. Going back to the old Hayden economic theory, his responses to just about every Fraser Budget was to attack it for having insufficient deficit. Of course, the Treasurer, having got his lectures from Jack Lang and Rex Connor, came to his office with a high deficit theory and Keynesian economic solutions to the then recession, which, he continues to tell us, was caused by bad economic management, when in fact it was caused by the worst drought in recent history.

When he fired up the Australian economy with $8 billion in the first year and a total of $26 billion in the first four years, he overlooked the naturally occurring recovery substantially caused by rain and the excellent practices of the Fraser Government which financed farmers during that drought to keep their breeding stock on hand so that there was a very speedy recovery in the economy.

When he put all that extra money in, it was more than the economy needed. But he did not stop there. For quite proper reasons, he decided to float the Australian economy, but he never ran around to see what people were going to do about that. Today we are actually imposing a training levy on people. It would not have been a bad idea if we had given a bit of training to our entrepreneurs as to how to handle their first taste of freedom. They literally went mad with money. I heard an instance the other day of one of those entrepreneurs who made a major take-over offer. He rang the manager of his bank in the same building and said, `I could need $800m this afternoon', and that afternoon he got the cheque. He got the cheque for $800m!

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I take a point of order. I understand that the debate this afternoon is a cognate debate dealing with very specific issues relating to a Social Security Amendment Bill. Given the fact that it is a cognate debate, I suggest that the major contribution by the honourable member for O'Connor has been so wide ranging that it really has not addressed the fundamental issues of the Bill.
—In responding to the point of order, we are talking--
—Mr Deputy--

—I sat down while you took your point of order. Just sit down. You have made your point of order. Sit down. I have the floor, as the Standing Orders give me the right. I am responding to the point of order to make the point that the fundamental issue is 900,000 unemployed. I am trying to explain to the Minister, which might help him a bit, how he got to that position.
—I am seeking a ruling from the Deputy Speaker on a point of order.
—The Minister stood on a point of order and I am responding to that point of order, and then he can give an answer.

—I ask the honourable members to resume their seats. I point out that it is a cognate debate and speakers have been given some latitude, and I am sure that the honourable member for O'Connor will address himself to the matter before the chair.

—Thank you, Mr Deputy Speaker. I am determined to. I was just referring to some background. This is a Bill about unemployment and, of course, some of the Government's proposals to handle it in the future, and I am trying to explain to the Government-and it is a pity that it unfortunately has not learnt this argument-how it messed it up and what it might consequently do in the future in the interests of the unemployed.

SPEECH.PARA: The honourable member for Phillip was very interested that we took some interest in the unemployed. Most of the unemployed, of course, would like a job. Jobs come from good economic management, not bad economic management, and I thought it would be rather helpful of me to give the Government some advice as to where it went wrong.

TALK.START.PARA: —How patronising.
—God save Australia! I am not patronising to all those people who are out of a job. We used to have the long term unemployed. Now we have got the long term employed unemployed.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me just get back. Having overheated the economy with borrowed money-borrowed by government and by the private sector-at the very point when we had a cyclical commodities peak, the Treasurer decided to put the fire hose on, with high interest rates. The end result was that as the economy started to slow up he drove it into recession with a fire hose. The evidence is here before us today in the figures from the Australian Bureau of Statistics: the April 1991 seasonally adjusted estimate of unemployed persons rose by 66,900 to 844,000. It is the largest monthly rise recorded by the survey.

A little while ago the Treasurer was in here trying to turn that into good news; I honestly wish it was good. But there are some aspects of the legislation that also concern me. In a simple sense, I do not think people over 55 wish to be treated differently from other people. Whether all people should report at two weeks or none should report at two weeks is one issue, but it is outrageous to suggest that a person who is 55, and therefore unlikely to get a job, will be told not to bother calling around. It is age discrimination and it should not be in the legislation.

Those people want to be perceived as trying as hard as anyone else. I do not think we should be sending them messages that there is no hope. Quietly, there is hope for them. Notwithstanding the dreadful economic circumstances and the very genuine circumstances of many people who literally cannot find work, I hope we have all learnt that by making the situation too easy we do not give people the incentive to get back into the work force.

I want to make another point. I think it is the most important point of all; I paid a lot of attention to it when I introduced the policy of the Opposition on employment and training before the last election. The point is that, wherever possible, we should not pay people to do nothing. It is not in their interests and it is not in anyone's interests. It is certainly very bad for people.

I have experienced four months in hospital. I lost incentive; I lost the desire to do anything. It is amazing how quickly the days passed. It astounded me how quickly I lost interest in wanting to do something. For that very reason alone, we should be creating circumstances where people who are unemployed are encouraged to do something. We have talked about community work, and that can be in all sorts of areas. People laugh when I ask, `What is wrong with some of the unemployed having to visit people in nursing homes?'. I make the point that some of the young may learn from the elderly. I receive letters from people asking, `Could you send us young people with a little responsibility who will stand in our swimming pools with our elderly when they go for their water treatment so that our qualified nurses can get on with looking after those in need of qualified treatment?'. Currently, they have to put their bathers on to stand in a pool. There are things like that.

There is also the opportunity for on-the job-training as a replacement for the dole. I do not want to talk about exploitation, but I believe agreements could be entered into with employers who say that at least for the time being they will not reduce their work force but will take one, two, six or 10 unemployed people to be taught and to gain job experience. The first part of work experience is learning to turn up on time and to knock off on time. They will get no more than the dole for that. I think it would be an ideal process if the employer held the dole cheque and handed it over. I think this would get a mass of people back into the employment sector. They would be trained and on the spot when the next job opportunity occurred.

By that process, we would get rid of the phantoms. Nobody wants to say they do not exist; I know they exist because I meet them. I knock around in a few industries where there are plenty of them. Anywhere there is cash there are phantoms. They are not the highest percentage, but they exist. All these processes would make that harder. We should consider those things not because we want to punish the unemployed but because we want to give them opportunities to get back into the work force. It is very important we do those things. It is unfortunate that this program does not appear to allow for that simple solution to the problem. It does not make enough use of private employment agents. We have to have ever increasing government bureaucracy when, as a employer, I know that, when I want someone, I go to a private agency because I know I will get somebody quickly and get someone who genuinely wants a job. All those things count, and why not?

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: West The Hon S.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Social Security (Job Search and Newstart) Amendment Bill represents a further development of the Government's strategy to combine income support to the huge army of unemployed with training and labour market assistance. In the process, it makes the receipt of income assistance subject to even more rigorous eligibility criteria. For example, Job Search allowance is payable for 12 months only and then is dependent upon the jobless person satisfying an activities test. In plain English, this means that unemployed people must be looking for work, be willing to work and, if requested, undertake an approved training course or involve themselves in a labour market program.

SPEECH.PARA: Furthermore, after 12 months it will be necessary for an unemployed person to enter into a Newstart activity agreement in order to be eligible for further payment of the Newstart allowance. These agreements stringently require the recipient to search for that elusive job, to accept training or retraining, paid work experience, and education, if necessary, to remove any perceived labour market disadvantage such as, say, total illiteracy, poor reading and writing skills or poor English language skills.

Given the current high-and in my view totally unacceptable-levels of unemployment, there is obviously scope for several important amendments to this legislation. New section 521 allows males of 55 to 64 1/2 years and females of 55 to 59 1/2 years to continue to receive Job Search beyond 12 months if they are considered unlikely to get a job. These age thresholds should be lowered, in my view, to 50 and 45 respectively. I have a totally different viewpoint to that put by the previous speaker, the honourable member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey).

What is the point of pursuing the rigid eligibility requirements of Job Search and Newstart for people of late middle age when at the same time the Opposition tells us that over one million people are looking for jobs and are unable to find them? Similarly, why persecute poor families by enforcing a 13-week waiting period for assistance upon education leavers when they cannot find a job or if they are turned away from a university or technical college? In this context, the waiting period is seen by many as almost vindictive in its treatment of young Australians. This waiting period should be reduced at least until the recession eases.

It cannot be denied that the underlying strategy of income assistance being linked with training and tougher compliance measures was designed for completely different labour market conditions from those which now exist in this country. To make it brutally clear, what we are proposing is not a strategy for the here and now; it was devised in early 1990 when different economic conditions prevailed. At best, it is now a strategy for the future. It may help to produce better trained people for future jobs, but it is not a strategy for the current economic situation.

We face an extremely serious policy induced recession and very depressed conditions in the national labour market. There is not one person in this Government who would deny that. Already, unfortunately, in some of the national media, this legislation is being seen as an attack on the victims of government policy. That is not meant to be so but, unfortunately, that is the way it is being seen.

The April 1991 Australian Bureau of Statistics (ABS) survey, released today, indicates that 844,000 people, or 9.9 per cent of the labour force, are now unemployed. This is 320,000 more than a year ago, when the participation rate was virtually the same as it is now. The Budget forecast was for an unemployment rate of 7.25 per cent by June 1991. In my Budget debate speech I said that this estimate was too sanguine and that, as a result of high interest rates and an overvalued Australian dollar, unemployment could rise to over 8.5 per cent. I find it personally quite depressing and distressing to be proven more than correct.

I must ask myself this question: how could the Government's advisers and senior bureaucrats, especially in the Treasury, get it all so tragically wrong? There is evidence that the figures of the Commonwealth Employment Service (CES) are higher than the sampling estimates produced by the ABS. I understand that the CES figures of people registered as unemployed or looking for work may now exceed one million Australians.

I also understand that in my area in the Illawarra region, which includes the Wollongong-Port Kembla industrial complex, which I represent in this Parliament, approximately 24,000 people are seeking employment. That is in the region between Nowra on the south coast and just north of Corrimal on the near south coast. I am told that 7,000 people have registered in the last six months. Furthermore, over 6,600 of these 24,000 are under 24 years of age and approximately 3,200 are under the age of 19.

I have to say to this House that I am dismayed by this waste of talent and ability, by the human despair and loss of self-esteem that are involved and by the lost opportunities for business and for the individual that these statistics represent. I have to complain about the sheer waste of it all.

While this Bill is important, given that it presents a strengthening of the commitment to labour market training, it is really not much use training people for non-existent jobs. It is an absence of jobs, not an absence of labour market programs, nor reluctance on the part of the unemployed to participate in those programs, that is causing massive unemployment.

I believe it now becomes more important to consider ways and means to alleviate the recession itself, to implement strategies to encourage domestic savings and increase investment in export and import replacement industries. The measures announced in the 12 March industry statement were most welcome and comprehensive, but in my strong view they did not go far enough. In short, what is to be done now? The Opposition, dominated by hard line Tory values, is of no assistance whatsoever. With its proposed $3 billion-plus of cuts on social justice program outlays it would further deflate and screw down the domestic economy. It would overturn the only positive outcome of the recession-that is, lower inflation-by imposing a hefty tax on goods and services.

It is clear to me that this recession is much deeper and more enduring than most economists, and indeed the Cabinet, anticipated. It is true that as a result of tight monetary policy and high interest rates, imports are down, slumping some 10 per cent in March and resulting in a $642m trade surplus for that month. The current account deficit has improved-24 per cent down on the figure for the same nine-month period of last financial year. When we get the consumer price index (CPI) figures for the March quarter next week, they will show a much improved performance on inflation-and that is good-of, say, 0.4 per cent for the quarter. But, welcome as they are, these gains are the results of a recession. They are the results of excessive unemployment. They are not a harbinger of a brave new trade world, nor are they an indication of an early economic recovery. Maybe they portent the reverse.

Three months ago, perhaps the expected impact of the January tax cuts and the six successive reductions in official rates were seen-certainly by me-as sufficient to get the recovery effectively under way in the September and December quarters. But what appeared eminently feasible in February now seems to have receded in May. In my view, the concern in February that an early, strong and sustained recovery, followed by a resurfacing of an inbuilt structural deficiency in the current account, would result in a secondary surge in imports, and then a 1992 upward trend in interest rates, is now completely dated. The more pressing danger is an extended recession and continued hardship in the labour market.

I think it is now time for some moderate stimulation of the domestic economy. The need is for moderate economic expansion, coupled with several measures to encourage savings, investment and further exports-that is, measures additional to those announced on 12 March.

This Bill and the measures in it are all right as far as they go, but we need to do something about the root cause of unemployment. I strongly reject the argument that fiscal policy has already been significantly loosened just because the expected Budget surplus of $8.1 billion has declined to approximately $1 billion. The decline is recession induced. We have seen unemployment benefits payments and reduced tax revenues.

It is a perversion of economic logic to screw down the domestic economy with high real interest rates and then say that the resulting lower surplus represents a looser fiscal policy. Those who subscribe to this view would probably advocate an even tougher crackdown on the unemployed-the human fallout of the economic downturn. That is exactly what the Opposition wants to do. It wants to further deflate the economy with $3,000m worth of social welfare cuts.

Official interest rates need to come down by at least one per cent over the next two months. An immediate reduction of 0.5 per cent is now justified. I hope the Reserve Bank does it tomorrow. If it does not do it tomorrow, it ought to do it next week. If it does not do it early next week, it should do after the consumer price index figures come out next Wednesday. The March quarter CPI figures will be good. Real housing and business rates are still historically very high, even given the actions to reduce rates already taken. Real variable housing rates are now about 9 per cent. Even more relevant, the differential between international and Australian rates allow scope for a fall. For example, domestic rates on 90-day bills are now 11.15 per cent. The Euro official rate in US dollars is now 5.9 per cent, a differential of 5.25 per cent. As well, United States discount rates are down 0.5 per cent in the last few days.

These significant differentials are the prime reasons why the Australian dollar is currently trading so high to the detriment of our international trading sector. The Australian dollar should and must fall, ideally to around US71c and US72c and several points on the trade weighted index. Given the deep recession, such a lowering of interest rates and the Australian dollar will not impact very greatly on inflation.

I am aware that exports of manufacturing goods have increased, but I believe that there are grounds for caution here. There has been a recent and severe decline in business investments, down by 9 per cent in the year to December last. For example, of the $24 billion of foreign investment in Australia during 1989-90, $14.4 billion was in property and tourism and only $3.1 billion was in manufacturing industry. Further, economic analysts Syntec forecast a 33 per cent fall in business spending over the last two quarters of 1991, compared with the same period in 1990.

My point tonight is not to propagate despair but to push the case for further measures to encourage domestic savings, investment, value added exports and employment to combat unemployment, which is what this debate is all about. The export facilitation scheme which offers credits against import tariffs for value added to the final export product-which has already been implemented in the motor vehicle industry and is to be implemented in the textiles, clothing and footwear industries-should be expanded to cover a much wider range of elaborately transformed products. Why not? Australia has already reduced protection-an action which I support-by a greater margin than any other trading nation. Given their own track records, I cannot take seriously any alleged hidden subsidy-type objections from members of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, including the European Community nations, the United States of America, and Japan.

Despite the recent negative Industrial Relations Commission decision on the additional 3 per cent employer contribution to industry superannuation, as proposed in accord mark 6, the superannuation investment portfolios will continue to expand. The Government should consider legislation to require a small percentage of these funds to be invested in certain broadly defined business and industry areas. This does not involve `picking winners' on a company or project basis. It means that government and superannuation funds should not resile from their responsibility to ensure that a moderate proportion of this investment arising from industry and award based superannuation should be steered towards the industries which must provide future exports, efficient and competitive import replacement and, above all, jobs and growth.

Furthermore, the United Kingdom initiative of tax exempt special savings accounts should be considered by this Government. This scheme offers tax relief to small savers through tax exemptions for accrued interest on limited investments for a fixed period; for example, investments to #9,000 sterling for five years without the withdrawal of capital. Another option would be to tax only the real interest over the period of the investments. We need to encourage domestic savings and the small savers of this country.

Australia's current recession is home-grown, brought on by the Government's perceived need to restrain imports and inflation by tight monetary policy and very high real interest rates. At this time, as we strive to emerge from a recession against the background of having achieved success on current account deficit and inflation, our efforts are being undermined by the international economic downturn, particularly in the United States where economic growth was down 0.7 per cent in the March quarter. This means that there is a double imperative to take further action at this time. There is also great concern about the aging of vital public infrastructure, and to renew it will create jobs. Constraints imposed on the provision of vital new infrastructure should be eased at the next Premiers Conference. Certainly, it is necessary to closely monitor and control the public sector borrowing requirement, but this need has to be balanced against the burden imposed on industry by aging and inadequate infrastructure.

Improved interface between road and rail transport into ports is a prime requirement. For example, borrowing constraints have prevented the completion of the $120m Maldon-Dombarton rail project to the coal and grain handling facilities at Port Kembla in New South Wales.
