This project was brought to a grinding standstill by the New South Wales Greiner Government. Even after that Government had spent approximately $40m on the project, it brought it to a stop as the recession was getting under way. That project could obviously have provided employment to some of the 24,000 people on the south coast I spoke about earlier.

Although the world trend will be for a developing capital shortage resulting in long term upward pressure on interest rates, right now the opportunities to shoot for improved growth and investment are available to us. The Government should act on these opportunities. Lower interest rates, a lower Australian dollar, plus moderate and selected stimulative measures must be implemented, together with initiatives to encourage savings and investment. It is really only against such a moderate expansionist policy background that the Job Search and Newstart measures in this legislation make any economic and social sense at all.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crawford Ms M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to speak on this important Bill-the Social Security (Job Search and Newstart) Amendment Bill 1991 and related Bills-which tackles in a new and different way issues related to the unemployed. A number of speakers today have spoken about unemployment, the nature of unemployment and why currently the situation is as it is.

SPEECH.PARA: We all have our own hobby horses and pursue them and whatever economic policy we happen to follow, but central to this debate is the whole notion of the unemployed, the way in which they should be treated, the kind of value they should have in the community and the kind of dignity with which they should be addressed. Indeed, the whole philosophical basis on which the unemployment benefit was first introduced, and the way in which we go about things, was brought home to me last week when I happened to be in Barcaldine for part of the Australian Labor Party's historic 100th year celebrations, celebrating with a group of women.

The kinds of changes which have emerged in our society and the reason for workers seeking parliamentary representation, in many ways, have not changed. It is for those of us in the Labor Party and in this Labor Government to voice the needs of the kind of people we represent. We are here to speak for the powerless, the voiceless and the most disadvantaged in our community. Certainly those who are currently unemployed fit into that category, unfortunately.

Job Search and the Newstart activity agreement attempt to look realistically at the problem and address the major problem in a new and different way. Indeed, the introduction of the Newstart allowance for the long term unemployed will enable us to meet this problem in the specialised way that is needed. I think none of us would argue about the fact that we have a dramatically changing world and a society which is changing, and that the needs and demands of the work force are dramatically changing.

Many honourable members in this place have heard me relate the story of Queenslanders. Most Queenslanders over the age of 42 years have not have secondary schooling. That is partly because the school system was structured in such a way that they went to school to year 8 and did a scholarship. If they did not pass that scholarship, they did not go on to high school. I know people show an enormous amount of disbelief about that, but if they were to go to any social gatherings or discussions anywhere in Queensland-certainly in rural Queensland-they would find that to be a fact.

Such people were in the work force for a very long time and now find themselves in the situation whereby the kind of skills which were once used in the work force and the marketplace have changed dramatically. I instance one small example within my own electorate. The Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd steel plant there employed over 480 people. It was automated and now employs 26 people working in two shifts, and produces enough steel to export to Asia. The 26 people who currently work there are very highly skilled technicians and computer people, and there are a number of out-posted industries which supply the kind of equipment needed for that business.

However, that is a very real indication of the changing nature of the work force, the kinds of skills needed and the kinds of demands made on us as a community as a whole to ensure that people who previously have not had the opportunity to be educated, develop skills or pursue any kind of skill-based training, be given that opportunity. We find realistically that few of the many people who are currently unemployed say that they lack the necessary skills and education-13.4 per cent in July 1990 said that they lacked the necessary skills or education to pursue any kind of work. Five per cent have insufficient English skills to be able to pursue any other work once they find themselves unemployed. Given the number of people that I see in my office and the needs they have, I think that figure is somewhat low.
Sitting suspended from 6.30 to 8.00 p.m.

TALK.START.PARA: —Prior to the dinner break, I was speaking about unemployment and the nature of unemployment, and the Government's response to that through the new programs of Job Search and Newstart. What we all need to remember is in fact the nature of people who are unemployed and the kinds of requirements that they have and the kinds of processes which have moved us towards this particular step. Unemployment benefits were first introduced in a very different kind of market in post-war Australia, and long term unemployment at the time was largely unknown. This was for a whole variety of reasons-the nature of the work force, the way in which society operated and the fact that over 50 per cent of the population, once they married, were unable to participate in the paid work force.

SPEECH.PARA: Society has changed dramatically and with it the kinds of demands made upon it. So, experience has shown that the key to tackling successfully the problems of the longer term unemployed lies in the integration of income support and other forms of assistance. What we see in this program is the Government's response to those kinds of needs. Indeed, between February 1989 and December 1990, 134,000 people in the Newstart group have left unemployment benefits. That is a dramatic saving to taxpayers. Indeed, it has been assessed that approximately $12,000 to $18,000 per year is saved, because not only do we save on the payment of unemployment benefits but also a gain is made in terms of the tax paid by people who have moved into the paid work force. Trials have revealed that this was a process which could also assist people to participate and improve a whole range of employment prospects.

The proportion of unemployed in the long term fell from about 38 per cent in February 1989 to 25 per cent in November 1990, so such programs have made quite a dramatic impact on the nature of long term unemployed people. From the figures released today, which I think we would all decry and certainly wish to see lower, one of the things that has been quite remarkable is a rise in the participation rate. So, we have 0.5 per cent more people moving into the work force at one end, quite an extraordinary situation. Therefore, the Government has responded to the kinds of demands made by the community at large and to the kinds of things which we know will work, as have been experienced through the earlier Newstart program. With the creation of Job Search and Newstart, we have a very different kind of arrangement. Thus, assistance and requirements will be tailored far more closely to individual needs and capacities.

At this juncture I might say that many very able CES officers in particular have been doing this for quite some time. Near my own electorate office at Woodridge, unfortunately we have a very large Department of Social Security and CES office. We see quite a lot of clients. The Department has responded to training programs, the provision of training programs, and to using the local TAFE college, which, I might add, is a new initiative of the Labor Government-we did not have one prior to its construction-where 7,000 people are assisted to have an opportunity for tertiary education who did not have that opportunity three years ago. All those things together make an important inroad to the kinds of training opportunities which people have and need.

Earlier I mentioned the quite dramatic needs in Queensland in terms of the nature of people, the level of people's education, the fact that many people over the age of 42 have no secondary schooling whatsoever because of the nature of the education system that existed, the fact that they have always had very low tertiary places and in fact a very small TAFE sector. We are seeing an expansion of that. That will assist in helping people to develop skills, training and to obtain certificates, diplomas and degrees providing them with a realistic chance in a 1991 job market.

Further, the Newstart program enables people to look at themselves and to recognise realistically their own talents for employability. I am chair of the management committee of a job care project funded under the job club program and we deal exclusively with women. I might say that many of these women are well into their forties, some are in their fifties and sixties, so I find it interesting that the honourable member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey) claimed that people over 55 years of age are being discriminated against. Certainly within the process of Newstart their needs will be assessed differently, as they are currently. We find at the job club that many of these women have talents and skills which they have not recognised themselves and have been unable to sell on the open job market.

What is interesting is that, despite the rise in unemployment and the recession and economic circumstances, we are still able through that job club to find work for people. The number of people who successfully complete our courses, address the issue and acknowledge the kinds of skills that they have and what they have to market and so are able to move into full time paid employment, is continuing to rise.

We must appreciate that, for very many women, particularly in their late forties and early fifties, this is actually their very first opportunity to be in the paid work force. Their needs are quite dramatically different. Often they have child-care needs or family needs. As well, they have very special transport needs as we are also located in one of the fastest growing cities in Australia-Logan City-with a population of 130,000 which has no public transport at all. That creates a very real problem and a great difficulty for people. I am interested to see figures which suggested earlier that one of the problems that people have is transport. In fact, 5 per cent of people who are unemployed have such difficulties. The urban and regional planning groups, which are addressing this issue, recognise that, as people move further from the centre of a city, not only are the infrastructures unavailable but transport becomes a very real problem. Whilst they may have saved money on a house, they need to spend money on a car. Often they find that difficult when their job is not near where they live and they need to be able to travel. So, public transport becomes a very key point in this argument.

We are hoping that through the activity agreements those kinds of issues will be realistically addressed and perhaps some ways in which people can tackle the transport problem may be raised. Indeed, we also acknowledge that there should be no misunderstanding about the activity agreement: it will be a requirement for payment. If people are not prepared to enter into and abide by an agreement, they will not be paid the Newstart allowance.

In fact, my own experience is, contrary to that of the honourable member for O'Connor, that almost all people, with very rare exceptions, are very anxious to return and participate in the work force, and to find themselves able to purchase goods, to have friends and to maintain a social life which comes from being in the paid work force. So, people will be anxious to enter into an agreement because they see this as a very real opportunity for them to be able to acquire skills to better place them for the marketplace.

Other important issues which are raised by the active employment strategy-and some of these concerns have been raised by a number of groups within the community-relate to the nature of the way in which it will be delivered. As I have said, my personal experience has been that the sensitivity very often shown by officers in dealing with unemployed people will be heightened because, of course, the agreement will need to be tailored for people, guidelines will be set up and the arrangements will require careful implementation by the CES. To this end, guidelines are being drawn up and will be developed in consultation with the Australian Council of Social Service. They have to be approved by the Minister. They will contain provisions of natural justice for clients and important review rights for clients. So the kinds of processes and requirements which we have for other clients dealing with government departments will also be here.

The important issue in the whole question of the Newstart and Job Search allowances is that the system will be tailored to meet individual needs and that there will be an acknowledgment of the very special qualities which people have and the very special needs which some of our unemployed people have. I instance the issue of literacy, which is very close to my heart and which I have dealt with. I have been on the literacy committee and have been horrified to learn that close to one million Australians are unable to read and write in English. Literacy has become a very major issue in the workplace in terms of award restructuring and what is happening there. It is also a major barrier to people trying to enter the work force. That kind of issue will be realistically addressed, and I know that it will be responded to in a sensitive and careful manner.

We also have people whose limited schooling, whose educational skills, whose ability to communicate with people, and whose ability to pursue their efforts in the marketplace are such that over a time they are really lost. The special treatment which they will get through the activity agreement will provide a very real opportunity for them to look at themselves and to look at the job market and see where they may fit. I know that we have heard people here tonight talking about jobs and the need for jobs, which we would all acknowledge, but it is also interesting to note that there are quite a number of companies that are expanding quite dramatically. So unemployment in many areas is very patchy. There are areas with skill shortages. A realistic assessment of what the labour market holds and offers for people may help them to re-enter the workplace.

Another important issue, which has been raised by the honourable member for O'Connor, was government bureaucracy. The honourable member for O'Connor holds the belief that governments should not do any of this and that private providers should provide work experience for people for nothing. This seems quite extraordinary. We would send a number of unemployed people along to a company, where they would work for nothing, and we, the taxpayers, would continue to pay unemployment benefits. The employer, of course, would gain profit from such people; at the end of the day, we, the taxpayers, would continue to pay an unemployment benefit. It is quite an extraordinary situation.

Realistically, we are not interested in such exploitation of people. What these programs attempt to do in a very real, tangible and accountable way is to look at people who have needs, to assess those needs and to attempt to meet those needs within the current framework of the marketplace. That, surely, is the role of a government committed to looking after every person in our community, including those people who are in most in need of us. As I said at the beginning of my speech, it is the Government's responsibility to ensure that their talents are used, that we as a community gain from what they have to offer, and that those individuals gain. So it is very much the role of government to pursue this. I say to the honourable member for O'Connor that government bureaucracy is shrinking, and has shrunk, under the current Government.

It is a question not of expanding government enterprises, but of using the government enterprises which we have to acknowledge the needs of people who are unemployed, particularly the long term unemployed, to realistically address those needs and, in the longer term, to meet them in a realistic way in which there is quality, integrity and a realistic relationship between the person who finds himself unemployed and the Government and the deliverer of that service. We have seen that Newstart, as a pilot, already has put 134,000 people into the work force. I have no hesitation in suggesting that the programs, as they now stand, will in fact produce the same results.

TALK.START.PARA: -Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Scott Mr L.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am very pleased to take the opportunity to speak on the Social Security (Job Search and Newstart) Amendment Bill. I listened to the honourable member for Forde (Ms Crawford) correcting some of the anomalies that were put forward by the honourable member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey) this afternoon. It was quite enlightening. The honourable member for O'Connor certainly has a different view from honourable members on this side of the House about how we look after our people.

SPEECH.PARA: I would like to begin my contribution to this debate by reminding honourable members opposite that it was actually a Labor government that introduced benefits for unemployed Australians and, following that tradition, it will always be a Labor government that introduces reforms, where necessary, to improve the provision of benefits to these people. Obvious as it may seem, behind all the rules and regulations of social security are people. Some of those people have families and some are on their own, but they all share one factor: they are all people in need. For this reason, when changes are proposed, it is important that people affected by the changes be considered.

The legislation before us embraces that quality, particularly in its attention to people issues in the area of financial assistance for the unemployed. The new structure will be made up of two distinct payments: a short term Job Search allowance payable for the first 12 months of unemployment and the Newstart allowance for those who are unemployed for 12 months or more. The new look system of providing benefits will see a two-phase approach to tackling unemployment. The first of these, the Job Search allowance, will apply to unemployed people aged 18 years and over and will bring about a better prepared work force in a number of ways.

With the assistance of the Commonwealth Employment Service (CES), unemployment benefit recipients will be encouraged to undertake more active and effective job search. To reduce the likelihood of unemployed people falling into a long term mind set, by way of a new clearly defined activity test recipients of Job Search allowance will be required to actively seek work or undertake a course of vocational training, or participate in a labour market program or any other course that the CES considers will improve or assist a person's prospects of obtaining work.

Provided the person actually undertakes CES approved courses, they will continue to receive both the Job Search allowance and any accompanying training allowances that they may be eligible for. The Government's all-encompassing approach to unemployment is seen in the continued payment of Job Search allowance to people under 18 and over 55 in special circumstances who are undertaking voluntary work in recognition of special labour market difficulties faced by these groups. While this voluntary work concession will not be available to 18- to 55-year-olds, all unemployed persons who have identified labour market disadvantages will be targeted at an early stage to participate in labour market programs and vocational training courses.

If a person is still unable to gain employment after 12 months, Newstart, the back-up stage of the Government's strategy to return people to the work force, comes into force. It will see these people enter into a Newstart activity agreement with the Commonwealth. Contrary to some emotive claims, this does not mean that people have to sign themselves over to multiple forms of psychoanalysis to see whether they are worthy recipients of benefits after a year; rather, it means that the Commonwealth takes a heightened interest in identifying the reasons why people may be having difficulty finding work and looks at ways of improving the person's chances of re-entering the work force.

It will achieve this by requiring the person to undertake such activities as Job Search, vocational training courses or labour market programs, training designed to assist a person in searching for work, or measures designed to eliminate or reduce any labour market disadvantages, such as medical treatment, rehabilitation or paid work experience. A person may also propose an activity such as voluntary work.

Reflecting their ability to best determine local conditions and needs, it is proposed that regional offices of the Commonwealth Employment Service must consider a number of variables when negotiating their contract. These include a person's education, experience, skills, age and physical condition as well as the state of the local labour market and the training facilities available. That these reforms are bringing about changes to the original financial assistance for the unemployed, as introduced by Curtin in 1945, is indicative of a willingness of Labor governments to adapt to the needs of the day. Let us not forget that people's needs are time specific.

Given changes that can occur in any of the aforementioned variables, it is intended that from time to time the CES will be able to renegotiate an agreement. Similarly, the recipient of Newstart allowance may request that his or her agreement be varied if he or she feels that circumstances have changed. The Job Search and Newstart measures build on other initiatives of this Government aimed at preparing Australia's work force for the next century through using policy measures which work in a coordinated way towards this goal.

The new payment structure clearly indicates to job seekers, and to the community generally, that receiving income support while unemployed is not just a matter of receiving payment. On the contrary, it will be strongly linked to a process of client contact, assessment, assistance and obligations designed to get people back into employment as soon as possible.

I emphasise the community side of unemployment as well here, for one of the most unjustified sides of being unemployed is the unfair assumption made about unemployed people by the community at large. I am pleased to speak on reforms which will remove redundant stereotypes about dole bludgers and replace them with self-esteem developed by greater and more extensive consultation with people out of work.

It is a fact of life that, while there is money to be obtained, a small minority will always be willing to use unscrupulous means to wrongfully obtain a financial benefit. Previously introduced initiatives of the Hawke Government have removed many of the loopholes that have cost the fair pay as you earn taxpayer in the past. The days of unemployed people spending their days on the beach and posting their forms to offices of the Department of Social Security each fortnight have long since gone.

While I give thanks to the Opposition for its support in the introduction of some of these measures, I remind the House that it has been this Government, not previous conservative governments, which has had the courage to stand up for pay as you earn taxpayers and bring about the genuine equitable reform to the provision of social security in this country. It has also brought about taxation reform.

Significantly, the restructuring of unemployment benefits is being accompanied by a major reform of labour market programs to link the two more effectively. The reform of labour market programs will see an additional $150m spent in this area over three years. However, the overall efficiency of this exercise is best reflected in the estimated net impact on government expenditure, which will be considerably less because of the increase in people returning to work due to Job Search allowance and Newstart programs.

The two-part benefit system also contains a heightened focus on obligations. This is both on the part of the Department of Social Security and of the client. Under the reforms proposed, there would be enhanced requirements for job seekers to take advantage of all suitable opportunities to improve job opportunities and find work and for the Department to make all clients aware of all the options open to them. As an incentive for both parties to adhere to the new guidelines, it is proposed that payment of benefit continue only if client obligations associated with each payment are met.

The Government is also aware of the need for a continued committed form of assistance to the families of the unemployed. It is determined to see a smooth transition to the new system of benefit provision. The intent of the legislation is that all those on unemployment benefits current at the time of implementation be transferred to the new payment structure and subsequently introduced to the associated obligations and assistance.

In my introduction I referred to the longstanding commitment of Labor governments to social justice. I am proud to be part of another Labor government that shares that passion for caring and providing for the less well off in our community. Under the unemployment benefits scheme, as it was first introduced by the Curtin Government, benefits were paid to people who were out of work, who were capable of undertaking and willing to undertake suitable work, and who had taken reasonable steps to obtain work.

In 1947 the Chifley Government provided provision for a partial additional payment for a partly dependent wife and extended eligibility for benefits to wives who had permanently separated from their husbands. The Whitlam Government increased sickness and unemployment benefits to the same level as pensions. It introduced recognition of de facto status for unemployment and sickness beneficiaries by making an additional payment for the partner.

The Hawke Government's recognition of families in need has built on these proud achievements. Sweeping reforms in the areas of youth, rent assistance, disability reform, family assistance, child support and the retirement incomes policy are all integral pieces of this Government's social security network ensuring an all-encompassing strategy to tackle the social problems facing today's families. We recognise that provision of payments goes much further than looking at one particular benefit.

The benefits won for Australian families by Labor governments are made all the more impressive when we look at the chronology of social security events in Australia. Indeed, perhaps the blackest mark on that chronology was the relentless push by the Fraser Government in 1981-82 to prevent the payment of unemployment or special benefit to the spouse of persons participating in industrial action-another attack on the workers. I note with disdain that on three separate occasions the Fraser Government introduced legislation to amend the Social Services Act 1947 to this end. The Australian community can be thankful that this proposal was rejected in the Senate on each of these occasions.

The presence of some members of that Government on the front benches of today's Opposition stands as a stern reminder for those in need of what social security framework would exist under a Liberal-National Government today. Instead of a planned coordinated approach to providing assistance to those Australian families in need, there would be a mismatched group of organisations with limited ability to coordinate resources determining eligibility for and provision of social services.

What honourable members opposite seem to forget is that there is more to social security than just finding a suitable person to dish out the money. Given that we have not heard any more from the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson) since the good doctor gave his last doorstop, we have to assume that he still has it in mind to go about providing social security the same way one sells newspapers. There comes with the responsibility to provide for people financially the need to recognise the different aspects of social security. That is something that neither the milkman nor the newsagent can do.

Evidence of the Government's recognition of this can be seen in the commitment made to maintain the benchmarks of adequacy in family payments. Specifically, these are to maintain the total value of family payments; that is, the first child rate of family allowance plus the family allowance supplement (FAS), equivalent to the married rate of pension for children under 13, and 20 per cent for children aged 13, 14 and 15. These benchmarks were achieved in July 1989. Accordingly, the Government increases the rates of FAS each January by the amounts necessary to ensure that the 15 per cent and 20 per cent benchmarks are maintained.

Put simply, the rule of thumb when initiating and revising social security policy is to keep in touch with the targeted group. This is precisely what the Government has done through the changing of the family income supplement to FAS in December 1987. This step has resulted in a more than fourfold increase in the number of families in receipt of FAS from 46,000 at its introduction in December 1987 to 183,000 in December 1990-an increase of which the Government can be justifiably proud.

The Government has also made a continuous effort to increase the awareness of the FAS program. Results from a FAS evaluation showed that 79 per cent of potentially eligible families were aware of the program. The Government has undertaken a range of measures to ensure the policies implemented are those best suited for the intended beneficiaries and that those people have every opportunity to take advantage of these benefits. Some of these activities include extensive publicity using a wide range of outlets from television to milk carton advertisements; social security regional offices developing an extensive range of publicity and information material for schools, hospitals, employers and other community groups; and market research to improve the quality of information products and publicity strategies. Because of the anticipated turnover of the FAS client group, a great deal of importance has been placed on continual and regular outreach programs.

As proof of the benefits of the constant feedback that comes to the Government through our ongoing analysis of the state of play in social security, to make the tasks easier for the families in need of help, since 1988 the separate family allowance and FAS claim forms have been combined into a single document. I ask the question: how would one derive such information under a system where assistance was not being provided by one central agency? How many butchers, bakers and candlestick makers would need to get together to determine the effectiveness of a particular benefit?

As honourable members opposite are left trying to work out the answers, I regret to say that I have to give them some more bad news. Through the united effort of a national social security system, the Government has been able to maximise take-up of benefits by pensioners and beneficiaries who have made the transition to the work force.

TALK.START.PARA: —By bringing on unemployment. Who wrote this?

—I will come back to that later. Terminating beneficiaries and pensioners are advised of possible eligi- bility for FAS as a matter of course, while, in cases where an ex-beneficiary or ex-pensioner is eligible for FAS and claims within six weeks of that pension or benefit being cancelled, FAS is backdated to the payday following the last receipt of pension or benefit.

SPEECH.PARA: The basic requirement of being able to ascertain the effectiveness of programs through determining the level of the take-up of a specific program can only be further complicated as the number of variables increases. Overseas experience shows, for instance, that there will always be difficulty in achieving, maintaining and measuring levels of take-up of income tested family payments, given that there is no single reliable source of data on the eligible population. Yet, through a national social security network, the Department is currently constructing a micro-simulation model which will have the capacity to impute FAS eligibility and take-up-something which is expected to be available later this year.

These cases are not only examples of how the Government is able to keep in touch with the needs of those requiring assistance through a national social security system; they also demonstrate the hypocrisy of the Opposition in its support for the re-write of the social security legislation on one hand-something the Government welcomes-while, on the other hand, desiring to tear apart the very system which is effectively providing for Australians in need of a helping hand.

The social security option put forward by the Opposition should also be seen as part of its bigger picture when it comes to providing for those in need or for workers. It would seem that, as far as the Opposition is concerned, recipients of social welfare deserve to be hit with the same big hammer as do workers-especially in light of the Opposition's attitude to industrial relations. The question could well be asked: what section of the community will be spared this hammer of repression?

Let us picture the Opposition's Australia. Workers would be playing off each other for jobs-something which would take their standard of living back 100 years. The workers who could not keep up with the scarcest of wages to keep their families would have no choice but to join the queues at the soup kitchens to fill their bowls and their pockets with whatever a particular agency thought was a fair thing. If the breadwinner of the family had the misfortune to be out of work for more than nine months, the Opposition would even take that benefit away and leave the family with absolutely nothing. There would be no coordinated approach to training in that scenario, just a widening of the gap between the rich and the poor, with the situation only able to get worse.

The alternative before us is much better. Families need not fear the removal of benefits. Uniform guidelines and working through a nationwide coordinated system of offices mean that there can be no cases of discrimination preventing eligibility for benefit. The outcome is that those people who are genuinely seeking re-employment will continue to be supported and will be able to devote all of their attention to that very end, instead of spending half their time wondering how close they are getting to the end of the road. What is more, there is every likelihood that, thanks to the heightened attention to individual cases, time spent on benefit will be greatly reduced.

As has already been seen with the success of the jobs, education and training program, which aims to return sole parents to the work force, the Government's strategy of applying programs which are specifically related to the needs of one target group has worked well. That policy will continue to do so in regard to Job Search and Newstart. As with the social achievements of Curtin, Chifley and Whitlam, I believe that the job creation that will flow from this reformation of unemployment benefits will stand as one of the most significant and equitable initiatives of the Hawke Government. I am pleased to support that aspect here tonight.

The honourable member for Flinders (Mr Reith) interjected a moment ago about unemployment. I can assure the honourable member that this Government is greatly concerned about unemployed people. I am certain that no-one on this side of the House takes any joy in the present unemployment figures. That has been indicated by other Government speakers today and, certainly, by our leaders as well. I think it is rather hypocritical of honourable members opposite to criticise this legislation, which will certainly help in a lot of ways to provide training and greater opportunities for people who are unemployed when eventually they get back into the job market.

I would like to acknowledge some of the areas in my own electorate-such as the technical and further education college and the Skillshare programs, which actually undertake a lot of this work-that will be enhanced by the legislation tonight. I would like also to acknowledge the commitment that people in my electorate-certainly in the Department of Social Security and the Commonwealth Employment Service-have in trying to get people trained and back into the work force. I am very pleased to have had the opportunity to support the legislation tonight. I am sure it will be passed later this evening.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Theophanous Dr A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —While I support the Social Security (Job Search and Newstart) Amendment Bill, I am concerned about some issues arising from the legislation. However, I will first make some introductory comments about the context in which this legislation was developed. The idea for the legislation originated at a time of high employment and low unemployment. In that situation, the general ideas that were proposed were good. Clearly, they were ideas which were worthy of consideration in that context. However, as has been mentioned by a number of honourable members, the unemployment situation has dramatically changed.

SPEECH.PARA: In that context, it is very important, given that we are to proceed with these programs, that we ensure that they are sensitive to the times. By `sensitive to the times', I mean that these programs need to be sensitive to the fact that we have a high level of unemployment at the moment and that in many areas of Australia there are not enough jobs. Given that situation, it is important that people not be penalised for something which is not their fault, namely, the fact that there are no jobs in a particular area or a particular city for them.

As I mentioned, both Job Search and Newstart were significant programs in the context in which they were developed. However, I want to refer to some of the features of the programs which I think need to be emphasised in order to ensure that, as I say, the programs are implemented with great sensitivity in the current situation. I refer in the first instance to the contract which will need to be signed by people after they have been unemployed for a period of time in order for them to continue to receive assistance. I think it is very important that the contract be signed only in the context of other alternatives being available. It is proposed that:

Under the terms of the agreement a person will be required to undertake such activities as job search, vocational training courses or labour market programs, training designed to assist a person searching for work, measures designed to eliminate or reduce any labour market disadvantage such as medical treatment or rehabilitation, or paid work experience. A person may also propose an activity such as voluntary work.

It is very important, therefore, that such programs be available. I have been told by the Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Dawkins) that many of the programs will be taken up on a voluntary basis by unemployed people. If, therefore, there will be very few programs left for other people, this factor should be taken into account. In other words, people should not be forced into an agreement if such programs are not available for them. I think it is a matter which the Government ought to have clarified in the second reading speech on the Bill. The Government should have stated that people in the current economic situation would not be forced to sign an agreement if there were to be no such programs available.

I now refer to another important clause. When negotiating the agreement, the Commonwealth Employment Service (CES) must consider a person's education, experience, skills, age and physical condition as well as the state of the local labour market and the training facilities available. This is an important matter because, as shall been seen later, very substantial powers are being given to CES officers in relation to these agreements. Therefore, it is important that this particular clause be up in lights so that it can be seen by the individual officers of the CES. I will repeat: they must consider a person's education, experience, skills, age and physical condition as well as the state of the local labour market and the training facilities available.

I want to make it clear that what we do not want as a Government and as a Parliament is to be told in a few months time that there are officers of the CES who are abusing these powers and who are not taking into account people's education, experience, skills, age and physical condition. In other words, while it is clear that people should be expected to seek employment-and I think the Australian community does expect that unemployed people should make every reasonable effort to find employment and that, if there are training programs available for them, they should go into those programs-it is quite absurd to suggest that people who have, for example, a very high level of education or experience or skills should be required to do totally unsuitable jobs which differ completely from their education, experience and skills. To suggest that and to say to a person, `Well, unless you sign a contract or an agreement to the effect that you will do this, you will not be paid an allowance' is in fact to force experienced, educated and skilled members of the work force into demeaning situations from which they may not be able to escape.

Australia contains a wide spectrum of people, both skilled and unskilled. Unfortunately, at the present time Australia has unemployed people, both skilled and unskilled. So it should be possible, if this program is carried out sensitively, for people to be asked to seek work and take up jobs, if those jobs are available, in those particular areas in which they have the education, experience, skills, age and physical condition.

I make the point that, given the wide powers that will be given to the officers of the CES, it is important that these provisions not be abused, and it is important in this context that people be given some flexibility in this matter. This is not to say that if a person is a university professor, he or she may not be required to go and teach in a school. That is fair enough. But to suggest that people who have the education, experience and skills, and who are in a situation in which there are already many unskilled, unemployed people, should be required to travel long distances and to work in totally unsuitable employment which is not commensurate with their education, experience and skills is to suggest something that, from what I can see in this particular clause, is not what the legislation intends. It must be the case that public servants, especially the more junior public servants in the Department, not abuse the powers that are given to them in relation to these matters.

I have raised a couple of what I think are crucial issues in relation to these contracts or agreements. The first is the question of whether people will be required to enter into such agreements where there are no programs available for them, and I think we need some reassurances on this point. The second is the question, as I said, of what sorts of work they will be required to look for, what sorts of areas they will be required to look at in terms of employment possibilities.

Let me also refer to rumours which are going around in relation to these contracts or agreements. I do not believe the rumours to be true, but it is important that the Government again clarify the position in relation to them. The rumours refer to the claim that these officials will be given the power in negotiating the contract to require unreasonable conditions from people-for example, to require them to completely change their mode of dress or their hair style. I inform the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Social Security (Mr Sciacca) that I have heard these rumours that are going around, and it is important that we put a stop to them.

Obviously, there are certain basic requirements. If people are trying to flout the system by deliberately dressing or deliberately behaving in such ways as to be rejected by prospective employers, that is one thing. But it is another thing if somebody comes along and says, `Look, I don't like your moustache' or `I don't like your beard' or `I don't like the fact you dress this particular way rather than that way'. Those sorts of statements can be seen as an infringement on people's rights, and I am sure that honourable members would agree that those sorts of abuses ought not be allowed to be perpetrated in relation to this matter. Clearly, if the departmental officers are going to have those powers, guidelines ought to be put forward to ensure that those powers are not abused.

We know from other departments, such as the department controlling immigration, what can happen when there are insufficient guidelines and when too much power has been given to people, especially bureaucrats and junior officials, in the exercise of their duties, so that they say to other persons, `I don't like the look of you. Go away and come back dressed differently, otherwise you won't get a social security payment, even though you cannot find a job'. That sort of thing must be avoided as much as possible. As I said, there are some reasonable requests that can be made, but we need guidelines in relation to these matters.

I have raised these questions because I am concerned about what is going to happen with the implementation of this program in the context of the present very high unemployment situation. I want to spend a few minutes addressing that situation and to say I believe that, ultimately, no matter which program of this kind we bring forward, the most important issue is for us to put into place policies and programs which will get us out of the recession as quickly as possible and which will create employment. In this context, it seems to me that we have to think about what sort of programs will create employment in the current economic climate. I am looking forward to the Budget because I hope that in it the Government will consider the issue of what has happened with unemployment and will put into place some programs for the creation of jobs.

I am not speaking here of another Commonwealth employment program of the kind we had in the past. I am speaking here about the fact that in this country, in the area of infrastructure-the roads, railway systems and all sorts of infrastructure developments where there is work to be done-we need to think of ways and means in which work can be done. It seems to me that the Government ought to think about the introduction of a major infrastructure program in this forthcoming Budget to soak up some of the unemployment and, therefore, to have secondary effects in terms of the creation of other jobs in the services areas. As we know, once basic jobs are created in the infrastructure area, other jobs are created in services, retail and associated areas.

I believe that unless we put such programs into place we will be in difficulties with the employment situation. Notwithstanding the general performance of the macro-economy, there is a need at this particular time for such programs. I believe the Government ought seriously to consider what it can do within the context of the Budget in relation to such programs. As I said, I will be looking forward to seeing what can be done in the Budget context.

One of the problems that has occurred as a result of current unemployment, and one of the concerns that I have with this program, is that we have had a sharp increase in unemployment for people in the semi-skilled and unskilled areas where we have gone in for restructuring or where we have had tariff reductions. I am referring to industries such as the textile, footwear and clothing industries and the motor car industry where we have had significant job losses. Very often the job losses have been amongst people of migrant backgrounds who have been doing the same job for many years. Often they are in their late 40s or in their 50s, and we are saying to them, `You have got to go out and retrain'. That is fine, we can say that about retraining, but if we are going to be talking about retraining in these areas we have to make it perfectly clear that often retraining involves additional courses in the English language.

In the context of the programs referred to in this Bill, we have to be prepared to put more resources into the provision of English language courses for the retraining of the work force, especially for the unskilled. We have already done that to some degree with the training levy. We have suggested to employers that part of the one per cent training levy could be used on English language courses, but that may not be enough. It certainly will not be much good for those who are already unemployed. These people are at a double disadvantage and they need to be helped. Not only do they have to retrain, but also as part of the training requirement they have to learn a better level of English. Therefore, we need to put resources into place to ensure that that succeeds.

Whilst, as I say, I support the general thrust of the program, I am concerned that it has come at a time when there is rising unemployment. In my view, the program would be more successful if it were to come in at a time when unemployment was going down and employment was increasing. If we are to proceed with it we have to ensure that there are more activities and programs so that if people are to be required to sign an agreement, there will be labour market programs, training courses, et cetera, for them to go into. As I mentioned in respect of many of the migrant workers who are to be retrained, we also need to have significantly increased resources for English language training.

I have one concluding comment. The Bill says that a person may propose an activity such as voluntary work as part of this program. At this time of high unemployment I suggest that that aspect should be highlighted. If people are prepared to do voluntary activities in the community they should be told, `Okay, you are doing this particular beneficial and voluntary activity for the community; we accept that as part of the agreement'. That should be particularly focused on in the current context of high unemployment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Scholes The Hon G.G.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I enter this debate because I have concerns about the concepts in this Social Security (Job Search and Newstart) Amendment Bill. I have no problems with advances which are being made in the social security system, and programs which are being put in place to make it more relevant to the real needs of the community.

SPEECH.PARA: Since 1909 Australian governments have always had a concern, as has the Australian community, for those among us who are less well off than others. Whilst we like to believe that we are an egalitarian society, we are certainly not. There are those among us who are less well off; there are those who have jobs who are not well off.

Until 1990 that was a view which I would have suggested was shared equally and pursued in different ways but, nevertheless, pursued by both sides of politics in Australia. That is not the case today. The present Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson) has made it clear that he believes that the aim of the Federal Government is to transfer funds from those on the lowest incomes to those who are best off already. His proposal to automatically remove unemployment benefits from persons who have been unemployed for nine months is a money-saving exercise at the expense of those people who no longer can, or are unable to, support themselves and have no other source of income. It could save $1 billion a year, but not to the Government. That $1 billion will be transferred to speculators and others who will be repaid, under the policies announced, moneys already paid in capital gains tax and other get rich quick schemes which dominated this society in modern times.

I want to discuss the problems which are related directly to my electorate and the problems which are fairly general throughout provincial and smaller towns throughout Australia. Retraining schemes have value if, at the end of the retraining, there is an opportunity for people who have been retrained to find useful and gainful employment and to remove themselves from what is now a very serious social stigma-the welfare system-which is fast becoming a morass from which they cannot remove themselves.

Because of events which took place nearly 20 years ago, where a public relations campaign was launched by a particular political party to damn the unemployed as being people who were deliberately unemployed-dole bludgers was the term used-people who are genuinely out of work today, unlike in the 1930s, say, are looked on as imposing themselves on others by choice. In most instances that is not true.

There are, and always will be, those in our society who would prefer not to work and probably they will not. A great deal has been done during the term of this Government to make that situation as difficult as possible. But between that, and the situation where you automatically remove income from people without concern or consideration, there is a gulf which is too wide to bridge.

Do you actually allow families to starve? That is a question which has not yet been answered. The only alternative to unemployment benefits or other welfare benefits which has so far been suggested is that people may go down to the Salvation Army, the Brotherhood of St Lawrence or the local soup kitchen and get a feed. I would have hoped that in 1991 that is not an option that Australians-and this Parliament-would seriously see as viable or acceptable from anyone in this country.

This Bill introduces significant changes in a whole range of welfare payments. Its success or failure depends very much on a group of people who will be responsible for choosing, administering and providing retraining schemes, or negotiating contracts with people on their futures and, more importantly, on whether or not all of that makes any difference. On today's figures in my electorate there are probably 11 per cent of those people seeking full time employment-I ignore those seeking part time work-who are unemployed.

In the last 12 months and less somewhere between 1,500 and 2,000 have lost their jobs in the car industry and its associated industries, which dominate the economy of Geelong. In addition, there is a like number of people who have lost their jobs in the textile, clothing and footwear industries, and although it is not spectacular and because the numbers have not attracted the same publicity it is of equal proportions and creates a double problem for many families. In numerous cases the people who have lost their jobs in the textile areas are from the same families as those who have lost their jobs in the automotive and other industries.

I acknowledge that I am a protectionist, not a free trader like the majority of the members of this Parliament, and I have already said that I am not converted to the new academic religion which has failed everywhere it has been tried, including Britain and the United States, but apparently it is going to be tried here as well. We are told that the medicine is nasty, but that it will provide a future which is brighter than that which exists at present.

We are told this by people who live in an enclave called Canberra, most of whom have never had dirt under their fingernails in their lives and would not know what a pay cheque of $400 a week or something of that nature is all about, the same people who are setting the guidelines and can change them in the future for the contracts people in my electorate are going to be asked to enter into.

We should remember that the policy makers in the Public Service now never leave Canberra; they do not have to go out to the State offices. Since Menzies started moving the Public Service into Canberra, and every Prime Minister since has followed his example-on both sides-we have reached a stage where we have an elite group of people who are born in Canberra, educated in Canberra, live in Canberra and probably go to Sydney University Economics School to get their proper right wing training and then come back to Canberra, and by the time they are in their forties they are in the executive service of the Public Service.

The people who are out on the ground in the State offices, in the capital cities, in the provincial cities, do not get the promotions. They only see the problems, and they are told by people who have never seen the problems how they should solve them, and the guidelines are set at that level.

I want to make this point, and make it very strongly: if we are going to retrain people, and there are no jobs in the area for the people we retrain, if we have some vague notion of lifting them all up and moving them all into the central business districts of Melbourne and Sydney, then we should forget it, or else we should acknowledge that it will cost and cost dearly.

To move home from Geelong to Melbourne, just the physical cost of selling a house and buying another one will be $40,000, and that is a lot of money if people are unemployed. It is not long ago that the Fraser Government was talking about forcing people to go to, say, the fruit picking areas. I have no objection to people being temporarily moved there, especially singles, as long as the costs are met. But that was not the case. Not only were they expected to move 400 miles from their homes and lose the support of the family that they had; they were not guaranteed accommodation; and, in the case of single girls, they were told they could sleep in the same huts as the men. Some might find that acceptable; most would not. However, that was a Government directive. Fortunately it did not come off. It was a Government policy, and where was it decided? In Canberra.

When we talk about retraining, for years in provincial cities the number of people who are trained for clerical and administrative jobs-which is fairly normal, especially amongst girls-and registered for employment with the CES often reaches a thousand in a month or more, and the number of jobs registered are five or six. Are we going to put people in retraining schemes to train them so that they can be added to that thousand?

The facts are that a good percentage of the people who lost their jobs in the textile, clothing and footwear industries in Geelong are-as the honourable member for Calwell (Dr Theophanous) said-migrants and in their forties and early fifties. They are not going to be retrained for jobs that exist; if they are being retrained it is to occupy their time so that they will not appear and be a problem on the unemployment list. There is no form of contract that can be devised, even in Canberra, which will provide them any opportunity of work whatsoever.

There are those who work for Ford and came to Australia to work for Ford in many cases, because that is why migrants were brought into the country in the 1950s and 1960s. They are still of working age and they are not going to be trained to take positions in other industries. There are a few jobs about, but precious few, and there are people already trained and skilled in those areas who can take those jobs when they become available.

I want to see what retraining is all about. I would like to see the guidelines, because I am very suspicious that those guidelines are going to be administered by people who have not been trained to administer them, have not got the training necessary to assess people, and they will be so overworked, because if they have to handle 3,000 or 4,000 people on the Social Security register in a small regional office which is already overworked, then they are not going to give the attention to detail that should be necessary and would be required if the scheme were to work properly.

I want to finish on this point: if we are going to introduce a scheme such as this, if we are going to depend on people to assess other people and fix conditions for other people, if we are going to offer people retraining, then there is some obligation to make sure that the people who are doing the work have the time to do it, the skills and training to do it, and that the retraining schemes have some prospects of actual employment at the conclusion. At the moment none of those conditions can be met in my electorate. There are no jobs and there are no prospects of any jobs, and we can retrain people week after week, scheme after scheme, and they are not going to get jobs. The only people who will get jobs are the people who train them.

I personally think that there should be built into this legislation provision whereby in certain areas the whole thing can be deferred until such time as some opportunity at least exists for it to work, because retraining schemes humiliate people. People are told that they must be retrained because they do not have skills for jobs that they did have skills for not very long ago. At the end of the retraining they are told, `Bad luck, mate. There were never any jobs there. We need a few people to fill another retraining scheme; let's start again.'

Finally, in his statement on 12 March, the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) said that $40m would be made available for assistance to those people who were displaced or who suffered from the consequences, in the short term, of the industry statement made on that date. It is now 9 May and no announcements of any forms of assistance have been finalised. It took just on a month before they were even looked at. I understand that some progress is being made, but I have to say that what I have seen to date is certainly a lot less than will be needed if people are to be given a decent way of life and a decent opportunity to live in the way that Australians are entitled to expect.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sciacca The Hon C.

TALKER.NAME: Mr SCIACCA
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Social Security)

TALK.START.PARA: —First, I want to thank those who have contributed to this debate. The Government members who contributed today, namely, the honourable member for Oxley (Mr Les Scott), the honourable member for Phillip (Ms McHugh), the honourable member for Cunningham (Mr West), the honourable member for Forde (Ms Crawford), the honourable member for Calwell (Dr Theophanous), and the honourable member for Corio (Mr Scholes), along with a number of others who spoke yesterday on the Bill, all made useful contributions. They indicated a concern that not only should we be implementing these initiatives, but that the resources are directed to those most in need.

SPEECH.PARA: The honourable member for Corio and the honourable member for Calwell mentioned a number of matters which were of concern to them. I can appreciate that they would be concerned, particularly the honourable member for Corio, because of the rural situation and because of the fact that there are many thousands of people who are presently unemployed. But this Government does not want to repeat what happened after the recession of 1982-83. The very fact that there is high unemployment does not mean that we should sit back and allow what will be to be.

In fact, the active employment strategy of the Government is a positive strategy designed to assist back to employment those most disadvantaged in the labour market. These people must not be left to languish without help and then miss out as the labour market picks up. The purpose of these changes is to help people into jobs by providing an enhanced level of client contact through the interviews between Commonwealth Employment Service (CES) officers and unemployed people in formulating the activity agreements, an enhanced range of labour market programs based on individual assessment of clients needs, and better targeting of the disadvantaged.

Expenditure on the four main programs for the long term unemployed has been increased by $113m, or 40 per cent. The centrepiece of the new arrangements will be activity agreements negotiated between long term unemployed clients and the CES. Payment of benefits will be conditional upon a client fulfilling their agreement. The arrangements require careful implementation by the Commonwealth Employment Service. To this end, guidelines are being presently drawn up to define the nature of activity agreements and the circumstances under which benefit can be cancelled. These guidelines are being developed in consultation with the Australian Council of Social Service (ACOSS). Although they have yet to be approved by the Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Dawkins), they will contain provisions on natural justice requirements for clients and they will contain important review rights for clients.

There is no direct relationship between the number of unemployed persons and the appropriate number of labour market program places. In particular, there is no sense in seeking to guarantee a labour market program place to every unemployed person, as the programs may not necessarily be able to assist every individual. There are other options for unemployed people outside the Commonwealth labour market programs; for example, technical and further education. Quality is important. Throughput of numbers is less important than ensuring that people's employment prospects genuinely improve.

The Government does not claim that these changes or expanded program provisions are a panacea for the problems of unemployment. The Government's policy responses to the unemployment problem are much broader than that, but these measures can and will play a useful supporting role. As I said, we cannot afford to repeat the mistakes of the 1982-83 recession when nothing was done about getting people into the labour market when the labour market did improve.

It is natural, I think, for the honourable member for Corio and the honourable member for Calwell, and Opposition members who spoke here today and yesterday, to be concerned about the fact that there is a limited number of jobs and that the labour market is certainly not very good. But these new measures will at least go some way to try to make sure that we reskill and do everything we can to train those in our work force if it is obvious that they are not going to be able to find a job after 12 months.

The honourable member for Calwell and some other honourable members mentioned their worries about the abuse of powers in so far as the Newstart activity agreements are concerned. I can understand that concern, but I assure the House that the Government will be looking very closely to make sure that these sorts of things do not happen. There will be moved shortly by the Government in the committee stage an amendment which will give the right of appeal to those who believe that for some reason the contract that they may have been asked to sign contains unreasonable conditions.

The Social Security Appeals Tribunal will have the power to set aside the whole of the agreement, or just conditions therein, but will not have the power to rewrite the contract. As is the case in any new program, obviously there may well be some hiccups; obviously there may well be some problems. This will always be the case, I guess, and it is something that I am sure the Department of Employment, Education and Training will be looking at very closely in so far as the Commonwealth Employment Service is concerned.

I now go to some of the comments made by some of the Opposition members during the debate. First, the honourable member for Dawson (Mr Braithwaite) said that we had not taken into account the current high unemployment. I reiterate what I have said with respect to being ready when the upturn comes-as it will. He also spoke of the tighter measures, for instance, in New Zealand. I am glad that he mentioned that: I was not going to say anything about New Zealand, but now I am going to. It is true that New Zealand has implemented a number of tighter measures. I quote from an article which appeared in the Telegraph Mirror newspaper of 10 April, by Brian Rudman. It is headed, `Brian Rudman's New Zealand'. It states:
Ugly scenes over savage welfare cuts . . .
Last week more than 100,000 people took to the streets. In Auckland the mood turned ugly when 6,000 education workers marching down the city's main street in opposition to labour market . . .
It then goes on to say:

Angry members of the unemployed march invaded several banks, hurled bottles at a McDonalds hamburger restaurant and burned effigies of Prime Minister Jim Bolger, Finance Minister Ruth Richardson and Social Welfare Minister Jenny Shipley.
In reply, a shopping arcade's electronic notice board flashed a message,``Stop your whingeing, get a job''. This sparked the smoke bombing and invasion of the arcade by 100 of the protesters.
It goes on to say:
In a bid to lop around $A1 billion from the annual welfare budget, the universal family benefit was abolished, virtually all benefits were cut, and stricter eligibility criteria were introduced.
Worst hit was the single, unemployed under-25-year-old whose benefit was slashed 25 per cent back to $A82 a week.

I can assure honourable members that the Government has absolutely no intention to restrict unemployment benefits and to do the sorts of things that are being championed by the Opposition in so far as those unfortunate enough to be unemployed are concerned. Indeed, one only has to look at the manifesto-I think it is called the Economic Action Plan-of the Opposition, which under the heading of `Unemployment Relief Plan' says:
Unemployment benefits will only be available for a maximum nine months. Within this nine month period, the onus of proof as to why benefits should be continued will rest with the beneficiary.
Estimated savings: $1500 million

I do not know where the Opposition gets that figure from. I understand that it will move an amendment later to suggest that people be taken off the Job Search allowance after nine months. It seems to me that the Opposition is simply saying that after a period of nine months-whether one can get a job or not, whether one has tried to get a job or not, whether one has done everything possible to get a job or not-people will be thrown out onto the scrap heap.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is not the case; speak the truth.

—It is not a matter of whether I speak the truth. I will repeat what the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson) and the shadow Treasurer, the honourable member for Flinders (Mr Reith), have been saying; then the honourable member for Dawson can tell me whether they speak the truth. It is fairly obvious that after a period of nine months the Opposition wants to wash its hands of the unemployed and say, `You look after yourself'.

SPEECH.PARA: The honourable member for Dawson asks me to tell the truth. I will tell him what the Leader of the Opposition said. The transcript of a Matthew Abraham radio interview on 2CN dated 6 May 1991 states:
Abraham:

They're not the sorts of things that scare the voters, though, not necessarily. The focus is always on that side of it. As you know, the problem for an Opposition is the whole question of particularly welfare, and spending cuts, and they must be substantial, mustn't they.
Hewson:

We will have substantial cuts, there's no doubt about that. They won't necessarily be in welfare, though. There will be some, look at the last election I think we had about $3 billion worth of cuts and about $1 billion of those were in welfare.
Abraham:
Would that be a minimum, by the way.
Hewson:

Well, we are reviewing, we have an Expenditure Review Committee, and we are updating, if you like, the numbers from the last election campaign. We don't resile from that in any sense. A lot of those changes were structural changes. Some are more difficult to make in a recession, for example, in relation to unemployment benefits, but the principle of the change, the need to restore incentive for people to go back to work, the key motivation, if you like, of our decision last time still stays, even though it may be somewhat harder to implement it in a recession. We don't resile from the decision. And I don't pull back in any sense.
An article by economic writer Laura Tingle in the Australian of 19 February 1991 headed `Reith urges $3 billion spending cut-higher taxes' states:
The Federal Opposition has called on the Government to introduce a goods and services tax immediately and cut government spending by $3 billion, half of which would come from restricting the dole.
It goes on:
Asked about the decision to cut the dole after nine months, Mr Reith said this was ``a structural thing'' as well as a savings measure.

``You are saying to people there is a limit to the system, we are placing outer limits on that system, and Australia does have, relative to the rest of the world, very long averages for people on the unemployment benefit,'' he said.

It is obvious that the Opposition has made it as clear as a bell that it will have its cuts in the area of welfare. Both the Leader of the Opposition and the Deputy Leader of the Opposition, the honourable member for Flinders, have specifically said that they intend to make cuts to the dole. One says the figure will be $1.5 billion, while the other says it will be at least $1 billion. We do not really know what it will be. It is obvious, though, that it is going to save its money, if it ever has the chance, by cutting such things as unemployment benefits.

By way of its computer matching programs and by way of stricter and more mobile review teams in the area of social security, this Government is doing everything that is possible to try to cut down the incidence of fraud in social security. It is doing so with a great deal of success. There have been substantial savings. Sure, there will always be a number of people who will try to get around the system. They will do everything that they possibly can to beat the system. The Government is doing everything that it can to make sure that those who are not genuine are penalised accordingly. But we will not have the situation that the Opposition would have-that is, that after nine months, by hook or by crook, people go off somewhere else and look after themselves. That is exactly what has been stated by the Opposition. The Opposition says that it will arrange to put people on a special benefit, or something like that.

The honourable member for McPherson (Mr Bradford) spent five minutes in his speech attacking the unions and the Australian Council of Trade Unions. That is fine; we expect that from the honourable member for McPherson. He also said that the Opposition would create a whole new attitude to work, but he did not say what it would be. The Opposition comes up with these things and says, `We're going to do this and we're going to do that. We're going to cut off $3 billion from government spending'. According to the Leader of the Opposition, at least $1 billion will be in the area of welfare cuts. According to the Deputy Leader of the Opposition, $1.5 billion alone will be cut from the dole. But they do not tell us what they are going to do to replace these things. I do not know where they think these unemployed people-people who are genuinely unemployed and who have not been able to find a job-are going to go. Where do they go? Do they go to St Vincent de Paul? They have to live; they have to survive. Do they turn to crime?

The fact is that the Opposition has not thought out its policies. We all know that. It blames this Government-or at least criticises this Government-because we are introducing reforms in labour market programs. We are trying to do everything that we possibly can to make sure that we get people retrained and to make sure that people who have problems in finding employment are able to get a job in due course and are at least responsible enough to enter into a Newstart activity agreement, a contract, where we tell them-after personal assessment-what we think they can and cannot do. The Opposition criticises us for that.

The honourable member for Hawker (Mrs Gallus) said that the Opposition's policy is certainly not punitive and is not to leave without support people who have no other means of support. She did not actually say what the Opposition's policy is, except that it wants the clients knocked off after nine months on benefit. The honourable member for Corinella (Mr Broadbent) said:

The coalition wants proposed changes to the unemployment benefits system stiffened and toughened. We would like to see that after nine months people are given an opportunity to begin to make a change to the situation they find themselves in. Whether they choose to find themselves in that position or not, the Opposition would like to see an earlier change. All we are saying is, `We don't want you on unemployment benefits for 12 months'. We would like to say, `After nine months we are giving you the opportunity to move on in another direction'.

What does this mean? Where is the policy? What is the direction that the honourable member is talking about? In what direction are these people supposed to go? In the direction of hopelessness? Down the road of crime, as I said, simply to survive and perhaps feed their wives and children? The Opposition simply wants to wash its hands of the problem. This Government will not allow that to happen.

As I said, the Opposition has made it very clear that it intends to move a number of amendments. I will discuss them at a later stage. The major point is the question of the 12 months and the nine months. Over the last couple of days we have met and consulted with people from the Australian Council of Social Service (ACOSS) and with people from welfare rights centres. We as a government have listened to their concerns. There will be one amendment, as previously stated, that will give the right of appeal to clients who believe that in some way they have signed an agreement which is not reasonable.

There were a number of other matters that were raised by ACOSS and the welfare rights centres. The Government will look at those suggestions. We may not take them all up; we may take only some up. But the fact is that we realise that these welfare bodies are out there in the field.
