They are out there with the people who are suffering, if they are unemployed, and we will take as much notice as we can of what they are saying.

The honourable member for Bradfield and the honourable member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey) also spoke in the debate. Amazingly, both members claimed that the Newstart reforms are being introduced as a response to the popularity of the Opposition's strategy. This must be a perverse measure of popularity. The Opposition has no strategy, unless dumping someone on special benefits without access to training programs is a strategy. The honourable member for O'Connor suggested that employers hold dole cheques to pay unemployed people to work, on the basis that this would give the otherwise unemployed valuable work experience, in his words. This surely is work for the dole-nothing short of slave labour, where employers have a free pocket of labour to exploit people at the Government's expense. As my colleague the honourable member for Forde (Ms Crawford) said, this is nothing short of extraordinary.

The honourable member for O'Connor also said that he has become aware of phantoms; I take it he means people who are collecting the unemployment benefit and who really do not exist. If that is the case, the honourable member for O'Connor should let me know. If he can give me some names and addresses, I believe it is his duty as a member of Parliament to do so. If the honourable member for O'Connor lets me know, I will make sure-and I give him this undertaking in Parliament-that the matter is investigated. It is no good giving the chamber anecdotal evidence and quoting rumours that big problems will be caused because people are out there rooking us and all the rest of it. If the member for O'Connor has that evidence, he should tell the Department. Do not tell everyone in the Parliament; tell the Department who they are, and we will do something about it.

I conclude by referring to the rumour which the honourable member for Calwell (Dr Theophanous) said he had heard to the effect that unreasonable conditions would be placed on some people by the Newstart activity agreement. I assure the honourable member for Calwell that will not be the case, and that the Government will monitor it very closely.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

INTERJECT.PARA: Message from the Governor-General recommending appropriation announced.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Clauses 1 to 6-by leave-taken together, and agreed to.
Clause 7.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Braithwaite Mr R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) Clause 7, page 5, line 34, omit ``12 months'', substitute ``9 months''.
(2) Clause 7, page 6, lines 5 and 6, omit from the definition of ``change day'' ``12 months'', substitute ``9 months''.
(3) Clause 7, page 8, after proposed subsection 519 (1) insert the following subsection:
`` `(1a) Where:
(a) a person disposed of liquid assets of the person within 3 months before lodging a claim for unemployment benefit or sickness benefit; and
(b) the person received no consideration, or inadequate consideration, in money or money's worth; and
(c) apart from the disposition, this section would have applied to the person;
this section applies to the person as if the disposition had not been made.'.''
(4) Clause 7, page 10, line 18, omit ``12 months'', substitute ``9 months''.
(5) Clause 7, page 11, line 15, omit ``12 months'', substitute ``9 months''.
(6) Clause 7, page 25, line 24, omit ``12 months'', substitute ``9 months''.
(7) Clause 7, page 31, after proposed section 542 insert the following section:
Requirement to attend for counselling

`` `542a (1) Where a person is receiving a job search allowance, the Secretary must, on the expiration of 6 months from the day on which the person commenced receiving the allowance, notify the person in writing that he or she is required to attend an office of the Department or of the CES for the purpose of counselling and advice in respect of that person's attempts to obtain employment.

`(2) Where a person has received a notice under subsection (1) and has not, without good reason, within 14 days from the day on which the person was so notified, attended an office of the Department or the CES for counselling and advice, a person will cease to be qualified for a job search allowance until the person attends for counselling and advice.'.''.
Amendments Nos 1 to 6 are clearly expressed. They were circulated and have been available to the chamber for the past 24 hours.

I want firstly to remove the misapprehension which is obviously in the minds of Government members in connection with the substitution of nine months for 12 months in relation to Job Search. Included in the first group of amendments is a requirement to attend for counselling. The Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Social Security (Mr Sciacca) quite obviously was not speaking the facts and the truth when he indicated there would be within the Opposition's policy of 18 months ago a withdrawal causing a loss to the unemployed of over $1m. Without looking at other aspects, he said, in an attempt to deliberately create concern among the people who are the clients of this Government, that there would be nothing to replace it. He asked in effect, `Where do they go? Into the soup kitchens and down to the Salvation Army. They will get thrown out onto the street'. He then immediately said that the Opposition intended to replace it with a system of special benefits.

The Parliamentary Secretary cannot have it both ways. He selectively quoted and deliberately misled this Parliament and the people in the community for whom the Opposition has a genuine concern. These were not the words of the Opposition; I quote many members on the Government side, who said that all the skilling and training for a job is absolutely useless unless jobs are available. I think the honourable member for Cunningham (Mr West) made a pertinent comment in that regard.

As a result of the economic policies of the Government we see a move in the direction suggested by these Bills for only one reason: the economic policy of this Government has created growth only in unemployment and insolvencies, and has created a long trail of misery in this growth which is the lot of the people who are on social welfare, particularly for those on the unemployment benefit. The Parliamentary Secretary lectured the Opposition about what it is doing by way of the first lot of the amendments, so I will put his mind at rest.

It is obvious that under this legislation no incentives or disciplines will be available for people on the unemployment benefit to try to take some corrective measures for the first 12-month period. They will be available only after 12 months when people go onto the second limb; that is, the Newstart legislation. That legislation at least will give them an opportunity to search for jobs, skills training, education programs, voluntary employment and part-paid employment, which have been denied to them because the first part of the Job Search program is just a continuation of the unemployment system at the moment, where none of these items are offered.

The Opposition initially believed that the unemployment benefit should be restricted to nine months. In connection with Job Search, the Opposition reiterates that it should be available only for nine months if intervention in order to train these people for some type of job occurs.

The Government should bear this in mind: these were comments made by its own members. I come back to the contribution of the honourable member for Cunningham, who said that all the skilling in the world will not take the place of creating jobs. Perhaps the Government ought to be as concerned about creating those jobs as it is about putting in this new system, which is the result of its bad economic administration.

The honourable member for Cunningham also referred to the honourable member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey), who said that the Government had only followed in the footsteps of the coalition when it issued these guidelines 18 months ago. I cannot help thinking that is more than the truth, at least in respect of what the Government reacted to. It reacted firstly to the terrible situation it has bequeathed to Australia-the recession that we `had to have'-and has done so in the way suggested originally by the coalition. Fair enough, the coalition did say, and still maintains, that people should come off the unemployment benefit-that is, what is now Job Search-after nine months and be more positively attached to a program whereby they learn skills.

It is wonderful how the Government clutches at the old sayings about slave labour, sweatshops and so on. Perhaps the Parliamentary Secretary would find it interesting if he were to get back to the grassroots and talked to unemployed people.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do, all the time.

—He does not. Last Friday night I was at a meeting of young people and they were the firmest of advocates from the word go of working for an unemployment benefit that was meaningful and might put them into a position where in later life they might be able to get a job. There was no suggestion by those kids who are faced with the problem that to get a job one needs experience, but to get that experience one needs a job. They are the people who are concerned, and that is what is coming from the grassroots of this country. I am fed up with the hackneyed sayings of the Government about slave labour, sweatshops and so on, because that is not the case at all.

SPEECH.PARA: I have given the reasons why the Opposition has moved amendments Nos 1, 2, 4, 5 and 6. However, amendment No. 7 is the most interesting one. The Opposition believes there should be intervention through a counselling process after six months on the Job Search program. When one looks at this, it is interesting that for 12 months people can do exactly what they are doing at the moment; they can look for a job and record it and so on. I mentioned in my contribution to the second reading debate that I know of people being told by the Commonwealth Employment Office that they were not to take voluntary work and were to look for only two jobs every fortnight. I believe that restriction will still apply with Job Search.
In amendment No. 7, the Opposition is offering the requirement that:

Where a person is receiving a job search allowance, the Secretary must, on the expiration of 6 months from the day on which the person commenced receiving the allowance, notify the person in writing that he or she is required to attend an office of the Department or of the CES for the purpose of counselling and advice in respect of that person's attempts to obtain employment.
That is where the counselling comes in. It goes on:

(2) Where a person has received a notice under subsection (1) and has not, without good reason, within 14 days from the day on which the person was so notified, attended an office of the Department or the CES for counselling and advice, a person will cease to be qualified for a job search allowance until the person attends for counselling and advice.

It is very important that the kids out there who would have suffered 12 months of knock-backs under the Government's system as they go looking for jobs, without any hope whatsoever of getting into a skill training program, be given that encouragement at six months before they completely lose that morale and opportunity. Basically, they are the aspects of the Opposition's amendments. It is very important for the Government to recognise that intervention after 12 months is far too late, and our requirement to bring back Job Search to a nine-month period with intervention at six months is more positive.

The Government talks about being active instead of passive. We believe that this is the aspect of activity that the Government is concerning itself with, particularly in connection with Newstart. We believe that it ought to start at Job Search level. As I said before, it is not what we are saying, it is what Government members have been saying for quite a while.

Amendment No. 3 concerns liquid assets. As we understand the Bill, if people dispose of liquid assets to their children within four weeks of making a claim, they can be denied the benefits of Job Search. Last year, in an earlier Bill, we mentioned that this does not go far enough in that it does not collect into the web the liquid assets disposed of by a person within three months to people even at arm's length. This amendment states:
`` `(1A) Where:
(a) a person disposed of liquid assets of the person within 3 months before lodging a claim for unemployment benefit or sickness benefit; and
(b) the person received no consideration, or inadequate consideration, in money or money's worth; and
(c) apart from the disposition, this section would have applied to the person;
this section applies to the person as if the disposition had not been made.'.''
Again, we believe that this tightens up a loophole. We mentioned it in the earlier Bill last year and mention it again. Those are the seven items that comprise our amendments in this regard.
Progress reported.

DEBATE.TITLE: POLITICAL BROADCASTS AND POLITICAL DISCLOSURES BILL 1991

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Beazley, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beazley The Hon K.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

There is no greater duty upon the representatives of the people in a democratic society than the duty to ensure that they serve all members of that society equally. This duty requires government which is free of corruption and undue influence. It requires standards of integrity and honesty from its representatives, and it requires that the system itself does not engender a diminution of those standards. The integrity of the electoral process is central to the maintenance of these standards and the honouring of this duty.

In our own society the pursuit of government office at all levels is far more complicated today than it was when the first elections were held for this Federal Parliament. The development of modern election campaigning and communication techniques has impacted greatly upon the electoral process. This has been no more so evident than in the area of campaign financing. The vast sums required to fund modern political campaigns have added substantially to the pressures upon the electoral system.

With these changes in mind the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters, as part of its inquiry into the 1987 Federal election, produced a report titled Who Pays the Piper Calls the Tune-Minimising the Risks of Funding Political Campaigns. This Parliament is indebted to the Committee for its report. The concerns raised in the Committee's report have been the subject of separate State corruption inquiries. Both Queensland Commissioner Fitzgerald and Assistant Commissioner Roden of the New South Wales Independent Commission Against Corruption dealt with the problems of political campaign finances in their reports. Related concerns are now the subject of inquiries in Western Australia and Tasmania.
The risk to which the title of the Joint Standing Committee's report refers is a real and dangerous one. As Commissioner Roden said in his report on his investigation into north coast development:

With the mounting cost of campaign advertising, parties must be increasingly vulnerable to attempts by substantial donors to exert influence. It appears that the parties are themselves aware of this, and various proposals for increased public funding, limits on allowable spending, free television time, and bans on television advertising, have all been mooted.

This risk applies throughout Australia. No political party or government is quarantined from that risk. Steps must be taken to protect the integrity of our systems of government. The Bill before the House today will take such steps. It will contain measures designed to repel the threat of corruption to public order in Australia.

The Government will not wait until the problem becomes unmanageable. Action must be taken now to sanitise the electoral system. Nor will the Government take action which only partially addresses the problem. The Joint Standing Committee identified the need to expose the system of electoral funding by enhanced disclosure provisions, but equally identified the need to control the burgeoning cost of political campaigning. As Commissioner Roden has stated:
. . . as increasingly vast sums of money become necessary for successful political campaigns, the problem will grow. It must be faced and dealt with firmly and openly . . .
The majority report of the Joint Standing Committee considered a number of options for addressing the risks of funding political campaigns.

The Committee reviewed the present disclosure provisions of the Commonwealth Electoral Act. These provisions and those of similar effect in the New South Wales Act are the only laws requiring disclosure of political donations throughout Australia. The lack of a national uniform legislative scheme which comprehensively covers all political donations in respect of all levels of government is lamentable. The Government will propose to the State and Territory governments that the lack of such a system be remedied as quickly as possible. In doing so, the Government will put forward the comprehensive disclosure laws proposed in this Bill as the basis for uniform legislation. The Government welcomes the commitment to such laws already made by the West Australian and Victorian governments and sees this as a positive start to this process.

The need for full disclosure laws is universally accepted. Disclosure will remove the taint of suspicion from legitimate campaign donations which are at present not required to be disclosed. As Commissioner Roden said in his report:
To allow large secret donations to political parties or candidates is but one step removed from allowing large secret deals with political parties or candidates.

The Committee considered a number of options for dealing with the problem of potential corruption stemming from campaign costs. The Committee recommended that a system of free time for party political broadcasts be offered to registered parties and candidates by broadcasters who would provide air time free of charge. The proposal was strongly criticised at the time it was released. Many of the criticisms had more to do with the protection of self-interest than a fair assessment of the proposal. The Government has rejected the proposal because it believes that the allocation of time to parties would be inequitable and administratively impracticable. Free time would unfairly advantage the major political and incumbent parties.

The Government has also rejected the proposal for a limitation on advertising expenditure by political parties. Experience, both overseas, particularly in the United States with so-called political action committees, and domestically, through such notorious examples as the community polling organisation in New South Wales, has shown how easy it is for political parties to conduct campaigns through front organisations.

The Government's preferred course for dealing with the problems associated with campaign costs is to prohibit the broadcasting of political advertisements. The Government has not taken this step lightly. The competing claims of the various options were considered. The Government opted for a ban on political advertising because it is the fairest and most effective means of addressing the problem of burgeoning campaign costs.

The proposed ban is aimed directly at the single greatest factor in campaign costs. The exorbitant cost of broadcast advertising precludes the majority of the community and all but the major political parties and large corporate interests from paid access to the airwaves. The Government carefully considered the implications of the proposals on the right to freedom of speech, both as it is generally accepted and specifically under international law. In respect of the latter, article 19 (2) of the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights, to which Australia is a party, requires parties to guarantee the right of freedom of expression. This right is not absolute.

Article 19 (3) of the covenant provides that the right may be limited in the interests of public order. The prohibition of the broadcasting of political advertising is directed squarely at preventing potential corruption and undue influence of the political process. The Government is satisfied that the proposals are a necessary and proportionate response to this threat and do not constitute a breach of our international obligations. Of course the ban will not affect the expression of opinion or information through broadcasting of material other than advertising.

Mr Speaker, I turn now to the text of the Bill. The Bill inserts a new part III into the Broadcasting Act 1942. The part contains a framework for the proposed ban on the broadcasting of political advertising. Part III is structured in a way which makes it clear that the several provisions of the amendments are to operate to the extent that the Constitution allows. The present Government of New South Wales has indicated that it will challenge the proposed ban to the extent of its application to State governments and elections.

The Bill has been drafted with the possibility of such a challenge in mind. It also reflects the different nature of election and non-election periods. During the former, when the heightened attention given to political issues creates more intense pressure on broadcasters to give access to politicians and parties, the Bill prohibits certain government advertising and does not provide for the same exemptions from the ban as those which operate in non-election periods.

The ban will prohibit broadcasters from carrying paid or unpaid advertising which includes political matter. It will extend to such advertisements, whether run by broadcasters on their own behalf or on behalf of others. The latter step is designed to ensure that broadcasters do not flout the ban. The ban extends to elections for all levels of Government, including by-elections and Commonwealth referendums to alter the Constitution. Were the ban to apply only to Federal elections, the problems created by the need of political parties to raise huge sums necessary to advertise during an election campaign would be only partially addressed. As the Joint Standing Committee report concluded, parties would merely transfer funds to exempt campaigns.

In the Bill, political advertising means advertising containing political matter. This definition of political matter is used throughout the Bill and is based upon that of electoral matter in the Commonwealth Electoral Act 1918. The provision has been modified slightly to fit the context of the Bill. Fundamentally, political matter is defined to include matter which is likely, or intended, to affect voting at an election or matter which includes an implied or explicit reference to an issue in an election. It would not include, for example, the ordinary fundraising activities of a charity.

Under section 95 of the Bill the ban is to operate at all times and includes the prohibition of advertisements containing matter likely to affect voters at, or matter before voters in, any election whensoever held. Sections 95b, 95c and 95d operate during specific Commonwealth, Territory, State and local government elections. Under these sections, the ban prohibits the broadcasting of advertisements containing political matter in respect of the relevant election period. The Government has been particularly vigilant to ensure that under the Bill incumbent governments do not enjoy an advantage over their opponents through the use of government advertising.

Firstly, government advertising which falls within the general prohibition on political advertising will be banned. Secondly, during a Commonwealth election period, the broadcast of all Commonwealth government departmental or authority advertising other than that containing exempt matter will be prohibited. A similar ban upon Territory government advertising will be imposed during Territory elections. The extended ban is designed to ensure that Government advertisements which arguably may marginally fall outside the definition of political matter cannot be screened during election periods. Whilst it is currently Commonwealth government practice to administratively apply such a ban, the Bill will ensure that the ban has the force of law in the future. The ban is confined to political advertisements, as commonly understood.

The broadcast of bona fide news reports, current affairs programs and documentaries which contain or relate to political issues will not be affected by the legislation. Broadcasters and members of the public will continue to be free to use these forums and others, such as talkback radio, to express views on political issues. Editorial comment by broadcasters will not be impeded by the ban on advertising. The delivery of information to the public, including the print handicapped, by such means will be unimpeded.

The airwaves of Australia belong to all Australians. Currently, access to those airwaves by means of paid advertising through commercially licensed operators is restricted to those few in the community who can afford to pay the prohibitively high cost. In respect of the broadcast of political advertisements, the chief users of the airwaves are the major political parties who at the 1990 Federal election expended over $15m on broadcasting advertisements. During the same election period, all other non-political party expenditure on such advertisements amounted to $1.7m. Of that figure, over $1.1m was expended by the logging industry, while the Australian Conservation Foundation spent just over $25,000 on broadcasting activity. These figures illustrate the inherent inequity in the presentation of political debate through electronic advertising. The reality is that only the rich can get their message across by such means.

As one political commentator has described the current situation, `A system in which money decides who is and who isn't heard renders meaningless the right of free speech'. The ban will thus remove the privileged status of those few in the community who can afford to pay the high costs of broadcast advertising to express their political views, at the exclusion of the vast majority who cannot afford to do so. It will place all in the community on an equal footing so far as the use of the public airwaves is concerned. It must also be remembered that television advertising leads to packaging of important political debates and information into 30-second or even 15-second messages, widely criticised for their trivialising of content and concentration on image making.

Whilst the bulk of expenditure by political parties on advertising occurs during elections, the proposed ban will operate at all times. If the ban were restricted to election periods, parties and others who buy political advertising would run campaigns outside the ban period. The problems associated with a need to raise the huge sums necessary to fund campaigns would remain but apply to mid-term and pre-election period campaigns which could be expected to take on the importance presently attached to election campaigns.

The Bill provides for certain matter to be exempted from the effect of the ban. This is primarily non-contentious matter and includes announcements concerning civil or military disorder, information relating to the conduct of and promoting participation in an election or referendum, the promotion of services and programs of the ABC and SBS, certain non-contentious Government administrative announcements and advertisements for goods and services which do not contain any political matter and which are run on behalf of Government departments or authorities.

A further exemption which applies in all but election periods is made for advertisements which concern matters of public health. This would include AIDS prevention and anti-drug abuse advertisements, but not advertisements which refer to public health systems. The voluntary broadcast of party policy launches during election periods will not be prevented by the ban. Such launches will be restricted to no more than half an hour in length and may be broadcast on only one occasion. The provisions of the Act requiring equal treatment of political parties will continue to apply to the broadcast of launches.

The use by politicians of `free broadcast time' for party political broadcasts will be prevented by the ban. This will ensure that politicians do not enjoy access to the airwaves which is not available to other members of the community. This will include the provision of `free time' by the ABC.

The Bill ensures that all broadcasters, whether public or private, are treated in the same way. Apart from applying the ban to the ABC, the Bill will not affect the ABC's power to determine to what extent and in what manner it shall broadcast political or controversial matter.
The Australian Broadcasting Tribunal will be able to receive complaints regarding alleged breaches of the ban provisions.

In recognition of the urgent nature of complaints of alleged breaches of the ban, for example during election periods, the Tribunal will be required to deal with complaints or information about alleged breaches forthwith.
Both the Tribunal and any individual with legal standing will be empowered to seek an order from the Federal Court to enforce or prevent a likely breach of the provisions of the new part.

The ban is expected in practice to operate chiefly as a deterrent. It will be an offence under the Broadcasting Act for a broadcaster to broadcast an advertisement contrary to the ban. Compliance with the ban will also be a condition of every licence granted under the Act.

The provisions of the part will also be conditions of licences and permits issued under the Radio Communications Act 1983 thus extending the ban to video and audio entertainment and information services, such as Sky channel.

I turn now to the amendments to the Commonwealth Electoral Act. I have already referred to the inadequacies of the current disclosure requirements in the Electoral Act. These were perhaps best summarised metaphorically by the former Commonwealth Electoral Commissioner, Dr Colin Hughes, in his evidence before the Joint Standing Committee:

What happens under the present arrangements would be that the recipients of donations stand to one side of the table with three walnut shells, only one of which is transparent if it is labelled `a donation to the next Federal election'. There are two other walnut shells which are completely opaque and it is up to us to guess which walnut shell the pea is under. If it is not under the transparent one, they merely say, `wrong', and that is the end of the matter . . .

The majority report of the Joint Standing Committee accepted that the matter referred to by Dr Hughes should not end there and made sweeping recommendations to overcome the deficiencies in the present law.
The Government agrees with the Committee that these changes must be made and electoral financing in Australia should be open and transparent.

The reforms proposed in the amendments to the funding and disclosure provisions of the Electoral Act will bring that transparency to the electoral process. It will enable the Electoral Commission to investigate and expose any avoidance of the disclosure obligations.

The public is entitled to be assured that the parties and candidates which make up the government or opposition of the day are free of undue or improper outside influence. The present system of disclosure cannot and does not engender complete confidence. The Government will restore confidence to the system by exposing who pays the piper.

The Electoral Act will be amended to require political parties to fully disclose all income, expenditure and debts. Parties will be required to lodge annual returns with the Australian Electoral Commission within four weeks of the end of each financial year in addition to the existing requirement for the lodging of returns in respect of electoral expenditure following elections.

Where a party is required to disclose a gift as income in an annual return, details of the identity of the donor will not be required where the donation or total of all of the donations given to the party by the donor is less than $1,000. The sum total of such gifts will need to be disclosed.

While the Government had earlier announced that the limits of gifts of $1,000 for political parties and $200 for gifts to candidates under which full details of the identity of the donor would be increased to $1,500 and $300, in finalising the legislation the Government has chosen to retain the present limits to ensure the disclosure requirements are not relaxed under the new proposals.
Tougher disclosure requirements will also be placed upon third parties who participate in the political process.
Third parties include persons or organisations other than registered political parties or candidates who incur electoral expenditure, including the making of a gift to a political party or candidate.

Currently third parties are required to disclose such expenditure but need not do so where the expenditure relates to an election which does not occur during the specific reporting period. This has enabled third parties to avoid the reporting requirements. The Joint Standing Committee identified this problem and recommended that the loophole be removed. The Bill removes this loophole by requiring disclosure of electoral expenditure in respect of any election.
Third parties will also be required to disclose any gift made to a political party or part thereof, regardless of whether the gift is for electoral or other purposes.

The Commission will also be required to publish a list of all third parties in its reports on the operation of the funding and disclosure sections of the Act. This will ensure that the identity of those participating in the political process will be publicly available in keeping with the commitment to full disclosure.

The Government is determined that the Electoral Commission should be armed with the powers necessary to enforce the disclosure requirements of the Act. The Commission has for some time had the power to conduct investigations where it has reasonable grounds to believe that an offence relating to the disclosure provisions of the Act has been committed. The provisions amount to the ability to conduct a spot audit of a political party or a candidate's financial affairs to ensure the Act has not been breached.

While the Commission retains confidence in the efficacy of such compliance audits as an enforcement tool, the current provisions require the Commission to have reasonable grounds to believe that a breach of the Act may have occurred in order to activate an audit. This has prevented the Commission from conducting random audits.

The Government's amendments will remove the deficiencies in the Act and provide the Electoral Commission with the power to subject political and third parties to random audits to ensure compliance with the disclosure requirements of the Act. The Commission will be able to do so at any time and will not be required to have a reasonable ground to suspect an offence under the Act has been committed. Political and third parties will be subject to a random audit at any time.

Furthermore, the Commission will be required to publish a record of all spot audits in the reports on the funding and disclosure provision of the Act which it is currently required to publish following each election. The Commission will also be empowered to issue such supplementary reports as it considers necessary to comply with its obligation to report all spot audits.

As some third parties are not established solely for political purposes and their financial affairs may only relate in a marginal way to their involvement in the political process, the Commission will be prevented from publishing any details obtained during a third party spot audit other than details of an offence under the Act.

The Government has moved, through the Bill, to recognise and protect the rights of donors. The Bill will make it an offence under section 327 to interfere or hinder with the free exercise by a person of his or her right to make a gift to a political party.

The Bill amends the Act to provide that registered political parties and candidates are entitled to the same level of public funding per Senate vote as is provided for a vote for the House of Representatives. Under the public funding provisions inserted in the Act in 1984 a Senate vote is currently valued at one half or two-thirds of a vote for the House of Representatives depending upon the type of Senate election held. These provisions discriminate against smaller parties who concentrate upon Senate campaigns and fail to sufficiently acknowledge the costs of such campaigns. The Bill will place all votes on the same footing.

Amendments are also made to the Electoral Act and the Referendum (Machinery Provisions) Act to ensure that the result of an election or referendum cannot be overturned by the Court of Disputed Returns by reason only of a breach of the Broadcasting Act or the Radiocommunications Act.

Mr Speaker, the Bill represents a comprehensive response to the threat of corruption and undue influence which hangs over the political process. In the terms of the Joint Standing Committee report these proposals minimise the risks created by the need to fund political campaigns. The importance of sanitising our electoral process and of restoring public confidence in it has never been more paramount. The potential risk in not doing so will not diminish in the future. I commend the Bill to the House and present the explanatory memorandum.
Debate (on motion by Mr Smith) adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: SOCIAL SECURITY (JOB SEARCH AND NEWSTART) AMENDMENT BILL 1991

PROCTEXT.PARA: Consideration resumed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reid The Hon N.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support the amendments moved by my colleague the honourable member for Dawson (Mr Braithwaite) during the committee stage of the debate. I also want to point out to the Government the enormity of the problem it has created as a result of its economic policies. Almost one million people are unemployed in this country. I have been trying for many months to obtain the Commonwealth Employment Service (CES) figures for my own electorate. In fact, for eight months I have been attempting to get the Government to address the problem of the unemployed in my electorate.

SPEECH.PARA: After writing a number of letters to the Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Dawkins) and after having no response to numerous letters asking for those unemployment figures from the Commonwealth Employment Service, and after putting a question on the Notice Paper and receiving absolutely no response, I then proceeded to make the matter the subject of a freedom of information request of the Minister. Finally, after eight months, I was able to obtain the figures.

I would like to give you, Mr Deputy Chairman, and the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Social Security (Mr Sciacca), an indication of the enormity of the problem which the Government faces and which it has created. In the Bendigo area there are 7,163 people registered as unemployed. This is 15 per cent of the work force. In fact, in the 18 to 44 years grouping, 5,719 people are unemployed; 79 per cent of the total unemployed are within that group. In Maryborough, in another part of my electorate, the unemployment figure is 1,294-running at 18 per cent. Again, in the 18 to 44 years grouping 913 people are unemployed. In fact, the unemployed in this age group comprise 71 per cent of that total unemployment figure.

The fact that we have these programs-Job Search and Newstart-being introduced by the Government and the fact these social security Bills are being debated cognately gives me an opportunity to ask the Parliamentary Secretary and the Minister responsible for employment in this country to address the enormity of this problem. I do not think the Minister realises its enormity. I understand that the Minister for Higher Education and Employment Services (Mr Baldwin) will be in the city of Maryborough on Saturday to launch a program known as the Maryborough rural enterprise scheme. I look forward to the Federal Minister and the State Minister, the Hon. Carolyn Hogg, being present at that launching so that they can address the question and talk to the people of Maryborough who are experiencing this massive increase in unemployment.

I was quite shocked when I tried to get hold of the figures from the Commonwealth Employment Service. Before one can really tackle the problems which these Bills seek to address, one has to understand just how large the problem is. When I sought to obtain the CES figures, I was, firstly, granted my request under freedom of information. However, I was told that the statistics for the numbers of people registered with the Commonwealth Employment Service awaiting placement-not seasonally adjusted figures, but people who have actually registered for employment-were not a true measure of unemployment. I accept the first two reasons that I was given. The first reason was:

coverage of jobseekers can vary over time as a result of changes in labour market conditions, variations in administrative procedures and the effects of Government policy, especially the impact of changes in labour market programs.
I can understand that that could be the basis for variation. I make allowances for that. The second reason was:
some job seekers remain registered with the CES although they have either independently found employment or left the labour force but have not notified the CES.
The third reason I was given was:
not all persons seeking employment register with the CES for assistance.

In other words, two of the reasons given could result in variation to the figures and perhaps could reduce the number of people registered as seeking placement by the CES. However, the third reason-that not all persons seeking employment register with the CES for assistance-would have meant that the figure would have been even higher than the 15 per cent in Bendigo and the 18 per cent in Maryborough. That enormous problem will be an ongoing one for the Government because I do not believe that we have reached the bottom of the current recession. I am sure that the Minister would concur with that view.

I then tried to obtain from the Department of Employment Education and Training figures on an ongoing basis for each quarter. However, I was told that these figures would not be available to me on an ongoing basis even though my colleague the honourable member for Forrest (Mr Prosser) was able to obtain those figures on an ongoing basis from the Department through a freedom of information request in Western Australia. We now find that the Government is discriminating between States and not allowing those figures to be made available to me in Victoria. I have gone back to the Department seeking those figures on an ongoing basis.

Finally, I paid my $30 to obtain the figures. I was told by the Department that I could not have that $30 reimbursed because the figures were not in the public interest. I can assure the Parliamentary Secretary at the table that those figures are very much in the public interest. In fact, I wrote to the Department on that freedom of information request and cited the areas in which there is interest. In fact, the figures I was able to obtain for the March quarter were published in the Bendigo Advertiser, which has an extensive circulation throughout the Bendigo Federal electorate. They were also broadcast on Australian Broadcasting Corporation radio throughout western Victoria and on radio station 3BO Bendigo and were published in the Maryborough Advertiser. Those figures are very much in the public interest. I have requested that the Department make those figures available to me on an ongoing basis and that the $30 for the freedom of information request be reimbursed.

I particularly wanted to address these matters following the moving of the amendments by the honourable member for Dawson and to support him during the committee stage of the debate. I put to the Parliamentary Secretary at the table that the Government has created this problem. The Government has to wear it and it has to address the question.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sciacca The Hon C.

TALKER.NAME: Mr SCIACCA
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Social Security)

TALK.START.PARA: —I sometimes wonder at the somewhat ghoulish behaviour, I guess one could describe it as, of members of the Opposition, who seem to want to make political capital here, day in and day out, out of the unemployment figures. We know how important the problem is. Honourable members opposite do not need to come here and tell us the figures all the time; we know what the figures are. We are trying to do something about the situation.

SPEECH.PARA: What does the Opposition expect us to do? Does it expect us not to worry about trying to implement labour reforms, trying to make sure that we bring in more training places and giving more resources so that we can find people jobs when the jobs do become available? There is no question but that we will get out of this recession. There are already signs that we are getting out of the recession, and there will be jobs available. I cannot see the rationale behind the Opposition coming here, expecting us simply to put our heads in the sand and pretend that the whole thing will go away.

The fact is that it will not go away. We know it is there. It will go away eventually, and it will be helped by the sorts of reforms that the Social Security (Job Search and Newstart) Amendment Bill and the Newstart program will implement. I know that the Government will not be doing what the Opposition does, and it does not wish to. As I say, after nine months the Opposition simply wants to get rid of the problem. After nine months, the unemployed will go on special benefit. I do not know who decides the criteria for this special benefit because, yet again, the Opposition has not spelt it out.

Why not be constructive? I say this to the honourable member for Bendigo (Mr Reid) and to all of his colleagues who keep rubbishing us in this place every day. They do not need to remind us. I know that they are trying to get some political capital; I guess that is their job. But I ask them to be positive and constructive; I ask them not to tell us what we already know, but to tell us how they think we could fix it up.

The Government does not accept any of the Opposition's amendments. Amendment No. 1 alters the qualification conditions for Job Search allowance, so that JSA can only be paid to a person who is over 18 if the person has been registered by the Commonwealth Employment Service (CES) as having been unemployed for less than nine months. The measures of the existing Newstart strategy for those unemployed for 12 months or more-that is, the long term unemployed-have proved effective and the new arrangements build on this experience.

When the Newstart program for the long term unemployed was introduced in February 1989, there were 160,000 long term unemployment beneficiaries, comprising 39 per cent of all unemployment benefit (UB) recipients. By May 1990, the number and proportion of long term UB recipients had fallen to 113,600 and 28 per cent respectively. Over this period, the number of long term unemployment beneficiaries decreased by 29 per cent compared to the decrease of 10 per cent in total beneficiary numbers.

Since February 1990, the number of UB recipients has increased by 196,600, or 49 per cent, while the number of long term recipients has increased by only 16,600, or 14 per cent. This rate of increase has been slower than occurred in the early part of the 1982-83 recession, when the number of long term unemployment beneficiaries increased by more than 50 per cent between February 1982 and February 1983.

Twelve months unemployment is generally accepted internationally, as instanced by the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development definition of `long term unemployment', the point at which intensive assistance is required. There is a need to focus resources on those most in need-that is, the long term unemployed. A lower duration would spread resources more thinly and make them less effective. However, it should not be forgotten that these clients with special disadvantages will be given access to program places in the first six months.

Amendment No. 2 is a consequential amendment to the amendment proposed to the qualification conditions for JSA. My comments in relation to amendment No. 1 apply similarly to this amendment. Amendment No. 3 seeks to ensure that a person would not be able to avoid the effect of the liquid assets test by transferring assets to another person within three months prior to lodging a claim for unemployment benefit or sickness benefit.

I commend the creativity of the honourable member for Dawson (Mr Braithwaite) in resurrecting an amendment which was proposed by the Opposition, and which was debated and defeated, in the Budget sittings last year. The amendment does not take into account proposed new subsection 14a (3) as it does not omit that provision and refers to unemployment benefits which will not exist on the day the Bill commences. It also refers to sickness benefit, which has nothing to do with the content of the Social Security (Job Search and Newstart) Amendment Bill 1991.

The amendment as drafted is at best a nonsense. Further, the proposed amendment is draconian in nature. Most people would not be able to forecast with sufficient certainty three months in advance the date on which they will become unemployed. For the sake of marginal savings to the Commonwealth, the proposed amendment would catch innocent people who, in good faith, have made relatively small gifts of money to, for example, parents, children or charities some months before becoming unemployed.

Amendments Nos 4, 5 and 6 are consequential amendments to amendment No. 1. My comments in relation to amendment No. 1 apply to these amendments. Amendment No. 7 inserts a new section 542 into the Social Security Act 1991. The new provision would compel a person in receipt of JSA to attend a counselling session after being on that payment for six months. If the person fails to attend the Department of Social Security (DSS) or the CES for counselling and advice, the person ceases to qualify for JSA until he or she does.

Under administrative guidelines which will be applied to JSA, both the CES and the Department will interview a person and review entitlement for various periods in the JSA phase. Each JSA recipient will be interviewed by the CES during the first three months of unemployment. DSS will then review a person's entitlement at the three-month stage. At six months the CES will interview each recipient to explain what labour market programs and other CES assistance is available to the client. An amendment along the lines proposed by the honourable member for Dawson is unnecessary.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Braithwaite Mr R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will just respond quickly to the comment of the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Social Security (Mr Sciacca) about ghoulish behaviour. I believe that it is not befitting for him to make that comment when Australia is faced with an unemployment level at which one in every 10 persons who seek work is out of a job because of a deliberately engineered recession `that we had to have'. I think it ill behoves the Parliamentary Secretary to say this, particularly as this very important debate has been interrupted tonight. Tonight the Government brought in a Bill about advertising, the Political Broadcasts and Political Disclosures Bill, which means that issue had precedence over the unemployed and their future. It shows a lack of commitment by the Government. I believe it is not fitting for the Parliamentary Secretary to have made his comment.

SPEECH.PARA: In connection with our amendment No. 7, page 62 of the Government's own economic statement of February 1990 leads one to suggest that it was thinking of precisely the same thing as an early intervention. The Parliamentary Secretary came in here ill-prepared to consider these recommendations. Even though the Government does not accept them, we will be pursuing them most vigorously in the Senate when they come before that House.
Amendments negatived.
Progress reported.

DEBATE.TITLE: SOCIAL SECURITY (JOB SEARCH AND NEWSTART) AMENDMENT BILL 1991

PROCTEXT.PARA: Consideration resumed.
Clause 7.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Braithwaite Mr R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (8) Clause 7, pages 56-110, omit proposed Part 2.12.

Possibly I will only repeat precisely what was said in speaking to the first six proposed Opposition amendments, because we believe that after the period of the Job Search allowance has been completed-and we would have liked that to be nine months-what is required is an opportunity for reassessment as far as that period is concerned. Again I go back to say that our own economic statement of 1989 was quite precise in this: the unemployment benefit was to be dropped and replaced with a special benefit where each individual would come under a special scrutiny and would progress from that point onwards. We believe in a better sense and purpose in trying to get jobs for people who are unemployed.

We admit that after 18 months the position has deteriorated to the extent that there is high unemployment among our youth. I think that has already been mentioned by the honourable member for Bendigo (Mr Reid), particularly in his statistics. I think that would be uniform right around Australia.

We have had released today the figure of 9.9 per cent unemployment. We take no pleasure whatsoever from that figure. The Parliament Secretary to the Minister for Social Security (Mr Sciacca) did say earlier that the light is at the end of the tunnel, that we are coming out of the recession. It was put to me today that the only indicator that the Government can give for that is the inflation rate; it has put that as the criterion for our coming out of the recession. I say to the Government that the inflation rate is bound to fall during a recession, when the real inflation rate is still high, but it is subsidised in its own way by businesses going broke and accounts not being paid. Obviously the inflation rate will not be a real indicator that the recession is at an end.

The objective, particularly in terms of this legislation, is to do something positive for the unemployed. We believe that the omission of this section from the Act would require that incentive, that intervention, that counselling that is required to get Australia back on its feet.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sciacca The Hon C.

TALKER.NAME: Mr SCIACCA
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Social Security)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government does not accept amendment (6) to omit proposed part 2.12, that is, the module which would provide for Newstart. Such a proposal of course is to be expected from the Opposition. All the evidence from the debate on the Bill was that its strategy would be to move people quickly from unemployment benefit to a special benefit. What would this achieve? As far as the Opposition is concerned, perhaps it would be a novel way of disguising unemployment numbers. They would be tucked away on special benefit.

SPEECH.PARA: As far as the client is concerned, it would do nothing. Putting a person on a special benefit would not help that person to enhance job skills, for example. As a Government we are promoting an active strategy. At best the Opposition is being fairly heartless and inactive. Could I just answer some of the comments made by the honourable member for Dawson (Mr Braithwaite)? I am not saying that in any deliberate way he is trying to be, as I said, ghoulish.

TALK.START.PARA: —You said it.

—I certainly did say that. What I meant by that is that every time a bad figure comes out, the fellows across the road there jump up and down with glee, whereas they should be a little more constructive and perhaps try to talk the economy up instead of down. At the end of the day, every time we get a good figure, the Deputy Leader of the Opposition, the honourable member for Flinders (Mr Reith), in his whingeing style says, `That is not good enough', et cetera. Frankly, all I am saying is that I expect honourable members opposite, as the Opposition, to try to make as much political capital as they can out of bad figures; but sometimes they could be constructive, particularly when we are trying to be constructive with this sort of legislation. The amendments are not agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reid The Hon N.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support the honourable member for Dawson (Mr Braithwaite) in moving his amendment, and to take up the challenge of the Parliamentary Secretary regarding positive suggestions. I say to him: call an election. Let us go to the people and let the people decide whether the Government is managing the economy, whether it has the economy of this country under control. Let us see just how far the Government is prepared to go. Is it prepared to undertake the necessary reforms in this economy? Is it prepared to carry out any labour market reform? Is it prepared to carry out reforms to shipping or to land transport or to the waterfront? I accept his challenge, and I come back with some positive suggestions.

SPEECH.PARA: There are plenty of things that the Government can do, but it is not prepared to do them because its hands are tied by the union movement. It is not prepared to take it on and carry out the necessary economic reforms to get this country back on its feet. When the Parliamentary Secretary tells us that the economy is bound to improve, he is saying that he is hoping that it will.

TALK.START.PARA: —It will. We are doing something positive about it.

—It is no good sitting there and hoping. I have given some positive suggestions on how the economy can be improved. Why does the Government not carry them out? It is not prepared to. So it should go back to the people, face up to them, and tell them how it is running the economy.

—Could I suggest to the honourable member for Bendigo that he has had a pretty fair go on this? We are in a committee debate. We are debating a specific amendment. I think it would be a good idea if all honourable members, including the honourable member for Bendigo, took note that we are in the Committee and dealt with the Bill.
—Thank you for that guidance. I could not resist the challenge of the Parliamentary Secretary. I am sure he is not about to take it up.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment negatived.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Braithwaite Mr R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (9) Clause 7, page 56, lines 32 and 33, omit paragraph (h), substitute the following paragraph:
``(h) at the commencement of the period, the person has been receiving a job search allowance for not less than 9 months''.
(10) Clause 7, page 57, lines 5 and 6, omit ``12 months'', substitute ``9 months''.
(11) Clause 7, page 59, after proposed subsection 598 (1) insert the following subsection:
`` `(1a) Where:
(a) a person disposed of liquid assets of the person within 3 months before lodging a claim for unemployment benefit or sickness benefit; and
(b) the person received no consideration, or inadequate consideration, in money or money's worth; and
(c) apart from the disposition, this section would have applied to the person;
this section applies to the person as if the disposition had not been made.'.''
(12) Clause 7, page 61, lines 12-26, omit proposed subsections 599 (2) and (3).
(13) Clause 7, page 65, line 11, at the end of proposed subsection 605 (1) add the following words:
``within 8 weeks of the person having commenced to receive a newstart allowance''.
(14) Clause 7, page 66, line 25, omit ``the Secretary is satisfied, because of the person's failure to'', substitute ``because of the person's failure, without good reason to''.

To be consistent in connection with all the amendments that we have moved, Nos 9 and 10 reduce the period to the nine months that we were seeking before, and for the same reasons. The amendments were moved at this stage for the sake of consistency. As I said before, the Opposition in the Senate will be very vigorously pursuing these amendments to get a satisfactory outcome. I mention that for consistency.

Amendment No. 11 comes back to the same reason about liquid assets and the deprivation of these assets voluntarily by a person within three months. I listened to the comments of the Parliamentary Secretary (Mr Sciacca) in this connection that perhaps there would be some disposition made which could not have been forecast. I must agree there is some validity in that, in that in these times we do have people who are losing jobs with very little notice. I think we had the Toyota situation today of 400 jobs being lost. So that is acknowledged. I would have thought the Minister for Higher Education and Employment Services (Mr Baldwin) would have taken this opportunity to close a loophole where there has been an obvious fraud intended in this regard. I would suggest that this is not being frivolous in any way whatsoever, as was suggested. We believe there is some merit in it.

Turning to amendment No. 12, this one has its basis in section 599 (1). It is precisely to put into action the type of thing the honourable member for Bendigo (Mr Reid) was speaking of before. In other words, we would seek to delete subparagraphs 2 and 3 because they depend on Commonwealth Employment Service (CES) data, which has been shown to be notoriously faulty.

The honourable member for Bendigo was too humble to have read into this debate the particular question he asked the Minister for Higher Education and Employment Services on 15 April at Hansard page 2637:

(1) Will he provide localised figures for the actual (a) percentages and (b) numbers of (i) males and (ii) females actively seeking employment who are registered with the Commonwealth Employment Service (CES) at (A) Bendigo and (B) Maryborough, Vic. offices.

TALK.START.PARA: —After many letters to the Minister.

—I admire the honourable member's perseverance-and I also admire him for his luck in that he got an answer. The Minister responded in this regard, and I think it is very interesting. Remember, this is the data in which and these are the people through which it is expected that paragraph 599 would be consummated. These are the comments of the Minister:

SPEECH.PARA: The Commonwealth Employment Service collects data on numbers of unemployed awaiting placement at local CES office level (local UAP) for internal management purposes only. The data is not released because it is neither an accurate measure of unemployment nor a reliable indicator of changes in unemployment. General release of UAP data would involve an undue use of Department of Employment, Education and Training (DEET) resources in preparation of material and responses to inquiries, yet it would provide no additional reliable information on the labour market.
That is a tremendous admission. It goes on to say:

. . . the CES and are still listed as possibly requiring assistance, but unavoidably it includes many who no longer require this assistance. It is certainly not a measure of the number of people `actively seeking employment'.
It goes on to say:
The inaccuracies and distortions in the data are especially significant at the local level.
We are suggesting that the registration by CES should be confined to subparagraph (1) of section 599, and that is why we seek the deletion of subparagraphs (2) and (3).

In clause 13, in changing the period to eight weeks, we are seeking to address the fact that the Newstart program does depend on an agreement. The Act itself indicates that an agreement is perhaps not absolutely necessary, and there has been some indication by the people involved-the Australian Council of Social Service and others-about the terms of that agreement. We are suggesting that if, within eight weeks of commencing to receive Newstart, people do not put in an application, it should be suggested that they come to the CES for further advice so that they can get that agreement.

We believe that two months is a reasonable time for people to activate that agreement and show that they are prepared to enter into a scheme of intervention and get assistance within that program. I believe that what we are suggesting is reasonable-that the secretary must require the person to enter into such an agreement within eight weeks of the person commencing to receive Newstart.

Amendment No. 14 concerns section 607 (b). Instead of saying `the Secretary is satisfied, because of the person's failure to', we seek to substitute `because of the person's failure, without good reason'. I believe that the word `to' should go in at the end. It was an omission, as I mentioned last night, because of the haste in dealing with this.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sciacca The Hon C.

TALKER.NAME: Mr SCIACCA
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Social Security)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government opposes the amendments. The effect of amendment No. 9 is to change the qualification conditions for Newstart allowance so that a person is qualified for Newstart if the person has been receiving the Job Search allowance for not less than nine months.

SPEECH.PARA: I have already addressed the nine months issue in my comments on amendment No. 1. I would also add that long term unemployment is not necessarily measured by time on an income support payment. In this regard there is a difference in the level of assistance required by a person who has been unemployed and receiving the Job Search allowance for 12 months, and a person who has been registered as unemployed by the CES for 12 months without necessarily having received income support for the entirety of that period. It is when a person has been unemployed for 12 months that extensive intervention of the kind available under the Newstart program is required to assist the person to compete effectively in the labour market.

As far as amendment No. 10 is concerned, it is consequential upon the changes proposed by the honourable member for Dawson (Mr Braithwaite) to the qualification conditions for the Newstart allowance. My comments in relation to amendment No. 1 apply similarly to this amendment.

Amendment No. 11 applies to the liquid assets test provision as it applies to the Newstart allowance. It is the same as that proposed in amendment No. 3, and my comments in relation to this amendment are the same as for amendment No. 3.

Proposed amendment No. 12 seeks to omit subsections 599 (2) and (3). Subsection 599 (2) qualifies the operation of subsection 599 (1) in that, where the secretary disregards a person's failure to register with the CES owing to circumstances beyond the person's control, the person is taken to have remained registered with the CES during that period for the purpose of qualification for a Newstart allowance. This provision ensures that a person is not disadvantaged by being denied the extensive assistance available under the Newstart allowance because of unforeseen circumstances beyond the client's control. It would be inequitable, for example, to penalise a person whose registration at the CES has lapsed for a short time because a flood prevented the person from attending a CES office.

Subsection 599 (3) enables a person's registration with the CES to lapse for up to 13 weeks without the person losing qualification for Newstart allowance. The effect of this provision is to encourage persons receiving Newstart allowance to take on short term work to broaden their skills base without adversely affecting their entitlement to the Newstart allowance at the completion of the work. Similarly, if a person attempts unsuccessfully to resume study and the attempt lasts less than 13 weeks, the person remains qualified for Newstart allowance.

Amendment No. 13 would provide that a Newstart activity agreement must be drawn up within eight weeks of a person having commenced receipt of the Newstart allowance. This amendment would introduce an unnecessary element of inflexibility into the administration of Newstart activity agreements. The Bill already provides that written Newstart activity agreements are a mandatory condition of qualification for a Newstart allowance. It is anticipated that most clients will have an agreement before eight weeks in normal circumstances.

There is nothing to be gained from imposing time limits on the CES and the client in negotiating these agreements. The imposition of such time constraints, particularly in the months following the introduction of the Newstart activity agreement, would only lead to bulk processing of agreements and additional unnecessary stress on clients. In any event, flexibility in relation to time may be needed so that a client's needs and capacities can be adequately assessed by the CES, and the CES and the client have adequate time to negotiate a tailor made agreement. This consideration is particularly relevant when dealing with clients who live in remote areas, who do not have ready access to CES or Department of Social Security offices and who have limited job and course opportunities.

Amendment No. 14 suggests that section 607 of the Bill should provide that if a client has good reason for failing to negotiate an agreement, the client should not be taken to have failed to negotiate an agreement. As currently drafted, section 607 provides that if a client is unreasonably delaying entering into an agreement by failing to attend negotiation of an agreement, to respond to correspondence about the agreement or to agree to the terms of the agreement proposed by the CES or otherwise, then the person is taken to have failed to enter into an agreement.

In assessing whether a client has unreasonably delayed entering into an agreement, the reasons a person gives for the failure are a relevant consideration. If the CES acts unreasonably in cancelling a person's payment, because of a failure by the person to enter into a Newstart activity agreement, then appeal rights are available to the person. In considering the reasonableness of the decision, the relevant review bodies would certainly take into account any reasons the person may have for having failed to negotiate an agreement. It is ludicrous to suggest that the CES would not do the same, given the reasonableness requirement built into the provision and the right of review available to the person.
I question the need for the amendment proposed by the honourable member and, as I said, the Government opposes the amendments.
Amendments negatived.
Clause agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sciacca The Hon C.

TALKER.NAME: Mr SCIACCA
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Social Security)

TALK.START.PARA: —This clause has the effect of adding subsection 251(1B) of the Act to the list of provisions which are not reviewable by the SSAT. Subsection 251(1B) allows the Minister to give, vary or revoke directions to the Secretary relating to the waiver of recovery of debts. Such directions may not extend to the Secretary's related power to write off debts.

SPEECH.PARA: When subsection 251(1B) was inserted into the Act in 1988, the Senate Scrutiny of Bills Committee suggested that the provision should be subject to disallowance. This suggestion was not taken up by the Parliament.

The position on the general question of review of subsection 251(1B) power remains unchanged and the amendment made by clause 19 is really just a logical progression of the 1988 decision to make subsection 251(1B) not subject to disallowance in Parliament. It is necessary that the directions issued by the Minister under this provision are of a binding nature to avoid difficulties in reconciling decisions made by review bodies with departmental policy on effective debt management and control. The directions only go to the criteria to be applied when waiving a debt rather than, for example, outlining cases where waiver is barred.

The system which was in place before subsection 251(1B) was enacted was based on administrative criteria flowing from those issued by the Minister for Finance to delegates making decisions on waiver under the Audit Act 1901. Those criteria, which were in line with those applying in most other Commonwealth departments and instrumentalities, were undermined over time by varying administrative review decisions. The Government believes that review bodies should not be free to operate in this area according to principles of their own devising and therefore the Minister's directions under subsection 251(1B) should not be subject to review.
Clause agreed to.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yesterday in the Senate during Question Time Senator Collins, the Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support, answered a dorothy dix question put forward by one of his back bench Senate colleagues. It was in relation to waterfront reform. Over the last year or so, since Senator Collins took up this task of being the Minister for Shipping and, particularly, the Minister responsible for reform of the waterfront, he has been able to answer the question without much accountability in the Senate.

SPEECH.PARA: The question that I refer to was about the number of redundancies on the waterfront under the Government's so-called waterfront reform program. Senator Collins claimed that 1,200 waterside workers had been made redundant under the Government's waterfront reform program. This happens to be a very interesting figure. It happens to be wrong, because 1,200 people have not been made redundant under the Government's waterfront reform program.

If the Minister chose to deal with the truth and if he chose to deal with facts which are provided by his own Department, he would find that the figure that he has put forward is totally misleading. It is not only misleading but is designed to be deceptive. For example, the figures which are provided by the Government indicate that, rather than 1,200, some 361 people in total have been made redundant on the waterfront under the Government's waterfront reform program as of 18 April this year. The figures also indicate that an extra 11 people are expected to be made redundant by about the end of April this year, just a week or so ago.

The figure of 1,200 that Senator Collins used in his answer to a dorothy dix question yesterday in the Senate is totally wrong. The true figure is 361. How we come to that figure is interesting. The first set of redundancies on the Australian waterfront under the Government's reform program took place in Cairns at the end of February this year. Some 13 people were made redundant there.

The second round of redundancies was due to take place following the establishment of an enterprise agreement between National Terminals (Australia) Ltd, one of Australia's largest stevedoring firms, and its employees. That was supposed to have delivered 451 redundancies by the end of March this year. Unfortunately for National Terminals and for the nation, those 451 redundancies were not achieved and there was a shortfall of a bit over 90 people as a consequence of some problems that occurred in the implementation of National Terminals enterprise agreement. As a consequence, the total number comes to 361.

How Senator Collins derives the figure of 1,200 is interesting. Senator Collins, in his explanation yesterday in Question Time, claimed credit for the redundancy of some 310 gangway watchmen. He claims that this is all part of the Government's waterfront reform program. If the truth be known, as indeed the Government's own departmental figures will provide, gangway watchmen agreed to be made redundant prior to the Government's waterfront reform program. The redundancy of those people was achieved by negotiation between the employers and the unions well and truly before the Government engaged in its waterfront reform program.

The next group of people that Senator Collins tried to claim credit for through redundancies was some 600 workers who retired from the industry due to normal circumstances. These 600 people retired due to reaching the maximum age for retirement, or through ill health or through death. For Senator Collins to take credit for those people who have died, who have been made sick and can no longer work, or who have reached the maximum retirement age is totally false. It spells very badly for Senator Collins's own ethics in dealing with the truth about waterfront reform. It spells very badly for the whole approach that this Government has taken to the manner in which it has reported the pace of waterfront reform in Australia today. I would hope that Senator Collins would desist from trying to deal out mistruths and misinformation in the Senate during Question Time and focus on the truth.
