TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to take up matters referred to briefly by the honourable member for Franklin (Mr Goodluck) the other evening when he took me to task for raising a matter in relation to the Tasmanian Royal Commission into an Attempt to Bribe a Member of the House of Assembly and Other Matters. Let me make it plain that my remarks were not addressed in any way to a call for Gray to resign but rather to draw attention to the hypocritical principle that was addressed to this House on a number of occasions by the Leader of the Federal Opposition (Dr Hewson), who in the case of Burke urged that the proper issue in relation to persons holding high public office is that, where their conduct or reputation is at issue before a commission of inquiry, they ought step aside.

SPEECH.PARA: I made the obvious point that he was applying one set of standards for his opponents-those in Western Australia, the Labor team-and failing to apply the same stringent standards to those on his own side, having made no comment of any critical nature at all in relation to Gray's decision to remain in office. To that criticism, Hewson's office has said that Gray's involvement was tangential, in much the same way that he says the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) may be tangential to the Western Australian inquiry and that Gray did not hold office of profit under the Crown.

Firstly, let me briefly dismiss the second objection to the charge of hypocrisy. It is plain that the position of Leader of the Opposition is one of the great constitutional offices of our nation, and to make hairsplitting distinctions of that kind simply is not worthy. I turn to the more substantial objection, that Gray's involvement may have been tangential, and to assess the merit of that point one has to turn to the terms of reference. To repeat elements of those terms of reference, they are as follows: one, the events, facts and circumstances leading to and surrounding the attempt to bribe Cox; two, whether any person or persons other than Rouse or Aloi were involved directly or indirectly; and three, if so, who was involved and what that involvement was, and whether that involvement was improper or unlawful.

It is central to the task of the commission of inquiry to examine the role, if any, of the then Premier of the State. Gray was a premier whose side had been defeated at an election, holding office in a minority capacity, wounded but still clinging to power. His Government would have been the plain beneficiary of the success of Rouse's criminal scheme.

Already in the inquiry there are two clear matters of conceded impropriety, although Gray is yet to give evidence himself. Firstly, evidence given by his present principal adviser, Tronson, is that Gray took $10,000 in cash from Rouse. It breached the Liberal Party's code of fund raising ethics, no receipt was issued for a roll of $100 bills, and the money was kept at Gray's home and was not passed on to his Party until months after the election. His former deputy, Ray Groom, who resigned from the Party, is said to have regarded this as one of the key reasons for his resignation, and said of it rather delicately to the Royal Commission, more in sorrow than in anger, `I think members should certainly be very cautious about accepting money directly from donors'.

Secondly, Gray used front organisations to trick Tasmanians into believing that there was a spontaneous campaign for a second election. The advertisement that was placed in the press was signed, `This advertisement and petition has been organised and paid for by Tasmanians concerned for the future of our State'. In fact it was inserted by an advertising agency at the behest of the Liberal adviser, Mr Tronson, acting on instructions from his boss, Robin Gray. Tronson said that if the Liberal Party had been identified as the instigator of the petition it would have had less impact. Carter, the royal commissioner, described it less delicately as either a deception or a lie.

Whilst Gray has not yet given evidence, there obviously is a miasma of suspicion. I certainly hope that the Royal Commission clears Gray of any direct involvement because it would be a disgrace to our State were it not to do so and many on my side would not regard it as in Gray's character to have participated. Nonetheless, there are elements, I suppose anyone would say, of suspicion. Aloi told Cox that Gray would ring him. Rouse told Aloi that Gray was expecting a call. Gray put forward Cox's name to the Liberal Party as a possible Liberal nominee for the Speaker's position and told his then deputy--

TALK.START.PARA: —The Republic of Armenia within the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics (USSR) is in a virtual state of war, and Armenians are dying at the hands of forces of the Soviet Army and of the neighbouring Republic of Azerbaijan. Fighting has occurred in the mountainous Karabagh region around the town of Kedashen. On the border between the republics of Azerbaijan and Armenia, Armenian villages have been forcibly emptied of their populations.

SPEECH.PARA: The present conflict has grown out of tensions between Armenia and Azerbaijan over the Negorno Karabagh territory within Azerbaijan, which has long supported a mainly Armenian population. It was preceded in 1989 by a pogrom against Armenian residents of the city of Sumgait in Azerbaijan, which led to intervention by Moscow and the declaration of martial law there. However, the origins of this conflict go back much further. They are to be found in religion: the Armenians have probably the world's oldest continuous Christian tradition, while the Azerbaijanis are Moslems. They are to be found in class; historically the Armenians were the merchants of the Caucasus and were prominent in the economy of the Byzantine Empire and later the Ottoman Empire, while the Azerbaijanis have a rural and latterly industrial tradition.

They are to be found in ideology. The Armenians recently elected a non-communist government under Premier Levan Ter-Petrosian. They are desperate for autonomy from the USSR, while the Azerbaijanis continue to live under orthodox communism and favour the continuation of the Soviet Union. They are to be found in politics: the enormous ethnic diversity and geographical spread of the USSR derives from the Czarist Empire. In the 1920s the Union of Republics was tacked together by Lenin's Commissar for Nationalities, Joseph Stalin, who manipulated the borders of the new republics, particularly Armenia, in order to ensure they remained weak and the central government remained powerful. It was Stalin who relegated the ethnic Armenians of Karabagh to Azerbaijan.

They are to be found in the Soviet crisis: the Armenian earthquake provided the first evidence of the crisis when the central authorities found themselves unable to deal with the disaster and for the first time opened Soviet territory to international aid agencies. The suffering of the Armenians and the lack of aid from the central government exposed the economic weakness of the Soviet Union, heightened demands for Armenian autonomy and contributed to the present hostility between Armenia and Moscow.

It is ironic that relations between the Armenians and the Soviets have come to this, as in past times the Soviets were seen as friends and mentors of the Armenians. The ancient Armenian homeland is not in the present Republic of Armenia situated in the Caucasus; it was much further south in the Mount Ararat region of Eastern Anatolia, most of which is now within Turkey. Turkish nationalism deprived the Armenians of their homeland and subjected them to forced deportation and savage oppression, which came to a climax around 1915 during the period of the `Armenian genocide' when possibly as many as a million people died. In contrast to their treatment by the Turks, the early Soviets provided the Armenians with a new state within the USSR.

After their traumatic experience early this century, very few Armenians remained in Turkey. Many were drawn to the new Soviet Armenian Republic, but others emigrated elsewhere to form a world diaspora of Armenians numbering around four million people. There are many Armenian Australians and within my electorate of North Sydney there is a substantial community.

With such a history it is hardly surprising that Armenian Australians are so deeply offended by the Prime Minister awarding Australia's highest civil honour, the Companion of the Order of Australia, to Turgut Ozal, the leader of a country which has never made amends or even apologised for its oppression of the Armenian people. The Parliament of Armenia has sought a special session of the USSR's Supreme Soviet to resolve the present crisis. However, the future of the `Soviet Empire' is as much at stake here as the future of Armenia. The Armenians now represent a serious threat to the Union, which President Gorbachev and his centralists will not tolerate.
Only the world community can help Armenia. I therefore urge the Australian Government to bring the Armenian crisis urgently before the United Nations and to protest formally to the Soviet Government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bevis Mr A.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government has placed workplace reform high on its agenda for this term in office as part of the micro-economic reform process. Earlier this evening, the honourable member for Gilmore (Mr Sharp) once again homed in on the waterfront, which is his wont, and highlighted that as an area that requires reform. There is no prize for identifying those workplaces in which reform is necessary. The real test comes in determining how that reform can best be implemented.

SPEECH.PARA: It is instructive to look at the sorts of things which the Opposition, and those on whose behalf it speaks within industry, are using to address this issue. Recently in the Brisbane Courier-Mail of 8 April, the Queensland Confederation of Industry (QCI)-and I am sure that the honourable member for Gilmore would be familiar with it-announced its concerns about the length of time that employees in Australia were working. The newspaper reported:
Queensland industries would benefit from a return to a 48-hour working week, a Queensland Confederation of Industry spokesman said yesterday.

The spokesman was none other than the QCI General Manager, Clive Bubb, who said that weekend penalty rates and paternity and maternity leave should also be eliminated. I read that article a couple of times because I thought that surely there had been a misprint. A 48-hour week is really turning the clock back even further than I anticipated the Opposition's agenda being set. But, in fact, it is a 48-hour week that is suggested.

I looked to see just how long ago it was that we had a 48-hour week in this country. As this debate comes so soon after May Day, it is appropriate that we should recognise the strides that have been taken by the industrial movement in achieving a reduction in working hours for Australian workers. In fact, the 48-hour week was the standard in 1904, when the Industrial Relations Commission was first established in this country. The very first time that this Parliament set about regulating wages and hours, we had a 48-hour week-not long after the Federation of our country.

The Queensland Confederation of Industry, a major employer body, on whose behalf the members of the Opposition are regularly spokespersons, is advocating a 48-hour week as the standard basis of determining workers' hours in the State of Queensland. No doubt, that would have some currency in some other States of Australia, at least amongst some of the employer groups.

From what I read in the article, I understand that the Confederation also believes that we should do away with weekend penalty rates and paternity and maternity leave. That is not a view that just the QCI has, because the Opposition has quite expressly endorsed at least that part of the QCI's policy. On 21 February this year, the Courier-Mail referred to comments made by the shadow spokesperson on industrial relations, the honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard). The paper reported that he said that a coalition government would take steps to remove penalty rates from awards. He is quoted as saying:
We should have a seven day a week 24 hour a day attitude to work.

That was the approach adopted, not just by the QCI, but also by the shadow spokesperson on industrial relations. We have in tandem an industry organisation advocating a 48-hour week and an Opposition which has formally adopted the proposition that we should also have a 24-hour a day, seven-day a week approach to the basis upon which Australian workers should be paid.

That is a policy which will, no doubt, incur the wrath of Australian working people throughout the country and, I suspect, the great bulk of fair-minded and progressive employers throughout the country. It is one which will be brought into focus when some of the industrial legislation before the Parliament comes on for discussion. No doubt, as the next 18 to 24 months roll on, it is one which will come into focus in the public arena more than it has to date. I have no doubt that when the people put that policy under some scrutiny, they will reject out of hand the Opposition's approach to industrial relations as being archaic and as literally turning the clock back to the start of this century.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Miles Mr C.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak tonight partly because the honourable member for Denison (Mr Kerr) has raised an issue tonight with regard to the Tasmanian Royal Commission into an Attempt to Bribe a Member of the House of Assembly and Other Matters. I find it rather incredible that a member of the Australian Labor Party, after the Premier of Tasmania had asked people not to make any comment, would actually make a big splash about this time last week on the television and in the media trying to link Robin Gray, as if he were involved in the same way as Brian Burke is in WA Inc.

SPEECH.PARA: I was interested to read the editorial in the Mercury on Monday this week commenting on this issue. The editorial is headed, `Gray right not to stand down'. It states:
Any parallel between Robin Gray and Brian Burke is tenuous, absolutely tenuous.
What we know now with regard to Brian Burke is the following: firstly, he made false statements to the police. He put billions of dollars of taxpayers' money at risk and he also neglected to pay tax.

Contrary to the comments of the honourable member for Denison, the position of Robin Gray compared with that of Brian Burke in WA Inc. is quite tangential. The central figure in Western Australia is Brian Burke. The central figure in Tasmania is Edmund Rouse, and that is quite different indeed. I wondered why a member of the Labor Party in Tasmania should go against the expressed wishes of his Premier. It seemed to be quite illogical. Then we realise that $20,000 from WA Inc. was given to the Tasmanian branch of the Australian Labor Party. And that was made public in Tasmania just last Thursday or Friday, at the same time.

In the Herald-Sun on Monday, I noticed the headline `Federal Labor fears stain of Western Australia Inc.'. With these thoughts put together, it became quite obvious that, even though it is a very tangential link that the honourable member was trying to make, he is concerned that the stain of WA Inc. will roll not just around the mainland but around Tasmania as well, and that at the next election he will be collected up in that rolling around. That is what it is all about.

The honourable member for Denison has decided that it is better to get publicity at any cost, because he knows that he is on the skids. He has tried to make a big issue out of this, and he went to the press and said, `I am going to raise it in the Parliament next week'. We have had to wait all week for it to be raised. And what a pathetic performance it was when he tried to defend his raising of this issue in public.

What we already know about the Tasmanian situation, which the honourable member for Denison did not tell us, is some of the behind-the-camera evidence which has been released concerning what Mr Rouse has said with respect to Mr Gray. He said, `If Mr Gray had known what I was doing, his hair would have stood on end'.

All the evidence so far indicates that there is no link between the Liberal Party and Mr Rouse. For the honourable member to try to beat this up shows that he is rattled and concerned, as many honourable members in Western Australia and on the mainland of Australia are concerned, about his, and their, future. As I said, there is only one explanation for this: any publicity is good publicity. So he has gone to the press, against the will of his Premier, and instead of putting John Hewson on the mat and to the test, he has put his own Premier to the test of whether he can get the Federal member for Denison to stop commenting on the Royal Commission's activities. So it is up to Michael Field to see whether the honourable member for Denison now actually keeps his peace.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carlton The Hon J.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not want to delay the House more than I should, but I am moved to respond to the honourable member for Brisbane (Mr Bevis) who, unfortunately, has left the chamber, because he came in with a quite remarkable argument about the Opposition's supposed views on industrial relations. It has become a pattern for the Government, and particularly the Ministers during Question Time when they have the advantage of Standing Orders, to deliver 10-minute tirades against the Opposition's supposed views without the Opposition having any chance to respond. But during the adjournment debate we would expect that newly elected members of the House would not indulge in this puerile behaviour. The honourable member for Brisbane came out with a view that, because some employer group had said that we should have a 48-hour week, that was somehow the Opposition's policy, that was what we were arguing and that is the way in which we were saying that the industrial relations system should work.

SPEECH.PARA: If the honourable member for Brisbane does not know how stupid his assertion is and how far from the truth it is, I have very real worries for him. I know that he spoke in the adjournment debate last night for five minutes about his interest in football matches. The honourable member for Brisbane has to know that, if he follows the pattern of the Ministers-such as the Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Dawkins) and the Minister for Community Services and Health (Mr Howe), who get up and totally distort an argument in a way which they must know is untrue-he is making an absolute ass of himself.

The honourable member for Brisbane said that, because some employer group somewhere had said that a 48-hour week is the correct way to run things, this is somehow the Opposition's policy. First of all, that is absolutely untrue, and he would have to know that. Secondly, if he believes that is so, he has no idea of how the rest of the world works in relation to industrial relations. It may be some news to the honourable member for Brisbane that in only two countries in the world does a bunch of quasi-judges set the conditions of employment, and unrelated to the requirements--

TALK.START.PARA: —It has always been the case.

—Almost since Deakin set it up in the first decade of this century. That is absolutely right. That does not make it correct. However, there are only two places in the world where we still have this absurd industrial relations system in place and they are Australia and New Zealand. Since last week it no longer exists in New Zealand. In common with the rest of the world, New Zealand will now have the opportunity for workers to be able to sit down with their employers and work out sensible ways of working, unlike what happens in Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: In the press today we read that the meat industry has had an inquiry going on for about 18 months-and the Australian Council of Trade Unions and the union have now pulled out of it-about how to sort out the absurd arrangements in that industry, totally ignoring the fact that, if sensible people in the individual workplaces were able to sit down with each other as human beings and not be interfered with by all these outside influences, they would be able resolve the working arrangements, as was the case at SPC Ltd. That is all we are talking about. In our industrial relations policy--

TALK.START.PARA: —SPC was settled in the Commission, and you know it.

—And the honourable member for Brisbane knows exactly the contrivance that was used to ensure that that happened. I must say that the interjections of the honourable member really make it quite clear that he is--
—The honourable member might not respond to the interjections.

—It just indicates to me that he simply has no understanding of the subject. All we are saying is that workers should be able to sit down in a workplace and, without all sorts of outside interference, which is required nowhere in any free country in the world now that New Zealand has left this absurd system, work out what they want to do with regard to their conditions of employment.

SPEECH.PARA: The honourable member knows that it is absolute nonsense to say that our policy is a 48-hour week just because some particular employer group has said this in some particular release. It is a great pity for a newly elected member to follow the example of his Ministers in Question Time and to operate at that level and, hopefully, the House will adopt a higher standard.
House adjourned at 11.30 p.m.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Australian Brushmakers Union: Migrant Workers Participation Scheme

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Scott Mr J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs, upon notice, on 20 December 1990:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Further to his answer to question No. 58 (Hansard, 6 December 1990, page 4705), did he state at parts (3) and (13) of the answer that the South Australian membership of the Australian Brushmakers Union (ABU) was 4500; if so, (a) who provided that figure, (b) to whom and in what form was it conveyed and (c) will he provide copies of any documents stating the ABU membership numbers; if not why not.

(2) Was the registered membership of the ABU 473 as at 28 March 1989; if so, (a) was the membership overstated in his answer, (b) does he condone the overstatement, (c) what action will he take with respect to the overstatement and (d) if no action will be taken, why not.

(3) Did he state at parts (3) and (13) of his answer to question No. 58 that in addition to the ABU membership of 4500, the memberships of the Australasian Society of Engineers (ASE) and the Federated Ironworkers Association (FIA), 6800 and 2500 respectively, amounted to a combined South Australian membership of the three unions of 13,800.

(4) Were the registered memberships for 1989 of the ABU, ASE and FIA 473, 6575 and 2479, respectively, amounting to a combined membership of 9527; if so, why is the figure provided in his answer incorrect.

(5) With respect to part (10) of his answer to question No. 58, (a) why did Central Office not recommend approval of the ABU's application for a grant under the Migrant Workers Participation Scheme (MWPS), (b) why did his predecessor decide in favour of the application and (c) how often did his predecessor decide in favour of applications for which State or Central offices had not recommended approval.

(6) Are applicants for MWPS grants required under section 5.4 of the MWPS Guidelines to identify any part of their application which they regard as being (a) given in confidence or (b) detrimental if released.

(7) Did the applicant for the MWPS grant referred to in question No. 58 identify any material in his application which should be exempt from FOI provisions; if so, (a) how was that identification (i) conveyed and (ii) recorded, (b) is he satisfied that a proper record was made, (c) did the applicant provide detailed reasons as required by the guidelines and (d) what was the range and number of items covered by the record.

(8) Does section 5.4 of the MWPS guidelines state that material may still not be exempt from disclosure under the FOI Act; if so, will he reconsider his refusal to provide the information requested at subparts (1) (h-j) of question No. 58; if not, why not.

(9) Further to his answer to Part (14) of question No. 58, what conflict was there between Mr Darras' application and his perception of the position and its objectives and that of the detailed work program.

(10) Further to his answer to part (23) of question No. 58, (a) has he pursued the allegations referred to and (b) have discussions been held between his officers in Adelaide and the ABU, ASE and FIA; if so, (i) what was the outcome of the discussions and (ii) were written reports produced; if so, will he make those reports available; if not, why not.
(11) Was a report by Mr Darras dated 27 April 1990 not received by his Department until 14 May 1990; if so, why is there such a difference between the dates.
(12) Did the report referred to in part (11) not disclose information relating to visits to South Australian country areas; if so, does this indicate that Mr Darras did not visit country areas.
(13) Did Mr Darras' work during March 1990 include visits to the southeast of South Australia, including Mount Gambier; if so, why was it not referred to in his report dated 27 April 1990.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hand The Hon G.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes.

(a-c) I am now informed that the figure thought to have been provided by the ABU in fact resulted from a misinterpretation of information provided to my Department at the time of the grant application. This is further explained at 2 below.
(2) (a-d) According to documentation provided to me recently by the honourable member, the registered membership of the ABU at 28 March 1989 was 473.

The membership was thus overstated in my answer. I am informed that there has been a misunderstanding at the time of the grant application between my Department and the ABU. The departmental assessment at the time of the joint application showed a figure of 4500 as the ABU membership. In fact, this was a misinterpretation and actually represents the number of migrant workers covered by the three unions.

In view of the above, and the fact that the application and the Departmental assessment focused on the proposed target group of 3,500 people, a number not in dispute, no action will be taken. For assessment purposes the membership numbers were not important.
(3) Yes.

(4) According to documentation provided by you the membership numbers were as stated in your question. I am now informed that in the Departmental assessment process at the time, membership numbers for the ASE and the FIA were confused with total numbers in the work force.

(5) (a) Central Office considers the recommendations for grants made by State Offices on the basis of the perceived Australia-wide needs. Because there are limited grants available not every State Office recommendation can be supported. Central Office considered that there were other applications which, from a national perspective ranked more highly.
(b) I am not aware of the reasons for my predecessor's decision.
(c) My predecessor approved 4 applications which neither State nor Central Offices had recommended.
(6) (a) Yes.
(b) Yes.
(8) Yes. I maintain my decision to refuse to provide the information requested for the reason given in my answer to question No. 58.

(9) The actual program of work to be undertaken was developed from the proposed program submitted in the application (in this case submitted in the joint application by ABU, FIA and ASE). Following the award of a grant to the applicant the final work program is negotiated with my Department.

(10) Responsibility for the MWPS was transferred to the Department of Industrial Relations with effect from 17 September 1990. My Department has thus not pursued allegations. I understand that the Department of Industrial Relations has written to the three unions concerned about arrangements to ensure the ongoing effective operation of the grant.
(11) Mr Darras' report dated 27 April 1990 was received by my Department's Adelaide Office on 14 May 1990. I do not know why there is a difference between the dates.
(12) The report did not disclose information relating to visits to South Australian country areas. This does not necessarily indicate that he did not visit those areas.
(13) According to my Department's record of the work program for this grant, such visits were not included.
